('7', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 1
('7', 0, 1, 2, 43) 1. ROYAL ASSENT The long deferred Royal assent to the Registration Act has now been gazetted.
('7', 0, 1, 3, 137) General Botha, although he has assured Lord Elgin that he will consult the feelings of British Indians, has refused to receive a deputation of British Indians, saying that no good purpose could be served by receiving it as the Act was to be gazetted last week; but we notice that, although the Act is gazetted, the date of its enforcement has been indefinitely postponed.
('7', 0, 1, 4, 509) It may be fixed now or never.
('7', 0, 1, 5, 539) The letter 1 of Mr. Essop Mia, Acting Chairman of the British Indian Association, published in The Star and taken over by us, is, therefore, most timely.
('7', 0, 1, 6, 693) Mr. Essop Mia, who is a merchant of long standing, with very large interests at stake, tells the public that he feels the degradation of the Act so keenly, that he is prepared to sacrifice all, if that is the price he has to pay for non submission to the Act.
('7', 0, 1, 7, 953) He then makes the most reasonable proposals, that the day for enforcing the Act may not be fixed for the time being, and that British Indians: and other Asiatics, in order to prove their bona fides, should be allowedto be voluntarily re registered.
('7', 0, 1, 8, 1202) If the experiment prove a failure, the Act shall be applied to those who have not adopted voluntary re registration.
('7', 0, 1, 9, 1319) We hope that the Transvaal Government will accept such an eminently reasonable suggestion.
('7', 0, 1, 10, 1410) General Botha, in the name of the people of the Transvaal, more than once expressed profound gratitude to the Imperial Government for the liberal constitution granted to the Transvaal, and his concern for the Empire as a whole.
('7', 0, 1, 11, 1638) If he includes India as a part of the Empire, there is reason to hope that he will, even at the last moment, by accepting the Indian compromise, avoid an exacerbation of the feelings of the British Indians in the Transvaal.
('7', 0, 1, 12, 1862) Indian Opinion, 15 6 1907
('7', 0, 2, 13, 1888) 2. TYRANNY OF LAW
('7', 0, 3, 14, 1906) He who will ferry others across to the shore, Will also take his boat to the port.
('7', 0, 3, 15, 1989) He who will let others go to the bottom, Shall himself flounder.
('7', 0, 3, 16, 2054) No good to wield the sword or the axe, The gun, the knife or the arrow,
('7', 0, 4, 17, 2126) 1 Vide “Letter to The Star” 8 6 1907
('7', 1, 0, 1, 2163) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 1, 1, 2, 2203) For you will but reap what you sow.
('7', 1, 1, 3, 2239) So sings the poet.
('7', 1, 1, 4, 2258) “Reap as you sow” is a proverb known throughout the world.
('7', 1, 1, 5, 2317) The principle of this proverb will not change for the benefit of the Indian community.
('7', 1, 1, 6, 2404) A creeper yielding bitter fruit will never bear jasmines and the palasha will not yield mangoes.
('7', 1, 1, 7, 2501) Likewise, it will never be that the Transvaal Indian community sows one thing and reaps another.
('7', 1, 1, 8, 2598) It is only when the community proves its manliness that we shall be able to live like men.
('7', 1, 1, 9, 2689) The community will enjoy respect if it deserves it.
('7', 1, 1, 10, 2741) It will add to its honour if it keeps its word and fulfils what it has undertaken.
('7', 1, 1, 11, 2824) If, on the other hand, the community forsakes its oath out of selfishness or fear or any other reason, it is certain that the rights of Indians in the Transvaal will be lost and that other Indians also will be crushed along with those in the Transvaal.
('7', 1, 1, 12, 3077) So great is the task the Indian community in the Transvaal has undertaken.
('7', 1, 1, 13, 3152) The poet adds that it is also the law of the world, or nature, or God, that he who takes others safely across will himself reach the other shore.
('7', 1, 1, 14, 3298) Likewise, if we serve others, our own needs will be provided for.
('7', 1, 1, 15, 3364) As for looking after oneself, even birds and beasts do this.
('7', 1, 1, 16, 3425) The chief difference between man and beast is that man is a benevolent creature.
('7', 1, 1, 17, 3506) All live happily where one feels happy in the happiness of others.
('7', 1, 1, 18, 3573) But where everyone looks after himself alone, all are lost.
('7', 1, 1, 19, 3633) For, as the poet says, “He who will let others go to the bottom, shall himself flounder.” This is an important idea and a little reflection will showthat it is true.
('7', 1, 1, 20, 3799) A mother suffers discomfort to bring up her child.
('7', 1, 1, 21, 3850) In the end such a mother finds herself happy.
('7', 1, 1, 22, 3896) Where the members of a family share one another’s burdens and give up individual interests, the whole family is well sustained.
('7', 1, 1, 23, 4024) Members of a community individually suffer to save the group as a whole and are themselves saved too.
('7', 1, 1, 24, 4126) Similarly, where men undergo suffering or die for their country’s sake, they truly live and bring credit to the country.
('7', 1, 1, 25, 4247) Is there any Indian who seeks happiness for himself by breaking this fundamental law?
('7', 1, 1, 26, 4333) These examples clearly prove that the Transvaal Indians will be victorious if, for the sake of the Indian community and for the sake of their personal honour, they endure all sufferings and face all hardships to accomplish the task they have undertaken.
('7', 1, 1, 27, 4587) They will then break their bonds and win immortal fame in history.
('7', 1, 1, 28, 4654) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 15 6 1907
('7', 2, 0, 1, 4696) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 3
('7', 2, 1, 2, 4739) 3. RHODESIA AND THE TRANSVAAL It has been argued in the Rhodesian Assembly that, since a law has been passed in the Transvaal for Asiatics, a similar law should be passed in Rhodesia too to prevent further Indian immigration and to provide for the registration of those already there.
('7', 2, 1, 3, 5024) All members spoke on the subject in strong terms.
('7', 2, 1, 4, 5074) A full account of it appears in our English section.
('7', 2, 1, 5, 5127) It can be seen from this that, if the Transvaal law remains on the Statute book and if the Indian community submits to it, its example will be followed everywhere else.
('7', 2, 1, 6, 5296) There is but one way now to help the Indians in Rhodesia, and that is for the Transvaal Indians to show their mettle.
('7', 2, 1, 7, 5414) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 15 6 1907
('7', 2, 2, 8, 5456) 4. INDENTURED INDIAN LABOURERS
('7', 2, 3, 9, 5487) At Thornville junction, a European cruelly beat up an Indian and the latter died.
('7', 2, 3, 10, 5569) The European was prosecuted and fined £10. We publish this report in full elsewhere.
('7', 2, 3, 11, 5654) This is a blood curdling case.
('7', 2, 3, 12, 5685) The Indian lost his life, but the European got off with a fine of £10. There is nothing in it to comfort us.
('7', 2, 3, 13, 5794) But we are not to think of revenge.
('7', 2, 3, 14, 5830) The European will have to answer to the Creator.
('7', 2, 3, 15, 5879) Had he been punished with hard labour, that would not have restored life to the Indian and would not have saved other indentured labourers from getting similar treatment in future.
('7', 2, 3, 16, 6060) If we are to cure a disease, its cause must first be ascertained.
('7', 2, 3, 17, 6126) Accordingly, if we look for the cause of this state of affairs, we shall find that indentured labour itself is an evil thing.
('7', 2, 3, 18, 6252) If the system of indentured labour is put an end to, the kind of oppression described above will also stop.
('7', 2, 3, 19, 6360) For in ordinary service one is not bound, as the indentured labourer is: if the service does not suit him, he is free to give it up.
('7', 2, 3, 20, 6493) Mr. Robinson has stated in his speech that the importation of Indians as indentured labourers must cease.
('7', 2, 3, 21, 6599) We also hold the same view.
('7', 2, 3, 22, 6627) It is necessary for the [Natal Indian] Congress to take steps towards that end.
('7', 2, 3, 23, 6707) That Mr. Robinson’s reasons and ours for ending the system of indentured labour are not the same is of no account.
('7', 2, 3, 24, 6822) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 15 6 1907
('7', 3, 0, 1, 6864) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 3, 1, 2, 6904) 5. “THE WISDOM OF THE EAST”
('7', 3, 2, 3, 6932) JALALUDDIN RUMI 1
('7', 3, 3, 4, 6950) We have received for review two volumes of a series entitled The Wisdom of the East being published in Britain.
('7', 3, 3, 5, 7062) The first is called The Way of the Buddha and the second, Persian Mystics, in which the author has assigned the first place to Jalaluddin Rumi.
('7', 3, 3, 6, 7206) An informative account of Sufis is followed by a narrative of the life of Jalaluddin and translations of some of his poems.
('7', 3, 3, 7, 7330) In the author’s view, a Sufi is a lover of God.
('7', 3, 3, 8, 7378) Above everything else, the Sufis aspire after a pure heart and love of God.
('7', 3, 3, 9, 7454) Jalaluddin was once observed dancing with joy at a funeral, and on being questioned what he meant thereby, the saint replied, “When the human spirit, after years of imprisonment in the cage and dungeon of the body, is at length set free and wings its flight to the source whence it came, is it not an occasion for rejoicing?” We can see that, in the olden days, even women freely participated in such [Sufi way of] life.
('7', 3, 3, 10, 7875) Rabia Bibi was a Sufi herself.
('7', 3, 3, 11, 7906) When asked if she hated the devil, she retorted that “her love of God left her no time to hate anyone”.
('7', 3, 3, 12, 8010) According to the Sufi point of view, no religion based on morality can be considered to be false.
('7', 3, 3, 13, 8108) In reply to a question Jalaluddin said, “The ways of God are as many as the number of souls of men.” Elsewhere he says, “God’s light is one but its rays are various in hue.
('7', 3, 3, 14, 8281) We can worship God along any path, provided it be with a true and sincere heart.” Referring to the nature of true knowledge, Jalaluddin says that “a blood stain can be washed away with water, but the stain of ignorance can be washed clean only with the water of God’s grace”.
('7', 3, 3, 15, 8557) And then again, “True knowledge is the knowledge of God.” Whenasked where one could find God, the poet replied, “I saw the Cross and also Christians, but I did not find God on the Cross.
('7', 3, 3, 16, 8744) I went to find Him in the temple, but in vain.
('7', 3, 3, 17, 8791) I saw Him neither in Herat nor in Kandahar.
('7', 3, 3, 18, 8835) He could be found neither on the hill nor in the cave.
('7', 3, 3, 19, 8890) At last, I looked into my heart and found Him there, only there and nowhere else.” This is an excellent book to read.
('7', 3, 3, 20, 9008) We can endlessly go on quoting passages such as those above.
('7', 3, 3, 21, 9069) We should like to recommend the book to everyone.
('7', 3, 3, 22, 9119) It will be of profit to all, Hindus and Muslims alike.
('7', 3, 3, 23, 9174) It costs two shillings in Britain.
('7', 3, 3, 24, 9209) The same firm has also published Gulistan of Sheikh Saadi 2, priced at 1s.
('7', 3, 3, 25, 9284) Then there is a
('7', 3, 4, 26, 9300) 1 (1207 73), Sufi poet of Persia.
('7', 3, 4, 27, 9334) 2 Vide “What Should the Brave Do?” 1 6 1907
('7', 4, 0, 1, 9378) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 5
('7', 4, 1, 2, 9421) book entitled The Essence of the Koran, costing ls.
('7', 4, 1, 3, 9473) The Way of the Buddha is priced at 2s and The Way of Zoroaster also at 2s.
('7', 4, 1, 4, 9548) Other books are to follow.
('7', 4, 1, 5, 9575) If any of our readers wants one or more of these books, he should send us the amount of the price quoted above, and an extra 6d for every book.
('7', 4, 1, 6, 9719) We shall procure the book for him.
('7', 4, 1, 7, 9754) The extra 6d is for postage.
('7', 4, 1, 8, 9783) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 15 6 1907
('7', 4, 2, 9, 9825) 6. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 4, 3, 10, 9848) NEW LAW General Botha has, as the saying goes, dug up a mountain to kill a mouse.
('7', 4, 3, 11, 9930) He has informed the Association that no good purpose would be served by receiving deputation, since all preparations had been made to bring the law into effect.
('7', 4, 3, 12, 10091) Everybody therefore got busy looking into the Gazette, watching for the date when the law would come into force and other particulars.
('7', 4, 3, 13, 10226) But nothing of the kind was found in the Gazette.
('7', 4, 3, 14, 10276) It only says that the law has received the assent of His Majesty.
('7', 4, 3, 15, 10342) There is nothing new in this.
('7', 4, 3, 16, 10372) Another piece of information the Gazette gives is that the date on which the Act will be brought into effect will be fixed later.
('7', 4, 3, 17, 10502) What does this mean ?
('7', 4, 3, 18, 10524) The only construction I can put upon it is that the Government has been set thinking as to what it should do to meet the gaol resolution of the Indian community and how to implement the provisions of the Act.
('7', 4, 3, 19, 10733) This may or may not be the right meaning, but one thing is certain, namely, that the gaol resolution has posed a problem for the Government.
('7', 4, 4, 20, 10874) SOME QUESTIONS
('7', 4, 5, 21, 10889) Thus, things are still unsettled.
('7', 4, 5, 22, 10923) The Indian community will do well to keep its weapons ready.
('7', 4, 5, 23, 10984) Questions are still being asked, which is a good sign.
('7', 4, 5, 24, 11039) One of them is:
('7', 4, 6, 25, 11055) IF OUR WELL WISHERS IN ENGLAND DISAPPROVE GAOL GOING?
('7', 4, 7, 26, 11109) This is a good question.
('7', 4, 7, 27, 11134) The answer, too, is straight.
('7', 4, 7, 28, 11164) The members’ of the Committee or other gentlemen in England should be regarded as our well wishers as long as they help us in preserving our self respect and our rights.
('7', 4, 7, 29, 11334) We may respect their views.
('7', 4, 7, 30, 11362) But when their views go against our rights, we are not bound by them.
('7', 4, 7, 31, 11432) Suppose someone compels us to become Christians.
('7', 4, 7, 32, 11481) We shall oppose him.
('7', 4, 7, 33, 11502) If those whom we considered till now our well wishers advise us to embrace Christianity, I am sure that every Hindu and every Muslim
('7', 5, 0, 1, 11635) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 5, 1, 2, 11675) will agree with me that we should not accept the advice.
('7', 5, 1, 3, 11732) This law too is much the same kind of thing.
('7', 5, 1, 4, 11777) Clearly, it would make cowards of us.
('7', 5, 1, 5, 11815) We can never follow the advice to be cowards.
('7', 5, 1, 6, 11861) It is enough that we are in the right and God is on our side.
('7', 5, 1, 7, 11923) In the end, truth alone will triumph.
('7', 5, 2, 8, 11961) WHAT SHOULD THOSE DO WHO HAVE RECEIVED LETTERS OF NOTIFICATION ?
('7', 5, 3, 9, 12026) A person from Natal writes that he has received an order allowing him to proceed to the Transvaal.
('7', 5, 3, 10, 12125) Should he do so?
('7', 5, 3, 11, 12142) Perhaps everyone knows that this order is not a permit.
('7', 5, 3, 12, 12198) It is futile at present to enter the Transvaal on the basis of such an order.
('7', 5, 3, 13, 12276) All contact with the Permit Office has been stopped by the community’s resolution.
('7', 5, 3, 14, 12359) Hence the said order can be of no use.
('7', 5, 3, 15, 12398) It is essential that those not holding old permits should keep away from the Transvaal.
('7', 5, 4, 16, 12486) WHAT ABOUT LOST PERMITS ?
('7', 5, 5, 17, 12512) Under the old law, no one who had lost his permit could get a duplicate.
('7', 5, 5, 18, 12585) The new Act provides for the issue of a duplicate.
('7', 5, 5, 19, 12636) However, that refers to a duplicate copy of the new permit.
('7', 5, 5, 20, 12696) No action need be taken by one who has lost his permit.
('7', 5, 5, 21, 12752) He should await events without any fear, like other permit holders.
('7', 5, 6, 22, 12820) CAN THOSE WITH LOST PERMITS ENTER ?
('7', 5, 7, 23, 12856) A certain individual, having lost his permit, obtained a certificate to that effect from the Permit Office.
('7', 5, 7, 24, 12964) Can he re enter the Transvaal on return from India?
('7', 5, 7, 25, 13016) The answer is that he can, just like any other permit holder.
('7', 5, 7, 26, 13078) But he should remember that, in the end, he has to go to gaol.
('7', 5, 7, 27, 13141) Those who are afraid of imprisonment are not to enter the Transvaal at present, whether they hold permits or not.
('7', 5, 8, 28, 13255) SHOULD MR. CHAMNEY’S SIGNATURE BE OBTAINED FOR A LICENCE?
('7', 5, 9, 29, 13313) A man in Boksburg applied for a licence, but the Licensing Officer asked him to obtain Mr. Chamney’s signature.
('7', 5, 9, 30, 13425) If the Officer said so, it was illegal.
('7', 5, 9, 31, 13465) As long as the new law has not come into .force, no one is under obligation to show his permit, much less to obtain Mr. Chamney’s permission.
('7', 5, 9, 32, 13607) While replying to questions about licences, I should also state that a correspondent of this journal writes that some persons are trading at present without a licence.
('7', 5, 9, 33, 13775) The licence may be in the name of one person and trade is carried on by another person.
('7', 5, 9, 34, 13863) The correspondent has given the names of such persons.
('7', 5, 9, 35, 13918) I have not been able to verify the truth of his statement.
('7', 5, 9, 36, 13977) But such men should beware.
('7', 5, 9, 37, 14005) If the correspondent’s information is correct, I would advise such men to
('7', 6, 0, 1, 14079) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 7
('7', 6, 1, 2, 14122) give up the evil practice, since the Indian community as a whole has to suffer for the wrongs of a few Indians and, sooner or later, the offending Indian will be punished.
('7', 6, 2, 3, 14294) CHINESE UNITY
('7', 6, 3, 4, 14308) I wrote earlier about the resolution passed by the Chinese not to submit to the new law.
('7', 6, 3, 5, 14397) Not stopping there, they have signed a document stating that the signatories would not take out the new permits, but go to gaol and would shun taking food or water with those who should take out permits.
('7', 6, 3, 6, 14601) Nearly 900 Chinese have appended their signatures to the document, and now only a hundred Chinese remain whose signatures are yet to be secured.
('7', 6, 3, 7, 14746) The Chinese appear to be full of enthusiasm.
('7', 6, 4, 8, 14791) A SUGGESTION
('7', 6, 5, 9, 14804) In connection with the proposal that, with a view to keeping the shop running, a permit may be taken out by one person in every shop on the last date fixed for the purpose, or after coming out of gaol, it is further suggested that those who so wish to continue business should contribute to the Law Fund the balance of their earnings after deducting all expenses.
('7', 6, 5, 10, 15168) If the shopkeepers accept this suggestion, it will be regarded as a highly patriotic step.
('7', 6, 6, 11, 15259) CRIMINAL PROCEEDINGS AGAINST WAITER
('7', 6, 7, 12, 15295) An Indian waiter is being tried at Pretoria for offering a bribe of £50 to the chief clerk of the Registrar.
('7', 6, 7, 13, 15404) A critic asks if persons offering bribes to officers have cropped up only now.
('7', 6, 7, 14, 15483) Did not people make such an attempt before now?
('7', 6, 7, 15, 15531) If they did, why were no proceedings instituted against them before ?
('7', 6, 8, 16, 15601) CAUTION TO JOHANNESBURG RESIDENTS
('7', 6, 9, 17, 15635) The Police Commissioner has issued a notice to say that several cheats gain access to private houses by posing as Light Inspectors.
('7', 6, 9, 18, 15767) No one should admit such men, unless they produce the pass issued by the Municipality.
('7', 6, 10, 19, 15854) REGULATIONS FOR HAWKERS
('7', 6, 11, 20, 15878) The dispute regarding regulations for hawkers still goes on.
('7', 6, 11, 21, 15939) A contributor to The Star says that for a hawker to take out a licence for
('7', 6, 12, 22, 16014) 1 The Chinese Association later submitted a petition, protesting against the Act, to the Chinese Ambassador in London.
('7', 6, 12, 23, 16133) Vide Appendix II.
('7', 7, 0, 1, 16151) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 7, 1, 2, 16191) every municipal area and for the area outside will mean paying up to £80 a year for business within a few miles.
('7', 7, 1, 3, 16304) Such extortion will ruin the hawkers, and will, for the sake of the shopkeepers, deprive the public of the facility afforded by hawkers.
('7', 7, 1, 4, 16441) No one should take it that the contributor favours Indians.
('7', 7, 1, 5, 16501) There are also hawkers other than Indian.
('7', 7, 1, 6, 16543) The Regulations apply to all of them, and the defence of hawkers in general includes that of Indians also.
('7', 7, 1, 7, 16650) The point is that we are to oppose only such regulations as are made specially against us.
('7', 7, 2, 8, 16741) EDUCATION BILL
('7', 7, 3, 9, 16756) When the Parliament meets again this month, the new Government is to bring before it a Bill regarding education.
('7', 7, 3, 10, 16869) The Bill contains a provision preventing black boys from attending schools meant for the whites.
('7', 7, 3, 11, 16966) It means that, if one wants to start a private school to educate the whites and the blacks together, one cannot do so.
('7', 7, 3, 12, 17085) Special schools for the blacks will be started if the Government so desires.
('7', 7, 3, 13, 17162) This again is a new curiosity!
('7', 7, 3, 14, 17193) The Education Bill indicates what will be gained by Indians if they accept the new law.
('7', 7, 4, 15, 17281) MALAY LOCATION
('7', 7, 5, 16, 17296) A person writes in The Star about insanitary conditions in the Malay Location.
('7', 7, 5, 17, 17375) He states that it is not the Indians but the Municipality that is at fault here.
('7', 7, 5, 18, 17456) For the Municipality does not provide drainage and taps for drinking water.
('7', 7, 5, 19, 17532) To this the Municipality replies that there is regular drainage of sewage, and that there are taps for drinking water at many places.
('7', 7, 5, 20, 17666) If the people are prepared to pay, taps will be provided elsewhere also.
('7', 7, 5, 21, 17739) The Municipal Officer adds that it could not be claimed that the residents of the Malay Location were not dirty in their habits.
('7', 7, 5, 22, 17868) Some of them had been prosecuted for insanitation.
('7', 7, 5, 23, 17919) I, too, have to admit that we cannot deny the charge of insanitation.
('7', 7, 5, 24, 17989) Many houses are full of filth, the windows are soiled, the fences creak and the state of the latrines is horrible.
('7', 7, 5, 25, 18104) The kitchens are very bad.
('7', 7, 5, 26, 18131) In my view all this is sinful, and we have paid for this heavily and shall have to pay still more heavily.
('7', 7, 5, 27, 18238) It will be to our great advantage if people learn the value of tidiness, free air and light.

('7', 8, 5, 7, 18936) 8. PRIZE POEM ON NEW LAW
('7', 8, 6, 8, 18961) WINNER AMBARAM MANGALJI THAKAR
('7', 8, 7, 9, 18992) The response to our announcement 1 of a prize [for the best poem] on the subject of the new law may, on the whole, be considered satisfactory.
('7', 8, 7, 10, 19135) There were 20 competitors.
('7', 8, 7, 11, 19162) All of them state that they entered the competition, not with an eye on the prize money, but to express their enthusiasm and to serve the cause of patriotism.
('7', 8, 7, 12, 19321) This spirit and enthusiasm deserve praise.
('7', 8, 7, 13, 19364) Even so, we should point out that patriotism is implicit in writing for the prize.
('7', 8, 7, 14, 19447) There is no need for anyone to be ashamed of accepting the prize; one should rather feel proud.
('7', 8, 7, 15, 19543) The poems of three competitors, out of the total of 20, seemed to have nearly equal merit, and it was somewhat of a problem to decide which poem should be placed first.
('7', 8, 7, 16, 19712) Considering the terms of the competition, the poem of Mr. Ambaram Mangalji Thakar, the President of the Natal Sanatan Dharma Sabha, was ultimately found to be worthy of the first place and we have sent to him the sum of £1. We congratulate Mr. Ambaram Thakar and hope that he will set an example to others by acting up to the high ideal expressed in his
('7', 8, 8, 17, 20066) 1 Vide “A Prize of £1”, 1 6 1907
('7', 9, 0, 1, 20099) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 9, 1, 2, 20140) poem and thereby serve the cause of the country.
('7', 9, 1, 3, 20189) When devotionmerges into courage and courage into devotion, both are at their best.
('7', 9, 1, 4, 20273) If we go on doing our duty, armed with both these weapons, we shall surmount every difficulty and come out victorious in the end.
('7', 9, 1, 5, 20403) Of the 20 competitors, some have not communicated even their names to us.
('7', 9, 1, 6, 20477) Some of them sent in more than one entry.

('7', 10, 2, 5, 22939) 10. GAOL REGULATIONS OF NATAL Our Natal legislators have passed a law which gives sweets to one and cactus to the other.
('7', 10, 2, 6, 23060) From the Natal Government Gezette we gather that there are four classes of prisoners in Natal: white, Coloured, Indian and Kaffir.
('7', 10, 2, 7, 23191) If any work is taken from the white or the Coloured prisoners, the Government will give them some reward.
('7', 10, 2, 8, 23297) But the Indian or the Kaffir prisoners who do any work will get nothing.
('7', 10, 2, 9, 23370) Moreover, the white and the Coloured prisoners are given a towel each, while the Indian and the Kaffir are not given even this as if they do not need it at all.
('7', 10, 2, 10, 23531) The Government have, in this manner, created classes even among prisoners.
('7', 10, 2, 11, 23606) The Coloured prisoners include the Cape Boy, the American Negro, the Hottentot and the like.

('7', 11, 1, 2, 24854) 12. YUSUF ALI AND WOMEN’S EDUCATION
('7', 11, 2, 3, 24890) Mr. Yusuf Ali’s book on conditions prevailing in India is widely read.
('7', 11, 2, 4, 24961) His views on the education of women as expressed therein are worth noting.
('7', 11, 2, 5, 25036) He says that so long as Indian women do not get proper education, the condition of India is not likely to improve.
('7', 11, 2, 6, 25151) Woman is known as the better half of man.
('7', 11, 2, 7, 25193) If a half of one’s body ceases to function, we call it paralysis and the person becomes unfit for any activity.
('7', 11, 2, 8, 25305) Thus, if women in India are not employed as they should be, it can be said that the entire country suffers from paralysis.
('7', 11, 2, 9, 25428) How is it surprising then that India is not able to keep pace with other countries?
('7', 11, 2, 10, 25512) All parents should think of this in regard to their daughters, and all Indians should do likewise with regard to the womenfolk of India.
('7', 11, 2, 11, 25649) We badly need thousands of women who can compare with Mirabai and Rabia Bibi.

('7', 11, 3, 13, 25769) 13. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 11, 4, 14, 25793) TRANSVAAL PARLIAMENT The second session of the new Parliament began on the 14th.
('7', 11, 4, 15, 25874) General Botha spoke on the policy the local Government proposed to pursue.
('7', 11, 4, 16, 25949) The speech deserves the attention of the Indian community.
('7', 11, 4, 17, 26008) I give below the main points.
('7', 11, 5, 18, 26038) CHINESE TO GO
('7', 11, 6, 19, 26052) The present indentured Chinese labourers will be repatriated on the expiry of their contract.
('7', 11, 6, 20, 26146) No other indentured Chinese labourers will be imported to take their place.
('7', 11, 6, 21, 26222) At this rate, 16,000 Chinese will have left the Transvaal by the end of the current year.
('7', 11, 6, 22, 26312) The rest will go probably by the end of 1908 1.
('7', 11, 7, 23, 26360) WHO WILL REPLACE CHINESE?
('7', 11, 8, 24, 26386) There will be a shortage of mine labourers when the Chinese leave.
('7', 11, 8, 25, 26453) One way of meeting the situation will be to get hold of Kaffirs from wherever possible, and have the work done by them.
('7', 11, 8, 26, 26573) For this purpose, talks are in progress with the Portuguese Government.
('7', 11, 8, 27, 26645) The alternative is to encourage white labourers to work in the mines, and in
('7', 11, 9, 28, 26722) 1 The original has 1907, evidently a slip; vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 26 6 1907.
('7', 12, 0, 1, 26804) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 13
('7', 12, 1, 2, 26848) the end to make the Transvaal entirely white.
('7', 12, 1, 3, 26894) To enable whitelabourers to work on lower wages, the Transvaal will get out of the Customs Agreement.
('7', 12, 1, 4, 26996) If necessary, it will enter into another agreement.
('7', 12, 1, 5, 27048) The purpose is to reduce very much the duty payable at present and bring down prices, so that in the end the whites should be able to live as cheaply as in Great Britain.
('7', 12, 1, 6, 27219) Full encouragement will be given to agriculture so as to change the present position in which the Transvaal depends for its prosperity exclusively on the mines.
('7', 12, 1, 7, 27380) A special bank will be started with a view to promoting agriculture and providing irrigation.
('7', 12, 1, 8, 27474) This bank will lend money to farmers.
('7', 12, 1, 9, 27512) To finance the bank the Imperial Government will give the local Government a loan of £5,000,000.
('7', 12, 2, 10, 27609) CONSEQUENCES OF SPEECH
('7', 12, 3, 11, 27632) This speech has thrown the minds of mine owners into confusion.
('7', 12, 3, 12, 27696) They are not likely to get many Kaffirs as labourers.
('7', 12, 3, 13, 27750) Therefore the condition of Johannesburg, it is feared, will for years continue to be what it is at present.
('7', 12, 3, 14, 27858) But the most important consequence of this is that Indians may have to leave bag and baggage.
('7', 12, 3, 15, 27952) It seems to be the firm determination of the local Government to allow no Coloured people except as labourers into the Transvaal.
('7', 12, 3, 16, 28082) If the Indian community is found lacking in courage, the Government will not hesitate to drive it out.
('7', 12, 3, 17, 28185) The Indian community is now placed in a situation where it must choose between extermination and counter attack.
('7', 12, 4, 18, 28298) LABOUR PROTECTION ACT
('7', 12, 5, 19, 28320) My last comment appears to be supported by one more law that is to be passed during the present session.
('7', 12, 5, 20, 28425) The Gazette has published a Bill to provide for payment of damages to workers and their families in case of disability suffered during performance of duty by workers employed in the various factories.
('7', 12, 5, 21, 28626) This law is to apply to the whites only.
('7', 12, 5, 22, 28667) If a white and an Indian labourer are working together in a mine or elsewhere, and if both should get their hand or foot crushed by being caught in a machine, the employer is bound by this law to maintain only the white labourer and his family.
('7', 12, 5, 23, 28912) The Indian worker does not count at all.
('7', 12, 5, 24, 28953) He would be doomed, if there were no God in Heaven above.
('7', 12, 5, 25, 29011) Moreover, no one can suppose that even a penny will be advanced to an Indian by the proposed bank.
('7', 12, 5, 26, 29110) The bank is solely for the white farmer.
('7', 12, 5, 27, 29151) This is the marvellous fruit of General Botha’s gallantry.
('7', 12, 5, 28, 29210) The men of his community watered the soil of the Transvaal with Boer blood.
('7', 12, 5, 29, 29286) No one has reason to wonder that, having thus

('7', 15, 2, 3, 33996) INTRODUCTION
('7', 15, 3, 4, 34009) In pursuance of our ideas, we commence this week a series of articles on the subject stated above.
('7', 15, 3, 5, 34108) It will always be our aim to bring about and preserve unity between Hindus and Muslims.
('7', 15, 3, 6, 34196) One of the ways of achieving this is to acquaint each with whatever is good in the other.
('7', 15, 3, 7, 34286) Moreover, when occasion requires, Hindus and Muslims should serve each other without any reserve.
('7', 15, 3, 8, 34384) The series that we are commencing is intended to serve both these aims.
('7', 15, 3, 9, 34456) It is also our object to spread education and culture among the Indian community.
('7', 15, 3, 10, 34538) With this end in view, we had intended, and still intend, to publish a separate book.
('7', 15, 3, 11, 34624) We intend to bring out a translation of Justice Ameer Ali’s book on Islam and [another book giving] an account of the hardships of Indians in South Africa.
('7', 15, 3, 12, 34780) But there is likely to be some delay since there are difficulties in the way which have not yet been overcome.
('7', 15, 3, 13, 34891) Meanwhile, we propose to give every week the biography of the Prophet written by a famous writer, Washington Irving.
('7', 15, 3, 14, 35008) The biography deserves to be read by both Hindus and Muslims.
('7', 15, 3, 15, 35070) Most Hindus are ignorant of the career of the Prophet.
('7', 15, 3, 16, 35125) Most Muslims are ignorant of the researches made by Englishmen and of what they write about the Prophet.
('7', 15, 3, 17, 35230) The history by Washington is likely to be of benefit to both these classes [of readers].
('7', 15, 3, 18, 35319) We do not give a full translation, but only the substance.
('7', 15, 3, 19, 35378) Washington Irving’s account is considered excellent, and though he has not written ill of Islam like other European writers, it is likely that occasionally his ideas may be such as may not appeal to our readers.
('7', 15, 3, 20, 35590) A wise man would make himself acquainted even with such ideas.
('7', 15, 3, 21, 35653) We advise our readers to go through the chapters that follow, 1 bearing in mind that the purpose of reading is to accept knowledge from everything that we read and to draw the right lesson from it.
('7', 15, 4, 22, 35851) WHO WAS WASHINGTON IRVING?

('7', 15, 5, 24, 35912) He was born in the city of New York in America in the year 1783. For many years he lived in Europe.
('7', 15, 5, 25, 36012) He was one of the front rank writers of America.

('7', 21, 4, 8, 49254) [GANDHIJI:] It is difficult to say, what will be the ultimate result of the enforcement of the law, but as far as I and my co workers areconcerned, we are determined not to submit to the proposed registration, being prepared rather to undergo the last penalty provided.

('7', 21, 5, 13, 49997) At the same time, from letters which I have received from all parts of the Transvaal, and from letters sent to the editor of Indian Opinion, I am inclined to think that fully 50 per cent of British Indians in the Transvaal will remain firm in the policy of non submission.
('7', 21, 5, 14, 50270) I have not yet heard of a single Indian who has justified the law.
('7', 21, 5, 15, 50337) Many feel that rather than bear the hardship of gaol, they would leave the country, but I do not know of one who has ever said he will take a new registration certificate under the law.
('7', 21, 6, 16, 50523) Indians, said Mr. Gandhi, were very indignant, and he calculated that 6,000 at least would refuse to register according to the new law.

('7', 23, 1, 10, 55494) This Act presumes every Indian to be guilty, and throws on him the onus of proving that he is not so, that is to say) that he has entered the Transvaal in a bona fide manner.

('7', 25, 2, 11, 59465) 19. FAMINE IN SOUTH AFRICA
('7', 25, 3, 12, 59492) South Africa is now passing through very hard times.
('7', 25, 3, 13, 59545) Scarcity prevails everywhere.
('7', 25, 3, 14, 59575) Both the whites and the Coloured people have been reduced to a precarious condition.
('7', 25, 3, 15, 59660) The greatest difficulty is felt by landlords and traders At such a time, far sighted men should think what is to be done.
('7', 25, 3, 16, 59782) Business will be slacker still and land values fall further.
('7', 25, 3, 17, 59843) How long can this last?
('7', 25, 3, 18, 59867) The crisis in this country is not due to lack of rains or damage to crops.
('7', 25, 3, 19, 59942) The land which was the source of money has ceased to be fruitful.
('7', 25, 3, 20, 60008) We can see from this that there is no loss in agriculture as such.
('7', 25, 3, 21, 60075) Our advice therefore is that, taking advantage of the opportunity, every Indian who can should devote his attention to agriculture.
('7', 25, 3, 22, 60207) Indians, traders as well as others, can take to farming.
('7', 25, 3, 23, 60264) This does not need much money, and there is no problem of taking out licences, etc.
('7', 25, 3, 24, 60348) We are certain that, if the Indian community pays sufficient attention to agriculture, not only will it bring profit to itself but it may also help remove the prejudice prevailing against it in this country.
('7', 25, 3, 25, 60556) The soil being virgin, there is scope here for crops of various kinds.
('7', 25, 3, 26, 60627) If by any chance the produce does not sell here, it can be exported.
('7', 25, 3, 27, 60696) The Dutch have been making efforts in the Transvaal to bring prosperity to the land through agriculture.
('7', 25, 3, 28, 60801) A similar attempt isin progress in Natal.

('7', 28, 7, 12, 65467) SIR, It may appear ungrateful to have to criticize your moderate and well meant leaderette on the so called “passive resistance” to the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 28, 7, 13, 65629) I call the passive resistance to be offered by the Indian community “so called”, because, in my opinion, it is really not resistance but a policy of communal suffering.
('7', 28, 7, 14, 65798) Even after reading the Regulations, you consider it to be a matter of sentiment.
('7', 28, 7, 15, 65879) Is it sentiment, if I, as a father, would prefer to be shot down before I see my eight year old boy being subjected to the tyrannical process of having to give his digit impressions, separately and then simultaneously, before an officer whom he may never have seen in his life time, and for no crime of his own?
('7', 28, 7, 16, 66191) Is it sentiment, when I decline to give the name of my mother and such particulars as the price of a precarious residence in this country?
('7', 28, 7, 17, 66330) Lord Elgin may certainly, sitting in his cushioned chair, see no distinction between making a mark with the thumb instead of with a pen, but I know that he belongs to that nation which would rise in rebellion from end to end to resent an attack on personal liberty, and that he would be the first person to cry out against even a forcible tracing of his signature.
('7', 28, 7, 18, 66695) It is the compulsion that stings, not the digit impression.

('7', 31, 1, 2, 70670) 27. LETTER TO “THE STAR”
('7', 31, 2, 3, 70695) JOHANNESBURG, July 4, [1907]
('7', 31, 4, 4, 70724) THE EDITOR THE STAR [JOHANNESBURG]
('7', 31, 5, 5, 70759) SIR, You have, much to the surprise of the Indian community, informed your readers that Indians suffer from practically no disabilities, and that the question of giving digit impressions is one to be dismissed from consideration, as the Indian sepoy voluntarily gives his thumb mark before receiving his pension.
('7', 31, 5, 6, 71072) I wonder whether you would now support the Immigration Bill published yesterday, as being an innocuous measure so far as Indians are concerned.
('7', 31, 5, 7, 71216) Asiatics have been credited with unfathomable subtlety, but that displayed by the framers of the Bill certainly, to use a vulgarexpression, takes the cake.
('7', 31, 5, 8, 71372) It is, if my reading of Sub section 4 of Section 2 be correct, I take it, an answer to “passive resisters” to the Asiatic Registration Act; and, in order to break the spirit of the last vestige of dignity that yet remains in Indians in the Transvaal, a system of State robbery is instituted.
('7', 31, 5, 9, 71664) For the section in question makes an Asiatic who does not take out the new registration certificate a prohibited immigrant, and a prohibited immigrant is liable to suffer imprisonment and then to be physically deported, the expenses of deportation to be levied from the estate, found within the Colony, of the deported.
('7', 31, 5, 10, 71984) Thus, the law manufactures a prohibited immigrant by a most circuitous method.
('7', 31, 5, 11, 72063) A man who has made the Transvaal his home, but who, rightly or wrongly, protests against a law applicable to him, by way of suffering further penalty is to be treated as an outlaw in the country of his adoption.
('7', 31, 5, 12, 72275) The section in question, moreover, can only refer to the Asiatic and Immorality Acts, that is to say, prostitutes, pimps, and Asiatics who refuse to surrender their self respect are to be classed in the same category.
('7', 31, 5, 13, 72493) Moreover, to show the wantonness of the insult offered, I draw the attention of the public to the fact that if an Indian who may satisfy the most rigorous test, say, for instance, Sir Mancherji, wishes to enter the Transvaal, he must, perforce, take out a registration certificate for himself and his minor children, the latter also, if over eight years, to
('7', 32, 0, 1, 72851) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 33
('7', 32, 1, 2, 72895) give their separate and simultaneous digit impressions, unless he wishes to be classed as a prohibited immigrant and to be deported.
('7', 32, 1, 3, 73028) Now the Registration Act is intended, so it is said, to serve as a measure of identification only.
('7', 32, 1, 4, 73127) Is there any meaning in identifying a man who, by reason of his possessing educational qualifications, can claim to remain in the Transvaal but for the Asiatic Act?
('7', 32, 1, 5, 73292) Does he not carry marks of identification on his own person, seeing that he is liable to be examined as to his knowledge of a European language, at any time, whether within or without the Colony?
('7', 32, 1, 6, 73488) What becomes of the speeches of General Botha, 1 who showed so much anxiety, when in London, for the welfare of the Empire as a whole, who assured Lord Ampthill that there was no intention of imp osing humiliation on Indian subjects of the Crown?
('7', 32, 1, 7, 73735) Is self govern ment to mean a licence to deprive Asiatics, without check, of all lib erty?
('7', 32, 1, 8, 73826) Sir George Farrar, speaking on behalf of the Progressive Party, stated that the question underlying the Asiatic Registration Act was of the highest importance, that the passing of the Act inflamed millions of Indians unnecessarily against the British Empire.
('7', 32, 1, 9, 74085) And yet, in order to assist the Government, Sir George, at the risk of wounding, at a most inopportune time, the susceptibilities of Indian subjects of King Edward, supported the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 32, 1, 10, 74290) Is the Progressive Party to approve of the Immigration Bill withthe hideous clause to which I have drawn attention, in spite of its boast of Imperialism?
('7', 32, 2, 11, 74444) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI The Star, 5 7 1907

('7', 37, 1, 2, 83772) 33. OBNOXIOUS LAW
('7', 37, 2, 3, 83790) ATROCIOUS REGULATIONS
('7', 37, 3, 4, 83812) The expected has happened.
('7', 37, 3, 5, 83839) It has been notified in the Transvaal Gazette that the new law will come into force from July l.
('7', 37, 3, 6, 83936) The Regulations framed under the Act are so oppressive, so obnoxious, that it seems impossible for any Indian to submit to them.
('7', 37, 3, 7, 84065) We give below a full summary of those Regulations 1: l.
('7', 37, 3, 8, 84121) This clause contains several definitions.
('7', 37, 3, 9, 84163) 2. Shows how a Register of Asiatics is to be maintained.
('7', 37, 3, 10, 84220) 3. Persons above the age of sixteen should apply in Form B. The application for a child under sixteen years and above eight years should be in Form C. 4. Every adult shall appear before such person as the Colonial Secretary may appoint, and furnish such person with the required particulars in Form B. and shall produce and surrender to such person his permit, the registration certificate obtained on payment of a fee of £3, and any other documents which he may desire to produce in support of his application.
('7', 37, 3, 11, 84732) When making an application for a minor, the father or guardian of the minor shall appear with such minor, shall produce the documents referred to above, and furnish the particulars required in Form C. Every application for registration shall be made at such place as the Colonial Secretary may prescribe.
('7', 37, 3, 12, 85037) The person appointed to receive applications shall, on completing the application, issue to the applicant a written acknowledgement of the receipt of the application, and thereafter transmit the application to the Registrar.
('7', 37, 3, 13, 85262) 5. If the Registrar refuses to register any adult as above, he shall issue a notice of such refusal to the applicant and send a copy of the same to the [Resident] Magistrate.
('7', 37, 3, 14, 85437) 6. The certificate of registration shall be in Form F. 7. Every adult shall, if required, supply the following particu lars to the police, in addition to producing his certificate of registration:
('7', 37, 4, 15, 85634) 1 The translation given here has been collated with the English text of the Regulations, vide Appendix IV.
('7', 38, 0, 1, 85741) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 39
('7', 38, 1, 2, 85785) (1) his full name; (2) his present residence; (3) his residence at the date he made application for registration; (4) his age; (5) a specimen of his signature, if he is able to write; (6) impressions of his thumbs and fingers.
('7', 38, 1, 3, 86012) 8. ('7', 41, 10, 10, 90319) EFFECT OF RULES
('7', 41, 11, 11, 90335) The Rules include the following additional points not anticipated earlier: 1. In India, Hindus and Muslims respect the mother so deeply that if anyone compels them to make a reference to her name, that may lead to murder.
('7', 41, 11, 12, 90557) The name of the mother will have now to be entered in an application.
('7', 41, 11, 13, 90627) 2. It was never dreamt that impressions of all fingers would be required from children.
('7', 41, 11, 14, 90715) Now they will take eighteen such prints.
('7', 41, 11, 15, 90756) It is the usual experience that delicate children of nine years will start crying if touched by a stranger.
('7', 41, 11, 16, 90864) These delicate Indian children will now have contact with rough hands.
('7', 41, 11, 17, 90935) Fathers will look on while impressions of their fingers are being taken.
('7', 41, 11, 18, 91008) 3. Not only that impressions of all fingers will have to be given, but it will be done twice—together and separately.
('7', 41, 11, 19, 91126) 4. The police have orders to take impressions—of children as well as of adults.
('7', 41, 11, 20, 91206) 5. If a merchant goes out, and the application for licence is made by his partner, he will need to have with him the power of attorney from the merchant, bearing the
('7', 41, 12, 21, 91372) 1 Particulars in this form are as in form “F” above.
('7', 42, 0, 1, 91425) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 43
('7', 42, 1, 2, 91469) thumb impression of his right hand.
('7', 42, 1, 3, 91505) This is insulting in the extreme.
('7', 42, 1, 4, 91539) From now on, a signature will not be sufficient on the power of attorney by an Indian, but a thumb impression will be required.
('7', 42, 1, 5, 91667) 6. All applications will be prepared by officers.
('7', 42, 1, 6, 91717) No one can have them prepared by a lawyer or agent.
('7', 42, 1, 7, 91769) At first sight it may appear that this rule will save expenditure.
('7', 42, 1, 8, 91836) But looking at it more closely, we find that it is like being served with a sweet dish with a tiger in front.
('7', 42, 1, 9, 91946) Even adult Indians become nervous in the presence of officers.
('7', 42, 1, 10, 92009) What then can we expect of children?
('7', 42, 1, 11, 92046) [From Gurajati] Indian Opinion, 6 7 1907
('7', 42, 2, 12, 92087) 34. MASS MEETING AT PRETORIA 1
('7', 42, 3, 13, 92118) In view of the fact that the new law was to come into force in Pretoria from July 1, there was a huge mass meeting on Sunday, June 30. Indians from Johannesburg went there specially at their own expense.
('7', 42, 3, 14, 92322) Among those who attended were the Acting President, Mr. Essop Mia, Moulvi Saheb Ahmed Mukhtiar, and Messrs M. S. Coovadia, Emam Abdool Cadir, Omalji Sale, Makanji, Zinabhai, Gulabbhai Kikabhai, Morarji Desai, Gulabbhai Patel, Bhula, Ranchhod Nichhabhai, Nadirshaw Cama, Mahomed Essak, Khushal, Peter Moonlight, Naidoo, A. S. Pillay, Gandhi and others.
('7', 42, 3, 15, 92674) From Pretoria nearly four hundred Indians attended, including, besides Mr. Hajee Habib, the Moulvi Saheb of the mosque at Pretoria, Mr. Hajee Cassim Jusab, Mr. Hajee Osman, Mr. Cachalia, Mr. Ally, Mr. Hajee Ibrahim, Mr. Gavarishankar Vyas, Mr. Prabhashankar Joshi, Mr. Mohanlal Joshi, Mr. Omarji and other gentlemen.
('7', 42, 3, 16, 92991) The delegates from Johannesburg were looked after by Mr. Hajee Habib and Mr. Vyas.
('7', 42, 3, 17, 93074) The meeting commenced punctually at 3 p.m.
('7', 42, 3, 18, 93117) and continued up to 7 p.m.
('7', 42, 3, 19, 93144) Welcoming them all, Mr. Hajee Habib said that the new law was barbarous.
('7', 42, 3, 20, 93217) So long as the Regulations [under it] were not published, he had hoped that if they happened to be reasonable the law could perhaps be accepted.
('7', 42, 3, 21, 93362) But after going through the Regulations, there could be no question of accepting the law.
('7', 42, 3, 22, 93452) The Indian community must unitedly oppose the law.
('7', 42, 3, 23, 93503) He proposed that
('7', 42, 4, 24, 93520) 1 The report in Gujarati carried the headlines: “Huge Mass Meeting of Pretoria Indians: Spirited Opposition to Obnoxious Law: Everyone Ready for Gaol” and was published as a “Special Report for Indian Opinion”.
('7', 43, 0, 1, 93731) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 43, 1, 2, 93772) Mr. Essop Mia should take the chair.
('7', 43, 1, 3, 93809) Mr. Essop Mia thanked Mr. Hajee Habib for placing his house at their disposal.
('7', 43, 1, 4, 93888) He asserted that the law being poisonous, they could not respect it.
('7', 43, 1, 5, 93957) He showed himself ready to serve the community even at the cost of his personal affairs.
('7', 43, 1, 6, 94046) He wanted all people to stand together.
('7', 43, 1, 7, 94086) So far, they had remained submissive, but they could not remain so any longer.
('7', 43, 1, 8, 94165) Nowhere in the world did they ask for the mother’s name.
('7', 43, 1, 9, 94222) Only on the Day of Judgement would they be identified by their mother’s name.
('7', 43, 1, 10, 94300) But now the Government would ask them to give the mother’s name.
('7', 43, 1, 11, 94365) The Indian community would never submit to such slavery.
('7', 43, 1, 12, 94422) Mr. Gandhi explained the implications of the law and said that it was necessary for every Indian, whether rich or poor, to be free.
('7', 43, 1, 13, 94554) Thatthis law had been approved by the [Imperial] Government made no deference.
('7', 43, 1, 14, 94633) It still remained to be approved by the Indian community.
('7', 43, 1, 15, 94691) Unless it was accepted by the Indian community, it could not be taken that the law had been passed.
('7', 43, 1, 16, 94791) If any Indian, big or small, should accept the title deed of slavery under the law, others would not follow his example.
('7', 43, 1, 17, 94912) Those who kept themselves free would win in the end.
('7', 43, 1, 18, 94965) In a spirited speech, Moulvi Saheb Ahmed Mukhtiar pointed out that it was necessary for all of them to stand together.
('7', 43, 1, 19, 95084) They alone were true Muslims who attended to the claims of worldly affairs as well as to those of religion.
('7', 43, 1, 20, 95192) When Hazrat Yusuf Abesalam was placed in a distressing situation, he prayed to God that he might be sent to gaol instead.
('7', 43, 1, 21, 95314) No Indian should submit to the oppressive law.
('7', 43, 1, 22, 95361) He suggested that a committee should visit every place to educate public opinion.
('7', 43, 1, 23, 95443) If such a committee was appointed, he would also be ready to join it.
('7', 43, 1, 24, 95513) Mr. Naidoo spoke in Tamil and asserted that, even if he were to die, he would not submit to the law.
('7', 43, 1, 25, 95614) Mr. Omarji Sale also made a speech and asked Indians to remain united and to boycott the Permit Office.
('7', 43, 1, 26, 95718) Mr. M. S. Coovadia supported the previous speaker.
('7', 43, 1, 27, 95769) Mr. Cama said that the law was so bad that no Indian with self respect could think of submitting to it.
('7', 43, 1, 28, 95873) He would not submit to it, even if he were to lose everything, including his life.
('7', 43, 1, 29, 95956) Mr. Emam Abdool Cadir said that he could not submit to the law, whoever else among the Indians did.
('7', 43, 1, 30, 96056) It inflicted a sentence of imprisonment worse than that of transportation for life.
('7', 43, 1, 31, 96140) The Moulvi Saheb gave his support to the resolution and declared that he was ready for a tour of all places.
('7', 43, 1, 32, 96249) Mr. Makanji said that he had thought of accepting the law if it
('7', 44, 0, 1, 96313) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 45
('7', 44, 1, 2, 96357) afforded the slightest relief.
('7', 44, 1, 3, 96388) But now it was his firm determination that he would not accept it, whoever else did so.
('7', 44, 1, 4, 96476) Mr. Hajee Ibrahim also spoke and said in conclusion that thelaw could not be accepted.
('7', 44, 1, 5, 96563) Mr. Noormahomed Ayub said that it was a golden opportunity for the Indians to show their spirit.
('7', 44, 1, 6, 96660) Messrs Ismail Jooma, Manji Nathu, Trimbaklal and Hajee Osman Haji Aba spoke in the same strain.

('7', 44, 1, 14, 97280) Mr. Haji Cassim said that the law could not be accepted by the Indian community in any circumstances.
('7', 44, 1, 15, 97382) Moulvi Saheb Ahmed Mukhtiar pointed out that the duty of the priest was not merely to lead prayers but also to share fully the hardships of the people.
('7', 44, 1, 16, 97534) It is because the whites wanted to insult their religion that they made distinctions in regard to railway fares.
('7', 44, 1, 17, 97647) The railway officials told them that Christian and Jewish priests were entitled to concession tickets for railway journeys, but not Indian Muslims.
('7', 44, 1, 18, 97795) The Indian community would never acquiesce in such slavery.

('7', 44, 1, 20, 98121) There was a heavy burden on his fellow countrymen at Pretoria and he was convinced that they would shoulder it quite well.
('7', 44, 1, 21, 98244) The whole Indian community was grateful to Mr. Hajee Habib for his hospitality.
('7', 44, 1, 22, 98324) The business was concluded on this note of enthusiasm, and the meeting came to an end at seven o’clock.

('7', 45, 0, 1, 98469) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 45, 1, 2, 98510) 35. INTERVIEW TO “RAND DAILY MAIL”
('7', 45, 2, 3, 98545) It has been notified in the Transvaal Government Gazette that the Asiatic Act will come into force on July 1. The Regulations framed under this new Act have been published and according to them impressions of all fingers will be taken simultaneously and singly.
('7', 45, 2, 4, 98807) A representative of the Rand Daily Mail interviewed Mr. Gandhi with a view to obtaining the reactions of Indians to these Regulations.
('7', 45, 2, 5, 98942) The following report was published in the issue of the Rand Daily Mail of the 29th [ultimo].
('7', 45, 3, 6, 99035) My co workers and I will undergo the extreme penalty prescribed by law rather than submit to the law for Asiatics that has been passed.
('7', 45, 3, 7, 99171) No self respecting Indian will submit to this Act.
('7', 45, 3, 8, 99222) From the letters received by me and the editor of Indian Opinion, about fifty per cent of the Indian population in the Transvaal will resist the law.
('7', 45, 3, 9, 99372) I have not met a single Indian so far who justifies it.
('7', 45, 3, 10, 99428) Some assert that they will leave this country.
('7', 45, 3, 11, 99475) But I have not come across a single person who even talks of applying for a register.
('7', 45, 3, 12, 99561) Indians are very angry and at least 6,000 persons will refuse to apply for registers.
('7', 45, 3, 13, 99647) If they are prosecuted by the Government, they will be ready to go to gaol.
('7', 45, 3, 14, 99723) No doubt they will run into loss by doing so.
('7', 45, 3, 15, 99769) But they are ready to sacrifice their all for the sake of their self respect.
('7', 45, 3, 16, 99847) Since we have no say even in regard to the making of laws that affect us, we feel that there is only one course left to us, and that is, not to submit to any law.
('7', 45, 3, 17, 100010) It has been said that the law is mild.
('7', 45, 3, 18, 100049) But I must say that I have read the laws of many colonies, and in not a single colony have I come across a law so insulting and humiliating as this Act.
('7', 45, 3, 19, 100202) Two thousand people were present at the meeting in the Empire Theatre, and they have solemnly resolved with one voice that they will not get registered under compulsion.
('7', 45, 3, 20, 100372) I am confident that they will keep the oath.
('7', 45, 3, 21, 100417) [From Gurajati] Indian Opinion, 6 7 1907
('7', 45, 4, 22, 100458) 1 What follows, however, is a summary.
('7', 45, 4, 23, 100497) Vide “Interview to Rand Daily Mail”, 28 6 1907

('7', 46, 1, 2, 100588) 36. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 46, 2, 3, 100612) NEW LAW
('7', 46, 3, 4, 100620) The Regulations, which Indians had been awaiting for long, have now been published.
('7', 46, 3, 5, 100704) A Gujarati proverb says, “As is the father, so is the son; as is the banyan tree, so is its fruit.” Likewise, as is the Act, so are the Regulations.
('7', 46, 3, 6, 100853) Those who had hoped for some leniency in the Regulations are disappointed.
('7', 46, 3, 7, 100928) I for my part am very glad that the Regulations are unexpectedly stringent.
('7', 46, 3, 8, 101004) This has made every Indian resolute.
('7', 46, 3, 9, 101041) All Indians say that there is now no alternative to gaol going.
('7', 46, 4, 10, 101105) SNAKES IN GRASS
('7', 46, 5, 11, 101121) There is a proverb in English that green grass sometimes harbours green snakes which remain invisible.
('7', 46, 5, 12, 101224) Their presence is felt only when they bite.
('7', 46, 5, 13, 101268) The same is true of these Regulations.
('7', 46, 5, 14, 101307) Only now do I realize that there are some snakes hidden in them.
('7', 46, 5, 15, 101372) When I first read them, I could not follow some of their implications.
('7', 46, 5, 16, 101443) I had thought that no one was likely to be interrogated so long as the new permits or title deeds of slavery had not been issued.
('7', 46, 5, 17, 101573) Now, on second thoughts, I see that, according to the powers granted to the police under the Regulations, they can require any Indian to give his finger prints and state his antecedents.
('7', 46, 5, 18, 101760) Again, this may be required as often as the police choose.
('7', 46, 5, 19, 101819) One has to beware of this snake.
('7', 46, 5, 20, 101852) If the Government should choose to apply pressure by turning this screw, the Indian community will perhaps feel baffled.
('7', 46, 5, 21, 101973) But the remedy is clear.
('7', 46, 5, 22, 101998) Under no circumstances is any Indian to give his finger prints.
('7', 46, 5, 23, 102062) All these days we used to give the thumb impression.
('7', 46, 5, 24, 102115) But now that the thumb impression has been made obligatory, we should refuse to give even that.
('7', 46, 5, 25, 102211) What will be the consequence of this?
('7', 46, 5, 26, 102249) The gaol, of course.
('7', 46, 5, 27, 102270) The thought of gaol should be an ordinary matter to every Indian.
('7', 46, 5, 28, 102336) According to the new law, the penalty for not furnishing the particulars or identity marks that the police may demand, is fine or imprisonment.
('7', 46, 5, 29, 102480) In no case is the fine to be paid.
('7', 46, 5, 30, 102515) Thus, only gaol remains.
('7', 46, 5, 31, 102540) I also advise that no one coming from Volksrust should now give his thumb impression or finger prints to the police.
('7', 46, 5, 32, 102657) When, in consequence, he is taken to a magistrate, he should prove [his right].
('7', 46, 5, 33, 102737) If the magistrate should still sentence him to gaol, he should undergo the sentence.
('7', 46, 5, 34, 102822) Again, this struggle is only for those who have a true
('7', 47, 0, 1, 102877) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 47, 1, 2, 102918) case, that is, what is stated above applies only to those who hold a permit bearing their own thumb impression.
('7', 47, 1, 3, 103030) This needs a good deal of courage, but that courage we ought to have and will certainly have.
('7', 47, 2, 4, 103124) ANOTHER SNAKE
('7', 47, 3, 5, 103138) That was but one snake.
('7', 47, 3, 6, 103162) Another snake relates to the question of licences.
('7', 47, 3, 7, 103213) I thought the taking of finger prints in connection with licences would commence in January.
('7', 47, 3, 8, 103306) But I now find that it comes into force immediately.
('7', 47, 3, 9, 103359) For finger prints can be demanded of anyone seeking a licence.
('7', 47, 3, 10, 103422) This matter may not have been noticed even by revenue officers.
('7', 47, 3, 11, 103486) I hope therefore that Indians have already taken out their licences.
('7', 47, 3, 12, 103555) But how long can we carry on like this?
('7', 47, 3, 13, 103595) The Government has brought in the question of finger prints everywhere.
('7', 47, 3, 14, 103667) We have therefore to be particularly careful.
('7', 47, 3, 15, 103713) I had believed that the provisions of the law would be duly complied with if one person in each big shop held a permit, but on reflection, I see that it is but following a mirage to keep on hoping that one person could carry on the trade.
('7', 47, 3, 16, 103952) I ought, therefore, to say that it will be good for the merchants to give up, if necessary, all hopes of continuing trade.
('7', 47, 3, 17, 104075) If we hold ourselves ready to sacrifice our business for the sake of the country and our self respect, we shall not get panicky when the time comes.
('7', 47, 3, 18, 104224) It does not, moreover, seem proper that one should, even for the sake of one’s trade, give the finger prints and be a bondsman.
('7', 47, 3, 19, 104352) The best and the only course is to repose full trust in God and sacrifice everything for the good of the country.
('7', 47, 3, 20, 104466) We shall surely need such unalloyed courage to achieve success.
('7', 47, 4, 21, 104530) PRETORIA’S OPPORTUNITY
('7', 47, 5, 22, 104553) Issuing of the title deed of slavery has started with Pretoria.
('7', 47, 5, 23, 104617) Hence a great responsibility has devolved on it.
('7', 47, 5, 24, 104666) But it has also the opportunity of proving its mettle.
('7', 47, 5, 25, 104721) All Indians wish and pray to God that Pretoria may act in a manner worthy of itself.
('7', 47, 6, 26, 104806) COMMENT BY “DAILY MAIL”
('7', 47, 7, 27, 104830) A correspondent of the [Rand] Daily Mail saw Mr. Gandhi on Friday last and obtained some information from him.
('7', 47, 7, 28, 104941) 1 Mr. Gandhi told him that at least 6,000 Indians were certain to go to gaol.
('7', 47, 7, 29, 105019) The Indian community would not swerve from the pledge taken in the name of God.
('7', 47, 7, 30, 105099) There was no disloyalty involved in disobeying the law.
('7', 47, 8, 31, 105155) 1 Vide “Interview to Rand Daily Mail”, 28 6 1907

('7', 48, 1, 2, 105248) In so doing, the Indian community sought only to preserve its honour and self respect.
('7', 48, 1, 3, 105335) One could not say how one would become free by thus opposing the law.
('7', 48, 1, 4, 105405) But the brave colonists would be able to appreciate the courage of the Indians.

('7', 49, 4, 9, 107946) JOHANNESBURG, July 6, 1907
('7', 49, 5, 10, 107973) TO THE EDITOR [RAND DAILY MAIL]
('7', 49, 6, 11, 108005) SIR, I trust I need not offer any apology for reverting to the Asiatic question.
('7', 49, 6, 12, 108086) I did not say to your interviewer 2 that “passive resistance” was a new way to my compatriots.
('7', 49, 6, 13, 108181) What I did say was that it was not possible for me to forecast the result, as we had been for generations unused to it, especially on a large scale.
('7', 49, 6, 14, 108330) I, personally, feel proud to notice that the faculty of suffering for the common good has only lain dormant, and that, under stress of circumstances, it is being again quickened into life.
('7', 49, 6, 15, 108519) Picketing is by no means a new thing to the Indian mind.
('7', 49, 6, 16, 108576) The network of castes in India simply illustrates the use and value of that weapon, provided that it is rightly used.
('7', 49, 6, 17, 108694) Ostracism and excommunication are the most powerful instruments resorted to today in India, in unfortunately trivial matters, and, if the Registration Act now enables my countrymen to realize the use of that terrible weapon for a higher purpose, both Lord Elgin and the Transvaal Government will have deserved their gratitude.
('7', 49, 6, 18, 109021) There is, of course, therefore, nothing strange in Indian pickets,
('7', 49, 7, 19, 109088) 1 This was published under the title “Indian Picketing” and reproduced in Indian Opinion, 13 7 1907.
('7', 49, 8, 20, 109189) 2 Vide “Interview to Rand Daily Mail”, 28 6 1907
('7', 50, 0, 1, 109238) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 51
('7', 50, 1, 2, 109282) with (for them) rare self sacrifice and courage, endeavouring to show their ignorant or weakly brethren the path of duty.
('7', 50, 1, 3, 109404) At the same time, there is just as much difference today between Western pickets and Eastern, or, rather, Indian, as there is, apparently, between West and East.
('7', 50, 1, 4, 109566) We have no desire to terrorise.
('7', 50, 1, 5, 109598) We do not wish to compel obedience to the wish of the majority, but, like the indomitable Salvation Army lasses, we do, in our humble manner, wish with all the persuasive power of which we may be capable to inform those who do not know of what is held to be the right view of the Asiatic Registration 1 Act.
('7', 50, 1, 6, 109906) It is, then, left open to such men either to accept the advice that may be given by us, or to accept the degrading Act and to sell themselves for a miserable existence in this country.
('7', 50, 1, 7, 110091) As I have said before, if the Colonists knew what the Act means, they would themselves call such Indians as obeyed it curs fit only to be kicked and despised.
('7', 50, 1, 8, 110250) You quote, I take it for the benefit of the Indian community, Mr. Henry’s remarks on the use of finger prints in India.
('7', 50, 1, 9, 110370) Their use, however, has never been denied.
('7', 50, 1, 10, 110413) It is the abuse of the system against which I have ventured, in common with my fellow countrymen, to protest.
('7', 50, 1, 11, 110523) You hope that wiser counsels will prevail among my country men, and that they will submit to the Act.
('7', 50, 1, 12, 110625) I, on the other hand, hope that, if my countrymen rise to the occasion and are prepared to sacrifice everything rather than their honour and self respect, you will change your views and respect them as men of their word.
('7', 50, 1, 13, 110846) Let me remind you that Indians have sworn before God that they will not submit to the law.
('7', 50, 1, 14, 110937) Perjury before a Court of Law can be expiated by suffering punishment that may be awarded by a judge.
('7', 50, 1, 15, 111039) What expiation is possible before the Judge of Judges, who never errs?
('7', 50, 1, 16, 111110) If we perjured ourselves before Him, we would then indeed be unfit associates for any civilised body of men, and the ghettos of old will be our proper and deserved lot.

('7', 51, 1, 2, 111405) 38. LETTER TO “THE STAR”
('7', 51, 2, 3, 111430) P. O. BOX 57, PRETORIA, July 7, 1907
('7', 51, 3, 4, 111467) TO THE EDITOR THE STAR [JOHANNSBURG]
('7', 51, 4, 5, 111504) SIR, Your Pretoria correspondent has given the Indian community deserved credit by saying that “no serious troubles are anticipated” with reference to the struggle of British Indians in this Colony not to submit to the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 51, 4, 6, 111749) The Attorney General, too, paid us a compliment by saying that he did not expect the law abiding Indians to resist the enforcement of the law.
('7', 51, 4, 7, 111892) The only difference is that the lawabiding instinct, while it makes rioting and physical resistance impossible, does not involve acceptance of any measure, however distasteful.
('7', 51, 4, 8, 112069) That instinct tells us that, if we cannot bear the yoke imposed by the law, we must suffer the consequences of its breach with quiet dignity and resignation.
('7', 51, 4, 9, 112227) Your correspondent threatens that, if my countrymen do not change their attitude, the penal clauses will be rigorously enforced and they will be deported.
('7', 51, 4, 10, 112382) This threat was unnecessary, for we have cou nted the consequence of non submission.
('7', 51, 4, 11, 112467) Gaol has no terrors for us compared to the enforced slavery of the Registration Act, which puts on the whole community a brand of criminality.
('7', 51, 4, 12, 112610) Deportation will be a welcome relief from the contemplation of a dog’s life in what we have been taught to consider our own home.
('7', 51, 4, 13, 112740) If the Act bears as heavily on us as we represent it to do, no sacrifice will be too great for us.
('7', 51, 4, 14, 112839) We are having a unique experience of Imperialism and the cos mopolitan nature of the Empire.
('7', 51, 4, 15, 112932) The Imperial arm is presumed to cover the weak from the strong.
('7', 51, 4, 16, 112996) Indians of the Transvaal are now waiting to see whether that arm is to protect the weak Indians from the strong whites—British and otherwise—or whether it is to be used to strengthen the hands of the tyrant to crush the weak and helpless.
('7', 51, 4, 17, 113235) Pardon the use of the word, but is it not tyrannical to disregard every sentiment and our religions, for this is no question of regulating immigration?
('7', 51, 4, 18, 113387) The principle of registration we have accepted; the manner of it we bitterly resent.
('7', 51, 4, 19, 113472) But the Government wish to impose
('7', 52, 0, 1, 113506) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 53
('7', 52, 1, 2, 113550) studied humiliation.
('7', 52, 1, 3, 113571) Are Indians to blame if, rather than suffer it, they are prepared to lose their earthly possessions?
('7', 52, 1, 4, 113672) If the whole of the white Transvaal be against us, God is with us.
('7', 52, 2, 5, 113739) I am, etc., HAJEE HABIB SECRETARY, BRITISH INDIAN COMMITTEE, PRETORIA The Star, 9 7 1907
('7', 52, 3, 6, 113828) 39. JOHANNESBURG LETTER Monday, [July 8, 1907]
('7', 52, 4, 7, 113875) WELL DONE, PRETORIA !
('7', 52, 5, 8, 113897) Pretoria has done exceedingly well.
('7', 52, 5, 9, 113933) Especially those from whom courage was hardly expected have borne tremendous suffering and neglected their own business in order to be ready for public service.
('7', 52, 5, 10, 114094) Indians are thinking of nothing but how their honour may be defended.
('7', 52, 6, 11, 114164) ALL PRAISE TO VOLUNTEERS
('7', 52, 7, 12, 114189) The volunteers, pickets or watchmen, or patriotic workers [what ever name we may use] have earned glory for themselves.
('7', 52, 7, 13, 114309) Their names will go down for all time in the history of the Transvaal Indians.
('7', 52, 7, 14, 114388) They devote all their time to keeping a watch.
('7', 52, 7, 15, 114435) Their names are as under: Messrs A. M. Cachalia, Gavarishankar Pranshankar Vyas, Gulam Mahomed Abdul Rashid, Cassim Sidoo, Khushal Chhita, Memon Ebrahim Noor, Govind Prag, Hossen Biba, Mahomed Valli, Ardeshir Framji, Chaool Beg, Gulab Rudra Desai, Moosa Suliman and Ebrahim Noor.
('7', 52, 7, 16, 114715) These patriots go round the Permit Office by turns throughout the day, and if they find any Indian going there, they persuade him courteously and stop him.
('7', 52, 7, 17, 114871) At present they have given up their private business and plunged into the service of the motherland.
('7', 52, 7, 18, 114972) They do not care for the dangers they may have to face.
('7', 52, 7, 19, 115028) They are quite prepared to suffer what ever consequences may follow.
('7', 52, 7, 20, 115097) It would not at all be surprising if such patriotism should lead to ultimate success.
('7', 52, 8, 21, 115183) LESSON FROM THEIR COURAGE
('7', 52, 9, 22, 115209) The work of these volunteers must be emulated everywhere in the Transvaal.
('7', 52, 9, 23, 115284) Officials will shortly be appointed everywhere to receive applications for new registers.

('7', 54, 5, 17, 118946) Many whites have been offering advice to Indians.
('7', 54, 5, 18, 118996) When the former ask ‘What will you do?’, many Indians say in reply, ‘We shall do what our leaders do.’ Some answer, ‘We shall do what others do.’ These are words of cowards, and they will do harm.
('7', 54, 5, 19, 119193) Everyone should give the reply: ‘I dislike the law and so I will never submit to it.
('7', 54, 5, 20, 119278) Moreover, I will not submit to it also because I have taken an oath in the name of God.
('7', 54, 5, 21, 119366) I would rather go to gaol than submit to the law which would make a slave of me.’ He who cannot give this answer will never reach the other shore.
('7', 54, 5, 22, 119513) None can swim with another’s buoy.
('7', 54, 5, 23, 119548) We are to swim with our own strength.
('7', 54, 5, 24, 119586) Will the reader swallow dust because I choose to do so?
('7', 54, 5, 25, 119642) Will he fall into a pit because I do so?
('7', 54, 5, 26, 119683) Will he forsake his religion because I do so?
('7', 54, 5, 27, 119729) I may stand my mother’s humiliation, turn my sons into thieves, and have the fingers of myself and of my sons cut off; will the reader do likewise?
('7', 54, 5, 28, 119877) Everyone will answer ‘Never!’ In a similar spirit, everyone should answer, ‘I don’t care what others do, but I for my part will not submit to the law.’ All do not give such straightforward answers, and that is why the newspapers make this comment that, though we seem to be enthusiastic now, we shall in the end unhitch our waggons.
('7', 54, 5, 29, 120210) Everyone has to think over all this.
