('7', 55, 6, 13, 121150) 40. PETITION TO TRANSVAAL LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY
('7', 55, 7, 14, 121197) JOHANNESBURG, July 9, 1907
('7', 55, 8, 15, 121224) TO THE HON’BLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF THE TRANSVAAL
('7', 55, 9, 16, 121308) THE PETITION OF THE ACTING CHAIRMAN OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION OF THE TRANSVAAL
('7', 55, 10, 17, 121395) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT: 1. Your Petitioner has been desired by the Committee of the British Indian Association to approach this Hon’ble House in connection with the Immigration Restriction Bill now under consideration.
('7', 55, 10, 18, 121611) 2. While the said Association ventures to approve of the principle of the measure, in its humble opinion, from an Indian standpoint, some of its features are open to serious objection, namely: (a) The Bill in question does not recognize Indian languages, which have a vast literature.
('7', 55, 10, 19, 121896) (b) It does not recognize the claim of those who have been formerly domiciled in the Transvaal.
('7', 55, 10, 20, 121992) (Many British Indians
('7', 56, 0, 1, 122014) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 57
('7', 56, 1, 2, 122058) who paid £3, under Law 3 of 1885 as amended in 1886, before 1899, for settling in the country, but who are now out of the Colony and who have not received permits under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, are by the Bill in question prohibited from re entering the country, unless they possess the educational qualifications contemplated by the Bill.) (c) Clause 4 of Section 2, as it has been interpreted to the said Association, makes it practically impossible even for British Indians with high educational attainments to enter the Transvaal, unless they comply with the terms of the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 56, 1, 3, 122669) (In the humble opinion of the Association, those who pass the education test imposed by the Bill need hardly furnish further identification for purposes of immigration.) (d) As interpreted to the Association, the said Clause 4 ranks British Indians with people affected by the Immorality Ordinance, and is therefore considered by the British Indian community to be highly offensive.
('7', 56, 2, 4, 123052) (e) The Bill in question, contrary to expectation, perpetuates the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 56, 2, 5, 123145) 3. The said Association humbly ventures to draw the attention of this Hon’ble House to the fact that British Indians are not represented therein, and that, therefore, they may respectfully claim additional consideration from this Hon’ble House.
('7', 56, 2, 6, 123390) 4. In conclusion, the said Association trusts that the petition will receive due consideration, and that such relief will be granted as may be possible in the circumstances.
('7', 56, 2, 7, 123564) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioner, as in duty bound, shall for ever, etc.
('7', 56, 2, 8, 123659) MOOSA ISMAIL MIA ACTING CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('7', 56, 3, 9, 123720) Colonial Office Records: C. O. 291/122
('7', 56, 4, 10, 123759) 1 In the petition actually presented, this paragraph was deleted by William Hosken, a member of the Transvaal Legislative Assembly, through whom it was submitted.
('7', 56, 4, 11, 123922) Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 15 7 1907
('7', 57, 0, 1, 123960) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 57, 1, 2, 124001) 41. NEW TRANSVAAL IMMIGRATION BILL [Before July 11, 1907] This Bill has not yet become an Act.
('7', 57, 1, 3, 124096) But it can be seen from the Bill what the Government’s intentions are; we therefore give below a summary of it: (1) The Permit Act [the Peace Preservation Ordinance, 1903] is repealed, provided that such repeal shall not affect or abridge any of the powers conferred under the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 57, 1, 4, 124399) (2) After the taking effect of the Bill, the following classes of persons will be treated as prohibited immigrants: (a) Any person without a good knowledge of a European language.
('7', 57, 1, 5, 124579) (b) Any person who has not in his possession or at his disposal means to support himself.
('7', 57, 1, 6, 124669) (c) Any prostitute or person procuring women for immoral purposes.
('7', 57, 1, 7, 124736) (d) Any person who under any law in force at the date of his entering or attempting to enter the Transvaal will be liable, if found therein, to be removed therefrom for failure to comply with its provisions.
('7', 57, 1, 8, 124944) (e) Lunatics or lepers or those suffering from such contagious diseases.
('7', 57, 1, 9, 125017) (f) Any person about whom a report may have been received from the Imperial Government or from any other official source that he is undesirable.
('7', 57, 1, 10, 125162) (g) Any person who in the opinion of the Government is dangerous to the peace, order and good government of the Colony.
('7', 57, 1, 11, 125282) (h) This Bill will not apply to the wife or minor child of any person who is not a prohibited immigrant, and it will also not apply to Kaffirs and to European workers (3) For administering this law, an Immigration Department will be set up.
('7', 57, 1, 12, 125523) (4) For enforcing this law, the Governor will have the authority to enter into agreement with the Government of any Colony.
('7', 57, 1, 13, 125647) (5) Every prohibited immigrant entering or found within this Colony shall be liable to a fine not exceeding £100 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months, and to be removed at any time from the Colony.
('7', 58, 0, 1, 125862) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 59
('7', 58, 1, 2, 125906) (6) Any person who violates the Immorality Ordinance [1903] or who may be deemed to be dangerous to the peace, order and good government of the Colony may be arrested and removed from the Colony.
('7', 58, 1, 3, 126102) (7) Anyone who aids or abets a prohibited immigrant in entering the Colony will be liable to a fine not exceeding £100 or to imprisonment not exceeding six months.
('7', 58, 1, 4, 126266) (8) No prohibited immigrant will be entitled to obtain a licence or to acquire any interest in land in the Colony.
('7', 58, 1, 5, 126381) (9) Every person suspected to be a prohibited immigrant may be arrested without a warrant.
('7', 58, 1, 6, 126472) (10) Ignorance of this Act will be no defence.
('7', 58, 1, 7, 126519) (11) Any person ordered to be removed from this Colony shall be liable to pay all expenditure incurred by the Government in carrying out such removal, which may be recovered from the property of the person concerned.
('7', 58, 1, 8, 126736) (12) The name, permanent residence, place of birth, etc., of eve ry person putting up at a hotel shall be recorded by the hotel keeper, and the Government will have the authority to inspect the same.
('7', 58, 1, 9, 126936) (13) The burden of proving that he is not a prohibited immigrant shall lie upon the accused.
('7', 58, 1, 10, 127029) (14) Every magistrate shall have jurisdiction to impose the maximum penalties for all contraventions of this Act.
('7', 58, 2, 11, 127143) IMPLICATIONS OF BILL
('7', 58, 3, 12, 127164) This is a frightful Bill.
('7', 58, 3, 13, 127190) The Imperial Government is likely to be deceived by it.
('7', 58, 3, 14, 127246) Superficially viewed, the Bill is harmless, but on closer scrutiny it is found to be poisonous.
('7', 58, 3, 15, 127342) The Bill entirely abolishes the rights of refugees without permits.
('7', 58, 3, 16, 127410) Those who hold permits but go out of the Transvaal, without getting the permits exchanged under the new Act, lose their right to return.
('7', 58, 3, 17, 127547) The educated Indian is granted a right with one hand and dep rived of it with the other.
('7', 58, 3, 18, 127636) For, those entering on the strength of their knowledge of a European language will have, under this obnoxious Bill, to give their finger prints within eight days of immigration and to take out a permit, failing which they will be deported.
('7', 58, 3, 19, 127876) Thus, the Indian is not likely to be benefited at all by this Bill.
('7', 58, 3, 20, 127944) The Bill will have to be sent to Lord Elgin for approval.
('7', 58, 3, 21, 128002) In that case, the Indian community will have to put up a fight in England.
('7', 58, 3, 22, 128077) More information about the Bill will be available between the writing
('7', 59, 0, 1, 128147) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 59, 1, 2, 128188) of this and the date of its publication, i.e., on Thursday, the 11th instant.
('7', 59, 1, 3, 128266) We shall be able to publish it in the next issue.

('7', 59, 4, 22, 129606) I am perfectly certain that whenever we think of having things done cheaply outside the country of our adoption, we bring into play the ordinary weakness, namely, to drive the hardest bargain possible, and it is for that reason that I have condemned in my mind the idea of having the South African book 4 printed in Bombay, and I feel this so

('7', 60, 9, 20, 131894) 44. MEASURE OF INDIAN STRENGTH
('7', 60, 10, 21, 131925) Till now the strength of the Indian community has not been tested.
('7', 60, 10, 22, 131992) It has remained a secret hidden in a closed fist, as it were, and no one has taken its measure.
('7', 60, 10, 23, 132088) The prevailing idea is that Indians are cowardly and lacking in spirit.
('7', 60, 10, 24, 132160) But, by good fortune, the community’s strength is now being tested in the Transvaal.
('7', 60, 10, 25, 132245) This opportunity is given to us by Lord Elgin
('7', 60, 11, 26, 132291) 1 A German theosophist who was attached to Gandhiji and was for some time in charge of the school at Phoenix; he died at Sevagram in 1960.
('7', 61, 0, 1, 132430) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 61, 1, 2, 132471) tested in the Transvaal.
('7', 61, 1, 3, 132496) This opportunity is given to us by Lord Elgin and General Botha and their friends.
('7', 61, 1, 4, 132579) In this trial of strength the community has proved its superiority, up to the time of writing this, at any rate.
('7', 61, 1, 5, 132692) The news letters published by us show that Pretoria, which hitherto the whites had thought to be weak, has all of a sudden shown itself to be quite strong, not a single Indian there taking out the obnoxious permit.
('7', 61, 1, 6, 132907) A Madrasi went to the Permit Office, but when he found that finger prints were required, he threw away his application and said that he would not give his finger prints on any account.
('7', 61, 1, 7, 133092) The Madrasi Postmaster preferred to resign his post rather than take out the new permit.
('7', 61, 1, 8, 133181) We hear that Mr. Chamney’s Punjabi attendant flatly refused to take out the new permit.
('7', 61, 1, 9, 133269) All this shows that the Indian people would not be found wanting when weighed in the balance.
('7', 61, 1, 10, 133363) Who can harm one whom God protects?
('7', 61, 1, 11, 133399) The Indian people are religious minded.
('7', 61, 1, 12, 133439) They believe in God.
('7', 61, 1, 13, 133460) He will easily bring success in any work we undertake with full faith in Him.
('7', 61, 1, 14, 133538) It is said that, because of his faith in God, Narasinha Mehta 1 could fulfil his social obligation on the occasion of the first pregnancy of his daughter, though he had no money of his own.
('7', 61, 1, 15, 133728) 2 With God’s help, Prophet Mahomed came through greathardships and subdued his opponents.
('7', 61, 1, 16, 133818) The same Creator will help the Indian community.
('7', 61, 1, 17, 133867) The eyes of Indians everywhere are at present fixed on their countrymen in the Transvaal.
('7', 61, 1, 18, 133957) They are all eager to know whether the community will succeed in the challenge that they have taken up.
('7', 61, 1, 19, 134061) Pretoria’s answer is that the Indian community shall never turn back.

('7', 61, 2, 21, 134173) 45. DUTY OF DURBAN
('7', 61, 3, 22, 134192) Is there any Indian who will not be thrilled with joy at Pretoria’s performance and at the courage of Indian pickets there?
('7', 61, 3, 23, 134316) It is easy to offer congratulations.
('7', 61, 3, 24, 134353) But true congratulation consists in doing likewise.
('7', 61, 3, 25, 134405) Durban should begin a boycott of the Permit Office like the one that is going on in the Transvaal.
('7', 61, 3, 26, 134504) Even a single Indian now
('7', 61, 4, 27, 134529) 1 Saint poet of Gujarat.
('7', 61, 4, 28, 134554) 2 Presents are given by parents to their daughter at a religious ceremony during the seventh month of her first pregnancy.

('7', 62, 1, 2, 134798) entering the Transvaal from Durban will be like a microbe getting into milk.
('7', 62, 1, 3, 134875) This is a time when the Transvaal Indians ought to sacrifice all their worldly possessions.
('7', 62, 1, 4, 134967) If any Indian is specially keen on going to the Transvaal, it will not be with a view to offering help, but only on personal business.
('7', 62, 1, 5, 135102) Such Indians will demoralize others by going to the Transvaal, rather than add to their strength.
('7', 62, 1, 6, 135200) Moreover, these Indians can enter the Transvaal only by going to the Durban Permit Office.
('7', 62, 1, 7, 135291) That will mean a break down of the boycott.
('7', 62, 1, 8, 135335) But if no Indian at all goes to the Durban Permit Office for a permit, the Office cannot run.
('7', 62, 1, 9, 135429) It is therefore essential that Durban Indians follow the example of Pretoria.
('7', 62, 1, 10, 135507) The Natal Indian Congress has intimated its offer of monetary aid to their brethren in the Transvaal.

('7', 62, 1, 12, 135668) It has also taken up the question of raising contributions.
('7', 62, 1, 13, 135728) This is certainly admirable.
('7', 62, 1, 14, 135757) But in addition, it is necessary to take up the question of boycotting the Durban Permit Office.
('7', 62, 1, 15, 135854) There are three ways of doing it.
('7', 62, 1, 16, 135888) First, pickets should be posted at the Durban Office to prevent Indians from going there.
('7', 62, 1, 17, 135978) Second, a watch should be kept on the Indians proceeding by train to the Transvaal, and if any such Indian is going there with a new permit, or with an old permit without at the same time being ready to go to gaol, he should be dissuaded from going further.
('7', 62, 1, 18, 136236) Third, it should be seen that no Indian gives his finger prints on board a steamer.
('7', 62, 1, 19, 136320) By doing all this, Durban will have given very good help and brought our deliverance nearer.

('7', 63, 5, 10, 137801) 48. JOHANNESBURG LETTER Monday, [July 15, 1907]
('7', 63, 6, 11, 137849) PRETORIA’S HONOUR
('7', 63, 7, 12, 137867) Pretoria is still going strong.
('7', 63, 7, 13, 137899) Its honour has been preserved, and it has come out unscathed through the second week.
('7', 63, 7, 14, 137985) Mr. Cody, the Permit Officer, has had “a holiday” for another week, and the brave watchmen, i.e., the volunteers, have earned glory for themselves.
('7', 63, 7, 15, 138133) Thewhites have been taken aback and wonder what it all means.
('7', 63, 7, 16, 138195) They ask whether Indians, who used to take insults lying down, will now stand up twirling their moustaches.
('7', 63, 7, 17, 138303) Some English ladies inquired of Indian hawkers selling vegetables whether they would take out permits.
('7', 63, 7, 18, 138406) The brave hawkers invariably gave an emphatic “no” in reply.
('7', 63, 7, 19, 138467) If this spirit is maintained to the very end, Indian prestige will go up, and the new law will receive a knock over.
('7', 63, 7, 20, 138584) Everyone will agree that the credit for it should go to Pretoria Indians and the pickets.
('7', 63, 7, 21, 138674) WHITE’S MISCHIEF
('7', 63, 8, 22, 138691) I hear that an agent of Mr. Stephen Frazer has been specially touring the country and telling things to Indians which might frighten
('7', 63, 9, 23, 138824) 1 Vide “Prophet Mahomed and His Caliphs”, 22 6 1907
('7', 63, 10, 24, 138876) 2 Gandhiji spoke at a meeting of the Hamidia Islamic Society held in the Indian Location.
('7', 63, 10, 25, 138966) This is a brief report of his speech.
('7', 64, 0, 1, 139004) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 65
('7', 64, 1, 2, 139048) To the Pietersburg Indians he held out the threat that, if the Indian community followed Mr. Gandhi’s advice and refused to submit to the new law, it would be ruined and the property of the persons concerned confiscated by the Government.
('7', 64, 1, 3, 139287) As the last date approaches, there will doubtless be more such frauds practised on us by hostile or selfish whites.
('7', 64, 1, 4, 139403) I should point out that it is the duty of every Indian to give a smashing reply to such people.
('7', 64, 1, 5, 139499) Indians do not have even time to listen to cowardly advice.
('7', 64, 1, 6, 139559) To say that the Government will confiscate property is an utter lie.
('7', 64, 1, 7, 139628) There is no authority under which it can do so.
('7', 64, 1, 8, 139676) As for being ruined, we know that Mr. Hajee Habib has already written about it to The Star.
('7', 64, 1, 9, 139768) He has made the point that, though we may be ruined, we shall have saved our honour and earned the reputation of being true to our pledge.
('7', 64, 1, 10, 139907) The truth therefore is that we are opposing the law not because of Mr. Gandhi’s advice, but because we mean to defend our manhood.
('7', 64, 1, 11, 140038) If we have that, we shall create wealth out of nothing.
('7', 64, 1, 12, 140094) If on the contrary, we behave like women, though being men, we shall find it difficult to preserve what we have, and shall have no peace of mind to enjoy what we save.
('7', 64, 1, 13, 140262) Richard III, a former king of England, came to the throne after killing his kinsmen.
('7', 64, 1, 14, 140347) But he could not enjoy it in peace.
('7', 64, 1, 15, 140383) He shook with fear whenever he held in his hand the sword stained with the blood of his kinsmen.
('7', 64, 1, 16, 140480) In the end, he died a cruel and unnatural death.
('7', 64, 1, 17, 140529) What Indian is there who will, out of greed, injure the interest of all, unmindful of the humiliation of his brethren?
('7', 64, 1, 18, 140648) If there is any such person, he will but die like King Richard in anguish and remorse.
('7', 64, 1, 19, 140735) I wish that the Indian community will, in this crisis, spurn such advisers with white faces and black hearts.
('7', 64, 1, 20, 140845) TWO OTHER WHITES
('7', 64, 2, 21, 140862) If Mr. Stephen Frazer’s agent talked disgracefully as above, two other whites, who are respectable merchants carrying on a large busi ness with Indians, speak reasonably and admit that, for the sake of its good name, the Indian community ought to stand by its resolve to go to gaol and that, if all remain firm in it, they will undoubtedly succeed.
('7', 64, 2, 22, 141211) Some might say that this “if” is a big thing.
('7', 64, 2, 23, 141257) But the “if” is big only for a coward.
('7', 64, 2, 24, 141296) The courageous will take others to be courageous too and they will only believe that the Indian community will fully keep its pledge on this occasion.
('7', 64, 3, 25, 141447) JOHANNESBURG MEETING

('7', 64, 4, 27, 141554) The meeting was to begin at 2.30 p.m., but the hall was fully packed before that hour.
('7', 64, 4, 28, 141641) Those who could not get in stood outside.
('7', 64, 4, 29, 141683) Many had come from Germiston also.
('7', 64, 4, 30, 141718) Haffejee Abdul
('7', 65, 0, 1, 141733) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('7', 65, 1, 4, 141897) Then Mr. Ram Sundar Pundit from Germiston made an eloquent and impassioned speech.
('7', 65, 1, 5, 141980) He said that at Germiston the people were in high spirits.

('7', 65, 1, 11, 142425) If the women of England were strong enough to go to gaol, would the men among the Indian people be scared by having to go to gaol or by having to suffer other losses?
('7', 65, 1, 12, 142592) Mr. Abdur Rehman said that the Indian community at Potchefstroom was very firm.

('7', 65, 1, 14, 142812) To that Mr. Rehman had given the answer that the slavery of the law was unacceptable to Indians, even if a thousand Stephen Frazers should stop giving them goods on credit.
('7', 65, 1, 15, 142985) He added that the Potchefstroom traders would put up with any amount of loss, but would not submit to the obnoxious law.

('7', 65, 1, 17, 143194) Swerve not from the path of truth.” Thereafter, Messrs Shahboodeen and Cama put some questions.

('7', 65, 2, 21, 143516) MEETING OF WAITERS
('7', 65, 3, 22, 143535) At the Ebenezer School, Mr. David Ernest had convened a meeting of the members of the Transvaal Football Association.
('7', 65, 3, 23, 143653) About 50 waiters attended it.
('7', 65, 3, 24, 143683) The meeting took place on Monday at 3.30 p.m.
('7', 65, 3, 25, 143729) Mr. Gandhi explained the position about the law.
('7', 65, 3, 26, 143778) Mr. Naidoo interpreted in Tamil.
('7', 65, 3, 27, 143811) Finally Mr. Polak spoke.
('7', 65, 3, 28, 143836) He told a story.
('7', 65, 3, 29, 143853) Once upon a time there was an animal.
('7', 65, 3, 30, 143891) It had this peculiar characteristic, that if its head was cut off, two would growl in its place.
('7', 65, 3, 31, 143988) Thus, whenever its head was cut off, it would be left with double the number of heads.
('7', 65, 3, 32, 144075) When people came to know of this, they stopped troubling the animal.
('7', 65, 3, 33, 144144) The Indian community had to behave in a similar manner.
('7', 65, 3, 34, 144200) There should be no waiting for anybody’s leadership.
('7', 65, 3, 35, 144253) It should be assumed that everyone was a leader.
('7', 65, 3, 36, 144302) In the place of one Indian gaoled or deported, two should come out to take up leadership and brave the
('7', 66, 0, 1, 144405) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 67
('7', 66, 1, 2, 144449) sentence of gaol or deportation.
('7', 66, 1, 3, 144482) If this happened, the Government could not but be defeated.
('7', 66, 1, 4, 144542) The waiters should realize that they were men first and servants next, and accordingly they must oppose the law firmly without being afraid of losing their employment.
('7', 66, 1, 5, 144710) Mr. David, who is a Government interpreter, said that he had given a flat refusal when the Government asked him to get himself registered, Then, on Mr. Gandhi putting it to the meeting, everyone stood up and replied that he would not seek registration, even if that meant losing his job.
('7', 66, 1, 6, 144998) The meeting terminated at 4.45 p.m.
('7', 66, 2, 7, 145034) GERMISTON MEETING
('7', 66, 3, 8, 145052) The Indians at Germiston are in high spirits.
('7', 66, 3, 9, 145098) Pundit Ram Sundar Maharaj has placed himself at their head, working fearlessly, and exhorting the people.
('7', 66, 3, 10, 145204) They held a special meeting and resolved that, no matter what risks awaited them, they would not submit to the law.
('7', 66, 3, 11, 145320) More than 200 men signed the resolution, and some brave men came forward to serve as volunteers, as had happened at Pretoria.
('7', 66, 4, 12, 145446) IMMIGRATION BILL
('7', 66, 5, 13, 145463) The second reading of the Immigration Bill is over.
('7', 66, 5, 14, 145515) Mr. Smuts clarified the aims of the Bill.
('7', 66, 5, 15, 145557) Messrs Hosken, Lindsay, Wybergh 1, Neser and Whiteside participated in the discussion.
('7', 66, 5, 16, 145644) Mr. Hosken, speaking on the Indian side, said that the new Bill would be appropriate only in Russia.
('7', 66, 5, 17, 145745) The Bill contained some provisions which ought to have no place under British rule.
('7', 66, 6, 18, 145829) ASSOCIATION’S PETITION
('7', 66, 7, 19, 145852) The Association has submitted a petition 2 against this Bill.
('7', 66, 7, 20, 145914) This has already been printed in our English section.
('7', 66, 7, 21, 145968) Below is a summary of it: Though this Association is not opposed to the principle of restricting immigration, it respectfully submits the following objec tions: (a) The Bill does not recognize any Indian language.
('7', 66, 7, 22, 146182) (b) It does not protect the rights of those who have been residents of the Transvaal for a long time.
('7', 66, 7, 23, 146284) For instance, many Indians had paid £3 to the Boer Government for the right of settling in the Transvaal.
('7', 66, 7, 24, 146390) Some of them have not received permits.
('7', 66, 7, 25, 146430) The rights of such persons would be annulled in case they did not know one of the European languages.

('7', 67, 4, 17, 148180) DISMISSED UNCEREMONIOUSLY
('7', 67, 5, 18, 148206) A few Indian friends at Pretoria thought that, if they placed some demands before the Colonial Government and if the demands were granted, they would be saved from the trouble of going to gaol.

('7', 70, 4, 5, 153290) 50. A GROSS LIBEL
('7', 70, 5, 6, 153308) Further correspondence on the Asiatic Act of the Transvaal, placed on the Table at the instance of Lord Ampthill, has now come to hand.
('7', 70, 5, 7, 153444) Lord Selborne, in pressing the measure on the attention of Lord Elgin, allowed himself to make the following remarks:
('7', 70, 6, 8, 153562) I hope that it may be possible for you to inform me at an early date that His Majesty will not be advised to exercise his power of disallowance in respect of this Act, so that it may be possible to bring it into force at once, and so to check the illicit unauthorized influx of Asiatics into the Transvaal which is at present proceeding at an alarming rate.
('7', 70, 6, 9, 153920) The italics are Ours.
('7', 70, 6, 10, 153942) We have no hesitation in saying that the emphatic pronoun cement made by Lord Selborne as to the illicit influx is a libel, pure and simple.
('7', 70, 6, 11, 154083) Here there is no qualification.
('7', 70, 6, 12, 154115) His Lordship has accepted the statements placed before him as to the unauthorized influx of Asiatics without any reservation whatsoever, and yet these statements could only have been one sided.
('7', 70, 6, 13, 154309) Indians have denied any such influx and they have challenged investigation.
('7', 70, 6, 14, 154385) 1 None has been made; still, Lord Selborne has seen fit, in spite of the tremendous responsibility resting on his shoulders, to give the imprimatur of his authority to an unproved charge.
('7', 70, 6, 15, 154573) This charge is inherently untrue.
('7', 70, 6, 16, 154607) If such an influx has been proceeding demonstrably, why have the entrants been allowed to remain in the Colony?
('7', 70, 6, 17, 154719) Either His Lordship’s informants knew of the men who had so entered, or they did not.
('7', 70, 6, 18, 154805) If they knew, the Peace Preservation Ordinance supplied all the machinery necessary to bring
('7', 70, 7, 19, 154898) 1 Vide “Cable to “India”, 28 8 1906 & “The Mass Meeting”, 11 9 1906 “Interview to “the Tribune”, 20 10 1906, “Interview to “the Morning Leader”, 20 10 1906 & “Letter to the Timess”, 22 10 1906 “Presentation to Lord Elgin”, 31 10 1906.

('7', 71, 1, 2, 155174) them to justice.
('7', 71, 1, 3, 155191) Lord Selborne’s libel, therefore, shows how difficult, if not impossible, it is for Asiatics to get even a fair hearing in South Africa, except in courts of justice.
('7', 71, 1, 4, 155357) In a matter such as this the courts are not open to them, so they have to sit still, and grin and bear their troubles as best they may.
('7', 71, 1, 5, 155493) When we come to examine Lord Elgin’s reply, it is sufficient to fill British Indians with dismay.
('7', 71, 1, 6, 155591) The Secretary of State for the Colonies has sanctioned the measure, not because he believes it to be just, but because there is behind it the weight of white authority.
('7', 71, 1, 7, 155760) So it comes to this, that any Act of a Colonial Parliament, if it is unanimous, will bind the Imperial Government, irrespective of the merits of that Act, and if this proposition be unimpeachable, Lord Elgin’s statement, that “His Majesty’s Government adhere to the opinion as to the desirability of recasting the restrictions to which Asiatics are at present subject”, is a pious wish by which British Indians cannot set much store.

('7', 71, 3, 13, 156752) The debate that took place on the second reading of the Immigration Restriction Bill in the Transvaal Assembly is in many respects an eye opener.
('7', 71, 3, 14, 156898) Mr. Smuts introduced the Bill to the House in a most summary manner.
('7', 71, 3, 15, 156967) Points that affect British Indians were hardly touched by the Honourable Gentleman.
('7', 71, 3, 16, 157051) He did not even consider them sufficiently interesting for the members of the public.
('7', 71, 3, 17, 157137) He took it as a settled fact that the Asiatic Registration Act should be a permanent feature of the Transvaal laws, and that, contrary to what Mr. Duncan said 1 at the time of introducing that measure, the Immigration Bill is not to supersede it but to supplement it in its harshness, so far as the Asiatic communities are concerned.
('7', 71, 3, 18, 157471) He did not trouble to inform the Members that Law 3 of 1885, which guaranteed
('7', 71, 4, 19, 157549) 1 Vide “Letter to The Times”, 12 11 1906 Patrick Duncan was Colonial Secretary from 1903 to 1906.

('7', 72, 1, 3, 158054) In reply to Mr. Neser’s gentle suggestion that the clause in the Bill giving extraordinary powers to the Government to eject, at his own expense, any person from the Colony, without a trial, was rather a dangerous thing, Mr. Wybergh showed the greatest resentment.
('7', 72, 1, 4, 158319) The latter’sremarks, however, we can only characterize as foolishness due to self forgetfulness.
('7', 72, 1, 5, 158416) In any other person, it would be grossest impertinence.
('7', 72, 1, 6, 158472) In discussing the clause and in asking the Government to hold on to it, he cited recent events in India.
('7', 72, 1, 7, 158577) We do not wish to enter into the merits of the controversy, but we do expect a responsible politician like Mr. Wybergh not to speak from his seat in the Legislative Assembly to the South African public in a most irresponsible manner.
('7', 72, 1, 8, 158811) Unless he has made Indian questions a special study, it is evident that he can only know what the cabled summaries of events have let the world know, and unless he believes in the inherent infallibility of all governments, he had no right to consider that the action of the authorities in deporting Indian leaders was either in itself good or that it had produced a sobering effect.
('7', 72, 1, 9, 159194) We may, perhaps, claim to know a little more than the Honourable Member, and yet, not being in close touch with what is happening in that part of the British Empire, we have deemed it wise not to comment.
('7', 72, 1, 10, 159399) To add to the folly, Mr. Wybergh went on to deduce from the events in India that the powers given by the clause might be useful for sending out Indian inciters to passive resistance in the Transvaal.
('7', 72, 1, 11, 159599) Herein he betrayed a lack of all perspective.
('7', 72, 1, 12, 159645) Happenings in India have received the colour of an insurrection, and they have been interpreted to mean a revolt against the British Raj.
('7', 72, 1, 13, 159783) The crusade of the Indians in the Transvaal has not the slightest resemblance to an insurrectionary movement.
('7', 72, 1, 14, 159893) It simply means an offer on the part of the community to suffer much physical hardship rather than allow its moral sense to be atrophied.
('7', 72, 1, 15, 160031) It is, on the part of Indians in the Transvaal, an endeavour to follow the precept of the Prophet of Nazareth, “Resist not Evil”.
('7', 72, 1, 16, 160161) Of course, it matters not in the slightest degree that Mr. Wybergh should incite the House against British Indians.
('7', 72, 1, 17, 160277) They are not likely to be turned away from their duty by any threats.
('7', 72, 1, 18, 160347) They have anticipated the worst.
('7', 72, 1, 19, 160380) Theirs is courage born of purity of motive and resolution not to tarnish their honour.
('7', 72, 1, 20, 160467) We deal with Mr. Wybergh’s remarks only because we believe him to be a sincere, though misguided, man, and to
('7', 73, 0, 1, 160577) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 73, 1, 2, 160618) illustrate how an atmosphere of prejudice can taint even a wellbalanced mind.
('7', 73, 1, 3, 160696) Of all the members of the Assembly, Mr. Hosken was the only one who strongly disapproved of the vindictive spirit that underlay Mr. Wybergh’s speech.
('7', 73, 1, 4, 160846) Mr. Hosken had no hesitation in saying that the Bill was possible only in Russian or German territories, not on British soil.

('7', 73, 2, 8, 161215) 52. IDENTURED IMMIGRATION
('7', 73, 3, 9, 161241) We are enabled this week to publish an important communi cation addressed by the Secretary of the Indian Immigration Trust Board to the employers of indentured Indians, giving information as to the cost of the introduction of such labour into Natal.
('7', 73, 3, 10, 161491) The document is well worth the perusal of Messrs Evans and Robinson 1, who, after mature consideration, have come to the conclusion that indentured immigration into Natal should cease.
('7', 73, 3, 11, 161676) Knowing, as we do, Mr. Haggar, we cannot mention him in the same category.
('7', 73, 3, 12, 161751) Although we happen to agree with him in the attempt to end indentured Indian immigration, our motives are not the same, and the Indian community can have very little to do with a member who does not hesitate to libel it, and, when challenged to prove his statements, has not the manliness either to do so or to apologize.
('7', 73, 3, 13, 162073) Mr. Rycroft’s letter is, from the European standpoint, almost a complete justification for stopping the labour.
('7', 73, 3, 14, 162185) It is evident that the employers are scarcely able to cope with the expenses of introduction.
('7', 73, 3, 15, 162279) Compulsory repatriation would for them be much worse, even if the Indian Government, surrendering its guardianship, were to agree to any such condition.
('7', 73, 3, 16, 162432) It appears that, in 1905, whereas the employers contributed only £20 towards the cost of introduction, the actual cost was £31.10.9 per male adult, and, as more and more Indians avail themselves of the free passage back to India, owing to the burden of the £3 tax, the cost will be on the increase.
('7', 73, 3, 17, 162731) It would thus appear that the sooner, from a purely economic standpoint, indentured labour is stopped, the better it will be for all parties.

('7', 74, 1, 2, 162957) 53. GENERAL SMUTS OBDURATE
('7', 74, 2, 3, 162984) Indians in Pretoria gave another opportunity to the Government to withdraw from the false position in which it has placed itself by reason of the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 74, 2, 4, 163156) The correspondence is lengthy and, unfortunately, we are unable to find space for it in this issue.
('7', 74, 2, 5, 163256) The attorneys for the Indians in question made very reasonable suggestions as to the most obnoxious clauses of the Registration Act.
('7', 74, 2, 6, 163389) The Colonial Secretary has returned a categorical refusal to almost every one of the requests.
('7', 74, 2, 7, 163484) We frankly confess that the Government could not have done otherwise.
('7', 74, 2, 8, 163554) In our opinion, it had a right to interpret the letter to mean that Indians were not strong enough to carry out the jail resolution.
('7', 74, 2, 9, 163687) The eminently reasonable letter, therefore, has been evidently misread by the Government.
('7', 74, 2, 10, 163777) It has passed regulations in keeping with the Act itself and its reply to the Indian petitioners of Pretoria simply follows out that policy.
('7', 74, 2, 11, 163918) The correspondence will have done some good in that it will have streng thened the Indian community in its resolve to undergo the sufferings consequent upon non submission to compulsory registration.

('7', 74, 4, 16, 164466) The Committee carries on its work and that is as it should be.
('7', 74, 4, 17, 164529) The Indian community is not bound to accept every piece of advice the Committee offers.
('7', 74, 4, 18, 164617) The members of the Committee are large hearted men, and they are going on with their work.
('7', 74, 4, 19, 164708) Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree is such a cautious and far sighted gentleman that, with him as President, the Committee is not likely to give up the Indian cause.
('7', 74, 4, 20, 164865) Moreover, Mr. Ritch, as his letter to Lord Ampthill shows, does not hesitate to put correctly the Indian standpoint before the Committee.

('7', 76, 2, 5, 167588) 56. NATAL BILL REGARDING LICENCES AND STAMPS
('7', 76, 3, 6, 167633) The Natal Government Gazette of July 12 publishes a Bill introducing certain changes in the matter of revenue licences.
('7', 76, 3, 7, 167753) Below we give its main provisions: (1) The Trading Act of 1897 will henceforth apply to Kaffir eating houses.
('7', 76, 3, 8, 167863) (2) A hawking licence issued for one magisterial district shall not be valid in another district (3) No hawker shall remain at a single farm for more than 12 hours or return to it during the following four days.
('7', 76, 3, 9, 168075) (4) An extra stamp of the value of 10 per cent of the municipal licence fee shall be affixed to the licence.
('7', 76, 3, 10, 168184) The said 10 per cent will be paid by the licensee and go to the Government.
('7', 76, 3, 11, 168260) (5) The agents of a foreign firm will be required to take out a licence.
('7', 76, 3, 12, 168333) An auctioneer selling foreign goods by auction will also have to take out a licence.
('7', 76, 3, 13, 168418) (6) At the time of taking out a trading licence, anyone possessing an agency is bound to disclose the fact to the Licensing Officer.
('7', 76, 3, 14, 168551) (7) Rent receipts will be issued to Natives or to Indians from a special book numbered and with counterfoils bearing embossed stamps.
('7', 76, 3, 15, 168685) It will not do to affix stamps.

('7', 77, 2, 6, 169671) 57. INDENTURED INDIAN LABOURERS
('7', 77, 3, 7, 169703) The Secretary of the Indian Immigration Trust Board, Mr. Rycroft, has addressed a letter to the employers of indentured Indian labourers, which we publish in full in our English section.
('7', 77, 3, 8, 169890) It will be seen from that letter that the employers find the cost of importing indentured Indian labourers too heavy to bear, and if the Indian labourers are to be repatriated on the expiry of the period of contract, the expenditure will be very much heavier still.
('7', 77, 3, 9, 170156) From this Mr. Rycroft concludes that legislation for the compulsory repatriation of labourers will mean heavy losses for employers.
('7', 77, 3, 10, 170288) Because of this the employers of indentured labourers are on the horns of a dilemma.
('7', 77, 3, 11, 170373) If they let the labourers return, their backs will be broken.
('7', 77, 3, 12, 170435) If they keep them, and afterwards there is legislation for their repatriation to India, they will be involved in much too heavy an expenditure.
('7', 77, 3, 13, 170579) It is a problem as to what should be done in this difficult situation.
('7', 77, 3, 14, 170650) The Indian labourers are not likely to gain anything from thiscontroversy.
('7', 77, 3, 15, 170725) Neither those who hold that there should be no further importation of indentured labourers, nor those who hold that it should continue, have any concern for the interests of Indians.
('7', 77, 3, 16, 170908) If Indian labourers accept still lower wages, no one will protest, even if the labourers are to be repatriated on the expiry of the period of contract.
('7', 77, 3, 17, 171060) Both sides will be happy.
('7', 77, 3, 18, 171086) There is only one thing which can be of benefit to the Indian community, that is, the recruitment of indentured labourers should cease altogether.
('7', 77, 3, 19, 171233) If any labourers come, they can gain nothing in conditions of slavery and circumstances will not permit them to live as free men.
('7', 77, 3, 20, 171363) We are happy to observe that the whole Indian community takes offence at the hardships inflicted on the indentured labourers.
('7', 77, 3, 21, 171489) This is a sign of our awakening.
('7', 77, 3, 22, 171522) If we take a step forward and can have their importation ended, the enslavement of Indians will cease and those Indians who are already in South Africa will have some relief.

('7', 83, 2, 15, 183053) 63. “STAGGERING HUMANITY”
('7', 83, 3, 16, 183079) The late President Kruger 2 is said to have “staggered humanity” by engaging in an unequal struggle with a mighty empire.
('7', 83, 3, 17, 183201) It is in his late country—though now nominally British—that history is to repeat itself through Indians in the Transvaal.
('7', 83, 3, 18, 183323) But the parallel is not exact.
('7', 83, 3, 19, 183354) The late President fought in a bloody war.
('7', 83, 3, 20, 183397) Indians in the Transvaal will stagger humanity without shedding a drop of blood.
('7', 83, 3, 21, 183478) Indians are about to do more, if we may say so without disrespect, than the late President did.
('7', 83, 3, 22, 183574) For the sake of their honour a mere sentiment, as some say—they are preparing to sacrifice their all.
('7', 83, 3, 23, 183676) Theirs, indeed, will be the widow’s mite.
('7', 83, 3, 24, 183718) Many friends tell them that the local Government are determined to enforce the Asiatic Act at all cost and that they are likely to have their worst fears realised.
('7', 83, 3, 25, 183882) The Indians retort that they are prepared for the eventuality.
('7', 83, 3, 26, 183945) Send them to prison?
('7', 83, 3, 27, 183966) They are ready.
('7', 83, 3, 28, 183982) Deport them forcibly?
('7', 83, 3, 29, 184004) They are ready also.
('7', 83, 3, 30, 184025) Anything, even death, would be better than that they should labour under the ban of criminality and that they should be traitors to their God.
('7', 83, 3, 31, 184168) It may be that they are misguided and that theirs is not intrinsically a right cause.
('7', 83, 3, 32, 184254) If so, they again appeal to the parallel cited
('7', 83, 4, 33, 184301) 1 Vide the preceding item.

('7', 84, 1, 2, 184426) by us and reply that, although many consider that the late President Kruger was ill advised in hurling defiance at the British Government, everybody admires him for the courage of his convictions.
('7', 84, 1, 3, 184623) It is enough that he fought for a cause he considered to be just.

('7', 84, 1, 5, 184816) Indians who migrated to this country in search of an honest livelihood, and who find themselves face to face with civic and social extinction, are fighting under the inspiration of the New Testament.

('7', 84, 3, 13, 186073) 64. MR. PARSEE RUSTOMJEE’S GENEROSITY
('7', 84, 4, 14, 186111) Mr. Rustomjee 2, whose name has become a household word among Indians in South Africa, has written to us a characteristic letter in Gujarati of which we give the following rendering: Although I have often publicly expressed my sentiments regarding the position of our countrymen in the Transvaal, you will, perhaps, allow me to voice them through your columns.
('7', 84, 4, 15, 186472) Every Indian in South Africa will partake of the result of the struggle in which Indians in the Transvaal are engaged.
('7', 84, 4, 16, 186591) We who are outside that country cannot possibly take any share in their
('7', 84, 5, 17, 186663) 1 Invaded India 17 times since his succession to the throne of Ghazni in 997 A.D., but could not consolidate his victories; vide “Petition to Natal Council”, 11 7 1903. 2 Leading Indian merchant of Natal
('7', 85, 0, 1, 186867) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 85, 1, 2, 186908) physical sufferings.
('7', 85, 1, 3, 186929) They will not only undergo the hardships of prison life but many of them will also have to lose all they have.
('7', 85, 1, 4, 187040) If we cannot go to gaol, we can at least follow their noble example in sacrificing our possessions for the common good.
('7', 85, 1, 5, 187160) I, therefore, with all humility and in the name of God, hereby inform my fellow countrymen in the Transvaal, as an earnest of my intense desire to share their sorrows, that henceforth everything I possess in this world is held by me in trust for my countrymen in the Transvaal until the struggle is over.
('7', 85, 1, 6, 187465) I have no doubt that many of my friends in South Africa are prepared as a matter of duty to render similar pecuniary help to the Transvaal Indians.
('7', 85, 1, 7, 187613) Pretoria has, indeed, filled our hearts with hope.
('7', 85, 1, 8, 187664) Let us trust that our countrymen there, as also in other parts of the Transvaal, will carry out their resolution to the end.

('7', 85, 1, 11, 187936) It is a letter which should fill every Indian with fresh courage and hope.

('7', 85, 2, 13, 188038) 65. DEATH OF MR. ADAMJEE MIANKHAN 1
('7', 85, 3, 14, 188074) Mr. Adamjee Miankhan of the firm of G. H. Miankhan & Co., Durban, and Vice President of the Natal Indian Congress, died at Ahmedabad, India, on the 20th instant, at the comparatively early age of 41. Mr. Adamjee went on a visit to India in February last, and his brother in Durban has been receiving regular letters, but no serious illness was complained of.
('7', 85, 3, 15, 188433) Mr. Adamjee has rendered very great service to the Indian community in Natal, and his able and willing help in all matters relating to their welfare will be much missed.
('7', 85, 3, 16, 188603) Born of a well known family of lace merchants in the capital of Gujarat, Mr. Adamjee Miankhan, with his father and his brother, Mr. Goolam Hoosen, migrated, when he was yet 18, to South Africa, in the year 1884. His knowledge of the English language was of the greatest service to him in making his mark as well among Indians as among his many European friends.
('7', 85, 3, 17, 188965) It was not, however, before 1896 that he became intimately connected with Indian public affairs.
('7', 85, 3, 18, 189062) On the temporary withdrawal of the then Secretary of the Congress, Mr. Adamjee, on account of his work and sterling qualities, was unanimously elected by the Congress to act as Honorary Secretary.
('7', 85, 4, 19, 189259) 1 Vide also the following item.
('7', 86, 0, 1, 189291) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 87
('7', 86, 1, 2, 189335) During his tenure of office, he was ably supported by Mr. Abdul Karim Hajee Adam Jhaveri.
('7', 86, 1, 3, 189425) Mr. Adamjee turned the credit balance of the Congress from £100 into that of £1,100, and during the latter part of 1896 and the beginning of 1897, when the now famous anti Indian demonstration took place in Durban, Mr. Adamjee, by his patience, calmness and perseverance, was instrumental in confronting the serious difficulties of the community.
('7', 86, 1, 4, 189772) Indian Opinion, 27 7 1907
('7', 86, 2, 5, 189798) 66. SAD DEATH OF ADAMJEE MIANKHAN
('7', 86, 3, 6, 189832) Inscrutable are the ways of God.
('7', 86, 3, 7, 189865) It is only five months since our well known leader, Mr. Adamjee Miankhan, returned home to India.
('7', 86, 3, 8, 189963) And now comes the news of his sudden death on the 23rd 1 at Ahmedabad after an illness of 20 days which caused him bed sores.
('7', 86, 3, 9, 190089) Those who have heard of him and of his work in Natal and other parts of South Africa, cannot but feel grieved at this sad news.
('7', 86, 3, 10, 190217) Gradually the time is coming in South Africa when patriotic workers will be needed in still larger numbers.
('7', 86, 3, 11, 190325) At such a time it is difficult to fill the gap created by the premature death of an able and conscientious leader like Mr. Adamjee Miankhan.
('7', 86, 3, 12, 190466) His patriotism and other valuable qualities of character are well known.
('7', 86, 3, 13, 190539) Traits of character such as intelligence, patience, quickness of grasp, and readinesss for self sacrifice, which he showed as Acting Secretary of the Congress and during his subsequent public career, deserve emulation.
('7', 86, 3, 14, 190758) His popularity was evident on the occasion of the farewell party at the time of his departure.
('7', 86, 3, 15, 190853) Even in India it was his intention to conduct a campaign against the hardships [of Indians] in South Africa.
('7', 86, 3, 16, 190962) It is but natural that the death of such a benevolent gentleman at the early age of 41 should cause grief.
('7', 86, 3, 17, 191069) We offer our condolences to the family of the departed, and urge his admirers to emulate his great virtues.
('7', 86, 3, 18, 191177) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 27 7 1907
('7', 86, 4, 19, 191219) 67. DIVINE LAW
('7', 86, 5, 20, 191234) The time to test the strength of the obnoxious law is approaching.
('7', 86, 5, 21, 191301) All Indians will be anxiously watching what the Government does on August 1. To speek the truth, however, we should wait with courage, not with anxiety.
('7', 86, 5, 22, 191454) Any pain we suffer in order to
('7', 86, 6, 23, 191485) 1 This is at variance with the preceding item which has “20th”.
('7', 87, 0, 1, 191549) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 87, 1, 2, 191590) save ourselves from the obnoxious law must be counted as pleasure.
('7', 87, 1, 3, 191657) Every Indian should pray, “let me be the first to go to gaol, so that my brothers are spared the pain.” We have already examined the various reasons why we ought not to submit to the obnoxious law.
('7', 87, 1, 4, 191855) It should be noted that in defying this murderous law we obey the divine law.
('7', 87, 1, 5, 191933) To submit to the unjust law will be a sin.
('7', 87, 1, 6, 191976) Likewise, it will be a sin to violate the divine law.
('7', 87, 1, 7, 192030) Hewho abides by the divine law will win bliss in this world, as also in the next.
('7', 87, 1, 8, 192112) What is this divine law?
('7', 87, 1, 9, 192137) It is that one has to suffer pain before enjoying pleasure and that one’s true self interest consists in the good of all, which means that we should die—suffer—for others.
('7', 87, 1, 10, 192309) Let us take a few examples.
('7', 87, 1, 11, 192337) When a lump of earth is broken into dust, it mixes with water and nourishes plant life.
('7', 87, 1, 12, 192425) It is by sacrificing themselves that plants sustain every kind of animal life.
('7', 87, 1, 13, 192504) Animals sacrifice themselves for the good of their progeny.
('7', 87, 1, 14, 192564) The mother suffers unbearable pain at the time of child birth, but feels only happy in that suffering.
('7', 87, 1, 15, 192667) Both the mother and the father undergo hardships in bringing up their children.
('7', 87, 1, 16, 192747) Wherever communities and nations exist, individual members of those communities or nations have endured hardships for the common good.
('7', 87, 1, 17, 192882) In the sixth century B. C., Lord Buddha, after wandering from forest to forest, braving the extremes of heat and cold and suffering many privations, attained self realization and spread ideas of spiritual welfare among the people.
('7', 87, 1, 18, 193113) Nineteen hundred years ago, Jesus Christ, according to the Christian belief, dedicated his life to the people and suffered many insults and hardships.
('7', 87, 1, 19, 193264) The prophet Mahomed suffered much.
('7', 87, 1, 20, 193299) People had prepared themselves for an attack on his life.
('7', 87, 1, 21, 193357) He paid no heed to it.
('7', 87, 1, 22, 193380) These great and holy men obeyed the law stated above and brought happiness to mankind.
('7', 87, 1, 23, 193467) They did not think of their personal interest but found their own happiness in the happiness of others.
('7', 87, 1, 24, 193571) The same thing happens in political matters too.
('7', 87, 1, 25, 193620) Hampden, Tyler, Cromwell and other Englishmen were prepared to sacrifice their all for the people and did not feel concerned at being robbed of all their possessions.
('7', 87, 1, 26, 193787) Nor did they feel anxious when their lives were in danger.
('7', 87, 1, 27, 193846) That is why the British people today rule over a large empire.
('7', 87, 1, 28, 193909) The rulers of the Transvaal enjoy power because they suffered great hardships before our very eyes.
('7', 87, 1, 29, 194009) Mazzini suffered banishment for the sake of his country.
('7', 87, 1, 30, 194066) Today he is being revered.
('7', 87, 1, 31, 194093) He is regarded as the father of Italian unity.
('7', 87, 1, 32, 194140) By suffering endless hardships, George Washington made America what it is today.
('7', 87, 1, 33, 194221) This again shows that one must pass through suffering before tasting happiness.
('7', 87, 1, 34, 194301) For public good, men have to suffer hardships even to the point of death.
('7', 88, 0, 1, 194375) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 89
('7', 88, 1, 2, 194419) Let us go further.
('7', 88, 1, 3, 194438) It is a sin to violate one’s pledge—to betray manhood with which we are endowed.
('7', 88, 1, 4, 194519) To save himself from the sin of incest, Yusoof Abesalam suffered gaol.
('7', 88, 1, 5, 194590) Imam Hasan 1 and Hussein 1
('7', 88, 2, 6, 194617) refused to acknowledge the authority of Yazid 2, for it would have been wrong to do so.
('7', 88, 2, 7, 194705) For this reason, that is, in order to preserve their honour, they becamemartyrs.
('7', 88, 2, 8, 194786) For the sake of honour, God’s devotee, Prahlad, boldly embraced the red hot pillar, and the child Sudhanva threw himself into the frying pan without any hesitation.
('7', 88, 2, 9, 194951) For the sake of truth, Harishchandra allowed himself to be sold to a low caste man; he gave up his throne and suffered separation from his wife and son.
('7', 88, 2, 10, 195104) For the sake of his father’s word, Ramachandra went into the forest.
('7', 88, 2, 11, 195173) And for the sake of their right, the Pandavas left their kingdom and wandered in the forest for 14 years.
('7', 88, 2, 12, 195279) Today it has fallen to the lot of the Indian community in the Transvaal to submit to this great divine law.
('7', 88, 2, 13, 195387) So persuaded, we congratulate our countrymen.
('7', 88, 2, 14, 195433) They have the opportunity now to see the Indian community throughout South Africa gaining its freedom through them.
('7', 88, 2, 15, 195549) How could such great happiness come to us without our going through equally great suffering?
('7', 88, 2, 16, 195642) Our petition is no longer addressed to man, but to God Himself.
('7', 88, 2, 17, 195706) Day and night He listens to our plaints.
('7', 88, 2, 18, 195747) We do not have to seek an appointment with Him for the hearing of our petition.
('7', 88, 2, 19, 195827) He hears the petitions of all at the same time.
('7', 88, 2, 20, 195875) With the purest heart therefore we pray to God that our brothers in the Transvaal may be prepared to suffer fearlessly anything that may befall them in August, placing their trust in Him alone, and with only His name on their lips.

('7', 88, 3, 22, 196149) 68. ALLY’S MISTAKE
('7', 88, 4, 23, 196168) Mr. Ritch’s letter this week and the letter, received along with it, addressed by Mr. Ally to Justice Ameer Ali, both deserve careful consideration.
('7', 88, 4, 24, 196317) We had some doubt whether these letters should be published.
('7', 88, 4, 25, 196378) On reflection, however, we decided in the end that, in the interest of the country, we certainly ought to publish them.
('7', 88, 4, 26, 196498) At such a critical time, we cannot afford to think of the effect they may have on the minds of certain individuals.
('7', 88, 4, 27, 196614) We have only to think, of what would
('7', 88, 5, 28, 196651) 1 Sons of Ali by his wife Fatima, daughter of Prophet.
('7', 88, 5, 29, 196706) 2 Caliph, 680 3. Hussein revolted against him, but was defeated and killed at Karbala.
('7', 89, 0, 1, 196793) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 89, 1, 2, 196834) lead to the common good.
('7', 89, 2, 3, 196859) Mr. Ally, in our opinion, acted hastily in writing to Justice Ameer Ali.
('7', 89, 2, 4, 196932) It was a mistake to have written such a letter.
('7', 89, 2, 5, 196980) It becomes clear now why a letter was received from the Committee advising us against taking the struggle to the point of going to gaol.
('7', 89, 2, 6, 197117) Mr. Ally’s letter led the Committee to think that there were differences among us.
('7', 89, 2, 7, 197200) If such differences do exist, a person having incomplete information will only advise us that we should give up the idea of carrying on the struggle by going to gaol.
('7', 89, 2, 8, 197367) In fact, no differences existed and there was therefore no need for Mr. Ally to write the letter he did to Justice Ameer Ali.
('7', 89, 2, 9, 197493) Moreover, no one was reluctant to meet General Botha.
('7', 89, 2, 10, 197547) On the Contrary, the British Indian Association made all out efforts to meet him.
('7', 89, 2, 11, 197629) In spite of these efforts, General Botha refused to grant an interview.
('7', 89, 2, 12, 197701) When the interview was refused, a written petition was submitted to him stating that the demands of the Indian community should be accepted.
('7', 89, 3, 13, 197842) To say that every Indian merchant is a Muslim and every hawker a Hindu is, we believe, a poisonous comment.
('7', 89, 3, 14, 197950) We take it as a disgrace to the Indian community that Mr. Ally should have penned such words.
('7', 89, 3, 15, 198044) The Transvaal struggle affects Hindus and Muslims alike.
('7', 89, 3, 16, 198101) The rights of both would vanish; moreover, it is obvious on reflection that the struggle would lack even dignity if the merchants did not join.
('7', 89, 3, 17, 198245) The more respectable the man, the greater would be the harm—such is the effect of the deadly law.
('7', 89, 3, 18, 198343) To a man with a greater sense of self respect, the law ought to be all the more abhorrent.
('7', 89, 3, 19, 198434) The question of such distinctions as Hindus and Muslims therefore does not arise at all.
('7', 89, 3, 20, 198523) Moreover, the relations between Indians in South Africa professing the two religions are not in the least strained.
('7', 89, 3, 21, 198639) By and large, all live in peace and amity.
('7', 89, 3, 22, 198682) That in these circumstances such a letter should have been addressed to the Committee portends, in our view, a very unfavourable issue for the Indian community.
('7', 89, 3, 23, 198843) Hence, we publish this letter along with our comments on it, to warn all Indians that, when the time of our deliverance is at hand, no one should imagine that differences exist between Hindus and Muslims or dream of creating any.
('7', 89, 4, 24, 199073) We do not wish to hurt Mr. Ally in any way by discussing the matter in public.
('7', 89, 4, 25, 199152) Those who disagree with him need not be angry with him; rather, they should pity him for his mistake.
('7', 89, 4, 26, 199254) The main point to be learnt from this is that every person engaged in public work should take a vow that he would not, under any circumstances, act in a way that might harm public interests.
('7', 89, 4, 27, 199445) We would advise Mr. Ally to correct his mistake.
('7', 90, 0, 1, 199494) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 91
('7', 90, 1, 2, 199538) We can also see from the above correspondence that, if Mr. Ally had not written the letter, the Committee perhaps would not have sent us a cable to dissuade us[from going to gaol].
('7', 90, 1, 3, 199719) However, it should be clearly borne in mind that the Committee’s advice is of no use to us at the present moment.
('7', 90, 1, 4, 199833) Those rushing into the field of battle cannot listen to the advice of men who keep themselves at home.
('7', 90, 1, 5, 199936) We have now to go on fighting, relying only on our own strength.

('7', 90, 2, 9, 200252) 69. INDIANS IN CAPE
('7', 90, 3, 10, 200272) Fresh elections to the Cape Parliament are likely to take place soon.
('7', 90, 3, 11, 200342) It is being asked how the black and brown peoples of the Cape will use their votes.
('7', 90, 3, 12, 200426) The discussion is going on not only in the Cape, but also in other parts of South Africa.
('7', 90, 3, 13, 200516) What we have to say is particularly for the Indian voters.
('7', 90, 3, 14, 200575) We think the Indian voters in the Cape have missed many opportunities of improving the conditions of the Indian community there and elsewhere.
('7', 90, 3, 15, 200718) There is no point in having the franchise if at the appropriate time it is not properly utilized.
('7', 90, 3, 16, 200816) If the natives and the Indians of the Cape realize the value of the vote, they can still bring about many changes.
('7', 90, 3, 17, 200931) The first thing to remember is that it is not absolutely necessary that the votes of the Kaffirs and the Asiatics should always be cast on the same side.
('7', 90, 3, 18, 201085) The rights they have to secure are different.
('7', 90, 3, 19, 201131) Their struggles are of different types.
('7', 90, 3, 20, 201171) For example, the Cape Immigration Act is a hardship to the Indian community; it has little effect on the Kaffirs.
('7', 90, 3, 21, 201285) Again, the Licences Act affects only the Indians.
('7', 90, 3, 22, 201335) Moreover, as South Africa is their mother country, they have a better right here than we have.
('7', 90, 3, 23, 201430) But the Indians can demand their rights with greater force on the strength of the Proclamation of 1858 and in view of their being an ancient nation.
('7', 90, 3, 24, 201579) Each has thus some advantages over the other.
('7', 90, 3, 25, 201625) The Indian community therefore should think independently as to which way it should cast its vote.
('7', 90, 3, 26, 201724) Another thing to remember is that a voter is under no obligation to vote for the one or the other side.
('7', 90, 3, 27, 201828) Sometimes, a very powerful effect can be produced by abstaining from exercising the franchise.
('7', 90, 3, 28, 201923) We know that once the few Indians of Durban who had votes resolved
('7', 91, 0, 1, 201990) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 91, 1, 2, 202031) to refrain from voting.
('7', 91, 1, 3, 202055) The effect was that a high officer sent for them and made certain promises which were later carried out.
('7', 91, 1, 4, 202160) Bearing these two things in mind, let us consider the conditions in the Cape.
('7', 91, 1, 5, 202238) There are two parties in the Cape: Bond 1 or Dutch; Progressive or British and “Foreign”.
('7', 91, 1, 6, 202328) We must admit that just now these two parties are in the condition of the pot calling the kettle black.
('7', 91, 1, 7, 202432) They are both tarred with the same brush.
('7', 91, 1, 8, 202474) Neither of them overflows with love for the blacks.
('7', 91, 1, 9, 202526) The Progressive party has violated the word of the late Mr. Rhodes 2. We would advise the Indian community in the Cape to ask the leaders of both the parties in writing whether certain amendments can be madeto the Immigration Act and the Licences Act.
('7', 91, 1, 10, 202778) Votes should be cast in favour of the party which boldly and honestly gives favourable replies.
('7', 91, 1, 11, 202874) If, however, both hesitate to give a straight reply, say one thing privately and another publicly, no encouragement should be given to such deceitful men.
('7', 91, 1, 12, 203029) They should be plainly told that in such circumstances the Indian community would vote for neither.
('7', 91, 1, 13, 203129) We are sure the prestige of the Indian community will rise by so doing.
('7', 91, 1, 14, 203201) And if not this time, next time one of the two parties will make certain definite promises.
('7', 91, 1, 15, 203293) We appeal to the Cape Indians to act this time only in the interests of the community.
('7', 91, 1, 16, 203380) No consideration should be shown to any whites either because they are friends or because they promise some benefits to a few Indians.
('7', 91, 1, 17, 203515) Some other time we shall consider what and how much to ask for.

('7', 92, 1, 21, 206027) If they keep their word and fight, Mr. Ross and others will stop insulting them.

('7', 93, 0, 1, 206378) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('7', 93, 1, 4, 206646) We do not believe that East London Indians have made any such demand.
('7', 93, 1, 5, 206716) Our enemies are only waiting for us to make such a mistake.
('7', 93, 1, 6, 206776) For if we demand a law introducing such distinctions, we shall be striking at our feet with our own axe.

('7', 93, 1, 9, 207079) One who is a hawker today may become a merchant tomorrow.

('7', 93, 2, 19, 207635) 72. RUSSIA’S EXAMPLE
('7', 93, 3, 20, 207656) Our readers are aware that the Czar of Russia has set up a Duma 1, that is, a Parliament.
('7', 93, 3, 21, 207746) Recently, the English Press published the news that most members of the Duma have been to gaol or suffered banishment in the country’s cause.
('7', 93, 3, 22, 207888) Therefore, the Parliament is also given the nick name of “an assembly of convicts”.
('7', 93, 3, 23, 207972) These members who have been to gaol and have been chosen by the people in the elections to the Duma are not mere illiterates or peasants, but are highly educated people.
('7', 93, 3, 24, 208142) Some of them are eminent lawyers or doctors.
('7', 93, 3, 25, 208187) There is one member, Mr. Gobernov who had even been sentenced to death.
('7', 93, 3, 26, 208259) Another member, Mr. Cymbersuck, had been banished to Siberia for several years.
('7', 93, 3, 27, 208339) The Russian rulers are often unhappy over the election of such men.
('7', 93, 3, 28, 208407) But neither the members nor the voters care for their displeasure.
('7', 93, 3, 29, 208474) There is a member, named Dimitriy Perlashin, who comes from a noble family.
('7', 93, 3, 30, 208550) He had suffered imprisonment for two years.
('7', 93, 3, 31, 208594) We can cite many such names.
('7', 93, 3, 32, 208623) But what
('7', 93, 4, 33, 208632) 1 Established in 1905, consisting of representatives elected on a restricted franchise.

('7', 94, 1, 2, 208790) has been said is enough to give the reader some idea.

('7', 94, 2, 14, 209830) 73. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 94, 3, 15, 209854) OBNOXIOUS LAW
('7', 94, 4, 16, 209868) Only four days of July will be left when this issue is published.
('7', 94, 4, 17, 209934) For the next issue I hope to send a telegram to Phoenix to say that the Government has begun arresting Indians for not taking out the new registers.
('7', 94, 4, 18, 210083) But it will not be wrong to believe that, while I look forward to it, some others may be afraid of it.
('7', 94, 5, 19, 210186) APPEAL TO PRETORIA
('7', 94, 6, 20, 210205) Meanwhile, I appeal to our countrymen in Pretoria to maintain to the end their own honour and that of the Indian community, as they have done so far.
('7', 94, 6, 21, 210355) I am sure there is not one Indian in Pretoria who will defile himself by a visit, on the last day, to the hell of the Permit office.
('7', 94, 6, 22, 210488) I think it will be fully realized that by going there nothing will be gained except disgrace, and so I hope the thought of such a visit will not occur to anyone even in a dream.
('7', 94, 7, 23, 210666) WHAT NEXT?
('7', 94, 8, 24, 210677) I have on various occasions given a reply to this question.
('7', 94, 8, 25, 210737) However, I think it right to give it again.
('7', 94, 8, 26, 210781) The courage that we have displayed in July is of one kind.
('7', 94, 8, 27, 210840) That required in August is of a different kind.
('7', 94, 8, 28, 210888) In July, we had to show the courage of remaining at
('7', 95, 0, 1, 210940) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 95, 1, 2, 210981) NOW, in August we shall be dragged to a magistrate in a court, where we shall have to give a bold answer.
('7', 95, 1, 3, 211087) The mere mention of a law court strikes fear in our hearts.
('7', 95, 1, 4, 211147) What will happen then, when we are produced before a magistrate?
('7', 95, 1, 5, 211212) It will be more difficult to maintain courage this time, but it is needed in full measure.
('7', 95, 2, 6, 211303) POLICE WILL ARREST
('7', 95, 3, 7, 211322) In the first place, on August I it will be open to the police to arrest any or all of the Indians for not applying for a fresh register.
('7', 95, 3, 8, 211459) Our firmness in keeping the pledge will then be tested.
('7', 95, 4, 9, 211515) DO NOT OFFER BAIL
('7', 95, 5, 10, 211533) Every Indian should remember that at that time no arrested person is to offer bail and that none should stand bail for him.
('7', 95, 5, 11, 211657) Then will begin our training for a stay in the prison palace.
('7', 95, 5, 12, 211719) The arrested Indian will be produced before a magistrate the same day or the next.
('7', 95, 6, 13, 211802) QUESTION OF DEFENCE
('7', 95, 7, 14, 211822) Probably he will be charged with failure to apply for fresh registration.
('7', 95, 7, 15, 211896) At this stage, provided the arrested person holds a valid permit or is a minor for whom no permit is necessary, Mr. Gandhi will appear for his defence gratis and Messrs Essop Mia and Gandhi will depose that the Indian community has been bound, by oath and by a resolution, not to submit to the new law, that the accused has accepted the said resolution, and that, if for such action a sentence has to be passed, it should first be passed on the office bearers of the Association.
('7', 95, 7, 16, 212376) Thereafter, if a deposition by the accused is considered necessary, he will state that not only has he acted in obedience to the community’s Resolution, but that he personally disapproves the Act, that he does not, therefore, intend to take out a new register and that, if sentenced, he will go to gaol, but pay no fine.
('7', 95, 8, 17, 212697) CONSEQUENCE
('7', 95, 9, 18, 212709) As a result of such a defence Messrs Essop Mia and Gandhi may be arrested first, and the accused may be let off.
('7', 95, 9, 19, 212822) If, however, this does not happen, the Court is bound to pass a sentence on the accused.
('7', 95, 9, 20, 212911) The Court has the power to impose a fine and may therefore sentence the accused to a fine, on the non payment of which, he will be sent to gaol.
('7', 95, 10, 21, 213056) NO FINE TO BE PAID
('7', 95, 11, 22, 213075) It must be distinctly remembered then that one is to go to gaol, not to pay the fine.
('7', 95, 11, 23, 213161) I recommend that, on and from August l, no Indian whatever should carry any money with him and certainly not
('7', 96, 0, 1, 213270) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 97
('7', 96, 1, 2, 213314) gold in any case.
('7', 96, 1, 3, 213332) Temptation is a very bad thing.
('7', 96, 1, 4, 213364) Not being used to the idea of gaol, on hearing the sentence of fine, the accused may find his hands unconsciously straying into his pocket or he may cast an imploring glance at his friends.
('7', 96, 1, 5, 213554) When this happens, he should mentally ask for God’s forgiveness, remove his hand [from the pocket], stand erect and, clearing his throat, declare that he will not pay the fine but go to gaol.
('7', 96, 1, 6, 213746) He should remember at the same time how in England women, both young and old, have refused to pay the fine of half a crown and preferred to go to gaol for the sake of their right.
('7', 96, 2, 7, 213926) WHAT WILL OTHERS DO?
('7', 96, 3, 8, 213947) We assume that ordinarily all the Indians will not be arrested simultaneously.
('7', 96, 3, 9, 214026) What will be the duty then of those who remain outside?
('7', 96, 3, 10, 214082) The answer is easy.
('7', 96, 3, 11, 214102) They should congratulate the brother who has shown courage and sought gaol, and help his relatives; as for themselves, they should not get panicky and apply for registration.
('7', 96, 3, 12, 214277) On the contrary, everyone should pray that his should be the next turn to go to gaol.
('7', 96, 4, 13, 214363) WHAT IF MR. GANDHI IS ARRESTED FIRST?
('7', 96, 5, 14, 214401) If this happens, there will be no defence to make.
('7', 96, 5, 15, 214452) Everything will be made clear at the time of Mr. Gandhi’s trial.

('7', 96, 5, 17, 214666) The struggle carried on so far will be worth while only if the Indian community remains firm, no matter who is imprisoned or deported.
('7', 96, 6, 18, 214801) WHAT WILL HAPPEN IF REGISTERS ARE TAKEN OUT?
('7', 96, 7, 19, 214846) But, if out of fear Indians apply for registers or pay the fine, or seek release on bail, the struggle waged so far will come to nought.
('7', 96, 7, 20, 214983) It will be proved that we had no real courage.

('7', 96, 7, 23, 215176) The gilt will come off and we shall be shown up to be base copper rather than gold, and we shall indeed have proved ourselves worthless.
('7', 96, 8, 24, 215313) GOVERNMENT’ S OTHER WEAPONS
('7', 96, 9, 25, 215341) As I have pointed out above, the Government can take steps other than charging us with failure to take out a fresh register.
('7', 96, 9, 26, 215466) For, all the present registers and permits stand cancelled.

('7', 96, 9, 28, 215593) As I said in earlier letters, if such a charge is made the person will be given a notice at the first trial to leave the country within a specific period.

('7', 97, 1, 4, 215975) On receipt of a notice after such trial, one should not leave, but should get arrested and go to gaol at the expiry of the notice period.
('7', 97, 2, 5, 216113) ANY FEAR FOR MERCHANTS?
('7', 97, 3, 6, 216137) Persons with a large business need not have any fear.
('7', 97, 3, 7, 216191) It is unlikely that all the men in an establishment will be simultaneously arrested.
('7', 97, 3, 8, 216276) The shops are certainly not going to be looted.

('7', 97, 4, 13, 216639) DUTY OF ASSOCIATION

('7', 97, 10, 23, 217625) WARNING
('7', 97, 11, 24, 217633) Some Indians think that, if even a single Indian takes out the new register, it will be difficult for others to keep back.

('7', 98, 2, 10, 218937) PRETORIA MEETING

('7', 99, 8, 12, 221302) SIR, My Committee have learnt with regret that applications for registration of Asiatics are being received by officials late at night and in private stores or other places.
('7', 99, 8, 13, 221476) My Committee have also learnt that this method has been adopted on the strength of representations made to the Government to the effect that British Indians desiring to make application under the Act are threatened with physical injury, etc.
('7', 99, 8, 14, 221718) My Committee disclaim all knowledge of any such threats having been used by any responsible member of the community.
('7', 99, 8, 15, 221835) The activityof the Committee has been confined to vigorous propaganda work in the way of showing the degradation and disadvantage involved in accepting the provisions of the Act.
('7', 99, 8, 16, 222014) The volunteers, it will be admitted, have simply performed missionary work.
('7', 99, 8, 17, 222090) My committee have publicly and emphatically informed British Indians that any member wishing to make his application will not only be left unharmed but that he will, if so desired by him, be escorted to the Registration Office.
('7', 99, 8, 18, 222318) In the humble opinion of my Committee, those Indians who
('7', 99, 9, 19, 222375) 1 This was presumably drafted by Gandhiji.
('7', 100, 0, 1, 222418) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 101
('7', 100, 1, 2, 222463) have applied secretly and at night time have done so in order to conceal from British Indians what they, too, in common with other members of the community, have believed to be an act derogatory to their honour.
('7', 100, 1, 3, 222675) In the humble opinion of my Committee, secret registration after office hours and in private stores, even if it be not illegal, can hardly be considered a dignified proceeding.
('7', 100, 1, 4, 222852) In any event, my Committee beg respectfully to assure the Government that the Indian community in what is to it a life and death struggle has no intention to resort to intimidation or methods which may in any way be considered even reprehensible.
