('7', 100, 2, 6, 223195) 75. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 100, 3, 7, 223219) [July 29, 1907]
('7', 100, 4, 8, 223235) NEW LAW — GHASTLY BETRAYAL
('7', 100, 5, 9, 223262) None of my letters so far has been written, I think, with so much grief as this one.
('7', 100, 5, 10, 223347) Whether I ought to publish this news at all is itself a difficult question to decide.
('7', 100, 5, 11, 223433) However, I feel that I ought to take notice of the incident that took place among the Indian community at Pretoria, if we mean to be truthful and courageous.
('7', 100, 6, 12, 223591) For the Indian community in South Africa the last week of July will prove memorable.
('7', 100, 6, 13, 223676) Just when we were hoping with confidence that the hour of our victory was at hand, there was treachery in the community and our success became doubtful.
('7', 100, 6, 14, 223829) The conspiracy came to light by accident at the Pretoria Railway Station after 10 p.
('7', 100, 6, 15, 223914) on Wednesday, July 24. Messrs Cachalia, Vyas, Beg and other Indians were present there to receive Mr. Gandhi.
('7', 100, 6, 16, 224024) They learnt that something suspicious was going on in Mr. Khamisa’s shop.
('7', 100, 6, 17, 224098) There were a few white men inside, and some detectives near the shop.
('7', 100, 6, 18, 224168) On receipt of this information, these gentlemen thought thatthey would knock at the door of Mr. Khamisa’s shop, and if the door should be opened and some move to submit to the new law should be found afoot, they would dissuade the persons concerned.
('7', 100, 6, 19, 224418) Mr Gandhi knocked at the door, and so did Mr. Vyas.
('7', 100, 6, 20, 224470) A man came out and inquired who they were.
('7', 100, 6, 21, 224513) Mr. Gandhi answered him, and asked his permission to go
('7', 101, 0, 1, 224569) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 101, 1, 2, 224611) inside.
('7', 101, 1, 3, 224619) No one opened the door.
('7', 101, 1, 4, 224643) Meanwhile, a detective came and started asking questions.
('7', 101, 1, 5, 224701) Mr. Beg gave a bold reply.
('7', 101, 1, 6, 224728) Then Mr. Gandhi spoke to the detective.
('7', 101, 1, 7, 224768) Thereupon the latter said, “You know the law, do what is proper”, and went away.
('7', 101, 1, 8, 224849) A few minutes later he and two other officers came there.
('7', 101, 1, 9, 224907) Meanwhile, Mr. Vyas had gone to call Mr. Hajee Habib.
('7', 101, 1, 10, 224961) Taking each member of the above party by hand, the detective asked him to move away.
('7', 101, 1, 11, 225046) They all left.
('7', 101, 1, 12, 225061) Everyone thought that a conspiracy must have been in the hatching in Mr. Khamisa’s shop.
('7', 101, 2, 13, 225150) Many Indians kept awake the whole night.
('7', 101, 2, 14, 225191) On the morning of Thursday, the entire Indian community became agitated.
('7', 101, 2, 15, 225264) Letters and telegrams were despatched to all the towns.
('7', 101, 2, 16, 225320) It is said that at Mr. Khamisa’s shop that night, at the stroke of twelve, some 20 men blackened their hands and faces, and brought a slur on the good name of the Indian community.
('7', 101, 3, 17, 225501) WHO IS GUILTY HERE?
('7', 101, 4, 18, 225521) This question will arise in the mind of every Indian.
('7', 101, 4, 19, 225575) I myself feel that we cannot absolve those who applied for registration.
('7', 101, 4, 20, 225648) None could have blamed them if, convinced that the new law was good and that there was no humiliation in submitting to it, they had, in broad daylight, gone to the Permit Office to apply for their title deed of slavery.
('7', 101, 4, 21, 225868) But they believed it to be a shameful thing and that is why they decided to take out permits secretly at night.
('7', 101, 4, 22, 225980) This proves that they knew their guilt and hence they should be considered to have committed an offence against the Indian community.
('7', 101, 4, 23, 226114) The Permit Officers can be held to be as much at fault as the Indian culprits and even more.
('7', 101, 4, 24, 226207) Going to people’s shops at night to receive in secret applications for new permits shows that they have been straining every nerve to make people submit to the new law.
('7', 101, 4, 25, 226376) For they are afraid that their prestige will suffer if the people do not submit to it.
('7', 101, 4, 26, 226463) If the Government stoops so low, what wonder is there that people are tempted?
('7', 101, 5, 27, 226542) AS IF THIS WAS NOT ENOUGH
('7', 101, 6, 28, 226568) For such secret registration the pretext is found to have been put forward that the Indian community has held out threats that those who take out new registers will be made to suffer.
('7', 101, 6, 29, 226752) This accusation is entirely false.
('7', 101, 6, 30, 226787) Trying to hide his own shame in taking out the register, the traitor has levelled false charges against the whole community, and invented lies.
('7', 102, 0, 1, 226931) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 103
('7', 102, 1, 2, 226976) HAJEE HABIB’S LETTER
('7', 102, 2, 3, 226997) As it is impossible to tolerate such an accusation, Mr. Hajee Habib has addressed the following letter to the Colonial Secretary: 1
('7', 102, 3, 4, 227129) BUT GOOD COMES OUT OF EVIL
('7', 102, 4, 5, 227156) The fight of the Indian community being righteous, the treachery appears to have led only to a good result.
('7', 102, 4, 6, 227264) Among those secretly taking out permits was an innocent Indian, named Abdul Karim Jamal.
('7', 102, 4, 7, 227353) Out of fear and temptation he applied for a permit, but, as he did not belong to the treacherous group, he was arrested on a charge of giving false information in the application.
('7', 102, 4, 8, 227533) He has been released on a bail of £100 and awaits trial.
('7', 102, 4, 9, 227590) This has shocked all Pretoria.
('7', 102, 4, 10, 227621) For, the Indians have found that, in applying for a permit under the new law, the fear was not only that the permit might not be granted, but also that ‘one might have to suffer imprisonment like a criminal.
('7', 102, 4, 11, 227829) Whether or not Mr. Abdul Karim Jamal is guilty is a separate question.
('7', 102, 4, 12, 227900) It is obvious that even an innocent person might all of a sudden find himself dragged to the court, so dreadful is this law.
('7', 102, 4, 13, 228025) Both one’s honour and safety lie in keeping away from the new law.
('7', 102, 4, 14, 228092) This case should serve as a warning to all.
('7', 102, 4, 15, 228136) There is no guarantee that even by seeking the title deed of slavery one can have the right of settling in the Transvaal.
('7', 102, 5, 16, 228258) “COMPASSION IS THE SOURCE OF RELIGION”
('7', 102, 6, 17, 228297) One should remember this famous line of verse 2, and have compassion on those who have betrayed the Indian community.
('7', 102, 6, 18, 228415) It is natural that we should feel angry.

('7', 102, 6, 20, 228556) It should also be remembered that the entire struggle would suffer if, in the course of it, any Indian used violence against another Indian or did him other harm.
('7', 102, 6, 21, 228719) In this connection I have regretfully to say that Mr. Khamisa sent word to each of his Indian customers that, if they did not apply for the new title deed of slavery by Monday morning, they should pay up all his dues, failing which he would have summons taken out against them.
('7', 102, 6, 22, 228997) This created a great stir.

('7', 104, 5, 27, 233670) That Lord Elgin expressed regret clearly shows that he himself regards the Act to be oppressive.
('7', 104, 5, 28, 233767) So, when Indians go to gaol, his sympathy is bound to be with them.

('7', 105, 3, 7, 234952) 76. SPEECH AT PRETORIA 1
('7', 105, 4, 8, 234977) [PRETORIA, July 31, 1907]
('7', 105, 5, 9, 235003) Mr. Gandhi said that Mr. Hosken had been explaining a great many things in connection with the Ordinance, 2 and he had expressed his sympathy with them in their trouble, but he thought that, although their struggle proceeded from a right mind, they were misguided, and that they ought to submit to the Ordinance, namely, to the compulsion that underlay the Ordinance as also to the ten finger impressions.
('7', 105, 5, 10, 235409) He had advanced many arguments in favour of this submission, one of which was that they ought to submit to the inevitable.
('7', 105, 5, 11, 235532) He (Mr. Gandhi) wanted to take up this argument of the inevitable.
('7', 105, 5, 12, 235599) 3 He thought and felt most deeply that neither Mr. Hosken nor any member of a Western race, and he said this with all humility, was capable of understanding what an Eastern mind understood by the inevitable.
('7', 105, 5, 13, 235807) Mr. Hosken had told them that the Asiatic Registration Act had behind it the force of white public opinion, and that for that reason it could not be overridden but must be submitted to.
('7', 105, 5, 14, 235993) He (Mr. Gandhi) did not call this the inevitable.
('7', 105, 5, 15, 236043) To him the inevitable was that British Indians who were voteless in this country, who had absolutely no voice in this country, whose petitions were flung into the wastepaper basket, for whom not a
('7', 105, 6, 16, 236240) 1 On July 31, the last day for filing applications under the Asiatic Registration Act, a meeting of British Indians from all over the Transvaal was held at Pretoria.
('7', 105, 6, 17, 236406) A telegraphic report of the speech appeared in Indian Opinion, 3 8 1907. This is a fuller report.
('7', 105, 6, 18, 236504) 2 Attending the meeting at the instance of General Botha, Hosken had informed Indians that the Government was firm in its policy in regard to the Act.
('7', 105, 6, 19, 236655) 3 Vide “Mr. Hosken’s Inevitable”, 10 8 1907
('7', 106, 0, 1, 236699) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 107
('7', 106, 1, 2, 236744) single voice was raised in the popular Assembly, for whom even Mr. Hosken had not been able to say one word of sympathy there because he felt that he would have to meet a solid phalanx of opposition, should oppose the Law.
('7', 106, 1, 3, 236967) Under these circumstances, the inevitable they had to submit to was the will of God.
('7', 106, 1, 4, 237052) If it was His will that every one of the 13,000 Indians should sacrifice everything, should give up whatever he had of monetary wealth accruing to him in this material world, then he must resign himself to the inevitable, and not accept the insult and the degradation that this Law involved.
('7', 106, 1, 5, 237344) He thought, with all respect, that Mr. Hosken was not in a position to change his skin, nor was he in a position to advise them in a matter of life and death to every Indian who resided in the country.
('7', 106, 2, 6, 237546) He had lived in this country, and had served his fellow countrymen for thirteen years.
('7', 106, 2, 7, 237633) (Cheers.) He claimed to be one of the most peaceable men in South Africa, and he had not embarked upon this crusade, he had not embarked upon this advice to his countrymen, without mature thought and deliberation.
('7', 106, 2, 8, 237847) He had read every sectionof the Asiatic Act and had read almost all Colonial legislation, and he had come deliberately to that conclusion, which he did not think he was likely to alter, that if the Asiatics who resided in the Transvaal submitted to that Law, theirs would be a state of slavery and nothing less.
('7', 106, 3, 9, 238159) And why?
('7', 106, 3, 10, 238168) He had given a simple illustration to Mr. Hosken’s countrymen when he had been in London.
('7', 106, 3, 11, 238258) He had said: “Everyone who goes in the street wears a chimney pot, a silk hat.
('7', 106, 3, 12, 238337) Supposing that in London they were to pass legislation making it compulsory for every Englishman to wear the silk hat, would not the whole of London go hatless?” This was the position he had put to those friends—only it was absolutely trivial.
('7', 106, 3, 13, 238581) There, it would be merely a question of hats, yet Englishmen prized their liberty so highly that they would resist in their own country a law which put such compulsion on them, whatever its objects.
('7', 106, 3, 14, 238780) Here it was not a question of hats, but the badge of slavery on arm and forehead.
('7', 106, 3, 15, 238862) He asked them not to wear that badge.
('7', 106, 4, 16, 238900) He took the sole responsibility for the advice he had given to his countrymen, but he would also couple that admission with the statement that his countrymen had felt far more severely the degradation involved in that Act than he could ever feel because he knew the loopholes that this Act contained for his countrymen.
('7', 106, 4, 17, 239220) He knew also that, living in a country like this, they had to make allowance for a certain amount of prejudice, so they had put up with some indignities, some insults, but now the cup was filled to overflowing, and British Indians recognized that it was not possible for them to suffer the degradation involved in the Act and to live in this country.
('7', 106, 4, 18, 239571) They had deliberately and of their own accord come to the conclusion that it was not possible for them to live in this country.
('7', 106, 4, 19, 239699) If these were not the feelings of his countrymen in regard to that Act, he would be the first to own his mistake, and he would be the first to comply with the Law and to publicly admit that he had been mistaken and that they had deserved that Ordinance.
('7', 106, 5, 20, 239953) Mr. Essop Mia had placed graphically before them the position.
('7', 106, 5, 21, 240016) He had shown the difference between the Act and voluntary registration.
('7', 106, 5, 22, 240088) They had before their
('7', 107, 0, 1, 240110) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 107, 1, 2, 240152) mind’s eye, and they could picture to themselves, the position in which they would be under voluntary registration and that in which they would be under compulsory registration.
('7', 107, 1, 3, 240330) It was not for him now to examine the Act in detail, but the Moulvi had drawn one or two comparisons for their edification.
('7', 107, 1, 4, 240454) Mr. Hosken, not understanding the language, had thought that the Moulvi was resenting a personal grievance, but those who served the community could not afford to have any such personal grievances.
('7', 107, 1, 5, 240652) What the Moulvi had said was that the Act was despicable, and he (Mr. Gandhi) would say with emphasis, and in all humility, that the Act was so despicable and so wantonly insulting that it even made distinctions between Mahomedans and Christians, it brought Turkish Mahomedans within the provisions of the Act but left Turkish Christians and Jews free.
('7', 107, 1, 6, 241005) He did not know of any Turkish Mahomedan who had a quarrel to pick with the Turkish Christian or the Turkish Jew, but they had found it hard to swallow this bitter pill, to swallow this insult.
('7', 107, 2, 7, 241199) And if, in order to eke out a miserable existence in this country, they submitted to all these things, what warranty, after all, had they that their position would be changed for the better and that there would be restored to them any of the rights of which they had already been deprived?
('7', 107, 2, 8, 241489) A few unimportant alterations would be made, but they would still have to submit to the deprivation of ownership of property, to segregation in locations and he knew nor what else.
('7', 107, 2, 9, 241670) This was the position they had to face, and for that reason he had taken the responsibility of advising his countrymen that they ought not to submit to this Act.

('7', 107, 4, 13, 242321) Resolution 2: This Mass Meeting of British Indians assembled in Pretoria congratulates the vast majority of the Indian inhabitants of Pretoria upon having refrained from bringing themselves under the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, and upon braving the serious consequences of non submission thereto, and also congratulates, the courageous Indians who, by acting as missionaries to spread a true
('7', 107, 5, 14, 242712) 1 Though the resolutions were moved and supported by other spokesmen of the Indian community, they were presumably drawn up by Gandhiji.

('7', 108, 1, 2, 242894) knowledge of the provisions of the Act amongst the members of the community, have made possible so noteworthy a stand against injustice and oppression.

('7', 108, 5, 11, 244136) 79. STRUGGLE IN TRANSVAAL
('7', 108, 6, 12, 244162) The month of July has ended.
('7', 108, 6, 13, 244191) It will remain memorable in the history of the Transvaal Indians, perhaps in the history of the Indians in the Colony of South Africa.
('7', 108, 6, 14, 244326) The mass meeting on July 31 marked a fitting conclusion to an eventful month.
('7', 108, 6, 15, 244404) We are happy to find that a meeting attended by delegates from all parts of the Transvaal has once again condemned the Ordinance unanimously.
('7', 108, 6, 16, 244546) That means, the whole of the Transvaal stands united in its eagerness to court imprisonment.
('7', 108, 6, 17, 244639) However, some persons, not realizing the importance of a struggle which will affect the future of Indians in the whole of South Africa,
('7', 108, 7, 18, 244775) 1 At the close of the meeting, Gandhiji gave an interview of which this is a brief report.
('7', 109, 0, 1, 244866) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 109, 1, 2, 244908) have betrayed the community.
('7', 109, 1, 3, 244937) Their conduct is tantamount to high treason against the motherland.
('7', 109, 1, 4, 245005) But the number of such persons is very small.
('7', 109, 1, 5, 245051) Moreover, many of them feel sorry for what they have done.
('7', 109, 1, 6, 245110) Taking a warning from this, and from the miserable condition of one or two persons whose valid permits were declared to be false, people everywhere in the Transvaal who are still wavering will, we hope, make up their minds to be firm.
('7', 109, 1, 7, 245345) It is the turn now of Pietersburg and other districts to do what Pretoria has done, and do one better.
('7', 109, 1, 8, 245448) If this happens, our struggle can have only one result, and that is success.
('7', 109, 1, 9, 245525) For the present, we only wish to tell the brave friends in Pretoria that, in keeping with the spirit they have shown in July, they hold themselves ready fearlessly for simple or rigorous imprisonment, or for exile, if the Government so chooses; in a word, for any hardship.
('7', 109, 1, 10, 245799) We are now in the thick of a battle.
('7', 109, 1, 11, 245836) There is no question of looking back.
('7', 109, 1, 12, 245874) Our fight is for justice, so that we have the great Creator of the world Himself on our side.
('7', 109, 1, 13, 245968) In the course of the struggle so far, the Government has climbed down frequently enough.
('7', 109, 1, 14, 246057) This success is the result of our firmness.
('7', 109, 1, 15, 246101) We cannot put a limit to what can be done.
('7', 109, 1, 16, 246144) We offer our sincere congratulations to Pretoria for what it has been able to do, and pray to God that He may always bring succour to those who may be in gaol.

('7', 109, 3, 19, 246379) Time and again we have warned Natal Indians to keep awake.

('7', 109, 3, 23, 246919) Following this example, all the Indians in Natal should collect as much as they can in their respective districts.
('7', 109, 3, 24, 247034) If the Congress leaders have been thus active, the rank and file of Indians have not lagged behind.

('7', 110, 2, 6, 247825) 81. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 110, 3, 7, 247849) [August 5, 1907]
('7', 110, 4, 8, 247866) SPECTRE AT PIETERSBURG
('7', 110, 5, 9, 247889) The spectre of the Permit Office has now shifted to Pietersburg, and by the time this letter appears in print, it will have been known whether the Indians are lions or lambs.
('7', 110, 5, 10, 248064) Though I am writing this as early as Monday, I think I can say they are lions.
('7', 110, 5, 11, 248143) On learning that the Permit Office will go to Pietersburg some time between the 7th and the 10th to issue the title deeds of slavery, the local leaders immediately went to Pretoria.
('7', 110, 5, 12, 248325) Mr. Hajee Habib, the very shrewd and energetic Secretary, who had been to Johannesburg on business, soon returned to Pretoria to help maintain the confidence of the Pietersburg leaders.
('7', 110, 5, 13, 248511) They have taken up the challenge, ensuring a total boycott of the Permit Office at Pietersburg.
('7', 110, 6, 14, 248607) WHY DID SPECTRE GO TO PIETERSBURG?
('7', 110, 7, 15, 248642) This question will strike everyone.
('7', 110, 7, 16, 248678) I have to say with regret that the blame for this lies with Pietersburg Indians.
('7', 110, 7, 17, 248759) They did not attend the famous mass meeting on July 31. Their telegram was lukewarm, and the Indian shops at Pietersburg remained open that day, though other shops throughout the Transvaal, including even that of Mr. Khamisa, were closed.
('7', 110, 7, 18, 248998) This naturally led the Government to infer that the Pietersburg Indians would be quite ready to wear the chain of slavery and accept the registration document which is almost like a warrant of death.
('7', 110, 7, 19, 249198) Moreover, since Mr. Khamisa and Mr. Hajee Ibrahim had tarnished the name of the Memons, who form the bulk of the Indian community at Pietersburg, the Government thought that its ammunition would prove effective against Pietersburg and that the fort of Indian freedom would fall there.
('7', 111, 0, 1, 249483) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 111, 1, 2, 249525) But the Government has made a mistake in thinking that the Pietersburg Memon community will follow the example of Mr. Khamisa and Mr. Hajee Ibrahim.
('7', 111, 1, 3, 249674) I believe that both these Indians are also repenting now.
('7', 111, 1, 4, 249732) Their new registers have proved too much of a liability to them.
('7', 111, 1, 5, 249797) Though no Indian has been avoiding these gentlemen or doing them any harm, they remain isolated and have to put up with bitter public criticism.
('7', 111, 1, 6, 249942) No Indian, therefore, will make bold to do what they have done.
('7', 111, 1, 7, 250006) Moreover, in public at least they have been saying that, though they had themselves soiled their hands and tarnished their faces, let no other Indian do like them.
('7', 111, 2, 8, 250170) CONCESSION TO PRETORIA?
('7', 111, 3, 9, 250194) In its Notice from Pietersburg the Government has now announced that the Pretoria Indians will be free to take out new registers at Pietersburg.
('7', 111, 3, 10, 250339) I for one take this to be a kind of bondage.
('7', 111, 3, 11, 250384) Temptation is an evil thing.
('7', 111, 3, 12, 250413) I consider that taking out of new registers is a crime.
('7', 111, 3, 13, 250469) To tempt them to commit that crime, the Government has only opened another door for the Pretoria Indians.
('7', 111, 3, 14, 250575) It will be wrong to regard it as a concession.
('7', 111, 3, 15, 250622) It is just a snare.
('7', 111, 3, 16, 250642) For my part, I am convinced that no Indian from Pretoria will succumb to the temptation.
('7', 111, 4, 17, 250731) KARIM JAMAL’S CASE
('7', 111, 5, 18, 250750) Thanks to Karim Jamal’s case 1, Indians have become more strongly confirmed in their opposition to the new law.
('7', 111, 5, 19, 250862) To submit to it, they have seen, is to go in for a bad bargain.
('7', 111, 5, 20, 250926) 2 The case against Mr. Karim Jamal has been withdrawn.
('7', 111, 5, 21, 250981) The public prosecutor admitted that there had been a mistake in instituting the case.
('7', 111, 5, 22, 251067) How does this help Mr. Karim Jamal?
('7', 111, 5, 23, 251103) He had to suffer inconvenience and incur monetary loss.
('7', 111, 5, 24, 251159) Disgusted with the heavy loss and damage, he has withdrawn his application for a register.
('7', 111, 5, 25, 251250) (See his letter to the Registrar on the subject printed elsewhere.) 3
('7', 111, 6, 26, 251320) This letter should be a warning to all Indians as to how this law can subject a poor man to hardship.
('7', 111, 7, 27, 251422) WHITE STANDS UP AGAINST FINGER PRINTS
('7', 111, 8, 28, 251460) A white man has been arrested on a charge of theft.
('7', 111, 8, 29, 251512) Under the
('7', 111, 9, 30, 251522) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 29 7 1907

('7', 112, 1, 2, 251703) gaol regulations, the police have the authority to require finger prints of a person sent to gaol.
('7', 112, 1, 3, 251802) In exercise of that authority, the police demanded this man’s finger prints in the gaol.

('7', 112, 2, 8, 252251) MONETARY AID FOR STRUGGLE
('7', 112, 3, 9, 252277) Mr. Bhatt writes to the Association from Waschbank to say that the Indians there are in high spirits and are raising a fund.
('7', 112, 3, 10, 252402) He has offered whatever help may be necessary when people go to gaol.

('7', 112, 3, 12, 252496) In this connection I must point out that whatever money is raised in Natal should be forwarded to the Congress Secretary.

('7', 112, 4, 18, 253039) MASS MEETING
('7', 112, 5, 19, 253052) The mass meeting at Pretoria proved a huge success; one can say that the mass meetings at the Empire Theatre and the Gaiety Theatre were nothing compared to this.
('7', 112, 5, 20, 253215) Moreover, it is a happy augury for our ultimate success that the meeting was held in the premises of a building as sacred as a mosque.
('7', 112, 5, 21, 253350) The editor of Pretoria News personally attended this meeting, while the other meetings were attended by reporters only.
('7', 112, 5, 22, 253470) At the two earlier mass meetings the local Members of Parliament were not present.
('7', 112, 6, 23, 253553) HOSKEN’S PRESENCE
('7', 112, 7, 24, 253571) This meeting was attended by Mr. Hosken, a prominent Member of Parliament.
('7', 112, 7, 25, 253646) Mr. Hosken’s speech should add to our strength.
('7', 112, 7, 26, 253694) He cannot, of course, give any different advice from what he did.
('7', 112, 7, 27, 253760) He came under instructions from General Botha, General Smuts and Mr. Hull.
('7', 112, 7, 28, 253835) This shows that our work in the month of July has had its effect on the Government.
('7', 112, 7, 29, 253919) When two parties are engaged in a struggle, it is usual for each to maintain an extreme position to the very last.
('7', 112, 7, 30, 254034) Of the two, the party which has right on its side and remains firm till the end will win.
('7', 112, 7, 31, 254124) It is no wonder, therefore, that the Government should send a message to say that the law would in no case be amended and that
('7', 113, 0, 1, 254251) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 113, 1, 2, 254293) voluntary registration would not be accepted.
('7', 113, 1, 3, 254339) No one listened to us hitherto, but now the Government is anxious to find out what we want.
('7', 113, 1, 4, 254431) Let us regard this as the first step towards success.
('7', 113, 2, 5, 254485) OTHER GOOD OMENS
('7', 113, 3, 6, 254502) Just as I regard the holding of the meeting in a mosque and the presence of Mr. Hosken at the meeting as a happy augury, so also the news which Mr. Hajee Cassim brought to the meeting, that the Government would not send anyone to gaol for the immediate present, may be taken by some as a good omen.
('7', 113, 3, 7, 254801) In reality this is bad news, for the sooner the Government took the offensive against us, the quicker would be the solution.
('7', 113, 3, 8, 254926) But I take it as a favourable circumstance that the news was received on the very day of the meeting.
('7', 113, 3, 9, 255028) The happiest sign is the cablegram from England received on the morning of July 31 to say that the South Africa British [Indian] Committee had been trying for an interview with Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman.
('7', 113, 3, 10, 255235) This cablegram gladdened the hearts of all.
('7', 113, 3, 11, 255279) All were gratified to think that they were not going to be entirely forsaken by the Committee.
('7', 113, 4, 12, 255374) CABLEGRAM TO REUTER
('7', 113, 5, 13, 255394) After the meeting was over, the Pretoria Committee sent a long cablegram to Reuter, and another directly to the Committee.
('7', 113, 5, 14, 255517) This meant an expense of £7. The Committee’s reply to this cablegram states that our question will be discussed in the House of Commons.
('7', 113, 5, 15, 255654) The question will come up in connection with the loan of £5,000,000 requested by the Transvaal.
('7', 113, 5, 16, 255750) If this happens, we may expect to gain something.
('7', 113, 5, 17, 255800) However, no one should depend much on such support.
('7', 113, 5, 18, 255852) We should not be surprised if we are disappointed in this.
('7', 113, 5, 19, 255911) The important thing is that everything depends on our own strength.
('7', 113, 5, 20, 255979) It may be taken for certain that there is no deliverance for us before we come out of the gaol gates.
('7', 113, 6, 21, 256081) MORE AID
('7', 113, 7, 22, 256090) Mr. Motilal Diwan says in a letter that he is prepared to make a personal sacrifice to save the cause of the Transvaal Indians.
('7', 113, 7, 23, 256218) He is ready to look after the wife and children of any Indian going to gaol, and to proceed to Charlestown to receive them.
('7', 113, 7, 24, 256342) Such examples are of great help to us.

('7', 114, 8, 9, 256703) 83. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO GENERAL SMUTS
('7', 114, 9, 10, 256752) JOHANNESBURG, August 8, 1907
('7', 114, 10, 11, 256781) THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO GENERAL SMUTS PRETORIA
('7', 114, 12, 12, 256829) I have heard from more sources than one that, in the opinion of General Smuts, I am responsible for the agitation against the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, and that my action is strongly disapproved of by him.
('7', 114, 12, 13, 257036) If the imputation means that my countrymen do not resent the Act at all but that I unnecessarily inflame them, I venture to repudiate it altogether.
('7', 114, 12, 14, 257185) On the other hand, if it means that I have voiced their sentiments and that I have endeavoured, to the best of my ability, to place before them accurately what the Law means, I beg to accept the entire responsibility.
('7', 114, 12, 15, 257403) I feel that, my parents having given me a liberal education, and [I] having studied to a certain extent modern history, I should be false to myself and my country if I did less.
('7', 114, 12, 16, 257581) Relying upon past professional connection with Mr. De Villiers, I sought a private interview with him, and requested his unofficial intervention with a view to finding a solution of the difficulty.
('7', 114, 13, 17, 257779) 1 Private Secretary to the Colonial Secretary, Transvaal.
('7', 114, 13, 18, 257837) 2 Pietermaritzburg.
('7', 114, 13, 19, 257857) 3 Companionship of St. Michael and St. George.
('7', 115, 0, 1, 257904) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 115, 1, 2, 257946) promised to see General Smuts and let me know.
('7', 115, 1, 3, 257993) He did so.
('7', 115, 1, 4, 258004) I was, however, unable to see him personally again.
('7', 115, 1, 5, 258056) He left a message with his Secretary to the effect that I should approach General Smuts directly, though there was little chance of relief being granted in the direction suggested by me.
('7', 115, 1, 6, 258243) I believe that I am as anxious to serve the Government as I am to serve my countrymen and I feel that the question is one of very serious and Imperial importance.
('7', 115, 1, 7, 258406) I, therefore, venture to enclose herewith a hurriedly drawn draft amendment to the Immigration Restriction Bill.
('7', 115, 1, 8, 258519) In my humble opinion, it meets the view of the Government entirely, and it removes the stigma which, rightly or wrongly, my countrymen think attaches to them by submission to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 115, 1, 9, 258725) I have seen a cabled summary of General Smuts’ reply to the South Africa British Indian Committee.
('7', 115, 1, 10, 258824) He has been pleased to remark that co operation with the leaders of the Indian community is not possible, as they have taken up an attitude of defiance.
('7', 115, 1, 11, 258977) With deference, I must say that there is hardly any defiance about the attitude, but complete resignation to the will of the Almighty, in whose name they have sworn not to surrender their manliness and self respect, which, in their opinion, are seriously attacked by the Registration Act.
('7', 115, 1, 12, 259266) I hope that the proposal submitted herewith will be received in the spirit in which it is offered.
('7', 115, 1, 13, 259365) I have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI [Enclosure]
('7', 115, 2, 14, 259443) PROPOSAL TO MEET DIFFICULTY REGARDING ASIATIC REGISTRATION ACT It is submitted that the Immigration Restriction Bill, which can still be recalled and amended, can meet the whole difficulty, as follows: l.
('7', 115, 2, 15, 259648) In Section 1 of the Bill, to omit from “provided” to “Act”.
('7', 115, 2, 16, 259708) 2. The following addition to be made to Section 2: The term “prohibited immigrant” shall not include and mean male Asiatics falling under Clauses (a), (b), (c) and (d) hereof, notwithstanding that they cannot comply with the requirements of sub section 1: (a) Any Asiatic duly authorized to enter and reside in this Colony by a permit issued under the Indemnity and Peace
('7', 116, 0, 1, 260080) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 117

Provided that such Asiatic shall before a date to be fixed by the Colonial Secretary take out a domicile certificate as per form prescribed by regulation, and provided further that children up to the age of 16 years shall be exempt from the operation of this Clause, after attaining which they shall be obliged to take out certificates of domicile to enable them to claim the exemption before mentioned.

('7', 118, 1, 2, 264032) 85. MR. HOSKEN’S “INEVITABLE”
('7', 118, 2, 3, 264062) Mr. Hosken is known all over South Africa to be the friend of the non white races.
('7', 118, 2, 4, 264145) He is one of the few men in South Africa who have the courage of their convictions.
('7', 118, 2, 5, 264229) His exhortations to the historic Mass Meeting of Indians at Pretoria, therefore, deserve most careful attention.
('7', 118, 3, 6, 264342) Let us then analyse the doctrine he laid down, namely, that Indians as an Eastern people, should recognize and bow to the inevitable.
('7', 118, 3, 7, 264476) By the term, Mr. Hosken meant to convey that the Act, having been demanded by the white people of the Transvaal, and unanimously sanctioned by the local Parliament, was in the nature of an act of God.
('7', 118, 3, 8, 264677) We are constrained to take exception to the proposition laid down by Mr. Hosken.
('7', 118, 3, 9, 264758) The honourable gentleman admitted that he himself did not like the Act, and that he would himself, if he could, grant the Indian request.
('7', 118, 3, 10, 264896) He also admitted that “passive resistance” was a legitimate method of securing redress of a felt grievance.
('7', 118, 3, 11, 265004) On his own showing, therefore, Mr. Hosken’s contention that the Act is in the nature of an act of God falls to the ground.
('7', 118, 3, 12, 265127) We, however, go further.
('7', 118, 3, 13, 265152) No action of a human being is considered by the Eastern mind as a divine dispensation, unless it is intrinsically justifiable.
('7', 118, 3, 14, 265279) And when an Eastern submits to the apparently inevitable, there is always traceable behind such submission, not a recognition of the Divine hand, but of base selfishness.
('7', 118, 3, 15, 265450) The spirit is then willing, but the flesh is weak.
('7', 118, 3, 16, 265501) And what is it that Mr. Hosken will have the Transvaal Indians to do?
('7', 118, 3, 17, 265571) To accept the enslaving Act in order that they [may] be able to exist in that country!
('7', 118, 3, 18, 265658) In other words, Mr. Hosken, a man of God, advises Indians, for their material good, to forswear their solemn oath and their honour.
('7', 118, 3, 19, 265790) We answer, in the words of his Master, “Seek ye first the Kingdom of God and His righteousness, and everything shall be added unto you.” We believe that, in resisting the wretched Act, Indians would be seeking the “Kingdom of God”.
('7', 118, 4, 20, 266022) Mr. Hosken says the oath is not binding, because it was ill taken.
('7', 118, 4, 21, 266089) But the solemn declaration was made by Indians with due deliberation.
('7', 118, 4, 22, 266159) And it was not only for their own self respect, but for that of their dear ones and their country, that they resolved upon resisting the Act and facing imprisonment or worse.
('7', 118, 4, 23, 266334) We, therefore, trust that Mr. Hosken will, with his accustomed
('7', 119, 0, 1, 266397) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 119, 1, 2, 266439) zeal for forlorn causes, study the Asiatic question, and we promise that he will accept the whole contention of the Indian community.
('7', 119, 1, 3, 266573) He went to the meeting as a messenger of peace from the Government.
('7', 119, 1, 4, 266641) He will, we doubt not, fulfil the functions of a true mediator, if he will only understand carefully the Indian standpoint.
('7', 119, 1, 5, 266765) Indian Opinion, 10 8 1907
('7', 119, 2, 6, 266791) 86. MR. ALLY’S PROTEST 1
('7', 119, 3, 7, 266816) We commend to the attention of the Transvaal Government the letter Mr. Ally has addressed to the Press.
('7', 119, 3, 8, 266920) Mr. Ally, it will be remembered, was a delegate to wait on Lord Elgin in connection with the Asiatic Ordinance.
('7', 119, 3, 9, 267032) The Rand Daily Mail calls it a bitter protest, and so it is.
('7', 119, 3, 10, 267093) Mr. Ally’s is perhaps an extreme case, but it shows most vividly, as nothing else can show, the suffering the Act is going to cost the community.
('7', 119, 3, 11, 267239) The objection of the Indian community has been set down as mere sentiment.
('7', 119, 3, 12, 267314) Mr. Duncan, not knowing what the Act meant, was good enough to say that the Asiatic objection should be overborne, but we ask whether it is sentiment that has dictated the course adopted by Mr. Ally.
('7', 119, 3, 13, 267514) Will the Indian community be told that Mr. Ally is probably facing starvation for a foolish sentiment, or will it dawn on Lord Elgin that, after all, even though an Indian, a British subject may be entitled to personal freedom and security wherever the British flag flies?

('7', 119, 4, 15, 267813) 87. THE TRANSVAAL INDIANS
('7', 119, 5, 16, 267839) The Pietersburg notice issued by the Government is undoubtedly a feeler, and it seems that the Government are still uncertain whether the feeling of resentment against the Asiatic Act is general and permeates the masses, or whether it is confined to a few “agitators” only.
('7', 119, 5, 17, 268113) Taken in that light, the Pietersburg notice is justifiable.
('7', 119, 5, 18, 268173) The reply returned by the Pietersburg Indians should set at rest any doubt lingering in General Smuts, mind.
('7', 119, 5, 19, 268282) The Pietersburg Indians view the sending of the Registration Office to their town as an infliction to be avoided.
('7', 119, 5, 20, 268396) We congratulate them on their boldness in having sent the petition to the Government, but we must warn them, as also all other Transvaal Indians, that the struggle before them may be bitter and prolonged before they make a breach in the almost

('7', 120, 3, 7, 269136) 88. WHAT NEXT
('7', 120, 4, 8, 269150) The mass meeting 1 passed off very well.
('7', 120, 4, 9, 269191) Pretoria acted bravely.
('7', 120, 4, 10, 269215) Several days of August have passed.
('7', 120, 4, 11, 269251) No one has so far been arrested.
('7', 120, 4, 12, 269284) What will happen next?
('7', 120, 4, 13, 269307) We often hear people asking this question.
('7', 120, 4, 14, 269350) It appears that the Government has no intention of taking any steps on the basis of the Pretoria notice.
('7', 120, 4, 15, 269455) The intention of the Government appears to be to start arresting people only after all the Indians in the Transvaal have had the opportunity of taking out the title deed of slavery.
('7', 120, 4, 16, 269637) The boycott at Pietersburg is now likely to succeed.
('7', 120, 4, 17, 269690) If therefore an office is now to be opened, the probability is that it will be opened at Johannesburg, where, after the expiry of the notice period, the attack will begin.
('7', 120, 4, 18, 269862) From the reports received, it appears that the Government intends to arrest the leaders first.
('7', 120, 4, 19, 269957) Such a decision will indeed be realistic.
('7', 120, 4, 20, 269999) If the Government suspects that the new law is being opposed by the people merely because of incitement by the leaders, the suspicion can be proved baseless if the Indian community remains firm even after the leaders are arrested.

('7', 120, 6, 23, 270294) The South Africa British Indian Committee has resumed the constitutional fight.

('7', 121, 1, 4, 271264) Everything depends on the strength they show by going to gaol.

('7', 121, 3, 7, 271394) The South Africa British Indian committee wrote a letter to General Botha, to which General Smuts has sent a reply.
('7', 121, 3, 8, 271510) A telegraphic summary of the reply has appeared in The Star and other newspapers.
('7', 121, 3, 9, 271592) This reply is a month old, and hence not much weight is to be attached to it.
('7', 121, 3, 10, 271670) Since then much has happened the effects of which cannot be judged.
('7', 121, 3, 11, 271738) But the reply sent by General Smuts a month ago shows that, if he can help it, he will not permit a single Indian to remain here.
('7', 121, 3, 12, 271868) Rights in regard to ownership of land are not to be conceded, finger prints will remain necessary, and tram regulations are in the interests of Indians!
('7', 121, 3, 13, 272021) The same about railways.
('7', 121, 3, 14, 272046) What else remains?
('7', 121, 3, 15, 272065) And yet he argues that, since Indian leaders do not wish to submit to the law, he does not intend to consult them.
('7', 121, 3, 16, 272180) In other words, he knows well enough himself what needs to be done to reduce the Indian community to slavery.

('7', 122, 2, 8, 273397) 92. OUR DUTY
('7', 122, 3, 9, 273410) In the current issue we publish two letters which mention the names of those who did not close their stores on July 31. We also publish the names we have received of those in Pretoria who have made applications for the title deed of slavery.
('7', 122, 3, 10, 273652) It is with exceeding regret that we publish these, but we hold that it is not proper for us to conceal the names of defaulters at a time when a great fight is being put up.
('7', 122, 3, 11, 273825) We do not entertain any feeling of anger or ill will against any one of them.
('7', 122, 3, 12, 273903) However, we believe that by publishing the names in this manner we are rendering patriotic service.
('7', 122, 3, 13, 274003) This is a time when Indians must cultivate the utmost strength and abjure all selfishness.
('7', 122, 3, 14, 274094) Such being the case, we publish the names of weak persons, and hope that this will give strength to the others.
('7', 122, 3, 15, 274206) We shall publish any statement that the persons concerned may have to make, provided it is briefly worded.
('7', 122, 3, 16, 274313) We shall also publish letters of regret that those who realize their mistake may send us.
('7', 122, 3, 17, 274403) We only wish them well, considering that they too are our countrymen.
('7', 122, 3, 18, 274473) We expect that our readers also will have a similar feeling towards them.
('7', 122, 3, 19, 274547) Anger, malice, arrogance, selfishness, violence—all these are not only useless in our fight—they are positively harmful.
('7', 122, 4, 20, 274668) [From Gujarati]

('7', 123, 1, 2, 274992) Immigration Law.

('7', 123, 1, 4, 275101) If one does not take out such pass and does not know English, one cannot return.
('7', 123, 1, 5, 275182) In our view such a law is excessively harsh.
('7', 123, 1, 6, 275227) It is not for a free man to take out such a “ticket of leave”.
('7', 123, 1, 7, 275290) Those who have earned the right of residence in the Cape should have their pass valid for all time once they take it out.
('7', 123, 1, 8, 275412) If an Indian merchant stays away for more than a year, should it be impossible for him to return to the Cape to look after his business?
('7', 123, 1, 9, 275549) The section prescribing such a time limit should be repealed.
('7', 123, 1, 10, 275611) Moreover, a photograph is required of anyone taking out a temporary pass.
('7', 123, 1, 11, 275685) In our view, it is more disgraceful to furnish a photograph than to give finger prints.
('7', 123, 1, 12, 275773) Such regulations ought to be abolished.
('7', 123, 1, 13, 275813) Another law concerns trading licences.
('7', 123, 1, 14, 275852) In this matter one should have the right of appeal to the Supreme Court against the decision of the Licensing Officer.
('7', 123, 1, 15, 275971) Also, the obligation on the hawkers to take out separate licences for each locality should be cancelled.
('7', 123, 1, 16, 276076) Amendments should be suggested to the special regulations pertaining to foot paths and Locations now in force in East London.
('7', 123, 1, 17, 276202) Also, a move should be made to have adequate educational facilities provided for the Indian community.
('7', 123, 1, 18, 276305) We hold that votes should be cast in favour of those candidates only who furnish satisfactory answers concerning these matters, and that, in the absence of such candidates, it is a matter of honour and duty for the Indian community not to exercise the vote at all.
('7', 123, 1, 19, 276570) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 10 8 1907
('7', 123, 2, 20, 276612) 94. ESTCOURT APPEAL

('7', 123, 3, 22, 276743) It has been ruled in this appeal that the Indian community has the right to vote at Local Board elections in Estcourt.
('7', 123, 3, 23, 276862) The only question that remains is whether the petitioners own property of the requisite value.

('7', 124, 1, 2, 277418) 95. ROSS’S LETTER
('7', 124, 2, 3, 277436) Mr. Ross, the General Manager of the Natal Railways, has sent a blunt refusal to the Indian community.
('7', 124, 2, 4, 277539) We congratulate the community on receiving such a letter.
('7', 124, 2, 5, 277597) For, the more they insult our religions and the more they despise the colour of our skin, the stronger will be our fight, provided we are in the right.
('7', 124, 2, 6, 277749) A letter such as Mr. Ross’s shows to what a miserable plight we have been reduced in South Africa.
('7', 124, 2, 7, 277848) If we do not get our reasonable rights, we shall feel crushed by our own wealth.
('7', 124, 2, 8, 277929) To a sensible man, money without honour is like a thorn.
('7', 124, 2, 9, 277986) In the Sahara Desert, anyone with goldbars in his pocket will find them like poison if he can get no drop of water anywhere.
('7', 124, 2, 10, 278111) Similarly, in this country money without self respect is likely to be veritable poison.
('7', 124, 2, 11, 278199) We see no need just at present to take any steps on the letter of Mr. Ross.
('7', 124, 2, 12, 278275) According to us, the solution of such problems depends on the outcome of the Transvaal struggle.
('7', 124, 2, 13, 278372) If we beg for them often enough, our Moulvis and Christian and Hindu priests may probably get concession tickets at half rates.
('7', 124, 2, 14, 278500) However, it is not a material question whether concession tickets are available or not.
('7', 124, 2, 15, 278588) The real point is that, in the eyes of the whites, we are persons of no consequence and it is precisely this that causes all the mischief.
('7', 124, 2, 16, 278727) In order that we may count [in their eyes], the only course for the Transvaal Indians is to fight desperately to the last—even unto death—and win glory.
('7', 124, 2, 17, 278880) We shall then be the equals of those who have votes, though actually we may have none.

('7', 128, 1, 2, 285617) 102. LETTER TO “RAND DAILY MAIL”
('7', 128, 2, 3, 285650) JOHANNESBURG, August 12, 1907
('7', 128, 3, 4, 285680) TO THE EDITOR [RAND DAILY MAIL]
('7', 128, 5, 5, 285712) You have commenced your special article on the Asiatic Act with the inflammatory heading, “Indians Will Not Pay Debts”.
('7', 128, 5, 6, 285832) The restrained language in this article shows that it is not ill meant.
('7', 128, 5, 7, 285904) At thesame time, it would certainly have been better and more serviceable to your readers if you had refrained from giving currency to what appears to be a fiction, until you had seen the leaders of the British Indian community, whose opinion, evidently, you did not know.
('7', 128, 5, 8, 286177) I may now be allowed to state that there is not, so far as I am aware, a single Indian of standing who has ever made a statement to the effect that every Indian “who is thrown into prison for passive resistance or loses his trading or hawking licence shall refuse to pay his debts”.
('7', 128, 5, 9, 286460) This would be quite contrary to the spirit of our struggle.
('7', 128, 5, 10, 286520) We have undertaken it with a view to suffering ourselves, placing our sole reliance upon God.
('7', 128, 5, 11, 286614) It would, therefore, be wicked if we were to cherish the thought and to repudiate our just debts.
('7', 128, 5, 12, 286712) It is our belief, whether we be Mahomedans or Hindus, that all debts that are not paid in our present life will have to be liquidated with severe penalty in our next.
('7', 128, 5, 13, 286879) On the great Judgment Day, we shall have to answer for our delinquencies, non payment of debts not being the least of them.
('7', 128, 5, 14, 287003) We do want to exert pressure from every side.
('7', 128, 5, 15, 287049) We undoubtedly want Imperial protection no less than the sympathy of the Colonists and even the Government, but we have no desire to do so by means that cannot be called scrupulously clean and honest.
('7', 128, 5, 16, 287250) Our one and only weapon of defence against what we consider to be an unwarrantable attack on our personal freedom and honour is to show the people of South Africa and the citizens of the great Empire, of which we claim to be members equally with the whites, that we are men enough to suffer for what we conscientiously believe to be a great wrong.
('7', 128, 5, 17, 287598) I have seen as many of my fellow merchants as I hurriedly could.
('7', 128, 5, 18, 287663) They are Messrs M. C. Camroodeen and Co., M. S. Coovadia,
('7', 129, 0, 1, 287721) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 129, 1, 2, 287763) M. A. Karodia, A. F. Camay and Co., Amod Moosajee and Co., M. P. Fancy, Mahomed Oosen and Co., and Jussab Ebrahim, and between us we have paid, during the last month and up to today, roughly speaking, £18,000 to the European wholesale houses whether here or in London.
('7', 129, 1, 3, 288032) Some of us, in order to prepare for contingencies, have even paid our debts before maturity.
('7', 129, 1, 4, 288125) It is true that many of us have cancelled orders in view of the struggle.
('7', 129, 1, 5, 288199) This is only fair to the wholesale houses and to ourselves.
('7', 129, 1, 6, 288259) We are sorry that, by our so doing, the latter have to suffer in common with us, but that is inevitable.
('7', 129, 1, 7, 288364) I AM, ETC., ESSOP ISMAIL MIA,
('7', 129, 2, 8, 288394) MANAGING PARTNER OF SULIMAN ISMAIL MIA AND CO., AND ACTING CHAIRMAN,
('7', 129, 3, 9, 288463) BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Rand Daily Mail, 13 8 1907

('7', 130, 1, 2, 289856) Colony.

('7', 130, 1, 4, 289991) So far as I am in a position to advise my countrymen, it is not possible for me, be the consequences what they may, to tell them to deviate from such a deliberate declaration, and, if, even at the eleventh hour, it is possible for General Smuts to respect that declaration without infringing upon the scope of the Act, I venture to request his sympathy and assistance.

('7', 130, 6, 11, 291276) 104. IMPLICATIONS OF INDIAN OFFER
('7', 130, 7, 12, 291310) The Permit Office has been perambulating in the Transvaal.
('7', 130, 7, 13, 291369) Like touts, officers move from house to house trying to mislead the people and persuading them to take out the registers according to the new law.
('7', 130, 7, 14, 291516) Moreover, they cross examine people to know what our demands are.
('7', 130, 7, 15, 291582) It is therefore necessary for every Indian to know what voluntary registration means.
('7', 130, 7, 16, 291668) We are glad to see that the common people are being thus put to the test.
('7', 130, 7, 17, 291742) The new law is such that it is necessary for every Indian to know clearly what it means and judge it independently for himself.
('7', 130, 7, 18, 291870) It is not surprising that the people are
('7', 130, 8, 19, 291911) 1 This appeared in Indian Opinion, 24 8 1907; vide “Letter to Indian Opinion”,17 8 1907
('7', 131, 0, 1, 291999) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 131, 1, 2, 292041) being tested.
('7', 131, 1, 3, 292055) If we fail to give proper replies, that will, no doubt, be surprising.
('7', 131, 1, 4, 292126) Let us therefore consider the implications of voluntary registration.
('7', 131, 1, 5, 292196) In so far as the law is concerned, the Government can compel people to take out new registers.
('7', 131, 1, 6, 292291) Not only that; it can also insist on their being renewed from time to time.
('7', 131, 1, 7, 292367) Moreover, people may be required to give their finger prints at any time.
('7', 131, 1, 8, 292441) Children’s finger prints may also be demanded.
('7', 131, 1, 9, 292488) Finger prints may be required at the time of taking out a licence.
('7', 131, 1, 10, 292555) Briefly, the Government has been empo wered to enforce all the obnoxious provisions of the new law and of the Regulations made under it.
('7', 131, 1, 11, 292692) This is not acceptable to us.
('7', 131, 1, 12, 292722) Instead, we say that we are willing, with a view to removing the suspicion of the Government, to exchange our present permits for new ones.
('7', 131, 1, 13, 292862) The new law should not apply to those who get their permits voluntarily exchanged in this manner.
('7', 131, 1, 14, 292960) None of its provisions should apply to us.
('7', 131, 1, 15, 293003) That is, we should not be required to give finger prints at any and every stage.
('7', 131, 1, 16, 293084) If every Indian thus voluntarily takes out the new register, the obnoxious law will be altogether nullified.
('7', 131, 1, 17, 293193) It will apply only to an Indian who, through inadvertence or on purpose, fails to get his permit exchanged.
('7', 131, 1, 18, 293301) There is thus a very great difference between our demand and the law of the Government.
('7', 131, 1, 19, 293389) To submit to the Government law is like riding an ass.
('7', 131, 1, 20, 293444) If the Indiancommunity does so, it will invite public ridicule.
('7', 131, 1, 21, 293508) Our demand means riding an elephant and will bring us honour and regal dignity.
('7', 131, 1, 22, 293588) Apart from this demand, some gentlemen from Pretoria have, through a lawyer, addressed a letter to Mr. Smuts which we may now consider.
('7', 131, 1, 23, 293724) They have placed before Mr. Smuts a demand for some amendments to the law.
('7', 131, 1, 24, 293799) We think this is only trifling with the problem.
('7', 131, 1, 25, 293848) If one is suffering from fistula but treats it as an ordinary abscess, some external application may bring about a superficial healing.
('7', 131, 1, 26, 293984) And so it happens, sometimes, that a person suffering from fistula believes that he has been radically cured of the disease, but in fact the disease is active under the surface that has healed up.
('7', 131, 1, 27, 294181) The deluded patient is shocked to find in a few days a fresh abscess appearing at another place.
('7', 131, 1, 28, 294278) As long as he does not take the treatment for fistula, abscesses go on appearing and subsiding.
('7', 131, 1, 29, 294374) Similar, we think, is the case with the letter referred to above.
('7', 131, 1, 30, 294440) The new law, which is like fistula, cannot be treated by a letter which asks for the deletion of two or three things.
('7', 131, 1, 31, 294558) It is only a palliative and in the long run will do harm.
('7', 131, 1, 32, 294616) Every Indian should realize that there is no effective treatment for this fistula like law other than a major Operation with the surgical knife.
('7', 131, 1, 33, 294761) Hence, whenever questions are asked regarding the new law, we have to state categorically that our demand is nothing short of the repeal of the
('7', 132, 0, 1, 294905) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 133
('7', 132, 1, 2, 294950) entire law.
('7', 132, 1, 3, 294962) To show that, in case the law is repealed, we have no intention of sheltering liars, we are willing to take out voluntary registers.
('7', 132, 1, 4, 295095) But after they are taken out, we do not want the constant pinpricks of the law.
('7', 132, 1, 5, 295175) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 17 8 1907
('7', 132, 2, 6, 295217) 105. CONGRATULATIONS TO PIETERSBURG
('7', 132, 3, 7, 295253) Pretoria put up a good show.
('7', 132, 3, 8, 295282) But Pietersburg was beyond praise.
('7', 132, 3, 9, 295317) Not a single black sheep was found there.
('7', 132, 3, 10, 295359) The boycott of the Permit Office proved one hundred per cent successful.
('7', 132, 3, 11, 295432) The Permit Office was sent back as hungry as it had come.
('7', 132, 3, 12, 295490) Moreover, to prevent that spectre from having a foothold in Pietersburg, they had sent a petition to the Government in advance, stating that they did not want that office there.
('7', 132, 3, 13, 295668) No town can do more than this.
('7', 132, 3, 14, 295699) No town should do less.
('7', 132, 3, 15, 295723) It does not in the least detract from the honour of Pietersburg that permits were forced on two prisoners.

('7', 132, 3, 18, 295971) In like manner, the officers of the murderous Act, deprived of their prey, behaved like starving men by forcing permits on prisoners; it can be seen from this that there isno self respect in the new permits, only humiliation.

('7', 133, 2, 16, 298548) 107. WARNING TO NATAL MERCHANTS
('7', 133, 3, 17, 298580) The Natal Government Gazette has published a Bill which, if passed, will require every merchant intending to sell his business or shop to give a fortnight’s notice through the Gazette and a local newspaper.
('7', 133, 3, 18, 298787) A similar notice will also have to be published by anyone desiring to take out a new licence.
('7', 133, 3, 19, 298881) Both these provisions are harsh, but it will not be possible for the Indian community to oppose them as they apply to all.
('7', 133, 3, 20, 299004) The same Bill also includes another provision to the effect that, unless a special contract exists, it will not be competent for a court of law to allow more than eight per cent interest on time barred debts.
('7', 133, 3, 21, 299213) A contract will not be nullified on the ground that the merchant concerned has charged exorbitantly for a particular commodity.
('7', 133, 3, 22, 299341) This is an official Bill and is likely to be passed.

('7', 135, 4, 20, 302982) 111. ACT TO PREVENT JUVENILE SMOKING
('7', 135, 5, 21, 303019) This Act was recently passed by the Natal Parliament.
('7', 135, 5, 22, 303073) We give below the substance of each section.
('7', 135, 5, 23, 303118) (1) It will be unlawful for any person under 16 years of age to smoke tobacco, a cigar, or a cigarette.
('7', 135, 5, 24, 303222) If any tobacco, tobacco pipe, cigar, cigarette or cigarette holder is found [on such person], a white police officer may take possession of the same and hand it over to the Government.
('7', 135, 5, 25, 303407) (2) If any school going boy is found with a cigarette or any of the other things mentioned above, the school teacher shall take them away and hand them over to the guardian of the boy.
('7', 135, 5, 26, 303592) If any students are found smoking tobacco, they will be considered guilty of breach of school discipline and will be liable to be punished accordingly.
('7', 135, 5, 27, 303744) (3) No one should supply or sell tobacco, a cigar or a cigarette to a person under 16 years of age without a note from parents, the guardian or the employer.
('7', 135, 5, 28, 303902) The note or order should state that the
('7', 136, 0, 1, 303942) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 137
('7', 136, 1, 2, 303987) cigarette, etc., is for the use of a person above 16 years of age and that it will be delivered into the hands of the signatory.
('7', 136, 1, 3, 304116) It will be unlawful to supply or sell cigarettes, etc., to a person under 16 years of age in the absence of such a note.
('7', 136, 1, 4, 304237) Anyone violating this section will be liable to be punished with a fine up to £5 or imprisonment extending to one month for every offence.
('7', 136, 1, 5, 304376) (4) Any person, not being a parent or guardian or employer, who sends a person under 16 years of age to buy cigarettes, etc., will be liable to be punished with a fine up to £5 or imprisonment extending to one month.
('7', 136, 1, 6, 304593) (5) If in connection with this Act there arises any doubt regarding the age of a person, the apparent age of such person as determined by the court will be taken as correct in the absence of satisfactory evidence to the contrary.
('7', 136, 1, 7, 304823) (6) This Act will be known as the Prevention of Smoking Act of 1907. [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 17 8 1907

('7', 140, 1, 3, 313165) The responsibility to be borne by the community will therefore be limited.
('7', 140, 1, 4, 313240) It will not happen that all the men in an establishment or a locality are arrested at the same time.
('7', 140, 1, 5, 313341) If this assumption is right, the families and property of those who are arrested will be looked after by their friends and relatives.
('7', 140, 1, 6, 313475) We know that this is what happens when a person is arrested under some other law.
('7', 140, 1, 7, 313557) However, that is not enough.
('7', 140, 1, 8, 313586) The Association will indeed look after the affairs of anyone arrested for defying the new law.
('7', 140, 1, 9, 313681) Where his family lives, what its condition is, and whether there is anyone to look after it—the Association will make all these inquiries.
('7', 140, 1, 10, 313820) In case the family is poor, arrangements for its maintenance will be made.
('7', 140, 1, 11, 313895) In other words, the man arrested under the new law stands the chance of double aid: his shop and family will be looked after to his satisfaction, and if the occasion requires it, he will have the benefit of the donations that may be received as a result of the offers made by brave men like Mr. Parsee Rustomjee.

('7', 141, 3, 4, 315984) Having been asked at the Permit Office to give his finger prints, Bakhtawar, an Indian from Calcutta, refused to comply.
('7', 141, 3, 5, 316105) Then he was asked to apply under the new law.
('7', 141, 3, 6, 316151) This too he refused to do.
('7', 141, 3, 7, 316178) Every Indian ought to have such courage.
('7', 141, 4, 8, 316219) EFFORTS IN LONDON
('7', 141, 5, 9, 316237) A vigorous agitation is being carried on in London against the obnoxious law.
('7', 141, 5, 10, 316315) Questions are constantly being asked by many Members [in Parliament].
('7', 141, 5, 11, 316385) In reply to one question, Mr. Churchill said that the Imperial Government could not interfere with the implementation of the law.
('7', 141, 5, 12, 316515) I find that people have been a little scared by such a reply.
('7', 141, 5, 13, 316577) But there is no reason for being scared.
('7', 141, 5, 14, 316618) For, in the first place, we are relying on our own courage in carrying on the fight.
('7', 141, 5, 15, 316703) Whether the Imperial Government intervenes or not, we shall not do what we believe to be evil.
('7', 141, 5, 16, 316798) In the second place, though the Government may not interfere with the enactment of the law, it cannot but do so if the law results in oppression.
('7', 141, 5, 17, 316944) If it does not, its prestige will be lost and ultimately the British Empire will come to an end.
('7', 141, 5, 18, 317041) The only interpretation I can put on Mr. Churchill’s reply is that, whatever his public utterances, it will be impossible for him to avoid intervention at the right time.
('7', 141, 5, 19, 317212) That right time will come after we go to gaol.
('7', 141, 6, 20, 317259) NEED FOR CAUTION The case against Mr. Suleman Wadi of Krugersdorp for selling liquor to a Native was heard on Wednesday.
('7', 141, 6, 21, 317380) Two white and two Native detectives deposed that he had sold half a bottle of liquor.
('7', 141, 6, 22, 317466) Mr. Stegmann and Mr. Gandhi appeared on his behalf.
('7', 141, 6, 23, 317518) They tried hard.
('7', 141, 6, 24, 317535) It was said in evidence that the sale of liquor was against religion.
('7', 141, 6, 25, 317605) The bank accountant and other whites deposed in their evidence that Mr. Wadi was a very respectable person.
('7', 141, 6, 26, 317713) The fact appears to be that the case against Mr. Wadi has been concocted and that he is innocent.
('7', 141, 6, 27, 317811) However, the magistrate found him guilty and sentenced him to six months’ imprisonment.
('7', 141, 6, 28, 317899) Mr. Wadi has gone in appeal.
('7', 141, 6, 29, 317928) The result cannot be predicted.
('7', 141, 6, 30, 317960) But every Indian has to be cautious.
('7', 141, 6, 31, 317997) The whites as well as the Natives will not be afraid of trapping other people to serve their own interest.
('7', 141, 6, 32, 318104) As Mr. Wadi is innocent, he has nothing to be ashamed of.
('7', 141, 6, 33, 318162) Shame lies not in being gaoled, but in committing a crime.
('7', 141, 6, 34, 318221) It is true that he has been put to unnecessary expense and that people not knowing the facts may think ill of him.
('7', 141, 6, 35, 318336) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 17 8 1907

('7', 142, 1, 2, 318423) 113. LETTER TO “INDIAN OPINION”
('7', 142, 2, 3, 318455) JOHANNESBURG, August 17, 1907
('7', 142, 3, 4, 318485) THE EDITOR INDIAN OPINION
('7', 142, 4, 5, 318511) SIR, I beg to enclose herewith for publication copy of the correspondence 1 that has passed between General Smuts and myself regarding the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 142, 4, 6, 318677) The question, in my humble opinion, has assumed more than parochial importance.
('7', 142, 4, 7, 318757) Up to the last moment, I shall continue to believe that the humanity of the Colonists will get the upper hand of their prejudice and that, if my countrymen undergo the suffering they seem to have resolved upon doing, the justice of their claims will be recognised.
('7', 142, 4, 8, 319022) But, whether this is so or not, I can only give one advice, and that is to prefer fearlessly the fulfilment of their solemn declaration to serving their self interest.
('7', 142, 4, 9, 319190) It is, therefore, necessary that my countrymen should know the emphatic warning 2 given by General Smuts in his letter.
('7', 142, 4, 10, 319310) It is also, perhaps, necessary for the public, in whose name the Act has been passedand is being administered, to know that the alternative I have humbly ventured to offer completely meets the difficulty.
('7', 142, 4, 11, 319515) It identifies every Asiatic resident in the Colony and, unlike the Asiatic Act, it determines once for all the number of Asiatics who (except those few who may be able to take advantage of the educational clause of the Immigration Bill) will be entitled to remain in the Colony.
('7', 142, 4, 12, 319794) The bedrock question, therefore, so far as I am in a position to see, is not one of finger prints or other details, but it is, broadly, whether the Government should at all meet Indian sentiment, unrepresented though Indians are at the polls, or whether, if the Government do not, Indians, to be true to their God and themselves, will sacrifice all.
('7', 142, 5, 13, 320144) I am, etc.,
('7', 142, 6, 14, 320156) M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 24 8 1907

('7', 143, 3, 4, 320447) TO THE EDITOR THE STAR [JOHANNESBURG]
('7', 143, 4, 5, 320485) SIR, In honouring by a leaderette what you please to call my “scheme” 2 with reference to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, you have done it and me less than justice by studying it superficially.
('7', 143, 4, 6, 320678) By admitting the clauses, as per my draft, into the Immigration Bill, the Government get the legal right to recall every permit and, in place thereof, to issue certificates of domicile to every bona fide Asiatic resident of the Transvaal.
('7', 143, 4, 7, 320917) What form such certificates should take has, if you will re read my draft, been left to the Government to fix by regulation.
('7', 143, 4, 8, 321042) The question, therefore, of finger prints is not made an issue at all nor, so far as I am concerned, has it ever been a fundamental point, the main objection being against the compulsion and the odour of criminality about the Act.
('7', 143, 4, 9, 321273) The draft submitted by me would enable the Government to ascertain the exact number of Asiatics entitled to claim domiciliary rights in the Colony andsuch Asiatics would be completely identified.
('7', 143, 4, 10, 321469) What the draft does leave out are the elaborate machinery and the penalties provided in the Asiatic Registration Act, and it leaves children under the age of 16 free from molestation, and avoids the pin prick inspection, with the power to take, at every street corner, identification particulars contemplated by the Registration Act.
('7', 143, 4, 11, 321803) But I submit that any surreptitious entry on the part of children is completely checked by reason of the provision that, on attaining the age of 16 years, they must also take out certificates of domicile, and by stating on the certificates of domicile the number of children under 16 years.
('7', 143, 4, 12, 322094) But, if my scheme be considered faulty, the principle of embodying identification legislation in the Immigration
('7', 143, 5, 13, 322207) 1 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 24 8 1907. 2 The reference is to the proposal submitted with “Letter to Private Secretary to General Smuts”, 8 8 1907

('7', 144, 1, 2, 322411) Bill can hardly be so considered, and any defects that I may have overlooked can be remedied.
('7', 144, 1, 3, 322505) The question, therefore, still remains whether the public will take sufficient interest in the welfare of Indian subjects of His Majesty to seriously study the alternative proposed.
('7', 144, 1, 4, 322687) With reference to the other portion of your leaderette 1, I can only say that, if an honourable status be [not] 2 guaranteed to my countrymen, no matter how humble they may be, imprisonment, deportation, and any other similar calamity would be comparatively a boon as against a surrender of their self respect and a reversal of their solemn declaration.
('7', 144, 1, 5, 323041) Of one thing I can give an emphatic assurance, namely, that there is not a single Indian who does not dislike the Act from the bottom of his heart.
('7', 144, 1, 6, 323189) I know most of those who have accepted registration under the Act in Pretoria, and I know this that they admit having committed a crime against their nationality and their God, but they have done so because, in their own words, they prized their pockets more than their honour.

('7', 145, 1, 2, 324678) the Transvaal, hereby bring to your notice the state to which Mahomedan Indians will be reduced under the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 145, 1, 3, 324811) We presume that you have acquainted yourself with the principal objections to the Act.

('7', 145, 1, 5, 324977) It is the section which applies the Act to Turkish Mahomedans, whereas it exempts Turkish Christians and Jews.

('7', 145, 3, 8, 325435) We may state that, fortunately, in South Africa, there is no antipathy between Mahomedans and Hindus.
('7', 145, 3, 9, 325537) We all live together in peace and friendship as Indians, and associate together with freedom and carry on a joint battle against prejudice and oppression against us.
('7', 145, 3, 10, 325703) If, therefore, we lay stress upon the grievance as it affects us, we do so only in order to draw the attention of Mahomedans all over India to our precarious position, in order that we secure your most active assistance in our struggle.
('7', 145, 3, 11, 325940) And we venture to ask you, as Mahomedans and Indians, to extend to us your sympathy by pleading our case before the Government and in any other manner you may consider desirable.
('7', 145, 3, 12, 326119) Whilst we are receiving much help from England, even the white Colonists who sympathise with us ask what India, our Motherland, is doing for us.

('7', 146, 1, 2, 326536) 116. LETTER TO “THE STAR” 1
('7', 146, 2, 3, 326564) JOHANNESBURG, August 20, 1907
('7', 146, 3, 4, 326594) TO THE EDITOR THE STAR [JOHANNESBURG]
('7', 146, 4, 5, 326632) SIR, I am obliged once more reluctantly to trespass upon your courtesy.
('7', 146, 4, 6, 326704) May I say that you have still not fully read the draft 2?
('7', 146, 4, 7, 326762) What I have suggested is not a repeal of some of the provisions of the Asiatic Act, and thus having a little of that and more of the Immigration Bill, but a total repeal of the former, holding, as I do, that my proposal gives everything to the Colonists without giving serious offence to my countrymen.
('7', 146, 4, 8, 327065) It is not possible for me to burden you with long extracts from what has been written by my fellow workers and myself to show that, though the question of finger prints has always been treated as a very serious incident in a highly objectionable Act, it has never been as one of paramount importance per se, except when it was intended to operate as a compulsory requirement.
('7', 146, 4, 9, 327441) You will further easily recollect the fact that we voluntarily attached finger prints to the permits that were issued under Lord Milner’s advice.
('7', 146, 4, 10, 327587) 3 Then it was a matter of doing it voluntarily and then, too, of giving [impression of] only one thumb.
('7', 146, 4, 11, 327691) In the Asiatic Act, it is a question of giving ten finger prints, and that, also, not once but as often as the authorities wish to exact them.
('7', 146, 4, 12, 327834) Even if I advised my countrymen to give ten finger prints voluntarily, I feel my advice will be summarily rejected.
('7', 146, 4, 13, 327950) I need not, however, go further.
('7', 146, 4, 14, 327983) I am sorry that the Indian side of the question cannot yet be studied seriously and dispassionately.
('7', 146, 4, 15, 328084) My countrymen can only say that, though the whole of the white Transvaal be against us, God is still with us.
('7', 146, 5, 16, 328194) I am, etc.,
('7', 146, 6, 17, 328206) M. K. GANDHI The Star, 21 8 1907

('7', 147, 7, 6, 328572) In the leaderette with which you have honoured my proposal submitted to General Smuts, you advise the Asiatic population to “think better of a resolve made in a moment of enthusiasm and probably without a full realisation of the seriousness of offering organised resistance to the law in a country with a large semi savage native population”.
('7', 147, 7, 7, 328915) It is strange that you should consider a resolve adhered to for the last ten months as one “made in a moment of enthusiasm”.
('7', 147, 8, 8, 329040) The reason, however, that I write these few lines is to ascertain whether it is possible for you to inform the public as to the connection between the “seriousness of offering organised resistance to the law” and a “large semi savage native population”.
('7', 147, 8, 9, 329294) I wonder whether that population is to be set upon British Indians because they cannot bring themselves to accept a law whose effect is to unman them!
