('7', 147, 11, 12, 329470) Rand Daily Mail, 22 8 1907
('7', 148, 0, 1, 329497) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 149
('7', 148, 1, 2, 329542) 118. PETITION TO SECRETARY OF STATE FOR COLONIES 1
('7', 148, 2, 3, 329593) P. O. BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, August 23, 1907
('7', 148, 3, 4, 329639) TO THE RIGHT HON’BLE THE SECRETARY OF STATE
('7', 148, 4, 5, 329683) FOR THE COLONIES LONDON
('7', 148, 5, 6, 329707) THE PETITION OF THE CHAIRMAN OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION OF THE TRANSVAAL
('7', 148, 6, 7, 329787) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT: The Committee of the British Indian Association of the Trans vaal respectfully approaches His Majesty’s Government regarding the Immigrants’ Restriction Bill passed by the Transvaal Parliament.
('7', 148, 6, 8, 330002) The said Committee humbly approached both Houses of the said Parliament with respect to the measure, as will more fully appear on reference to copies of the petitions 2 presented to the said Houses and annexed hereto, marked A and B. The said Committee respectfully submits that the said Bill is open to objection on the following grounds, in that: (1) It gives permanence to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 148, 6, 9, 330409) (2) It disregards the right of residence of those British Indians who settled in the Transvaal before the war and, in many cases, even paid £3 as the price of their residence in virtue of Law 3 of 1885, but who have not been able to return to the Transvaal either because they, having applied, have not received permits to return, or because they have not yet applied for such permits under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 148, 6, 10, 330834) (3) It does not recognise any of the Indian languages as part of the educational test required by the Bill.
('7', 148, 6, 11, 330942) (4) Sub section 4 of Section 2 3 of the Bill requires even Indians
('7', 148, 7, 12, 331009) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 31 8 1907 and a Gujarati version of it in the issue of 24 8 1907. 2 Vide “Petition to Transvaal Legislative Assembly”, 9 7 1907 and “Petition to Transvaal Legislative Council”, 22 7 1907 3 Vide Appendix C to the petition, 23 8 1907
('7', 149, 0, 1, 331281) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 149, 1, 2, 331323) who may pass the education test prescribed by the Bill to be subject to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 149, 1, 3, 331426) (5) It makes no provision for facilities to the Indian merchants already settled in the Transvaal for temporarily importing confidential clerks and assistants or domestic servants.
('7', 149, 1, 4, 331607) (6) Sub section C of Section 6 of the Bill gives the power for physical and forcible deportation of those affected by the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 149, 2, 5, 331756) ARGUMENT ON THE ABOVE
('7', 149, 3, 6, 331778) The said Committee would now crave leave to discuss seriatim the aforementioned grounds of objection.
('7', 149, 4, 7, 331880) FIRST GROUND
('7', 149, 5, 8, 331893) As His Majesty’s Government is aware, the Asiatic Law Amendment Act continues to cause the greatest irritation to the British Indian community residing in the Transvaal.
('7', 149, 5, 9, 332063) Its provisions are felt to be so insulting and injurious to the self respect of that community, that many of its members, rather than accept registration under it, are prepared humbly to suffer the penalty of non registration, even at the risk of losing all their worldly prospects.
('7', 149, 5, 10, 332346) The measure, when it was first introduced, was meant to be of a temporary nature, and was resorted to in order not to anticipate the verdict of a popularly elected Assembly on Asiatic Immigration, and in the absence of any other law like the Bill under discussion.
('7', 149, 5, 11, 332611) The very first section of the Bill renders the Asiatic Law Amendment Act permanent, and retains the provisions also of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, in so far as they may be necessary for the administration of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 149, 6, 12, 332856) SECOND GROUND
('7', 149, 7, 13, 332870) It is common knowledge that many British Indians who left the Transvaal at the outbreak of hostilities have not yet returned to the country of their adoption.
('7', 149, 7, 14, 333029) Many of them paid £3 to the old Dutch Government for the purpose of settling in the country.
('7', 149, 7, 15, 333122) Owing to the serious obstacles placed in the way of their getting permits under the Peace Preservation Ordinance—although European aliens received them practically for the asking—they have not yet been able to return to the Transvaal.
('7', 149, 7, 16, 333357) Some of them have not even applied.
('7', 149, 7, 17, 333393) These refugees would, under the Bill, become prohibited immigrants for want of knowledge of some European language.
('7', 149, 7, 18, 333509) The prohibition will operate very harshly against deserving British subjects possessing vested rights.
('7', 149, 7, 19, 333612) In thus cancelling the right of domicile, the Bill goes further than similar legislation in [the] Cape Colony.
('7', 150, 0, 1, 333723) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 151
('7', 150, 1, 2, 333768) THIRD GROUND
('7', 150, 2, 3, 333781) In refusing to recognise Indian languages, the Bill draws an invidious and unjustifiable distinction.
('7', 150, 3, 4, 333883) FOURTH GROUND
('7', 150, 4, 5, 333897) In the humble opinion of the said Committee, Sub section 4 of Section 2 is very vague and difficult of interpretation.
('7', 150, 4, 6, 334016) It is, however, evident that it aims, amongst other things, at Indians of attainments.
('7', 150, 4, 7, 334103) By requiring them to comply with the terms of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, it takes away with the other hand what it gives with the one, for it is hardly conceivable that any Indian, having received a liberal education, will ever accept the terms of that Act.
('7', 150, 4, 8, 334365) Nor is it possible to see any reason for subjecting such Indians to the Act, whose object is to identify Indian residents in the Transvaal, for such Indians, by reason of their knowledge of a European language, carry on their own persons marks of identification.
('7', 150, 4, 9, 334628) The Asiatic Law Amendment Act is supposed to be necessary because of the illiteracy of the majority of Asiatics residing in the Colony.
('7', 150, 4, 10, 334764) To require educated Indians to comply with the Act is, in the humble opinion of the said Committee, a wanton insult, and an indirect mode of depriving Indians of the benefit of the educational clause of the Bill.
('7', 150, 5, 11, 334977) FIFTH GROUND
('7', 150, 6, 12, 334990) It cannot be denied that want of facilities to Indians entitled to reside in the Transvaal to import temporary assistance would be a serious grievance.
('7', 150, 7, 13, 335142) SIXTH GROUND
('7', 150, 8, 14, 335155) Sub section (c) of Section 6 did not appear in the original draft.
('7', 150, 8, 15, 335222) As has been pointed out above, Indians in the Transvaal at carrying on a life and death struggle in respect of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 150, 8, 16, 335364) It is surmised that thousands of Indians are prepared to suffer the hardships of imprisonment rather than submit to the said Act.
('7', 150, 8, 17, 335494) To many the Transvaal is their home, where they earn an honest livelihood.
('7', 150, 8, 18, 335569) For them to be turned out of the country is to make them, perhaps, face starvation, certainly to ruin their prospects in life.
('7', 150, 8, 19, 335696) Whilst the Asiatic Law Amendment Act provides for a notice of removal from the Colony for failure to take out the registration certificate required to be taken out by the Act, disregard of such notice renders the delinquent liable to be imprisoned.
('7', 150, 8, 20, 335945) Sub section (c) above referred to gives the local Government power to physically and forcibly deport at his own expense any person disregarding notice of removal under
('7', 151, 0, 1, 336113) 152 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 151, 1, 2, 336155) the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 151, 1, 3, 336186) Thus, it is humbly submitted that the sub section in question is not only a cruel provision in itself, but it is also extremely unfair, in that it indirectly amends the Asiatic Law Amendment Act very greatly to the disadvantage of those affected by it.
('7', 151, 1, 4, 336439) The said Committee feels sure that, had such an amendment been made in the Act itself, it would not have received the Royal sanction.
('7', 151, 1, 5, 336573) The said Committee, therefore, trusts that the method adopted under the said sub section to take extraordinary powers under the said Act will be considered by His Majesty’s Government to be much more objectionable.
('7', 151, 1, 6, 336788) Moreover, the effect of forcible deportation would amount to a confiscation of the property of the deported, and there seems to be no place provided to deport persons to.
('7', 151, 1, 7, 336959) The Cape and Natal will not receive such persons.
('7', 151, 1, 8, 337009) These would, therefore, be forcibly sent back to India to face starvation.
('7', 151, 1, 9, 337084) This deportation for a venial offence (if it be an offence at all) will, therefore, be much worse than deportation for heinous offences, for, in the latter, the persons condemned are at least housed and fed.
('7', 151, 2, 10, 337292) GENERAL REMARKS
('7', 151, 3, 11, 337308) The said Committee is humbly of opinion that, since the British occupation of the country, His Majesty’s Government have neglected or disregarded the interests of British Indians, as being the weaker party, in deference to the clamours of interested persons, because they happened to be strong, and this in despite of repeated promises and assurances made and given to the Indians.
('7', 151, 3, 12, 337690) The said Committee, moreover, respectfully draws the attention of His Majesty’s Government to the fact that Indians are totally unrepresented in the House of Assembly, that not a word was said by any member thereof in favour of the petition presented on its behalf to that Honourable House, and that a similar fate overtook a similar petition presented to the Honourable the Legislative Council, although that Honourable House has been constituted for, among other things, the protection of interests not represented in the Lower and Elected House.
('7', 151, 3, 13, 338239) Under the circumstances, the said Committee respectfully submits that British Indians have a right to receive special protection from His Majesty’s Government as the central power in the Empire.
('7', 151, 5, 14, 338434) The said Committee, therefore, respectfully prays that the said Bill may be disallowed and that the good offices of His Majesty’s
('7', 152, 0, 1, 338564) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 153
('7', 152, 1, 2, 338609) Government be used to secure such an amendment of the Bill as to relieve the present tension adversely affecting Indian subjects of His Majesty the King Emperor owing to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 152, 1, 3, 338810) But, if His Majesty’s Government find it impossible to secure relief for the community represented by the said Committee, in its humble opinion, it were better for them and for the sake of peace within the Empire that Indian subjects of the Crown were withdrawn from the Transvaal and fully compensated for dispossession of vested and acquired rights, either from the local or the Imperial Exchequer.
('7', 152, 1, 4, 339211) And for this act of justice and mercy, the petitioner shall as in duty bound for ever pray, etc.
('7', 152, 2, 5, 339308) [I have, etc.,]
('7', 152, 3, 6, 339324) ESSOP ISMAIL MIA, CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('7', 152, 4, 7, 339379) APPENDIX C
('7', 152, 5, 8, 339390) Extracts from the Bill dealt with in the foregoing Petition:
('7', 152, 6, 9, 339451) Section 1. The Peace Preservation Ordinance, 1903, shall.
('7', 152, 6, 10, 339509) be and is hereby repealed; provided that no such repeal shall affect or abridge any powers or jurisdiction by the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, 1907, conferred for the purpose of carrying out such Act; but the said Ordinance shall for all the purposes of such Act be deemed to remain of full force and effect.
('7', 152, 7, 11, 339816) Section 2. Sub sections I and 4. “Prohibited immigrant” shall mean and include any of the following classes of persons desiring to enter or entering this Colony after the date of the taking effect of this Act:
('7', 152, 8, 12, 340026) (1) Any person who when asked whether within or outside this Colony by a duly authorised officer shall be unable through deficient education to write out (from dictation or otherwise) and sign in the characters of an European language an application for permission to enter this Colony or such other document as such officer may require; provided that for the purposes of this Sub section, Yiddish shall be accepted as an European language.
('7', 152, 9, 13, 340467) (2) Any person who at the date of his entering or attempting to enter this Colony is subject or would if he entered this Colony be subject to the provisions of any law in force at such date which might render him liable either at such date or thereafter if found therein to be removed from or to be ordered to leave this Colony whether on conviction of an offence against such law or for failure to comply with its provisions or otherwise in accordance with its provisions; provided that such conviction be not the result of the commission by such person elsewhere than in this
('7', 153, 0, 1, 341045) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 153, 1, 2, 341087) Colony of an offence for which he has received a free pardon.
('7', 153, 2, 3, 341149) Section 6. Any person who
('7', 153, 3, 4, 341175) (a) is convicted after the date of the taking effect of this Act of a contravention of sections three, thirteen [and] or twenty one of the
('7', 153, 4, 5, 341314) Immorality Ordinance, 1903, or any amendment of such sections; or
('7', 153, 5, 6, 341380) (b) is deemed by the Minister on reasonable grounds to be dangerous to the peace, order and good government of this Colony if he remain therein; or
('7', 153, 6, 7, 341528) (c) having been ordered under any law to leave this Colony fail[s] to comply with the terms of such order; may be arrested and removed from this Colony by warrant under the hand of the Minister and pending removal may be detained in such custody as may be prescribed by regulation; provided that no such person as is in paragraph (b) hereof described shall be removed from this Colony, except on the order of the Governor, provided further that every such person arrested shall be discharged from custody unless an order be made by the Governor for his removal from this Colony within ten days after his arrest.
('7', 153, 7, 8, 342140) Section 11. Any person ordered to be removed from this Colony under this Act and any other person who shall have been convicted under section seven of aiding
('7', 153, 8, 9, 342298) or abetting him in entering or remaining in the Colony in contravention of this Act shall be liable to pay all expenditure incurred by the Government in carrying out such removal whether from the Colony or South Africa or in the detention within the Colony or elsewhere of any person pending his removal; and the amount of such expenditure on production to the Sheriff of the certificate of an officer of the department stating the items and total amount of such expenditure shall be recovered by execution levied on the property within the Colony of the person so liable in manner provided for execution levied under a judgement of the Supreme Court; and the proceeds of such execution shall be paid by the Sheriff to the Treasurer who, after deduction of the amount of expenditure aforesaid and the costs of execution, shall remit the balance to the person so liable or to any person appointed by him to receive same.

('7', 154, 10, 14, 343705) We publish in another column correspondence that has passed between the Transvaal Colonial Secretary and Mr. Gandhi.
('7', 154, 10, 15, 343822) 3 It is a great pity that General Smuts has not accepted the suggestion made by Mr. Gandhi.
('7', 154, 10, 16, 343914) Although it is not made in the name of the community, we think that it affords either party a safe way out of a serious difficulty.
('7', 154, 10, 17, 344046) General Smuts relies upon his ability to enforce the law in full and, therefore, rejects Mr. Gandhi’s proposal.
('7', 154, 10, 18, 344158) We cannot help remarking that the rejection of so reasonable a solution shows in what low esteem Indians in the Transvaal are held by General Smuts.
('7', 154, 10, 19, 344307) Accordingly, we consider that it is now more than ever the dutyof Indians in the Transvaal to prosecute their campaign of non submission to the law to the uttermost end.
('7', 154, 10, 20, 344477) The fixed determina tion of the Transvaal Government can do no harm to those Indians who are already reconciled to sacrifice, no matter how great.
('7', 154, 10, 21, 344624) Neither imprisonment nor deportation need occasion the slightest fear in the minds of those Indians who place their honour above everything else.

('7', 161, 3, 29, 360318) 1 Similarly, it will be impossible to get the new law repealed unless we suffer loss of money, and the hardships of imprisonment and even of deportation.

('7', 162, 2, 14, 361840) LAW OF DEPORTATION

('7', 162, 3, 16, 361926) It is likely to be published in the Gazette on Friday.
('7', 162, 3, 17, 361981) It will not come into force immediately, as it will be sent to England for approval.

('7', 163, 3, 4, 363311) “THE STAR”
('7', 163, 4, 5, 363322) The Star has strongly criticized this letter of Mr. Gandhi asking why, if the giving of finger prints was not the chief objection, so much emphasis was laid on the question till now.

('7', 165, 0, 1, 366976) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 165, 1, 2, 367018) 132. THE IMMIGRATION PETITION
('7', 165, 2, 3, 367048) The British Indian Association of the Transvaal has lost no time in petitioning Lord Elgin 1 regarding the Immigrants’ Restriction Bill of the Transvaal, which was gazetted as an Act on the 26th instant, containing the reservation clause that “it shall not take effect unless and until the Governor shall proclaim in the Gazette that it is His Majesty’s pleasure not to disallow the same”.
('7', 165, 2, 4, 367438) It is of no force until the Royal pleasure becomes known.
('7', 165, 2, 5, 367496) Lord Elgin, therefore, has now an opportunity of retrieving what we consider was an Imperial blunder in his having advised His Majesty to sanction the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 165, 2, 6, 367673) Mr. Essop Ismail Mia, in the petition, has dealt with every point arising out of the Act.
('7', 165, 2, 7, 367763) For the present, however, we propose to confine ourselves to the Act as it affects Indians domiciled in the Transvaal.
('7', 165, 2, 8, 367882) We recollect Mr. Duncan having stated emphatically that the Asiatic Registration Act was considered necessary because there was no Immigration Ordinance in force at the time, and that it was to be treated merely as a temporary step.
('7', 165, 2, 9, 368115) It was also, undoubtedly, panic legislation to stop the so called inflowing tide of Asiatic immigration at the rate, the Honourable Mr. Curtis told us, of at least 200 per month.
('7', 165, 2, 10, 368294) It is a curious commentary on Mr. Duncan’s statement 2, as also [on] Mr. Curtis’, that a year after the introductory speech by the then Colonial Secretary, registration has not yet been effected, and that the Asiatic Registration Act is still practically of no force, except for the fact that registering officers perambulate the Colony in search of Asiatic applicants for the benefits which, Lord Selborne states, the Registration Act confers upon them.
('7', 165, 2, 11, 368749) And it is this very Act which the measure under consideration makes permanent, and thus, whilst it frees the white inhabitants of the Transvaal from the Peace Preservation Ordinance, it draws the noose tighter round the necks of Asiatics.
('7', 165, 2, 12, 368988) Asiatics, then, find that a grant of greater liberty to white British subjects corresponds with a greater restraint on that of Asiatic British subjects.
('7', 165, 2, 13, 369141) Unlike other and older self governing Colonies, this new pet child of the Empire is to be allowed to set aside rights of British Indians who are already domiciled in the Transvaal, by reason of their having paid £3 to the old Dutch Government, for, under the Immigration Act, as the British Indian Association points out, only those Asiatics who are registered in the terms of the Asiatic Act are
('7', 165, 3, 14, 369538) 1 Vide “Petition to Secretary of State for Colonies”, 23 8 1907 2 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 4 8 1906
('7', 166, 0, 1, 369641) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 167
('7', 166, 1, 2, 369686) allowed to retain their domicile.
('7', 166, 1, 3, 369720) The last point dealt with by the Association outdoes the other two mentioned by us in severity.
('7', 166, 1, 4, 369816) It provides for the physical deportation of those British Indians who fail to take out registration certificates under the new Act.
('7', 166, 1, 5, 369948) Now the taking out of the certificate is, after all, a formality invested with many incidents of slavery.
('7', 166, 1, 6, 370054) It is not as if the people who fail to take out registration certificates are not residents of the Transvaal.
('7', 166, 1, 7, 370164) Indeed, most of the Indians, who are making a brave stand against the Asiatic Act, are old respectable inhabitants of that Colony, some of them, like the Chairman himself, of 20 years’ standing, having all their earthly possessions in that Colony, having there even their families, places of worship and everything they hold dear in the world.
('7', 166, 1, 8, 370508) It is these men who, because they decline to take out a degrading document, are to be forcibly turned out from their home; and this deportation is to take place at the expense of the deported, and it is to create no obligation on the part of the Transvaal Government even to feed and house them!
('7', 166, 1, 9, 370804) Well may Mr. Mia declare that this deportation will be much worse than deportation for heinous offences.
('7', 166, 1, 10, 370909) We shall be painfully astonished if Lord Elgin, with his declared sympathies and with his past Viceregal career before him, advises His Majesty to sanction a measure of this description.
('7', 166, 1, 11, 371096) He has more than once stated that he does not like the Asiatic Act.
('7', 166, 1, 12, 371164) He has now thrown into his hands a golden opportunity of treating with the Transvaal Government, with a view to having the Asiatic Act repealed, and the principle of re registration being embodied in a modified form in the Immigration Act.
('7', 166, 1, 13, 371404) Indian Opinion, 31 8 1907
('7', 166, 2, 14, 371430) 133. CAPE INDIANS 1

('7', 167, 2, 6, 372579) 134. THE LADYSMITH TRADERS 1
('7', 167, 3, 7, 372608) Ladysmith Chamber of Commerce is again on the track of British Indians who have been unjustly deprived by the Ladysmith Board of their licences to trade in the Klip River District, and who have the temerity to continue to earn their livelihood by plying their trade without licences.
('7', 167, 3, 8, 372892) When we say it is the Ladysmith Chamber of Commerce which is after these poor Indians, it simply means that the European merchants who are jealous of their rivals are endeavouring to hound the latter out of the district.
('7', 167, 3, 9, 373113) There seems to have been some sort of an understanding on the part of the Government that they would mark their disapproval of the conduct of the Ladysmith Board by refusing to sanction the prosecution of innocent men, but it is quite evident that the Chamber has coerced the Government into action, for it appears that the Attorney General has authorised the Crown Prosecutor to institute proceedings against these men, should they still continue to trade without licences.
('7', 167, 3, 10, 373588) Such is the working of the Dealers’ Licences Act of Natal, from which the Imperial Government has avowed itself practically powerless to grant relief.
('7', 167, 3, 11, 373739) The Indian Government, which certainly is all powerful, refuses to make use of the only and effective remedy at its disposal, namely, to stop indentured Indian immigration, if the free Indian population of Natal is denied bare justice.

('7', 168, 4, 14, 375607) 136. NEED FOR GREAT CAUTION
('7', 168, 5, 15, 375635) All eyes are at present turned on the Transvaal Indians.
('7', 168, 5, 16, 375692) Just at such a time, we have received news of some weakness in the Indian community.
('7', 168, 5, 17, 375777) At the present juncture whatever is unhealthy in the community is to be exposed; it cannot be suppressed.
('7', 168, 5, 18, 375883) It will be, we think, an act of treason to suppress it.
('7', 168, 6, 19, 375939) The Indian community comprises mainly Surti, Memon and Konkani Muslims, Parsis and Hindus.
('7', 168, 6, 20, 376030) We hear that a large proportion of Memons and Konkanis have become impatient with the struggle against the law.
('7', 168, 6, 21, 376142) It is said that they are now prepared to yield, but, before yielding, desire the Government to make some changes.
('7', 168, 6, 22, 376256) We have seen the draft petition seeking the amendments.
('7', 168, 6, 23, 376312) We feel humiliated even to print it.
('7', 168, 6, 24, 376349) The draft, in our judgment, is a document inviting slavery for ourselves.
('7', 168, 6, 25, 376423) The concessions desired therein are no concessions.
('7', 168, 6, 26, 376475) The language in which the request is made is so cringing that it can only mean that most of the leaders of the Indian community were never opposed to the new law.
('7', 168, 6, 27, 376638) The giving of finger prints is accepted.
('7', 168, 6, 28, 376679) No objection is taken to the humiliation of Turkish Muslims.
('7', 168, 6, 29, 376740) The only demand is for the appointment of special
('7', 169, 0, 1, 376790) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 169, 1, 2, 376832) officers to inspect the permits of respectable Indians and for obtaining their finger prints in private.
('7', 169, 1, 3, 376937) Moreover, if the holders of old licences are able to give their signatures, the Licensing Officer should not demand finger prints.
('7', 169, 1, 4, 377068) The temporary permits should continue to be issued as at present, and children’s finger prints taken after they have attained the age of 16.
('7', 169, 2, 5, 377209) Among these demands there is not one to concede which any change in the Regulations may be necessary, let alone the law.
('7', 169, 2, 6, 377330) “Very well,” can be General Smuts’ reply to such a letter.
('7', 169, 2, 7, 377389) In that case, those who feel pleased with the letter may immediately take out the title deed of slavery, i.e., the register.
('7', 169, 2, 8, 377514) The draft moreover states that Indians are wax in the hands of law.
('7', 169, 2, 9, 377582) We hold that such a statement does not lie well in the mouth of anyone who believes in the existence of God.
('7', 169, 2, 10, 377691) For man is like wax in the hands of God alone.
('7', 169, 3, 11, 377738) We are glad to say that the letter referred to above has not been despatched to General Smuts.
('7', 169, 3, 12, 377833) Nor do we mean to say that the letter was approved by Memons, Konkanis or any others.
('7', 169, 3, 13, 377919) Our only reason for making this matter public is that, though this blow was warded off in time, there can be no certainty that such an attempt will not be repeated.
('7', 169, 3, 14, 378084) A frightened man will clutch at anything.
('7', 169, 3, 15, 378126) Is there anyone who will not try to get hold of the dry stumps while rolling down the slope of a hill?
('7', 169, 3, 16, 378229) Some Indians in the Transvaal are in a similar plight.
('7', 169, 3, 17, 378284) We would advise such Indians to submit to the law immediately and take out registers instead of meddling with the question of the law.
('7', 169, 3, 18, 378419) That will not lay them open to much blame.
('7', 169, 3, 19, 378462) But, if they have such letters written which tarnish the fair name of the community, they will be regarded to have done, and will have actually done, very much more harm than what Mr. Haji Ebrahim and Mr. Khamisa have done.
('7', 169, 3, 20, 378686) Mr. Haji Ebrahim and his comrades put themselves to shame out of fear, being unable to keep up courage.
('7', 169, 3, 21, 378790) But those addressing letters such as the above will drag down the community while they blacken their own faces.
('7', 169, 3, 22, 378902) They will have proved that the struggle of the Indians was not against the law as such, but only for slight changes in it.
('7', 169, 3, 23, 379025) The draft petition referred to above also states that, barring some men intent on mischief, Indians are eager to get themselves registered.
('7', 169, 3, 24, 379165) How amusing this is !
('7', 169, 4, 25, 379187) Moreover, if such a petition is sent to General Smuts on behalf of the Indians, the petition that has been submitted concerning the Immigration Bill will also receive a set back.
('7', 169, 4, 26, 379366) The fight that is
('7', 170, 0, 1, 379384) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 171
('7', 170, 1, 2, 379428) being put up by the South Africa British Indian Committee will have been in vain, and the Indian community will have been robbed in broad daylight.
('7', 170, 1, 3, 379576) It is our particular request, therefore, that any individual or group that desires to take out the register is free to do so.
('7', 170, 1, 4, 379702) Only, they should not drag others along with them.
('7', 170, 1, 5, 379753) Why should all Memons or all Konkanis or all Hindus have their faces besmirched just because some Memons, or some Konkanis, or some Hindus or Surtis or Parsis do so?
('7', 170, 1, 6, 379919) Is there among the Memons no brave man who will courageously declare: “Even if other Memons should go, I certainly will not.” Why can a Konkani not speak out to the same effect?
('7', 170, 1, 7, 380097) Why will Indians follow the example of others in doing evil?
('7', 170, 1, 8, 380158) If, like sheep, we are still ready to follow one another into a ditch, it should be taken for certain that we shall be doomed to have the obnoxious law with us for ever.
('7', 170, 1, 9, 380328) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 31 8 1907
('7', 170, 2, 10, 380370) 137. LICENCES IN LADYSMITH
('7', 170, 3, 11, 380397) Clouds are gathering again over those Indians in Ladysmith who have not received licences.
('7', 170, 3, 12, 380488) They carry on trade without a licence.
('7', 170, 3, 13, 380527) The Chamber of Commerce has therefore recommended that they should be prosecuted.
('7', 170, 3, 14, 380609) Mr. Labistour has replied that if they continue to do so, action will be taken against them.
('7', 170, 3, 15, 380702) An assurance was given to the leaders of the Congress that those who traded without a licence would not be harassed.
('7', 170, 3, 16, 380819) This promise was given out of a sense of justice.
('7', 170, 3, 17, 380869) Now that the Europeans are bringing pressure, this sense of justice has collapsed and the Government, submitting to the pressure, wants the shops to be closed down.
('7', 170, 3, 18, 381034) This gives the clearest picture of the shape of things to come in the nature of hardships for Indians.
('7', 170, 3, 19, 381137) There are three ways to scatter these clouds: (1) To prefer an appeal to the Privy Council.
('7', 170, 3, 20, 381229) (2) If such an appeal is not to be filed, the President of the Congress should meet the Imperial Government.
('7', 170, 3, 21, 381338) This step can be taken along with the first.
('7', 170, 3, 22, 381383) (3) To have courage and keep the shops open.
('7', 170, 3, 23, 381428) In case of prosecution, not to pay the fine, but allow the goods to be auctioned.
('7', 170, 3, 24, 381510) The first way can be adopted only when the Congress has a fund of £1,000. The second step must be taken in any case.
('7', 170, 3, 25, 381627) It will not solve the difficulties for ever.
('7', 170, 3, 26, 381672) The third way is the easiest of all and the best.
('7', 171, 0, 1, 381722) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 172
('7', 171, 1, 2, 381764) But it is a way that the brave alone can take.
('7', 171, 1, 3, 381811) It does not depend on anybody’s advice.
('7', 171, 1, 4, 381851) One must have courage oneself.
('7', 171, 1, 5, 381882) If this is there, everything can be done.
('7', 171, 1, 6, 381924) There is no provision in this Act for a sentence of imprisonment.
('7', 171, 1, 7, 381990) Only a fine can be imposed.
('7', 171, 1, 8, 382018) If the fine is not paid, it can be collected by auction of goods.
('7', 171, 1, 9, 382084) We urge Indians to adopt that way.
('7', 171, 1, 10, 382119) Men like Dr. Rutherford have adopted it, and we, too, can do likewise.
('7', 171, 1, 11, 382190) But in such matters, prompting by others is of no avail.

('7', 171, 2, 14, 382333) 138. WHY WAS “ THE LIFE OF PROPHET MAHOMED” DISCONTINUED?
('7', 171, 3, 15, 382391) We feel sad in answering this question.
('7', 171, 3, 16, 382431) In utter good faith and out of great regard [for Islam], we started publishing a translation [of Irving’s book], with a view to serving the Indian community and, in particular, the Muslim brethren.
('7', 171, 3, 17, 382629) Among the biographies written by white men, Washington Irving’s work is regarded as excellent.
('7', 171, 3, 18, 382724) On the whole, he has shown the wonderful greatness of the Prophet, and has presented the good teachings of Islam in shining colours.
('7', 171, 3, 19, 382857) Whether this is so or not, we believe it is the duty of every Muslim to know what the whites write about Islam and its Founder.
('7', 171, 3, 20, 382985) In translating the book, our object was to help them perform this duty.
('7', 171, 3, 21, 383057) While the translation was being given, some of our readers were pained to read the account of the Prophet’s marriage in chapter V, and suggested that we should stop publishing the life.
('7', 171, 3, 22, 383243) Our aim is to show as far as possible that this journal belongs to the whole of the Indian community.
('7', 171, 3, 23, 383345) We have no desire to injure needlessly the feelings of anyone in any way.
('7', 171, 3, 24, 383419) Therefore we have stopped publishing the “Life” 1 and feel sorry that
('7', 171, 4, 25, 383489) 1 Mahadev Desai, Gandhiji’s Secretary, records in his Diary, under July 29, 1932: “Bapu .

('7', 172, 5, 17, 385726) There is a report in the Press that the Moors (who are Muslims) have shown excellent bravery in Casablanca.

('7', 172, 6, 22, 386106) The reader may ask how one can return from the mouths of cannons.
('7', 172, 6, 23, 386172) But that is the wonderful thing about bravery.
('7', 172, 7, 24, 386219) So great was their fervour that the French gunners did not have the heart to fire on such brave warriors.

('7', 177, 1, 2, 394230) has raised a question in the Parliament about introducing there an Act similar to the Transvaal Registration Act; in the Cape licensed hawkers and shopkeepers have to put up with hardships; new laws are being passed and new restrictions imposed in Delagoa Bay; even in Rhodesia special legislation is being enacted against Indians, and in German [East] Africa, too, proposals humiliating to Indians are being can vassed.

('7', 180, 4, 5, 401878) 147. ON THE DUTY OF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE 1
('7', 180, 5, 6, 401919) It would seem as if the action of both Houses of Parliament in passing the Bill to legalise the marriage with a deceased wife’s sister will convert the clergy of the Established Church into passive resisters of sorts.
('7', 180, 5, 7, 402137) The Archbishop of Canterbury today issued a message in which he requested the clergy not to celebrate marriages with a deceased wife’s sister although such unions are now recognised as legal by the law of the land.
('7', 180, 6, 8, 402352) The Daily Press
('7', 180, 7, 9, 402368) We have no desire to enter into the controversy as to whether marriage with a deceased wife’s sister is a reform in the right direction or not.
('7', 180, 7, 10, 402512) We have quoted the above mentioned cablegram in order to show that passive resistance is one of the most approved methods of securing redress in given circumstances, and that it is the only course law abiding and peaceful men can adopt without doing violence to their conscience.
('7', 180, 7, 11, 402792) Indeed, it would appear that it is a method they must adopt if they.
('7', 180, 7, 12, 402861) have a conscience, and it revolts against particular legislation.
('7', 180, 7, 13, 402927) It may be retorted that, between the passive resistance offered by British Indians in the Transvaal and that advised by the Archbishop of Canterbury, there is no resemblance.
('7', 180, 7, 14, 403102) We demur and claim that, if it is lawful for the Archbishop of Canterbury to disregard the deceased wife’s sister relief legislation, it is much more so for British Indians to withhold submission to the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 180, 7, 15, 403331) If there is no penalty provided by law to punish the clergy who may
('7', 180, 8, 16, 403399) 1 In writing this and subsequent articles on the subject, Gandhiji drew on the essay “On the Duty of Civil Disobedience” by Henry David Thoreau (1817 62), the American philosopher, naturalist and writer.
('7', 180, 8, 17, 403603) The essay first appeared in 1849 under the title “Resistance to Civil Government”.
('7', 181, 0, 1, 403686) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 182
('7', 181, 1, 2, 403728) not recognise it, by refusing to perform a marriage ceremony, it should be doubly their duty to accept the law.
('7', 181, 1, 3, 403840) But the Archbishop, in deliberately giving contrary advice, has brought into play a higher law, and that is the law dictated by conscience.
('7', 181, 1, 4, 403980) Rightly or wrongly, His Grace believes that there is no warrant for such unions in the Bible and that, therefore, the Legislature has committed a breach of God’s law, which it would be irreligious for the clergy to countenance.
('7', 181, 1, 5, 404208) In other words, he has recognised what Thoreau has said, that we should be men before we are subjects, and that there is no obligation imposed upon us by our conscience to give blind submission to any law, no matter what force or majority backs it.
('7', 181, 1, 6, 404457) Such is also the position of British Indians in the Transvaal.
('7', 181, 1, 7, 404520) Law abiding they are, and it will take away nothing from the certificate they have enjoyed so long by their now refusing to accept registration underthe Asiatic Law, which their conscience rejects as degrading to their manhood and offensive to their religion.
('7', 181, 1, 8, 404780) It is possible to carry the doctrine of passive resistance too far, but it is equally so with reference to the doctrine of obedience to law.
('7', 181, 1, 9, 404921) We cannot give the dividing line in words more appropriate than those of Thoreau when, speaking of the American Government, he says:
('7', 181, 2, 10, 405054) If one were to tell me that this was a bad Government because it taxed certain foreign commodities brought to its ports, it is most probable that I should not make any ado about it, for I can do without them.
('7', 181, 2, 11, 405263) All machines have friction, and possibly this does enough good to counterbalance the evil.
('7', 181, 2, 12, 405354) At any rate, it is a great evil to make a stir about it.
('7', 181, 2, 13, 405411) But, when the friction comes to have its machine, and oppression and robbery are paramount, I say let us not have any such machine any longer.
('7', 181, 2, 14, 405554) In the Asiatic Registration Act, British Indians have not only a law which has some evil in it, that is to say, using Thoreau’s words, a machine with friction in it, but it is evil legalised, or it represents friction with machinery provided for it.
('7', 181, 2, 15, 405804) Resistance to such an evil is a divine duty which no human being can with impunity disregard, and, as in the case of the Archbishop of Canterbury, so in that of British Indians, it is their conscience that must decide, as it has already decided, whether to submit to the Asiatic Act or not, cost what it may.

('7', 182, 6, 23, 408125) NOTABLE INSTANCE
('7', 182, 7, 24, 408142) Nowadays the people of Ireland are striving hard for their rights.
('7', 182, 7, 25, 408209) Some Irish leaders are convinced that the people of Ireland suffer because they live in a particular country, just as Indians suffer because of the colour of their skin.
('7', 182, 7, 26, 408379) In other words, the Indian people suffer many hardships both in India and outside and are treated as
('7', 183, 0, 1, 408480) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 184
('7', 183, 1, 2, 408522) inferior to Englishmen.
('7', 183, 1, 3, 408546) The Irish people count for nothing in their own land and are oppressed by their English rulers.
('7', 183, 1, 4, 408642) But no sooner do they go out of Ireland than they enjoy rights quite similar to those of Englishmen.
('7', 183, 1, 5, 408743) There are about 86 members in the House of Commons representing Ireland.
('7', 183, 1, 6, 408816) But the British Members of the House, blinded by their self interest, do all they can to prevent the Irish from succeeding in their efforts.
('7', 183, 1, 7, 408957) For this reason, some Irish leaders now wish to adopt a different line of action to have their grievances redressed.
('7', 183, 1, 8, 409074) That movement is called Sinn Fein 1, which, literally translated into Gujarati, means exactly our Swadeshi movement.
('7', 183, 1, 9, 409191) Day by day, the Sinn Fein party is growing stronger.
('7', 183, 1, 10, 409244) In their struggle, passive resistance is one of the main weapons.
('7', 183, 1, 11, 409310) Till now, Irishmen favoured violent action.
('7', 183, 1, 12, 409354) While theIrish people are tenants, the landlords are British who are foreigners there.
('7', 183, 1, 13, 409441) As a remedy, the tenants often resorted to violence against their foreign landlords.
('7', 183, 1, 14, 409526) Now it has been decided to educate the people for gradually withdrawing the Irish Members from the British Parliament, refraining from taking disputes between Irish parties to the law courts established in Ireland, and boycotting British goods even at the cost of hardship to themselves.
('7', 183, 1, 15, 409814) Through such measures they would raise the resounding cry of Swadeshi or Sinn Fein, so that without any violent struggle taking place the British would ultimately be obliged, or might agree, to grant Home Rule to Ireland, or would quit Ireland, and the Irish people would have an absolutely independent government.
('7', 183, 2, 16, 410129) This movement had its roots in Austria Hungary in the south of Europe.
('7', 183, 2, 17, 410200) Austria and Hungary were two separate countries.
('7', 183, 2, 18, 410249) But Hungary was under the rule of Austria and was always exploited by it.
('7', 183, 2, 19, 410323) To discomfit Austria, a Hungarian named Dick taught the people that they should not pay any taxes to Austria, should not serve any Austrian officers, and even forget the very name of Austria.
('7', 183, 2, 20, 410515) Though the Hungarians were very weak, this kind of spirit enabled them in the end to assert themselves against Austria.
('7', 183, 2, 21, 410635) Now Hungary is not regarded as subject to Austria, but claims parity with it.
('7', 183, 3, 22, 410713) These instances deserve to be emulated by the Transvaal Indians.
('7', 183, 3, 23, 410778) They clearly prove that what is known to have happened earlier in history must also happen in the case of Indians in the
('7', 183, 4, 24, 410899) 1 Irish for “ourselves alone”.
('7', 183, 4, 25, 410930) It was an Irish nationalist movement founded in 1905 which developed into a mass republican party and succeeded in establishing the Irish Free State,
('7', 184, 0, 1, 411080) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 185
('7', 184, 1, 2, 411124) Transvaal.
('7', 184, 1, 3, 411135) That is to say, none can imprison thousands of men or deport them.
('7', 184, 1, 4, 411202) But every Indian ought to be prepared to be imprisoned or deported; and to prove that Indians are so ready, some of them shall indeed have to suffer imprisonment, even deportation.
('7', 184, 1, 5, 411383) The Indian who may be called upon to suffer deportation or imprisonment will be said to have truly lived and won the battle of life.
('7', 184, 1, 6, 411516) His name will be immortal, and he will have fully met the claim of the motherland on him.

('7', 185, 3, 24, 415931) The part the Transvaal Indians play will show whether this is the time when we shall acquire these qualities or whether we shall have to wait for them for many years yet.

('7', 186, 3, 19, 417685) DUTY OF DISOBEYING LAWS 3 [1]
('7', 186, 4, 20, 417715) Many years ago, there lived in America a great man named Henry David Thoreau.
('7', 186, 4, 21, 417793) His writings are read and pondered over by millions of people.
('7', 186, 4, 22, 417856) Some of them put his ideas into practice.
('7', 186, 4, 23, 417898) Much importance is attached to his writings because Thoreau himself was a man who practised what he preached.
('7', 186, 4, 24, 418008) Impelled by a sense of duty, he
('7', 186, 5, 25, 418040) 1 Vide “Letter to Dr. E. Nundy”, 26 9 1906 ; 27 9 1907.

('7', 187, 0, 1, 418374) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 188
('7', 187, 1, 2, 418416) wrote much against his own country, America.
('7', 187, 1, 3, 418461) He considered it a great sin that the Americans held many persons in the bonds of slavery.
('7', 187, 1, 4, 418552) He did not rest content with saying this, but took all other necessary steps to put a stop to this trade.
('7', 187, 1, 5, 418658) One of those steps consisted in not paying any taxes to the State in which the slave trade was being carried on.
('7', 187, 1, 6, 418771) He was imprisoned when he stopped paying the taxes due from him.
('7', 187, 1, 7, 418836) The thoughts which occurred to him during this imprisonment were boldly original and were published in the form of a book.
('7', 187, 1, 8, 418959) The title of this article conveys the general sense of the English title of his book.
('7', 187, 1, 9, 419045) Historians say that the chief cause of the abolition of slavery in America was Thoreau’s imprisonment and the publication by him of the above mentioned book after his release.
('7', 187, 1, 10, 419221) Both his example and writings are at present exactly applicable to the Indians in the Transvaal.
('7', 187, 1, 11, 419318) We, therefore, give below a summary of these [writings]: I accept that that government is best which governs least.
('7', 187, 1, 12, 419434) That is, government is a kind of disease and the greater the freedom the people enjoy from it, the more admirable is the government.
('7', 187, 1, 13, 419567) Many persons say that it would be good if America had no [standing] army or had only a small one.
('7', 187, 1, 14, 419665) What they say is quite right [as far as it goes], but those who hold such a view base it on a false premise.
('7', 187, 1, 15, 419774) They say that the State is beneficial; it is only the army that is harmful.
('7', 187, 1, 16, 419850) These eminent men do not realize that an army is but the arm of the Stateand without it the State cannot exist for a moment.
('7', 187, 1, 17, 419975) But wecannot see this because we are ourselves intoxicated with the power of the State.
('7', 187, 1, 18, 420063) Really speaking, it is we, the subjects, who are responsible for the existence of both the State and the army.
('7', 187, 2, 19, 420174) Thus we see that we are deceiving ourselves.
('7', 187, 2, 20, 420219) It is not the government of America that keeps the people free, or educates them.
('7', 187, 2, 21, 420301) The [achievements of] government that we observe are, in some small measure, the result of the inherent character of the American people.
('7', 187, 2, 22, 420439) In other words, though we are educated and intelligent, we are somewhat less so than we could have been if it were not for the government.
('7', 187, 3, 23, 420578) But, I do not ask for no government at once, but at once for a better government.
('7', 187, 3, 24, 420660) This is the duty of every citizen.
('7', 187, 3, 25, 420695) It is a great error to believe that nothing but justice prevails in a country in which everything is decided by a majority vote.
('7', 187, 3, 26, 420824) Much injustice continues to be perpetrated because this error is not recognized.
('7', 187, 3, 27, 420905) It is a mere superstition to believe that what is done by a multitude is bound to be right.
('7', 187, 3, 28, 420997) Can there not be a government in which majorities do not decide right and wrong, but conscience?
('7', 187, 3, 29, 421094) Must the citizen always
('7', 188, 0, 1, 421118) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 189
('7', 188, 1, 2, 421162) resign his conscience to the legislators?
('7', 188, 1, 3, 421204) I would say that we are men first and subjects afterwards.
('7', 188, 1, 4, 421263) It is not necessary to cultivate a respect for the law so much as for the right.
('7', 188, 1, 5, 421344) The only obligation which I have a right to assume is to do at any time what I think right.
('7', 188, 1, 6, 421436) Law never made man a whit more just.
('7', 188, 1, 7, 421473) But I have seen and I do see that even ordinarily well disposed persons become, through their simplicity, the instruments of injustice.
('7', 188, 1, 8, 421609) One result of an undue respect for law is that we may see people taking to soldiering and, like monkeys, mechanically carrying out the orders of their superiors unquestioningly.
('7', 188, 1, 9, 421787) Many people thus take to it [soldiering] as their profession.
('7', 188, 1, 10, 421849) They have no doubt that it is a damnable business in which they are concerned; yet they rush to join it.
('7', 188, 1, 11, 421954) Are they men, or axes in the hands of butchers ?
('7', 188, 1, 12, 422003) Such men are on a level with wood and earth and stones.
('7', 188, 1, 13, 422059) How can that kind of men command any respect?
('7', 188, 1, 14, 422105) How can they be valued better than dogs or cats?
('7', 188, 1, 15, 422154) Then some others become advocates, ambassadors or lawyers.
('7', 188, 1, 16, 422213) They imagine that they serve the State with their heads.

('7', 188, 1, 18, 422345) Those who obey their sense of justice while holding the reins of government are always found to be in conflict with the State.

('7', 201, 1, 2, 451878) 164. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 201, 2, 3, 451903) WRETCHED INDIA Everywhere the Indian is in a sad plight.
('7', 201, 2, 4, 451960) Now comes a report from America that Indian labourers in Washington were belaboured by cowardly whites and that four of them were wounded.
('7', 201, 2, 5, 452099) The rest of the labourers are running away in panic.
('7', 201, 2, 6, 452152) These white assailants I regard as cowards, for it was not particularly brave for a thousand of them to have attacked the innocent labourers.
('7', 201, 2, 7, 452294) They are cowards who oppress those weaker than themselves.
('7', 201, 2, 8, 452353) There is a proverb among us that an angry potter will twist the ears of his donkey.
('7', 201, 2, 9, 452437) 1 Similarly, these cowardly whites assault the employees, because they can do nothing to the whites who employ Indians.
('7', 201, 2, 10, 452557) The truly brave are those who use their strength against persons stronger than themselves.
('7', 201, 2, 11, 452648) The Mayor of Washington has assured the Indian labourers that he will protect them and that they are welcome to return to their jobs.
('7', 201, 2, 12, 452782) He has engaged a special police force to protect them.
('7', 201, 2, 13, 452837) This fact does credit to the Mayor.
('7', 201, 2, 14, 452873) There is a Press report that the Foreign Office in England is also looking after them.
('7', 201, 2, 15, 452960) The lesson to be drawn from this assault seems to be that Indians will be able to hold their own in foreign countries only if they cultivate courage.
('7', 201, 2, 16, 453110) If the whites kick us every day, no protection can be given by the Imperial Government or any other Government.
('7', 201, 2, 17, 453222) God does not help those who live like cowards.
('7', 201, 2, 18, 453269) Living amidst tigers and wolves, we can do only two things.
('7', 201, 2, 19, 453329) True courage lies in absence of fear of wild animals.
('7', 201, 2, 20, 453383) Tigers and wolves too have been created by God, and we should view them without any ill will.
('7', 201, 2, 21, 453477) This can be practised only by saints or true devotees after a long period of devotion to God.
('7', 201, 2, 22, 453571) There is a second type of courage which consists in facing tigers and wolves with weapons.
('7', 201, 2, 23, 453662) This also involves risk to one’s person.
('7', 201, 2, 24, 453703) Such is the plight of those living in the midst of whites.
('7', 201, 2, 25, 453762) A saint will not go to distant lands seeking a livelihood.
('7', 201, 2, 26, 453821) Ordinarily, therefore, we need courage of the second kind.
('7', 201, 2, 27, 453880) To have that courage we need to be brave in facing physical dangers and to discipline the body.
('7', 201, 2, 28, 453976) According to Mrs. Besant 2, all Indians, high and low, should learn wrestling and other physical exercises to train all parts of the body.
('7', 201, 2, 29, 454115) All this will

('7', 203, 5, 9, 457284) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant regarding the letter addressed to you by the Assistant Honorary Secretary of the British Indian Association on the 14th instant.
('7', 203, 5, 10, 457498) You have been pleased to advise the community represented by my Association to assist in carrying out the laws of this Colony.
('7', 203, 5, 11, 457625) I beg to draw your attention to the fact that, hitherto, the community has always done so, and it will continue to do so, whenever such laws do not put on the community an unwarranted affront and do not wound its religious susceptibilities.
('7', 203, 5, 12, 457866) To the Asiatic Registration Act, British Indians have undoubtedly been advised by my Association not to submit, because, in my humble opinion, it is their duty first to submit to a higher law, namely, that which dictates to mankind an idea of self respect and respect for declarations solemnly and sincerely made.
('7', 203, 5, 13, 458180) To accept the Registration Act, in my humble opinion, takes away every vestige of manliness from Indians and would make them godless, and it was in order to invite your attention to this fundamental issue that the letter of the 14th instant was addressed to you.
('7', 203, 5, 14, 458443) It would be childish for any responsible British Indian to advise the community to enter upon a life and death struggle and to be prepared to sacrifice all their material wealth for the sake of avoiding finger impressions.
('7', 203, 5, 15, 458666) My Association is quite aware of the threat you have seen fit to use in your address—the subject matter of this correspondence—and
('7', 204, 0, 1, 458797) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 205
('7', 204, 1, 2, 458841) to repeat in your letter under reply, but I hope you will pardon me for saying that it loses its force on those who have never concealed from themselves the fact that the Government is not only strong enough to enforce the Law but that it has declared its intention so to do.
('7', 204, 1, 3, 459117) Whether such enforcement of the Law will redound to its credit, or whether, if my countrymen remain firm, all the credit will be due to them for undergoing unmerited suffering is a question which can safely be left to posterity to decide.

('7', 205, 1, 2, 460024) 167. MONSTER PETITION 1
('7', 205, 2, 3, 460048) [JOHANNESBURG, Before September 21, 1907]
('7', 205, 3, 4, 460090) TO THE HONOURABLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA SIR,
('7', 205, 4, 5, 460145) We, the undersigned British Indians residing in this Colony, hereby beg to dissociate ourselves entirely from the letter addressed to you onbehalf of some leading Indians of Pretoria, Pietersburg, Standerton and Middelburg by Messrs Stegmann, Esselen and Roos, and dated the 30th day of August, 1907, regarding the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, No.
('7', 205, 4, 6, 460491) 2 of 1907. We respectfully submit that nothing short of total repeal of the Act can meet the difficult situation that has arisen.
('7', 205, 4, 7, 460621) In our humble opinion the Act is degrading to our self respect, offensive to our religions, and in its incidence it is such as can be thought of only in connection with dangerous criminals.
('7', 205, 4, 8, 460811) Moreover, the solemn declaration made by us renders it imperative for us, as honest citizens of the Empire and God fearing men, not to submit to the provisions of the Act, irrespective of any consequences which we may have to suffer, and which we understand to be imprisonment, banishment and/or loss or confiscation of our property.
('7', 205, 4, 9, 461145) In making the above statement, we do not desire to shirk an enquiry into the allegations as to surreptitious entry by British Indians on a wholesale scale, or to refuse to hold documents that in the opinion of the Government may sufficiently identify us.
('7', 205, 4, 10, 461400) We therefore respectfully pray that the Government will be pleased to recognise British Indians in the Transvaal as men and worthy citizens in this free and self governing Colony.
('7', 205, 5, 11, 461580) We have the honour to be,

('7', 206, 2, 16, 463391) Indian Opinion, 21 9 1907
('7', 206, 3, 17, 463417) 168. A MONSTER PETITION
('7', 206, 4, 18, 463441) The Transvaal Indians are to be congratulated on having organised a monster petition to the Government.
('7', 206, 4, 19, 463545) It forms a complete answer to the document we had the misfortune to reproduce last week.
('7', 206, 4, 20, 463634) 1 The petitioners have, once for all, placed on record, in the
('7', 206, 5, 21, 463697) 1 The reference is to the letter of Messrs Stegmann, Esselen and Roos; vide the preceding item.
('7', 207, 0, 1, 463793) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 208
('7', 207, 1, 2, 463835) briefest terms possible, the main issue.
('7', 207, 1, 3, 463876) The petitioners, in frank but respectful language, inform the local Government that nothing short of total repeal of the Asiatic Registration Act can possibly meet the emergency.
('7', 207, 1, 4, 464055) They couple the statement with another to the effect that, in asking for a repeal, they do not shirk any inquiry into the allegation of a surreptitious influx of Asiatics, nor do they decline to exchange the permits at present held by them.
('7', 207, 1, 5, 464296) The fundamental issue, therefore, is—are Indians or are they not to be recognised as self respecting citizens of the Empire?
('7', 207, 1, 6, 464421) Our contemporary, The Star, the other day twitted Indians on having misled their friends in England as to the real cause of the struggle, and it credited British Indians with fighting against ten digit imprints only.
('7', 207, 1, 7, 464638) Almost at the time The Star wrote, Mr. Ritch, the indefatigable Secretary of the South Africa British Indian Committee, was writing to the Lancashire Daily Post, from which we take the following:
('7', 207, 2, 8, 464834) It is, of course, true that the Asiatic Registration Act requires British Indians as well as alien Asiatics ‘to submit to a registration for identity’, and that the regulations for administration of the Act include the taking of the ten digit imprints, a precaution associated almost entirely with criminality.
('7', 207, 2, 9, 465145) But to rightly understand the full measure of the burden of disability borne by our Indian fellow subjects in the Transvaal, it is necessary to recognise that thishumiliation is but an incident, and unimportant compared with the larger particular principle involved in the question of the right of the Transvaal British Indian community to treatment as civilised subjects of the Empire, and as such to protection by their overlord from their invasion and dispossession of that most elementary right.
('7', 207, 2, 10, 465645) The case for Indians could not be put more clearly.
('7', 207, 3, 11, 465697) Indian Opinion, 21 9 1907
('7', 207, 4, 12, 465723) 169. THE WEENEN LICENSING APPEAL
('7', 207, 5, 13, 465756) It is not often that we find ourselves in agreement with decisions of trade licensing officers and licensing boards, but hard as Mr. Bhayat’s case 1 was, we are bound to admit that, on principle, the decision of the Licensing Officer, as also of the Board, was free from reproach.
('7', 207, 5, 14, 466037) The Licensing Officer, Mr. Ingram, gave full and luminous reasons for his decision, and we believe him when he states that, had the position been reversed as to race, his decision would have been the same.
('7', 207, 5, 15, 466243) In view of the prejudice that exists in the Colony, our
('7', 207, 6, 16, 466299) 1 Vide “an Important Permit Case” 23 6 1906& “Johannesburg Letter”, 23 6 1906.

('7', 212, 9, 13, 475440) 1 Gandhiji made this observation while reproducing the following from Sanj Vartman, a Gujarati daily evening newspaper of Bombay: Thumb impressions in Bombay The complaint which was made in the Readers’ Views column of The Bombay Gazette, and which we reproduced in this paper, that a new law had come into force requiring thumb impressions from all persons other than Europeans for the purposes of the Registration Department of the High Court, appears to have been unfounded.
('7', 212, 9, 14, 475918) This is seen from the copy of the new law placed by the Government on the table in answer to a question in the Legislative Council by Mr. O. P. Dixit.
('7', 212, 9, 15, 476069) Under that law, if any person wants to get a document of any kind registered in the Department, he will have to affix the impression of his right hand thumb on that document, as also on the Government register recording thumb impressions.
('7', 212, 9, 16, 476308) The following rules have been framed in this connection: (1) When the person registering a document is an educated man and is personally known to the Registrar, he will not be required to give his thumb impression.
('7', 212, 9, 17, 476523) (2) No thumb impression will be required also if the person registering a document is a European Iady or gentleman or any other respectable person about whose identity there can be no doubt.
('7', 212, 9, 18, 476714) (3) Persons whose right hand thumbs cannot be used for any reason will be required to give the impression of their left hand thumb, or, if that is not possible, of any of the other fingers.
('7', 212, 9, 19, 476904) (4) The impression will be taken in the presence of the Registrar.

('7', 216, 5, 18, 486295) “HOW CAN WE PUT UP WITH LOSSES?”
('7', 216, 6, 19, 486328) I have been asked how people can put up with losses likely to occur in the course of the struggle against the new law.
('7', 216, 6, 20, 486447) In the first place, what one takes to be a loss is not a loss, but a gain.
('7', 216, 6, 21, 486522) If we buy a carriage for a hundred rupees, we do not think it to be a loss of money, but take it as a proper return for our money.
('7', 216, 6, 22, 486653) In just the same way, we have to buy our rights by forgoing our money.
('7', 216, 6, 23, 486724) One who feels assured that the rights will certainly be won should not be afraid of forgoing the money.

('7', 216, 6, 25, 486871) It is true that some people may not feel certain in their minds that they will get the rights.

('7', 219, 1, 2, 492276) 176. LETTER TO PRIME MINISTER’S SECRETARY
('7', 219, 2, 3, 492318) JOHANNESBURG, September 21, 1907
('7', 219, 3, 4, 492351) THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO THE RIGHT HON’BLE THE PRIME MINISTER PRETORIA SIR, The Committee of my Association desires me to draw the Prime Minister’s attention to the following report in the papers:
('7', 219, 4, 5, 492548) He regretted that Asiatics were objecting to registration on such a flimsy excuse as that of the taking of finger impressions.
('7', 219, 4, 6, 492675) It was enforced for white people, and he did not see that anyone suffered from the rule.
('7', 219, 4, 7, 492764) If the report referred to is correct, I venture to draw the Right Hon’ble gentleman’s attention to the fact that finger impressions themselves have never been a primary cause of the opposition to the Registration Act.
('7', 219, 4, 8, 492982) While they undoubtedly constitute a serious item among many others, my Association is free to admit that, by themselves, they would never justify the very great and intense irritation that the Act has caused.
('7', 219, 4, 9, 493191) I take the liberty to quote from the grounds of objections framed: 1. It is manifestly in conflict with the past declarations of His Majesty’s representatives; 2. It recognises no distinction between British and alien Asiatics; 3. It reduces British Indians to a status lower than that of the aboriginal races of South Africa and coloured people; 4. It renders the position of British Indians in the Transvaal much worse than under Law 3 of 1885, and therefore, than under the Boer regime; 5. It sets up a system of passes and espionage unknown in any other British territory; 6. It brands the communities to which it is applied as criminals or suspects; 7. The alleged influx of unauthorised British Indians is denied; 8. If such a denial is not accepted, a judicial, open, and British inquiry should be instituted before such drastic and uncalled for legislation is enforced;
('7', 220, 0, 1, 494069) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 221
('7', 220, 1, 2, 494113) 9. The measure is otherwise un British, and unduly restricts the liberty of inoffensive British subjects, and constitutes a compulsory invitation to British Indians in the Transvaal to leave the country.
('7', 220, 1, 3, 494317) Thus, it will be seen that, when the Law was first introduced last year, the main objections did not contain even so much as a reference to finger prints.
('7', 220, 1, 4, 494472) The whole flavour about the Act is, in my humble opinion, that of criminality, and submission to it would make the lives of British Indians in the Transvaal intolerable.
('7', 220, 2, 5, 494642) I have the honour to be,
('7', 220, 4, 6, 494667) Your obedient servant,
('7', 220, 5, 7, 494690) ESSOP ISMAIL MIA, CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 28 9 1907

('7', 226, 1, 6, 507313) All, therefore, that is needed is to focus the energy of the different associationsand organs of opinion in India, and to bring the weight of this solid influence to bear on Lord Minto; then the Indian question cannot but be solved in accordance with principles of justice and humanity.

('7', 226, 2, 8, 507626) 181. PICKETS DUTY
('7', 226, 3, 9, 507644) Johannesburg Indians will soon be put upon their mettle, and there can be little doubt that the ultimate course of action as to the Asiatic Act will be largely determined by the result of the attempt of the Registration Office to register Asiatics in Johannesburg.
('7', 226, 3, 10, 507909) Johannesburg contains nearly one half of the Asiatic population of the Transvaal—all the different Asiatic races, too, are largely represented on the Rand—and, if they remain firm in their opposition to the Asiatic Act, it must give the local Government some food for serious reflection.
('7', 226, 3, 11, 508197) The building of a jail, no matter what threats may be held out, is not a joke in these times when the money market is so tight.
('7', 226, 3, 12, 508325) Deportation of thousands of inoffensive people is not a matter of practical politics, because it is likely to appal the conscience of even Generals Botha and Smuts.
('7', 226, 3, 13, 508490) We have, therefore, arrived at threats as to the stopping of Asiatic licences, but, were such a thing possible, the Government will be stultifying themselves in that they will have left the largest number of Asiatics untouched.
('7', 226, 3, 14, 508718) Whatever action, therefore, the Johannesburg Asiatics take will very largely decide the issue.
('7', 226, 3, 15, 508813) The responsibility, therefore, on the shoulders of leading Indians and other leading Asiatics in Johannesburg is very grave and very great.
('7', 226, 3, 16, 508953) There is no denying the fact that, hitherto, the boycott of the Registration Office has been so successful, because of the work of the Indian pickets or missionaries.
('7', 226, 3, 17, 509120) They have done their work calmly, deliberately and unobtrusively.
('7', 226, 3, 18, 509186) There are many disturbing elements in Johannesburg.
('7', 226, 3, 19, 509238) Those who have volunteered to do the missionary work are, some of them, fiery spirits.
('7', 226, 3, 20, 509325) Indians in Johannesburg, too, are drawn from all classes.

('7', 228, 2, 3, 512046) The debate in the Legislative Assembly of Natal on the proposal to raise the licence fee payable by hawkers is very enlightening.
('7', 228, 2, 4, 512176) No one minded the exorbitant increase in the fee payable by the Natal hawker, because hawking is largely in the hands of Asiatics, and because, as the Minister of Justice put it, “Hawking was not a fit pursuit for white men in this country.” Quite on a par with this method of dealing with questions affecting non whites is the proposal made by that arch anti Asiatic, Mr. Haggar, that “it is in the public interest undesirable to employ Asiatics on the N.G.R. 1 in positions usually filled by white men”.
('7', 228, 2, 5, 512682) Strictly speaking, the great M.L.A. should have said “in the white interest”, instead of “in the public interest”.
('7', 228, 2, 6, 512797) The motion, let it be said, was accepted by the Minister of Railways and Harbours and he said that, if he could not kick out “coolies”, as he described Indian pointsmen, it was because he had a mandate about retrenchment from the members of the House.
('7', 228, 2, 7, 513049) In both these cases, therefore, there was not even so much as an examination of the claims that Indian hawkers and Indian pointsmen might presu mably have.
('7', 228, 2, 8, 513205) The “British subjects” theory has evidently been played out so far as the Colonies are concerned—they will have all the adva ntages that their association with the ancient flag may secure to them, but they will have none of the inconveniences or the responsibilities that the bearers of the flag must necessarily carry with it.

('7', 231, 4, 15, 519422) 189. LETTER TO J. A NESER
('7', 231, 5, 16, 519448) [JOHANNESBURG,] September 28, 1907
('7', 231, 6, 17, 519483) J. A. NESER, ESQ., M.L.A. P. O. BOX 22 KLERKSDORP SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th instant, and to tender to you the thanks of my Association for your very courteous, frank and full letter.
('7', 231, 6, 18, 519717) The greatest stumbling block in the way of a proper solution of the Indian question has been, undoubtedly, a great deal of apathy on the part of public men and consequent want of knowledge about the question.
('7', 231, 7, 19, 519926) 1 (1874 1908), who, in December 1907, founded the Nationalist Party in Egypt
('7', 232, 0, 1, 520003) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 233
('7', 232, 1, 2, 520047) I am deeply thankful for the sympathy you express for my countrymen who have vested interests in this Colony, and it is because the fight is entirely for the protection of such interests that I see in your attitude a common meeting ground.
('7', 232, 1, 3, 520287) Not only does my Association sympathise with the objection to wholesale immigration from India, but it has recognised its validity, in view of the very general prejudice against such immigration, and has always offered to co operate with the Government in attaining the object.
('7', 232, 1, 4, 520565) The ground is now clear for an examination of the Asiatic Act on its merits.
('7', 232, 1, 5, 520642) I venture to draw your attention to the fact that, when, in the September of 1906, objections against the draft Ordinance, as the Act then was, were framed, finger prints were not even so much as mentioned, although it was understood that the Government intended to insist on finger prints.
('7', 232, 1, 6, 520933) The attitude of my Association would not, therefore, have been in any way altered, had signature been substituted for finger prints.
('7', 232, 1, 7, 521066) It is the sting of compulsion running throughout the Act that offends and bears so heavily on the community.
('7', 232, 1, 8, 521175) The finger prints do not offend any religious susceptibility but the exception made in the Act in favour of Turkish Christians.
('7', 232, 1, 9, 521303) Turkish Jews does most emphatically wound religious feelings.
('7', 232, 1, 10, 521365) The Act bristles with severe penalties for breaches of the requirements thereof, but it is not the fact of the penalty that is resented, but the underlying assumption that Johannesburg as a class, are capable of impersonation, fraudulent transfers of permits, and fraudulently bringing unauthorised immigrants into the country that is most strongly and, I think, rightly objected to.
('7', 232, 1, 11, 521749) Whenever in a country exceptional penalties are provided for a particular offence, the general existence of such an offence in that country is, as you are aware, presumed.
('7', 232, 1, 12, 521921) Knowing well that British Indians, as a class, have not been guilty of the practices above described, they manfully struggle to avoid the presumption which the Act has made tacitly and which the framers of the Law publicly declare as their conviction.
('7', 232, 1, 13, 522173) It should, moreover, be borne in mind that this Law is a class measure of an obnoxious type, and is calculated to degrade British Indians in the estimation of Malays, with whom many of them are nearly related, Cape Coloured men, with whom they come in close contact, and the Kaffir races, who are largely employed by them as their servants.
('7', 232, 1, 14, 522514) While all these three are, in common with the other inhabitants of the Colony, exempt from any such restrictions on their personal liberty, Asiatics have been especially singled out.
('7', 233, 0, 1, 522697) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 233, 1, 2, 522739) The obvious answer to the last objection is, naturally, that it is the competition of the Asiatics that is feared and not that of the Coloured races, and it is because my Association recognises this that voluntary identification or registration has been suggested in place of the compulsory measure.
('7', 233, 1, 3, 523039) Such voluntary registration will not insult Indians by separating them from the rest of the community, will satisfy the European objection wholly, and will protect vested rights.
('7', 233, 1, 4, 523218) You seem to think that voluntary registration will leave untouched dishonest Indians, whose existence I do not deny, but that is, I beg to state, a mistake.
('7', 233, 1, 5, 523375) Under the voluntary offer, it has been submitted to the Government that by a short Bill, passed by consent, the Act can be made applicable to those who do not comply with the offer.
('7', 233, 1, 6, 523557) Indeed, at a stated period, all Indians or Asiatics may be examined simultane ously, and those who are found to be without the new identification certificates may be bundled out of the Colony under the Peace Preservation Ordinance or under a General Immigration Law that may be passed, in the place of the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 233, 2, 7, 523893) I will not trespass further upon your time, but will conclude by saying that, while my countrymen have honestly endeavoured to examine and meet reasonable objections raised by Europeans, the latter have, as a body, entirely failed to reciprocate, but have simply persevered in their policy of prejudiced opposition without caring to examine the Indian position.
('7', 233, 2, 8, 524255) As you have been, in your professional capacity, very largely connected with British Indians, I may not be wrong in asking you to step into our shoes and look at the whole position from our standpoint, and see whether a reasonable compro mise is not possible by the exercise of a little patience and some co operation.
('7', 233, 3, 9, 524574) I have the honour to be,
('7', 233, 5, 10, 524599) Your obedient servant,
('7', 233, 6, 11, 524622) ESSOP ISMAIL MIA CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION

('7', 234, 2, 3, 524782) [GERMISTON,] September 28, [1907]
('7', 234, 3, 4, 524816) TO THE EDITOR [RAND DAILY MAIL JOHANNESBURG]
('7', 234, 4, 5, 524861) SIR, The Reporter has informed the public that in Germiston it was the intimidation of British Indian pickets that many Indians refrained from registering themselves.
('7', 234, 4, 6, 525028) I, as chief picket, beg tostate that the information given to you is absolutely incorrect.
('7', 234, 4, 7, 525119) I may inform you that, as a matter of fact, for two days the whole Indian population of Germiston was picketing because they all stopped work.
('7', 234, 4, 8, 525262) Such was their enthusiasm and opposition to the law.
('7', 234, 4, 9, 525315) It was only after the appointed pickets persuaded the other Indians that they recommenced their work.
('7', 234, 4, 10, 525417) But it is quite true that some of the Indians from different other places came to Germiston to get registered, and they listened to the expostulations and arguments advanced by the Germiston pickets and returned without compromising themselves or their community.
('7', 234, 4, 11, 525681) But, where such reasonable argument failed, strict instructions were given that those who wished to accept the slavery imposed by the law should be personally escorted, and this was done in the instance of an Indian named Joseph Bahadur who came from Boksburg.
('7', 234, 4, 12, 525942) In our fight we do not need intimidation.
('7', 234, 4, 13, 525984) Those who understand the Act and all the consequences of it refrain, except when they are blinded to a sense of their own dignity by their selfishness, of their own accord from accepting the yoke.
('7', 234, 4, 14, 526181) I may state for the information of your numerous readers that even hospital attendants and labourers refused to register themselves under threat of being dismissed from their employment, and their dignified refusal had such marked effect on their employers that the threats were withdrawn.
