('7', 241, 1, 2, 539351) Below is Mr. Neser’s reply to Mr. Essop Mia’s letter to him:
('7', 241, 2, 3, 539412) The report of my speech referred to by you is [substantially] 1 correct and I adhere to every word I said on the subject.
('7', 241, 2, 4, 539534) I feel considerable sympathy with Asiatic people who have legitimately obtained vested interests in this country.
('7', 241, 2, 5, 539648) I have fought their cause before in the Courts here and I am prepared to continue fighting it in future on every possible occasion, but I am not prepared to allow further Asiatic immigration [into the Transvaal if I can prevent it] and I am quite determined to assist in every possible way to obstruct and render such immigration impossible.
('7', 241, 2, 6, 539990) It is only a matter of self preservation and nothing else.
('7', 241, 2, 7, 540049) [For the life of me] I cannot understand what objection any man can have to finger prints.
('7', 241, 2, 8, 540140) [It is certainly the safest way of identifying anybody and] I, personally, would have no objection to be so identified.
('7', 241, 2, 9, 540260) In what respect fingerprints could wound the religious susceptibilities of any person I fail to understand.
('7', 241, 2, 10, 540368) You make a good deal of voluntary registration.
('7', 241, 2, 11, 540416) Now what is the difference between voluntary and compulsory registration?
('7', 241, 2, 12, 540490) Will you be good enough to tell me ?
('7', 241, 2, 13, 540527) In my opinion voluntary registration would be a mere waste of time.
('7', 241, 2, 14, 540595) Honest people would comply with it [or perhaps suffer under such a system] whereas the dishonest man would score every time and I do not think that you can claim absolute honesty for every one of your co religionists any more than I pretend to do so for Europeans or people of European descent.
('7', 241, 2, 15, 540890) ESSOP MIA’S REPLY Mr. Essop Mia has thereupon sent the following reply: 2
('7', 241, 3, 16, 540964) I have the honour to tender to you the thanks of my Association for your very courteous, frank, and full letter.
('7', 241, 3, 17, 541077) The greatest stumbling block in the way ofa proper solution of the Indian question has been, undoubtedly, the fact that public men among the whites are not well informed about the question.
('7', 241, 4, 18, 541267) I am deeply thankful for the sympathy you express for my countrymen who have vested interests in this Colony, and it is because the fight is entirely for the protection of such interests that I see in your attitude a common meeting ground.
('7', 241, 5, 19, 541507) Not only does my Association sympathise with the objection to wholesale immigration from India, but it has recognised its validity, in view of the very general prejudice against such immigration, and has always offered to co operate with the Government in attaining the object.
('7', 241, 6, 20, 541785) The ground is now clear for an examination of the Asiatic Act on its
('7', 241, 7, 21, 541854) 1 The matter in square brackets has been supplied from the original in English which appeared in Indian Opinion, 5 10 1907.
('7', 241, 8, 22, 541978) 2 The translation given here has been collated with the original in English; vide “Letter to J. A. Neser”, 28 9 1907
('7', 242, 0, 1, 542095) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 243
('7', 242, 1, 2, 542139) merits.
('7', 242, 1, 3, 542147) When, in the September of 1906, the Asiatic Act was drafted, fingerprints were not even so much as mentioned.
('7', 242, 1, 4, 542257) The attitude of my Association would not, therefore, have been in any way altered, had signatures been substituted for finger prints.
('7', 242, 1, 5, 542391) It is the sting of compulsion running throughout the Act that offends and bears so heavily on the community.
('7', 242, 1, 6, 542500) The finger prints do not offend any religious susceptibility, but the exception made in the Act in favour of Turkish Christians and Turkish Jews does most emphatically wound religious feelings.
('7', 242, 2, 7, 542694) The Act bristles with severe penalties for breaches of the varied requirements thereof, but it is the underlying assumption that Indians, as a class, are capable of impersonation, fraudulent transfers of permits, and fraudulently bringing unauthorised immigrants into the country that is most strongly and, I think, rightly objected to.
('7', 242, 2, 8, 543031) Whenever in a country exceptional penalties are provided for a particular offence, the general existence of such an offence in that country is, as you are aware, presumed.
('7', 242, 2, 9, 543203) Knowing well that British Indians, as a class, have not been guilty of the practices above described, they manfully struggle to avoid the presumption which the Act has made tacitly.
('7', 242, 2, 10, 543385) It should, moreover, be borne in mind that this Law is a class measure of an obnoxious type, and is calculated to degrade British Indians in the estimation of Malays, with whom many of them are nearly related, Cape Coloured men, with whom they come in close contact, and the Kaffir races, who are largely employed by them as their servants.
('7', 242, 2, 11, 543726) While all these are, in common with the other inhabitants of the Colony, exempt from any such restrictions on their personal liberty, Asiatics have been especially singled out.
('7', 242, 3, 12, 543903) The obvious answer to the last objection is, naturally, that it is the competition of the Asiatics that is feared, and it is because my Association recognizes this that voluntary identification or registration has been suggested.
('7', 242, 3, 13, 544133) Such voluntary registration will not insult Indians, will satisfy the European objection wholly, and will protect vested rights.
('7', 242, 3, 14, 544262) You seem to think that voluntary registration will leave untouched dishonest Indians, whose existence I do not deny, but that is, I beg to state, a mistake.
('7', 242, 3, 15, 544419) Under the voluntary offer, it has been submitted to the Government that by a short Bill, passed by consent, the Act can be made applicable to those who do not comply with the offer.
('7', 242, 3, 16, 544601) Indeed, at a stated period, all Indians or Asiatics may be examined simultaneously, and those who are found to be without the new identification certificates may be bundled out of the Colony under a General Immigration Law.
('7', 242, 4, 17, 544825) I will conclude by saying that, while my countrymen have honestly endeavoured to examine and meet reasonable objections raised by Europeans, the latter have, as a body, entirely failed to reciprocate, but have simply persevered in their policy of prejudiced opposition without caring to examine the Indian position.
('7', 242, 4, 18, 545141) As you have been, in your professional capacity, very
('7', 243, 0, 1, 545195) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 243, 1, 2, 545237) largely connected with British Indians, I may not be wrong in asking you to step into our shoes and look at the whole position from our standpoint, and see whether a reasonable compromise is not possible by the exercise of a little patience and some co operation.
('7', 243, 1, 3, 545501) WARNING TO WITNESSES GIVING FALSE EVIDENCE
('7', 243, 2, 4, 545544) Five Indians were being tried for robbery before Mr. Wenderburg at Johannesburg.
('7', 243, 2, 5, 545625) The magistrate thought that the evidence given by the complainant and some other Indians was false.
('7', 243, 2, 6, 545725) He rebuked the witnesses.
('7', 243, 2, 7, 545751) Finding the evidence weak, he discharged the accused without examining them.
('7', 243, 2, 8, 545828) In the crowded court, he told the many Indians who were present that these days there were many faked cases among them, and that, if such cases occurred in future, the witnesses would be prosecuted for giving false evidence.
('7', 243, 2, 9, 546053) I feel sorry to give publicity to this fact.
('7', 243, 2, 10, 546098) But I think it necessary to bring it to the notice of all.
('7', 243, 2, 11, 546157) The Indian community loses its good name on account of such cases, and we suffer humiliation.
('7', 243, 2, 12, 546251) I understand that the witnesses were merely pawns in the hands of some schemers, and it was these schemers who were the real culprits.
('7', 243, 2, 13, 546386) I must tell them that it is not proper for them to ruin poor people for a little gain to themselves, and to bring the community as well as themselves into contempt.
('7', 243, 2, 14, 546551) There are many ways of earning money other than getting up false cases.
('7', 243, 3, 15, 546623) WHAT TO DO IF PERMIT IS LOST?

('7', 243, 4, 20, 546897) When the final notice is published, even permits held will be as good as lost.
('7', 243, 4, 21, 546976) For no one will be released on production of the old permit.
('7', 243, 4, 22, 547037) Therefore, those who wish to defy the new law have no reason to be afraid of the loss of permits.

('7', 244, 7, 17, 548604) 199. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('7', 244, 8, 18, 548638) JOHANNESBURG, October 7, 1907 THE HON’BLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA
('7', 244, 9, 19, 548712) SIR, I have been directed by the Committee of my Association humbly to address a few remarks on your speech delivered to your constituents and containing reference to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 244, 9, 20, 548910) If the report published in the papers be correct, it contains, in my humble opinion, many misstatements of facts.
('7', 244, 9, 21, 549024) My Association feels deeply grieved that from your responsible position you should give currency to the popular inaccuracy as to the cause of the depression.
('7', 244, 9, 22, 549182) Those who are engaged in business havestated emphatically that the cause of the terrible depression is to
('7', 244, 10, 23, 549288) 1 Vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 12 10 1907
('7', 244, 11, 24, 549329) 2 A client of Gandhiji; vide “Letter to Kalyandas Mehta”, 23 4 1907.
('7', 245, 0, 1, 549398) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 245, 1, 2, 549440) be sought elsewhere.
('7', 245, 1, 3, 549461) In any case, it has affected Indians just as much as Europeans.
('7', 245, 1, 4, 549525) My Association totally denies the statement that there are 15,000 Indians at present in the Colony.
('7', 245, 1, 5, 549625) An analysis of the figures which have been received by my Association will shortly be submitted to you which go[es] to show that there are at present not more than 7,000 Indians in the Transvaal.
('7', 245, 1, 6, 549821) You have been pleased to state that certificates issued under the old Law have been fraudulently duplicated and sold, and that, in Bombay, Johannesburg and Durban, there are known to be places where these manufactured certificates could be bought by Indians for so much cash.
('7', 245, 1, 7, 550097) My Association repudiates the statement entirely and respectfully invites a public inquiry into the matter, but my Association is aware that there was in the Registration Office a clerk who carried on a traffic in forged permits and undoubtedly used as his tools some Indians who had no notion either of their nationality or their honour.
('7', 245, 1, 8, 550436) That, however, is totally different from what you have been pleased to place before the public.
('7', 245, 2, 9, 550532) You have, again, been pleased to state that the Indians have objected to this Act because of the fingerprints; My Association has very often submitted to the Government that the fingerprints are not a primary cause of the Indian opposition, but the principle of compulsion and the whole object of the legislation which stamps British Indians as criminals.
('7', 245, 2, 10, 550888) When the objections against the measure were first framed, fingerprints were not even so much as mentioned.
('7', 245, 2, 11, 550996) At the same time, I take the liberty of pointing out that the Indians who have come to the Transvaal have never been called upon to give either their finger impressions or even their thumb impressions in India.
('7', 245, 2, 12, 551207) While thumb prints are undoubtedly taken in India, in some cases not connected with criminality, the digit impressions are taken only from criminals or those who are in any way connected with crimes, and, even thumb impressions are taken, the rule applies in cases of illiterates only.
('7', 245, 3, 13, 551493) My Association has always been aware of the intention of the Government to enforce the Act strictly and rigorously, but I may be permitted to mention once more that the most rigorous enforcement of the Law would be as nothing compared to the degradation involved in submission to it and violation of the community’s solemn and deliberate undertaking not to accept the Law.
('7', 245, 3, 14, 551866) My Association feels that, although you have declared that you have especially studied the Indian point of view of the question, the whole spirit of the opposition as also the most important points raised by my Association have been
('7', 246, 0, 1, 552099) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 247
('7', 246, 1, 2, 552143) entirely missed by you.
('7', 246, 1, 3, 552167) In conclusion, I beg to repeat that my Association has always appreciated the objection against a wholesale influx of British Indians and against unrestricted competition in trade, and, with a view of showing the bona fides of the community, has come forward with humble suggestions which would completely meet the two objections, but it is impossible for British Indians to surrender what little self respect may be left to them by accepting a measure which was conceived in ignorance of the true state of things, which is oppressive to a degree in its incidents, and which hurts the religious susceptibilities of the community represented by my Association.
('7', 246, 1, 4, 552827) l have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servant, ESSOP ISMAIL MIA CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 12 10 1907

('7', 246, 3, 6, 552994) JOHANNESBURG, October 9, [1907]
('7', 246, 4, 7, 553026) TO THE EDITOR [RAND DAILY MAIL JOHANNESBURG] SIR, As you were good enough to warmly take up the case of Mr. Suliman Manga 1 and an Indian woman named Punia 2, who were both grossly ill treated, I take the liberty of inviting your attention to a third case that has come under my observation, which equals, if it does not surpass, the other two in wanton insult.
('7', 246, 4, 8, 553388) Mr. Anthony Peters, a born Indian Christian, and an old civil servant of Natal, at present Interpreter at the Chief Magistrate’s Court, Pietermaritzburg, was on his way to Johannesburg on Sunday and was a passenger by the Johannesburg Mail which left Pietermaritzburg on Saturday.
('7', 246, 4, 9, 553669) He held a concession ticket and a certificate from the Railways in which his official position was described.
('7', 246, 4, 10, 553779) At Volksrust, the
('7', 246, 5, 11, 553797) 1Vide “Letter to Chhaganlal Gandhi”, 5 2 1903 and “Indian Position in New Colonies”, 16 3 1903. 2 ibid.
('7', 247, 0, 1, 553901) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 247, 1, 2, 553943) Examining Constable put him through a searching cross examination.
('7', 247, 1, 3, 554010) Mr. Peters produced his permit, which was issued to him at a time when the Indian community had not voluntarily given thumb impressions.
('7', 247, 1, 4, 554147) This did not satisfy the Constable.
('7', 247, 1, 5, 554183) Mr. Peters, therefore, produced the concession ticket referred to by me and offered to give his signature, but all to no avail, the Constable insulting him by saying that he might have got somebody else’s concession ticket.
('7', 247, 1, 6, 554407) Mr. Peters, therefore, went so far as to produce his walking stick, which bore his initials, and his shirt, which bore his full name.
('7', 247, 1, 7, 554541) Even this was not satisfactory.
('7', 247, 1, 8, 554573) He then offered to deposit money to ensure his return after three days, but the Constable ordered a Kaffir policeman to literally drag Mr. Peters out of the compartment.
('7', 247, 1, 9, 554743) Sergeant Mansfield, before whom Mr. Peters was taken, realised the terrible mistake, apologised to Mr. Peters, and let him go.
('7', 247, 1, 10, 554870) That, however, was small comfort.
('7', 247, 1, 11, 554904) Added to the insult was weary waiting at Volksrust, where he knew nobody, and a large slice taken out of his all too brief holiday of three days.
('7', 247, 1, 12, 555050) Mr. Peters returns to his duty tonight.
('7', 247, 1, 13, 555090) I need hardly comment upon this episode, beyond saying that this is a sample of what many a respectable Indian has to suffer in even visiting this country.
('7', 247, 1, 14, 555246) Here there is no question of general legislation, no question of an Asiatic influx, but a question of simple courtesy and justice between man and man.
('7', 247, 1, 15, 555397) Or is the wearing of a coloured skin to be, in the words of Mrs. Vogl who wrote the other day to the Glasgow Herald, a crime against the white people of the Transvaal?

('7', 247, 4, 18, 555618) 201. INDIANS AT THE CAPE
('7', 247, 5, 19, 555643) Though somewhat late in the day, we reproduce in another column the report 1 from the Cape Times of an important test case heard before the Cape Supreme Court and arising out of the Immigration Law.
('7', 247, 5, 20, 555842) We have before now expressed our great regret for the lethargy of the leading Cape Indians when the immigration measure was passing through the Cape Parliament.
('7', 247, 5, 21, 556003) We feel sure that a law of that description would undoubtedly have been considerably modified, had representations been made.
('7', 247, 5, 22, 556129) Though the facts of the case are fully dealt with in the report, they will bear repetition here.
('7', 247, 5, 23, 556226) A certain Indian domiciled at the Cape, having landed property there,
('7', 247, 6, 24, 556296) 1 Not reproduced here
('7', 248, 0, 1, 556318) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 249
('7', 248, 1, 2, 556362) and being a general dealer since 1897, intended to visit India and, in order to avoid inconvenience at the time of his return, wanted a permit to absent himself from the Colony for a period to be fixed by him.
('7', 248, 1, 3, 556572) The Immigration Officer refused to do so, offering a permit whose period was to be decided by himself.
('7', 248, 1, 4, 556675) Whether the Immigration Officer’s offer was reasonable or not is not the question, because on the one hand there was an attempt to get the right, on the other hand an attempt to deny the right.
('7', 248, 1, 5, 556869) The Immigration Officer said the gran ting of a permit to an Asiatic to absent himself was a concession.
('7', 248, 1, 6, 556974) The Asiatic said he demanded it as a matter of right.
('7', 248, 1, 7, 557028) The Supreme Court has now decided that, in accordance with the law, there was no inhe rent right in the Asiatic to receive a permit of absence.
('7', 248, 1, 8, 557172) In the abstract, the thing is simply farcical, in that it reduces Asiatics to a state of slavery, for which no one is to blame but the leading Indians themselves.
('7', 248, 1, 9, 557335) The most interesting point, however, raised in the course of the argument was left undecided.
('7', 248, 1, 10, 557429) The first section of the Immig ration Act seems to preserve the rights created under the Immigration Act of 1902 repealed by the Act in question.
('7', 248, 1, 11, 557575) It states that:
('7', 248, 2, 12, 557591) Such repeal shall not affect any acts or things done or commenced, any rights, privileges, or protection acquired, any penalties or liabilities incurred, any disability or disqualification existing, ally offences committed or any proceedings taken at the commencement of this Act.
('7', 248, 3, 13, 557872) Now Act 47 of 1902 safeguarded the rights of Asiatics among others who were domiciled in South Africa.
('7', 248, 3, 14, 557975) It would appear, then, that the rights of Indians who were settled before 1902 at the Cape or even in South Africa are not detrimentally affected by the Act of 1906. Justice Maasdorp clearly stated that the point could only be raised and decided on an Indian, domiciled at the Cape before 1902, leaving, it and returning without having taken out the permit of absence.
('7', 248, 3, 15, 558344) It is very simple, and we trust that the Indians at the Cape will lose no time in having the right tested.
('7', 248, 3, 16, 558451) The custom of issuing permits of absence is extremely oppressive, and undoubtedly interferes with the freedom of movement that every independent man must claim.

('7', 248, 6, 19, 558667) Our readers must have noticed that originally we gave four pages to the Gujarati section, but later increased them to eight and then again to 12. For some weeks past the number has gone up to 13, 14 and even 15. Now we intend to give 16 pages every time.
('7', 248, 6, 20, 558922) Owing to
('7', 249, 0, 1, 558931) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 249, 1, 2, 558973) several difficulties, it may occasionally happen that we cannot give so many pages.
('7', 249, 1, 3, 559057) Such an increase involves additional expenditure to us, though that will not deter us, for our aim is to earn our bread through public service.
('7', 249, 1, 4, 559201) Service is the principal object.
('7', 249, 1, 5, 559234) Earning a livelihood takes the second place.
('7', 249, 1, 6, 559279) From the time that Indian Opinion was founded 1 till today, no one has thought of making money out of it, and no one will ever think of it in future.
('7', 249, 1, 7, 559429) Hence we intend to give to the reader greater benefits in proportion to the rise in income.
('7', 249, 1, 8, 559521) If and when there remains any balance after the salaries of those connected with the journal reach a certain level, all of it will be spent on public work.
('7', 249, 1, 9, 559677) We are convinced that an increased circulation of Indian Opinion will mean growth of education and patriotism among us.
('7', 249, 1, 10, 559797) The journal has at present only 1,100 subscribers, though the number of readers is much larger.
('7', 249, 1, 11, 559893) If all readers buy their copies, Indian Opinion can render three times better service than it does today.
('7', 249, 1, 12, 559999) We hope it will not be considered unreasonable of us if we expect encouragement in proportion to the increase in the number of our pages.
('7', 249, 1, 13, 560137) If those who fully realize the value of the service rendered by this paper secure even one additional subscriber each, we shall feel heartened thereby and get some help in meeting the increased expenditure consequent upon the increase in the number of pages.

('7', 253, 3, 18, 570573) 206. CAPE INDIANS The more we read about the Cape Immigration Act, the more we blame the Indian leaders.
('7', 253, 3, 19, 570678) We think the case fought on behalf of Mr. Dharsey of Vryburg was an important one.
('7', 253, 3, 20, 570761) We have reported it in full in English and have also offered our comments on it.
('7', 253, 3, 21, 570842) 2 We give here such of the facts of the case as can be easily understood.
('7', 253, 3, 22, 570916) Mr. Dharsey has been doing business in the Cape since 1897. He asked for a temporary permit for 18 months to go to India.
('7', 253, 3, 23, 571038) The officer refused to give such a permit, and offered to give a permit for
('7', 253, 4, 24, 571114) 1 Not reproduced here 2 Vide “Indians at the Cape” 12 10 1907.
('7', 254, 0, 1, 571177) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 255
('7', 254, 1, 2, 571221) one year.
('7', 254, 1, 3, 571231) Mr. Dharsey asked for the permit as a matter of right.
('7', 254, 1, 4, 571286) The officer said he had no such right; it was the officer’s discretion whe ther or not to grant a permit.
('7', 254, 1, 5, 571392) There upon Mr. Dharsey took the matter to the court.
('7', 254, 1, 6, 571445) The Supreme Court dismissed his application and held that an Indian could not compel an officer to give [him] a permit.
('7', 254, 1, 7, 571565) This judgment means that, if an Indian leaves the Cape without permission, he cannot return.
('7', 254, 1, 8, 571658) As the power of giving a permit rests with the officer, the Indians are for ever imprisoned in the Cape.
('7', 254, 1, 9, 571763) That permits are at present being given to all means nothing at all, but that a permit should have to be asked for is itself tyrannical.
('7', 254, 1, 10, 571900) There is no such law anywhere else.
('7', 254, 1, 11, 571936) In Natal, once a certificate is issued, it is valid for ever.
('7', 254, 1, 12, 571998) In the Transvaal, too, the certificate intended to be issued will be a permanent one.
('7', 254, 1, 13, 572084) In the Cape, when an Indian wants to go out, he must take a “ticket of leave”.
('7', 254, 1, 14, 572163) If he does not take it and if he does not know English, he cannot return.
('7', 254, 1, 15, 572237) We hold this to be a very oppressive measure.
('7', 254, 1, 16, 572283) Besides, for such a ‘ticket of leave”, a fee of £l has to be paid.
('7', 254, 1, 17, 572350) There is not much difference between this and slavery.
('7', 254, 1, 18, 572405) Why cannot one leave the Cape without a “ticket of leave” ?
('7', 254, 1, 19, 572465) There are remedies yet.
('7', 254, 1, 20, 572489) One is that the Cape leaders should put up a big fight and get the law amended.
('7', 254, 1, 21, 572569) The other is that they should show their strength at the Cape election.
('7', 254, 1, 22, 572641) There is also another sting in the law which is worth noting.
('7', 254, 1, 23, 572703) Every Indian is compelled to give his photograph.
('7', 254, 1, 24, 572753) That some people are not asked to show the photograph need not flatter anyone.
('7', 254, 1, 25, 572832) If influential people are excluded from this, what benefit does it mean to the Indian community?
('7', 254, 1, 26, 572929) That will not preserve our honour in any way.
('7', 254, 1, 27, 572975) There is a third way which we may think of.
('7', 254, 1, 28, 573019) In the course of the argument in the above mentioned case, it was submitted that the Act of 1906 was not applicable to those Indians who had been living in the Cape since before 1902. As this question was not one of the points for decision in the case, the Court did not give a ruling on it, and declared that it would consider the question as and when such a case arose.
('7', 254, 1, 29, 573391) According to the Act of 1902, any Indian living in South Africa had the right to enter the Cape.
('7', 254, 1, 30, 573488) From this it is assumed that the Act of 1906 cannot be applied to Indians living there since before 1902. If this argument is correct, then such Indians do not require “tickets of leave”.
('7', 254, 1, 31, 573676) In order to raise such a case in a court of law, an Indian residing there from before 1902 should go out of the Cape and try to return.
('7', 254, 1, 32, 573812) If the Immigration Officer prevents him, then the question can be raised in the Supreme Court.
('7', 254, 1, 33, 573907) There is no doubt at all

('7', 255, 2, 5, 574153) 207. JOHANNESBURG LETTER.
('7', 255, 3, 6, 574179) SMUTS REPLY TO DISGRACEFUL LETTER I said earlier that Mr. Smuts had replied to the petition submitted to him by Mr. Roos on behalf of certain Indian leaders.
('7', 255, 3, 7, 574337) Here is a translation of the reply: 1
('7', 255, 4, 8, 574375) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th August last on the subject of the regulations framed under the Asiatic Law Amendment Act (No.
('7', 255, 4, 9, 574541) 2 of 1907) and to inform you as follows: 1. If Asiatics who are residing in the Transvaal submit to the provisions of the law in question, the Government is prepared to accede to their request that special authority be granted empowering certain selected officers, who shall be white persons, to call for the production of certificates from Indians except in cases of suspicion or crime.
('7', 255, 4, 10, 574929) 2. Clerks who issue trading licences will not be em powered to investigate the bona fides of applicants.
('7', 255, 4, 11, 575034) Such licence will be issued on the presentation by its lawful holder of a certificate of registration and all that will be further required from the applicant in this respect is the furnishing of an impression of his right hand thumb.
('7', 255, 4, 12, 575269) This impression will be forwarded for verification to the Registrar of Asiatics, Pretoria, and, if found to be correct, no further investigation or action will be necessary.
('7', 255, 4, 13, 575443) 3. With regard to the proposed importation of Asiatic clerks under temporary permits, the earlier decision cannot be altered.
('7', 255, 4, 14, 575569) 4. There is no question of removing children from the ca re of their parents or guardians, and no order to leave the Colo ny will be made in respect of Asiatics under the age of 16 years.
('7', 255, 4, 15, 575757) The requirement that parents and guardians shall on making application for registration supply the particulars of
('7', 255, 5, 16, 575871) 1 The translation given here has been collated with the original in English which appeared in Indian Opinion, 5 10 1907.

('7', 256, 1, 2, 576036) their male children and wards must be carried out.
('7', 256, 1, 3, 576087) 5. Apart from the Chinese Consul and others from whom it is not the practice to demand finger prints, it is not possible to exempt other Asiatics from the requirement of furnishing their finger impressions.
('7', 256, 2, 4, 576294) AS THE GIFTS, SO THE SONGS 1
('7', 256, 3, 5, 576323) Accordingly, the gentlemen on whose behalf the petition was addressed have received the reply that they deserve.
('7', 256, 3, 6, 576436) This reply shows that Mr. Smuts has not conceded even a single point.
('7', 256, 3, 7, 576506) The demand that the permits should be inspected by white officers would not be granted if the applicants alone got themselves specially registered, but only if all Indians submitted to the law.
('7', 256, 3, 8, 576700) If I were at all to have my hands blackened, I for one would say that it would make no difference whether my register was inspected by a white or a black.
('7', 256, 3, 9, 576855) If the black inspects it, he may be a little polite.
('7', 256, 3, 10, 576908) Readers may inform me if there is any instance of a white officer having been polite to slaves.
('7', 256, 3, 11, 577004) I shall then do my best to make the name of such white officer immortal through this paper.
('7', 256, 3, 12, 577096) As for the remaining demands, Mr. Smuts has given a flat refusal, and that too in language deserved by those who would make themselves slaves.
('7', 256, 3, 13, 577239) He has also shown how some of the demands were pointless.
('7', 256, 3, 14, 577297) For instance, the one pertaining to boys.
('7', 256, 3, 15, 577339) Even if Mr. Smuts desired to do so, he could not lay hands on boys under 16 years without amending the new law.
('7', 256, 3, 16, 577451) If a child does not give its finger prints, it cannot be punished, but the father who fails to teach his child the alphabet of slavery will be punished!
('7', 256, 3, 17, 577604) How can the Government afford to have sons of slaves grow up in a spirit of independence?
('7', 256, 3, 18, 577694) The sons of Englishmen learn drill and know how to handle a gun from the age of eight.
('7', 256, 3, 19, 577781) We, however, have been branded as slaves; hence our sons can only have an education for slavery.
('7', 256, 3, 20, 577878) “Like father, like son”: this has always been so.
('7', 256, 3, 21, 577928) What further comment on the reply should I make?
('7', 256, 3, 22, 577977) It will be enough to say just this: If the cruel blow dealt by this letter should in some degree rouse the spirit of our brethren at Pretoria, they might yet give up their attachment to money and make bold to send a fitting reply to Mr. Smuts, and retrieving their mistake, heartily join the fight that is being waged by the Indian community.
('7', 256, 3, 23, 578320) Indeed, Mr. Smuts’ letter should provoke every Indian.
('7', 256, 3, 24, 578375) It should lead every Indian lion to this decision: “I shall have nothing to do with the Transvaal, if Mr. Smuts
('7', 256, 4, 25, 578487) 1 A Gujarati proverb implying that one gets what one deserves
('7', 257, 0, 1, 578549) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 257, 1, 2, 578591) will let me stay here only on the terms mentioned in his letter.
('7', 257, 1, 3, 578656) There is the great God to provide for us.
('7', 257, 1, 4, 578698) A mere crumb of bread He will give at any other place as well.” Once we are inspired by such a spirit, people will see how glorious our struggle can be.
('7', 257, 1, 5, 578851) Such persons, like the brave Thoreau, will find gaol to be a palace, and the cry of challenge from Indians in prison shall pierce Mr. Smuts through and through.
('7', 257, 2, 6, 579012) HAJEE CASSIM’S EXPLANATION
('7', 257, 3, 7, 579039) The responsibility for Mr. Roos’s letter is placed on Mr. Hajee Cassim.
('7', 257, 3, 8, 579111) He, therefore, believes that injustice has been done to him, and offers the following explanation, which I place before the community.
('7', 257, 3, 9, 579246) Mr. Hajee Cassim writes:
('7', 257, 4, 10, 579271) The petition submitted to the Colonial Secretary was made jointly by certain gentlemen.
('7', 257, 4, 11, 579359) Again, it was couched in humble language not at my instance but on the advice of the counsel.
('7', 257, 4, 12, 579453) We, too, thought it proper to apply to the Government in humble terms.
('7', 257, 4, 13, 579524) People had joined in making that application, thinking that a humble petition would induce the Government to grant our demands.
('7', 257, 4, 14, 579652) They all gave their consent.
('7', 257, 4, 15, 579681) It is not true that it was especially I who got the application made.
('7', 257, 4, 16, 579751) Indian Opinion wrongly lays the blame at my door.

('7', 257, 4, 18, 579826) To get registered or not depends on one’s own will.
('7', 257, 4, 19, 579878) Someone seems to have supplied you with false information.
('7', 257, 4, 20, 579937) It is not proper to rely upon it and wrongly mention my name in the paper.
('7', 257, 4, 21, 580012) From the very first, I have publicly told the leaders of the British Indian Association that, as long as God kept up my courage, I would go along with my brethren and that, even if I were to lose courage in the end, I would do whatever might be necessary on their advice and with their assistance.
('7', 257, 5, 22, 580310) It is quite a different matter if the charge against me is that of joining the other gentlemen in sending the petition.
('7', 257, 5, 23, 580430) I have always been a person of mild temper, and I joined [them] thinking that those seeking a compromise with the Government were doing a wise thing.
('7', 257, 5, 24, 580580) For, like the rest I also thought that the law would not be repealed and the better course would be only to seek amendments through an understanding with the Govern ment and thus handle the situation in a spirit of compromise.
('7', 257, 5, 25, 580807) The struggle put up by the British Indian Association is just, I have full sympathy with it, and I wish it godspeed.
('7', 258, 0, 1, 580924) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 259
('7', 258, 1, 2, 580968) SMUTS SPEECH Mr. Smuts made a speech 1 at a meeting in his constituency, in which he also touched upon the question of the new law.
('7', 258, 1, 3, 581100) I give below a translation of his speech: 2
('7', 258, 2, 4, 581144) There is yet another Asiatic question—namely, the Indians and the Chinese living in the country.
('7', 258, 2, 5, 581241) These people are detrimentalto the everlasting prosperity of South Africa.
('7', 258, 2, 6, 581316) Under the old law, Indians could not remain in the country unless they allowed themselves to be registered and paid a certain sum of money.
('7', 258, 2, 7, 581456) Under that law, all Indians were registered.
('7', 258, 2, 8, 581501) However, on account of the severe competition from the Indians, the Volksraad passed a law whereby Indians could only trade in Bazaars.
('7', 258, 2, 9, 581637) But the British Government stepped in, and said that these people were their subjects, and according to the London Convention, all their subjects are to be treated alike.
('7', 258, 2, 10, 581808) The law thus became impracticable, and the result was that the Indians carried on trade all over the country.
('7', 258, 2, 11, 581918) They carried on business without a licence, and they were thereby even better off than the white traders.
('7', 258, 2, 12, 582024) This position, however intolerable, was kept up by the British Government till the war broke out.
('7', 258, 2, 13, 582122) The result may now be studied in Prinsloo Street, Pretoria, Pietersburg, Potchefstroom and other centres, where trade is largely in the hands of the Indian storekeepers.
('7', 258, 2, 14, 582292) And yet people persist in asking—Whence this depression?
('7', 258, 2, 15, 582349) Why all this poverty ?
('7', 258, 2, 16, 582372) Indian trade is one of the causes thereof.
('7', 258, 2, 17, 582415) The Indians have tried to get the same hold here as they have done in Natal.
('7', 258, 2, 18, 582492) They want to have all trade in their hands.
('7', 258, 2, 19, 582536) The Government has tackled the question.
('7', 258, 2, 20, 582577) We have passed a law unanimously, making it compulsory for Indians to register.
('7', 258, 2, 21, 582657) I think it highly desirable that the public should know the exact details of the law, as I expect that there may be trouble over it.
('7', 258, 2, 22, 582790) The law has been made severe because of the large number of Indians we have to deal with, there being no fewer than 15,000 Indians and 1,200 Chinese storekeepers in the Colony.
('7', 258, 2, 23, 582967) Certificates issued under the old law have been fraudulently duplicated and sold.
('7', 258, 2, 24, 583049) In Bombay, Johannesburg and Durban there are known to be places where these manufactured certificates can be bought by Indians for so
('7', 258, 3, 25, 583183) 1 Vide “Smuts’ Speech”, 12 10 1907
('7', 258, 4, 26, 583218) 2 The text given here is from the report in English as reproduced in Indian Opinion, 12 10 1907, with some changes needed to bring it into conformity with the Gujarati version.
('7', 259, 0, 1, 583395) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 259, 1, 2, 583437) much cash, and as one Indian cannot be well distinguished from another, the Government has decided to have the finger print system.
('7', 259, 1, 3, 583569) The Indians object to this on the plea that it is too degrading.
('7', 259, 1, 4, 583634) (Laughter.) A deputation of Indians went to England and interviewed the Government, but the latter sanctioned the law.
('7', 259, 1, 5, 583753) I have personally investigated the pleading of the Indians.
('7', 259, 1, 6, 583813) What do I find?
('7', 259, 1, 7, 583829) I find that these self same people have to make their finger impressions before they leave India, where the system is in vogue for several objects.
('7', 259, 1, 8, 583977) Any person being an ex official or ex soldier in India entitled to a pension must put his finger prints down, otherwise he cannot draw his pension.
('7', 259, 1, 9, 584125) All these things came to light when the Indians sent a deputation to England.

('7', 259, 2, 11, 584307) The Indians have been given time to register.
('7', 259, 2, 12, 584353) The Government has found that pickets of coolies have been placed near the Registration Office, with the result that only a few registrations have taken place, but I may just remind them that all things have an end.
('7', 259, 2, 13, 584569) The law will be rigidly enforced, and any Indian who has not registered himself after expiry of the period for registration will be put across the border.
('7', 259, 2, 14, 584724) A new notice has been issued that on December 31 no traders’ licences will be issued unless registration has taken place.

('7', 259, 2, 18, 585059) (Loud applause.) The Indians evidently think that the Government will give in, but I assure you that the Government does not contemplate any such course.
('7', 259, 2, 19, 585213) I warn the Indians that the Government will insist on the strict enforcement of the law, and I trust that the newspapers will make it fairly plain that on December 31 the doors will be closed against them for ever.
('7', 259, 2, 20, 585428) I have no quarrel with the Indians; the object is not persecution, but a stoppage of the influx of Indians.
('7', 259, 2, 21, 585536) We have made up our mind to make this a white man’s country, and, however difficult the task before us in this matter, we have put our foot down, and shall keep it there.

('7', 260, 2, 3, 585864) ASSOCIATION MEETING
('7', 260, 3, 4, 585884) With the permission of the Hamidia Islamic Society, a meeting of the Association took place at the Society’s hall last Sunday.
('7', 260, 3, 5, 586011) Mr. Essop Mia took the chair.
('7', 260, 3, 6, 586041) The hall was packed to capacity.
('7', 260, 3, 7, 586074) Mr. Quinn, President of the Chinese Association, and other Chinese were also present.
('7', 260, 3, 8, 586160) After Mr. Essop Mia’s speech, Mr. Gandhi said with reference to the pickets that it was necessary for them to use utmost courtesy.
('7', 260, 3, 9, 586291) They should not stand in a group at any one place.
('7', 260, 3, 10, 586342) They were in the position of soldiers.
('7', 260, 3, 11, 586381) The soldier’s duty was to carry out orders, maintain discipline and never leave the place of duty.
('7', 260, 3, 12, 586480) Soldiers had a leader over them, and he should also be obeyed.
('7', 260, 3, 13, 586543) If any of the pickets whose names were with Mr. Gandhi were arrested while they were doing their duty, he (Mr. Gandhi) would defend them.
('7', 260, 3, 14, 586681) If, however, they should be sentenced to a fine, they were not to pay it, but must go to gaol instead.
('7', 260, 3, 15, 586784) Pickets who misbehaved or went in for violentquarrels would not be defended in any way.
('7', 260, 3, 16, 586872) Then Mr. Gandhi went on to explain the need to continue the South Africa British Indian Committee, and referred to Mr. Ritch’s letter in detail.
('7', 260, 3, 17, 587017) Afterwards the meeting was addressed by Messrs Emam Abdool Cadir, T. Naidoo, Abdul Rahman (of Potchefstroom), Nawab Khan, Coovadia, Ali Mahomed, Joseph, Omarji Sale and others.
('7', 260, 3, 18, 587194) They pointed out that the Committee must be maintained.
('7', 260, 3, 19, 587250) Mr. Joseph asked what was to be done for those losing their jobs.
('7', 260, 3, 20, 587316) In reply, Mr. Gandhi said that all of them had to suffer every hardship that might befall, including that of going to gaol.
('7', 260, 3, 21, 587440) If those in service cared for their honour, they would not care for their jobs.
('7', 260, 3, 22, 587520) If a person lost his job, he could get another.
('7', 260, 3, 23, 587568) But honour once lost could never be regained.
('7', 260, 3, 24, 587614) If a job were lost for the sake of the country, what would it matter?
('7', 260, 3, 25, 587684) In regard to licence notices, Mr. Gandhi said in reply to a question by Mr. Coovadia that, if no licence was issued, the only proper thing would be to go to gaol.
('7', 260, 3, 26, 587847) But there would be no difficulty in trading without a licence.
('7', 260, 3, 27, 587910) If, however, the Indian community felt afraid, a test case could be made.
('7', 260, 3, 28, 587984) That would, of course, need money.

('7', 264, 5, 5, 594349) 211. LETTER TO “THE STAR” 1
('7', 264, 6, 6, 594377) JOHANNESBURG, October 18, 1907
('7', 264, 8, 7, 594408) THE EDITOR THE STAR JOHANNESBURG] SIR,
('7', 264, 9, 8, 594447) Whilst the totally inoffensive Indian pickets are being charged, without an iota of proof, with intimidation of those who may wish to take out registration certificates, you will, perhaps, be so good as to allow me to draw public attention to the hollowness of the charge, as also to counter intimidation, which is a reality.
('7', 264, 9, 9, 594773) A case happened yesterday in which three Indians from Pietersburg were actually offered escort by the pickets, but it was refused.
('7', 264, 9, 10, 594904) The fact is that an attempt is being made to discredit the pickets by feigning terror, and by asking for police protection.
('7', 264, 9, 11, 595028) We, too, have our “national scouts”.
('7', 264, 9, 12, 595065) They undoubtedly wish to increase their number, and allegation of intimidation is one of the methods adopted.
('7', 264, 9, 13, 595175) If there is any truth in the charge, why has not anyone been prosecuted?
('7', 264, 9, 14, 595248) It must be theeasiest thing to prove, because intimidation is supposed to take place in broad daylight in Von Brandis Square in the presence of hundreds of passers by.
('7', 264, 9, 15, 595416) As to counter intimidation, many Indians believe that Indians possessing permits issued by either Capt.
('7', 264, 9, 16, 595520) Hamilton Fowle or Mr. Chamney are, under quasi official pressure, being dismissed for not having submitted to the Registration Act.
('7', 264, 9, 17, 595652) Whether such pressure exists
('7', 264, 10, 18, 595681) 1 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 26 10 1907.
('7', 265, 0, 1, 595734) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 265, 1, 2, 595776) or not, I have before me a letter from the chief ganger at Germiston, confirming the information received that nine Indians were dismissed because they would not apply to be registered under the new Act.
('7', 265, 1, 3, 595980) It causes little wonder, seeing that General Smuts himself has led the way.
('7', 265, 1, 4, 596056) He has threatened all kinds of punishment—deportation and deprivation of licences at the same time for the same persons.
('7', 265, 1, 5, 596177) How both can take place I do not know.
('7', 265, 1, 6, 596216) Physical deportation is not even possible without the immigration measure, which has still to receive Royal sanction.
('7', 265, 1, 7, 596334) Indians do not mind a fair fight, and, so far as I can see, they are prepared even for an unfair fight, though it will be strictly un British.
('7', 265, 1, 8, 596477) Why should the assistance of European employers be called in to force Indians to take out certificates of slavery?
('7', 265, 1, 9, 596592) That many employers have up to now resisted any such pressure and positively declined to dismiss Indians in their employ redounds to the credit of both—of the employers because they will not take part in the process of hitting below the belt, of the Indians because they are too valuable and faithful servants to be dismissed.
('7', 265, 1, 10, 596919) I have just learned that the four Indians on whose behalf it was stated that they were intimidated, and who were admittedly without any permits, have to day been discharged and assured in the open Court that they will receive registration certificates.
('7', 265, 1, 11, 597172) No doubt slaves deserve their badge.
('7', 265, 1, 12, 597209) In my opinion, those who possess old Dutch passes, as these men are alleged to do, should be treated in the same way as those who have received permits under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, but it is a matter of public knowledge that Mr. Jordan had to perform the painful duty of giving all such persons notice to quit the Colony.
('7', 265, 1, 13, 597542) One such man received notice the same day that the four men above named stated they would apply for new registration certi ficates.
('7', 265, 1, 14, 597674) General Smuts is thus, indeed, finding out the lawful residents from the unlawful ones.
('7', 265, 1, 15, 597762) The latter will become, under the Registration Act, the chosen people, because they will have applied for certificates under it, and the former, because they value their manliness more than worldly riches, will be turned into unlawful residents.

('7', 265, 4, 18, 598054) 212. MR. RITCH’S SERVICES
('7', 265, 5, 19, 598080) A member of the South Africa British Indian Committee writes of Mr. Ritch in the following strain:
('7', 265, 6, 20, 598179) The Indian community can never be sufficiently grateful [for] or appreciative
('7', 266, 0, 1, 598257) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 267
('7', 266, 1, 2, 598301) of the Herculean work and devotion of this able, capable, self sacrificing man.
('7', 266, 1, 3, 598381) Not only do Indians in South Africa endorse every adjective used above, but they realize that at no time can his services be so valuable as now.
('7', 266, 1, 4, 598526) The Indians in the Transvaal are fighting a struggle the like of which will not recur in this generation.
('7', 266, 1, 5, 598632) It is, therefore, imperative that Lord Ampthill, in his endeavour to secure redress for the Transvaal Indians, should be assisted by the ever vigilant and indefatigable Mr. Ritch Indian Opinion, 19 10 1907
('7', 266, 2, 6, 598838) 213. GENERAL BOTHA’S EXAMPLE
('7', 266, 3, 7, 598867) Though the Indian community is fighting heroically in the Transvaal, there is a secret anxiety as to what will happen in the end.
('7', 266, 3, 8, 598997) Anyone who feels such anxiety must have very little faith in truth and in God.
('7', 266, 3, 9, 599076) To those who feel concerned for this or any other reason, we hold up the example of the present rulers of the Transvaal.
('7', 266, 3, 10, 599197) Readers will remember that, before the whites of the Transvaal were granted self government, Mr. Lyttelton had offered them partial self govern ment, on the advice of Lord Milner.
('7', 266, 3, 11, 599377) General Botha, General Smuts and others could have joined it.
('7', 266, 3, 12, 599439) But such rights appearing insufficient, General Botha wrote to Lord Milner to say that they would not participate in his Government and that they were not satisfied with the constitution which was offered to them.
('7', 266, 3, 13, 599653) This piqued Lord Milner.
('7', 266, 3, 14, 599678) There was a huge meeting at the Wanderers’ Hall.
('7', 266, 3, 15, 599727) Speaking at the meeting, Lord Milner held out the threat to General Botha that if the Boers did not join in running the government, it would be carried on without them.
('7', 266, 3, 16, 599896) The threat did not move General Botha.
('7', 266, 3, 17, 599935) The result now is that the Boers have complete self government.
('7', 266, 3, 18, 599999) Here is an example of a great boycott.
('7', 266, 3, 19, 600038) Botha carried out a boycott and won.
('7', 266, 3, 20, 600075) It should be noted in regard to this instance that the Boers prepared themselves for a boycott because they did not get the additional rights they had demanded.
('7', 266, 3, 21, 600236) We are not asking for more rights, but are opposing the yoke of slavery that is being imposed upon us.
('7', 266, 3, 22, 600339) What is there for us to be afraid of in doing so?
('7', 266, 3, 23, 600389) Botha’s boycott succeeded because he had full confidence, and because he convinced Lord Milner that it was not merely an empty threat he was holding out of not participating in the government, but that he meant what he said.
('7', 266, 3, 24, 600614) In our struggle, Mr. Smuts is still not convinced that the Indians are really strong enough.
('7', 266, 3, 25, 600707) We hope the Indian community will take a lesson from General Botha’s example and hold out to the last.
('7', 266, 3, 26, 600810) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 19 10 1907
('7', 267, 0, 1, 600853) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 267, 1, 2, 600895) 214. LESSON FROM PETERS CASE
('7', 267, 2, 3, 600924) Why did Mr. Peters have to suffer in Volksrust?
('7', 267, 2, 4, 600972) This question ought to arise in the mind of every Indian.
('7', 267, 2, 5, 601030) If a well dressed European travels in a first or second class carriage, he will be presumed to be a respectable man.
('7', 267, 2, 6, 601147) In fact he may be a great criminal.
('7', 267, 2, 7, 601183) In the case of a person with black skin, it will be presumed that he is a rogue, though in fact he may be a respectable man.
('7', 267, 2, 8, 601308) This is what happened to Mr. Peters.
('7', 267, 2, 9, 601345) The examining constable took it for granted that Mr. Peters had a false permit.
('7', 267, 2, 10, 601425) The officer is not much to blame in this.
('7', 267, 2, 11, 601467) The blame lies with the Government.
('7', 267, 2, 12, 601503) They have passed the obnoxious law on the assumption that Indians are liars and the examining constable acted on it.
('7', 267, 2, 13, 601620) Thus it is that the Indian is not respected today.
('7', 267, 2, 14, 601671) If the Indian community were now to submit to the obnoxious law, how could it be surprising if the whites, apart from respecting an Indian, never even talked to him without first giving him a kick?
('7', 267, 2, 15, 601869) It is for these strong reasons that the Indian is opposing the law, not on account of any one section in it, or because of finger prints.
('7', 267, 2, 16, 602007) If the root of the law is bad, what is the use of quarrelling with its twigs?
('7', 267, 2, 17, 602085) It is necessary to lay the axe at the root.
('7', 267, 2, 18, 602129) And that axe is the courage and manliness of Indians.
('7', 267, 2, 19, 602183) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 19 10 1907

('7', 268, 2, 3, 603199) Everyone knew that as in Natal, so in the Transvaal, a law would be passed to fix closing hours for shops.

('7', 268, 4, 12, 603998) HAMIDIA MEETING
('7', 268, 5, 13, 604014) This Society is growing in strength.
('7', 268, 5, 14, 604051) The spirit of the people is also rising and both Hindus and Muslims shout with one voice that the law should be wrecked.
('7', 268, 5, 15, 604172) On Sunday Mr. Emam Abdool Cadir took the chair.
('7', 268, 5, 16, 604220) The Moulvi Saheb and the Dervish Saheb spoke at great length.
('7', 268, 5, 17, 604282) Messrs Coovadia, Omarji Sale and others also spoke.
('7', 268, 5, 18, 604334) Mr. H. A. Coovadia and others argued that since Mr. S. Haloo had soiled his hands and face and had applied for registration, he be boycotted.
('7', 268, 5, 19, 604476) The suggestion was hailed by the whole meeting.
('7', 268, 5, 20, 604524) The Society has recommended that all contacts with Mr. Haloo should be cut off, his employees should give notice and quit his service, and that other Indians should have no business dealings with him.
('7', 268, 5, 21, 604725) Then a member of the Society, Mr. Dawji Patel of Klerksdorp, who was proceeding to India, paid all the arrears of subscription and also paid another ten shillings with a view to retaining his membership of the Society while he was away in India.
('7', 268, 5, 22, 604971) The Society presented to him a silver medal.
('7', 268, 5, 23, 605016) There were complimentary speeches by some gentlemen.
('7', 268, 5, 24, 605069) Mr. Dawji Patel has already left for India.
('7', 268, 5, 25, 605113) Next day (Monday) Mr. Haloo himself went to Mr. Gandhi’s office to express regret for having made the application to register himself.
('7', 268, 5, 26, 605248) The pickets immediately came to know of this and sent a
('7', 269, 0, 1, 605304) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 269, 1, 2, 605346) notice to Mr. Gandhi: “Please note that if Mr. Haloo visits your office again, you too will be boycotted.” In reply to the notice, Mr. Gandhi thanked the pickets and complimented them on having done their duty.
('7', 269, 1, 3, 605557) I want all Indians to have the same burning enthusiasm always.
('7', 269, 1, 4, 605620) Having such enthusiasm is unconnected with the question whether, if Mr. Haloo should offer a formal apology to the Society and express regret, his apology should be accepted or not.
('7', 269, 1, 5, 605802) What is to be noted and acted upon is that a pledge once given must be observed and that the duty assigned to us must be carried out.
('7', 269, 1, 6, 605936) It was the duty of the pickets to act as they did, so long as Mr. Haloo’s action had not been condoned.

('7', 269, 4, 16, 606760) ILLUMUTHU’S CASE
('7', 269, 5, 17, 606777) Illumuthu’s case is worth studying.

('7', 269, 5, 19, 606946) In 1897, Illumuthu had gone to Bulawayo.
('7', 269, 5, 20, 606987) Before the war, he had been working on Cook’s Farm at Johannesburg.
('7', 269, 5, 21, 607055) For a month he worked in Robinson Mine.

('7', 269, 5, 25, 607317) There they asked for his particulars, which he gave as above.

('7', 269, 5, 29, 607564) The Registrar did not offer him a pie by way of travelling expenses.
('7', 269, 5, 30, 607633) The magistrate says that it is none of his concern.

('7', 270, 2, 15, 608578) CHINESE UNITY Messrs Harvin and Paterson, a prominent business firm here, have a large business with the Chinese.
('7', 270, 2, 16, 608692) They supply them on credit goods worth about £500 every month.
('7', 270, 2, 17, 608755) The firm gave notice to the Chinese that further credit would be stopped if they did not take out the new registers.
('7', 270, 2, 18, 608872) The Chinese, instead of being intimidated by this, became bolder.
('7', 270, 2, 19, 608938) In reply, they asked the amount of the debit entries against them in the firm’s books, offering immediate payment, and declining to do any further business with the firm.
('7', 270, 2, 20, 609109) Mr. Harvin was silenced by this reply, apologized to the Chinese and agreed not to refer any more to the registers or to their accounts.
('7', 270, 2, 21, 609246) Our merchants, when threatened by white merchants, get scared and become ready to take out registers as if they were slaves.
('7', 270, 2, 22, 609371) They then forget the oath they had taken not to submit to the law.
('7', 270, 3, 23, 609438) PICKETS’ WORK
('7', 270, 4, 24, 609452) The pickets have been exerting themselves a great deal.
('7', 270, 4, 25, 609508) There is no doubt that their exertion has prevented many weak kneed Indians from going to the Registration Office.
('7', 270, 4, 26, 609623) Pickets have been posted at Park, Fordsburg, Bramfontein, Doornfontein and at Jeppe stations, as also round the Permit Office.
('7', 270, 4, 27, 609750) As a result of these arrangements, three Indian workmen coming from Roodepoort were intercepted.

('7', 271, 4, 9, 610777) CAN TIME BE GRANTED FOR LEAVING ?
('7', 271, 5, 10, 610811) A question has been asked: If the attack begins in December and people are produced before a magistrate, will they be allowed time [for leaving]?
('7', 271, 5, 11, 610957) When a person is produced before a magistrate for not taking out the new register, he can ask for time, and it will be for the magistrate to decide what time to give.
('7', 271, 5, 12, 611124) That is, he may grant anything between one hour and one year.
('7', 271, 5, 13, 611186) I do not say that a long time will necessarily be allowed, but there is no doubt that the magistrate has the power to allow whatever time he thinks fit.
('7', 271, 5, 14, 611339) I think asking for time will be humiliating and I shall not advise anybody to do so.
('7', 271, 5, 15, 611424) Still, those who get frightened of gaol and desire to wind up their affairs can ask for time, and I don’t think the magistrate will refuse to grant it altogether.
('7', 271, 5, 16, 611587) Everything will depend on the merits of each case, on the magistrate and on the circumstances.

('7', 272, 1, 2, 612528) “THE SUNDAY TIMES” Since the Passive Resistance movement [was mooted], The Sunday Times has been publishing cartoons every week.
('7', 272, 1, 3, 612657) The cartoon published this week shows the office of the Registration Officers who draw their salaries without doing any work.

('7', 272, 2, 5, 612879) HAJEE HABIB Mr. Hajee Habib has arrived at Pretoria from Durban.
('7', 272, 3, 6, 612944) WHY IS WHOLE OF NOVEMBER KEPT BLANK ?
('7', 272, 3, 7, 612982) Some people have asked me whether the Government is so hungry that it will eat up the whole of November.
('7', 272, 3, 8, 613087) If Indians are to be prosecuted, why should it not start on the first of November?
('7', 272, 3, 9, 613170) Those who ask this question have not been reading Indian Opinion carefully.
('7', 272, 3, 10, 613246) Otherwise, my explanation of the notice did include this point.
('7', 272, 3, 11, 613310) I request the reader to read Indian Opinion henceforth with great care.
('7', 272, 3, 12, 613382) It will not take many days to do so.
('7', 272, 3, 13, 613419) Rather, I am convinced that the reader will find in it something worth knowing.
('7', 272, 3, 14, 613499) After saying this, I reply to the question.
('7', 272, 3, 15, 613543) The notice issued says that those without new registers on or after December 1 will be prosecuted.
('7', 272, 3, 16, 613642) The month of October will all be taken up in receiving applications for registers.
('7', 272, 3, 17, 613725) The Registrar does not give his decision immediately on receipt of an application.
('7', 272, 3, 18, 613808) He has the authority to order further investigation after receiving it.
('7', 272, 3, 19, 613880) He is bound to take some time for such investigation.
('7', 272, 3, 20, 613934) The Government has allowed the month of November to Mr. Chamney for scrutiny of applications.
('7', 272, 3, 21, 614028) During this period, it will be decided whether those who have made the slavish application should be rewarded with slavery or not.
('7', 272, 3, 22, 614159) Hence everyone can have the register in December.
('7', 272, 3, 23, 614209) Some may ask why one whole month is allowed for this in spite of the boycott by the Indian community.
('7', 272, 3, 24, 614311) The answer is that the Government cannot take notice of the boycott.
('7', 272, 3, 25, 614380) In case a very large number of applicants turn up on 31st October and flood the Registration Office with applications, the Registrar has to be allowed enough time to decide on them.
('7', 272, 3, 26, 614562) For this reason, there is unfortunately a gap in November.
('7', 272, 4, 27, 614621) ATTACK ON PICKETS Mr. Alexander, advocate, and Mr. De Villiers, advocate, had each two Konkanis as clients on Tuesday.
('7', 272, 4, 28, 614740) The Konkanis were charged with staying on without a permit.
('7', 272, 4, 29, 614800) Both the counsels told Mr. Jordan that the said Konkanis were intimidated by pickets, and therefore could not go to the Registration Office.

('7', 275, 4, 14, 620719) 219. LETTER TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('7', 275, 5, 15, 620757) JOHANNESBURG, Before October 26, 1907]
('7', 275, 6, 16, 620796) [THE EDITOR THE TRANSVAAL LEADER JOHANNESBURG]
('7', 275, 7, 17, 620843) SIR, My Association is grateful to you for your temperate leaderette with reference to alleged intimidation by Asiatic passive resisters.
('7', 275, 7, 18, 620981) We can have no hesitation in endorsing every word of what you have said against any violence being used in the Indian movement.
('7', 275, 7, 19, 621109) Our aim in connection with the Asiatic Act has always been to secure redress by suffering ourselves, not by imposing suffering on others.
('7', 275, 7, 20, 621247) The paragraph in your columns is evidently inspired.
('7', 275, 7, 21, 621300) I have no
('7', 276, 0, 1, 621310) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 277
('7', 276, 1, 2, 621355) hesitation in denying the existence of a reign of terror, unless the very strong feeling against the Act permeating the whole mass of Indians in the Transvaal acts as a reign of terror among those who want to cut themselves adrift from the community and take out certificates under the Act, not because they like the process, but because they hold their pockets to be superior to their honour.
('7', 276, 1, 3, 621749) I admit the fact that several Asiatics who had left their places of employment with the distinct intention of registering decided not to do so on being accosted by the watchful pickets, who used the effective argument of placing before the registrants the true state of the Law and disabused their minds of the subtle inducements that had been held out to them as a reward for registering.
('7', 276, 1, 4, 622139) The public can haveno knowledge of the Herculean efforts being put forth by the Government to induce the community to register.
('7', 276, 1, 5, 622267) The pickets have never used threats, and constant watch is being kept by the responsible members of the community on the doings of the pickets.
('7', 276, 1, 6, 622411) The information about a Mahomedan priest being assaulted is, unfortunately, true, but he was.
('7', 276, 1, 7, 622505) not assaulted by a number of Indians.
('7', 276, 1, 8, 622543) The facts are these: The priest in question is not an Indian, but a Malay.
('7', 276, 1, 9, 622618) We have in our midst a Dervish, who is a devout follower of the Prophet.
('7', 276, 1, 10, 622691) He passes all his time in one of the three mosques, and earns his bread, whenever he thinks it worthwhile, by accepting the work of breaking stones on one of the mines.
('7', 276, 1, 11, 622860) He listens to no one, and is perhaps the most independent spirited man going in South Africa.
('7', 276, 1, 12, 622954) Everyone who has seen him and his simple life respects him.
('7', 276, 1, 13, 623014) When he heard that the Malay priest incited Indians, especially Indian Mahomedans, to violate the sanctity of their solemn oath and to submit to the Law, he was enraged.
('7', 276, 1, 14, 623184) He deliberately walked to the Malay Mosque, met the priest, and entered into an argument with him.
('7', 276, 1, 15, 623283) He cited a text from the Koran to convince the priest that he, of all the people, should have desisted, especially as he was not an Indian, from interfering with Indian matters and from inducing people to violate the Koranic precepts.
('7', 276, 1, 16, 623518) Warm words followed, and the unfortunate assault was the result.
('7', 276, 1, 17, 623583) To charge Indians with responsibility in the matter would, you will admit, be strictly unfair.
('7', 276, 1, 18, 623678) Many of us have reasoned with the Dervish and have implored him to restrain himself, but he recognises no intervention between himself and his God.
('7', 276, 1, 19, 623826) To him, needless to say, his home and the jailyard are one and the same thing, and, when reasoned with, he said he was quite willing to appear before the Court and justify his action.
('7', 276, 1, 20, 624010) As to the poisoning of the dog, the charge is wicked.
('7', 277, 0, 1, 624064) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('7', 278, 3, 7, 626949) He was one of the greatest and most moral men America has produced.

('7', 279, 4, 11, 629510) 223. PERVERSITY OF MEMONS
('7', 279, 5, 12, 629536) There is a saying among us to the effect that those who are about to be destroyed grow perverse first.
('7', 279, 5, 13, 629639) That is what has happened to the Memons in the Transvaal.
('7', 279, 5, 14, 629697) Only a very few of them must have remained without the title deed of slavery.
('7', 279, 5, 15, 629775) Those who have remained so we hold to be lions.
('7', 279, 5, 16, 629823) We are not writing this with the intention of giving pain to the persons who have made the evil choice but in the hope that other Indians will take a lesson from their evil deed.
('7', 279, 6, 17, 630002) There is no need for the other communities to get nervous because the Memons have taken out registers.
('7', 279, 6, 18, 630105) Fear is a sign of cowardice.
('7', 279, 6, 19, 630134) None need imagine that the Memons, having taken out permits under the obnoxious law, will be able to carry on their business in the Transvaal without let or hindrance and mint money and that other Indians will have to run away.
('7', 279, 6, 20, 630362) In fact, though some Memons have become slaves, hundreds of Indians have remained free and for this we must offer prayers of thanks to God.
('7', 279, 6, 21, 630502) We hold that only an ignorant man will expect the Memons to be able to carry on their business in peace though they might have taken out the title deed of slavery.
('7', 279, 6, 22, 630666) If the other Indians have at all to quit the Transvaal, the whites at least will witness the kicks that the Memons will get.
('7', 279, 6, 23, 630791) We shudder to think of the fate awaiting them.
('7', 280, 0, 1, 630838) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 281
('7', 280, 1, 2, 630883) However, we believe that, if most of the remaining Indians continue to be firm and are prepared to court arrest, no one will be required to leave the Transvaal.
('7', 280, 1, 3, 631044) All Indians who have the right to settle in the Transvaal will be able to do so in peace, and the new law will be wrecked.
('7', 280, 1, 4, 631167) We take it that those who think that it will not be wrecked have no faith in God’s truth and in His most holy justice.
('7', 280, 1, 5, 631286) We, therefore, entreat the other Indians to hold the honour of India high and to suffer all hardships rather than submit to the new law.

('7', 281, 3, 5, 633335) 225. INDIAN MERCHANTS OF LADYSMITH
('7', 281, 4, 6, 633370) Twelve Indian stores in Ladysmith district have been closed down.
('7', 281, 4, 7, 633436) We think this is very bad news indeed.
('7', 281, 4, 8, 633475) These merchants had applied again for licences.
('7', 281, 4, 9, 633523) No licences were issued to them, but they were served with notice that, if the stores were not closed down, they would be prosecuted.
('7', 281, 4, 10, 633657) Frightened by this notice, the merchants have closed down their stores.
('7', 281, 4, 11, 633729) We would like to urge them to be bold and open their stores for business.
('7', 281, 4, 12, 633803) Let the Government, if it so desires, prosecute them for carrying on trade without a licence.
('7', 281, 4, 13, 633897) After being tried, they will be fined, and when the fine is not paid, their goods will be auctioned.
('7', 281, 4, 14, 633998) We would particularly advise that they should allow the goods to be sold thus.
('7', 281, 4, 15, 634077) That will need courage.
('7', 281, 4, 16, 634101) Who will show that courage, if not brave people?
('7', 281, 4, 17, 634150) Some may say that, if the goods are auctioned, the people will be ruined.
('7', 281, 4, 18, 634224) Will not the people be ruined if the stores are closed down?
('7', 281, 4, 19, 634285) The Government will auction the goods once.
('7', 281, 4, 20, 634329) Can it do so every time?
('7', 281, 4, 21, 634354) It may prosecute one trader.
('7', 281, 4, 22, 634383) Will it prosecute twelve?
('7', 281, 4, 23, 634409) Supposing it does, will not the Imperial Government intervene?
('7', 281, 4, 24, 634472) It cannot but do so.
('7', 281, 4, 25, 634493) If, indeed, it does not, that also will be worth being sure about.
('7', 281, 4, 26, 634560) If the Indian community unites to give a fight, we are sure that the Natal Dealers’ Licences Act will be wrecked.
('7', 281, 4, 27, 634674) We advise the leaders of Durban that they should join hands with the merchants of Ladysmith to present a united front.
('7', 281, 4, 28, 634793) We are convinced that doing this requires courage rather than money.
('7', 281, 4, 29, 634862) He who is bold enough to give such a fight must remember (1) that the fight can be about old stores, (2) that the stores should be clean, and that (3) the proprietor should have an unblemished record.
('7', 281, 4, 30, 635063) If such storekeepers give a concerted fight, they cannot but win in the end.

('7', 282, 7, 23, 636631) As usual, a meeting of the Hamidia Islamic Society took place last Sunday.
('7', 282, 7, 24, 636706) The hall was packed to the full, and people were in high spirits.
('7', 282, 7, 25, 636772) Mr. Emam Abdool Cadir presided.
('7', 282, 7, 26, 636804) Mr. Ram Sundar Pundit made an eloquent speech and gave an account of his meeting with the Indian employees of the Railway.
('7', 282, 7, 27, 636927) Quoting verses from the holy
('7', 282, 8, 28, 636956) 1 “Dada” in Gujarati means grandfather.
('7', 283, 0, 1, 636996) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 283, 1, 2, 637038) Koran, Moulvi Saheb Ahmed Mukhtiar showed that, having taken an oath in the name of God, Muslims could never submit to the law.
('7', 283, 1, 3, 637166) He said that if Mr. Haloo’s servants encouraged him, they too ought to be boycotted.
('7', 283, 1, 4, 637251) No member of the community could allow it to be demoralized in any way.
('7', 283, 1, 5, 637323) Mr. Gandhi read out Mr. Hajee Habib’s letter from Pretoria and also the letter received from Klerksdorp.
('7', 283, 1, 6, 637428) He then pointed out that no one should talk of boycott.
('7', 283, 1, 7, 637484) But once boycott was decided upon, it should be carried out.
('7', 283, 1, 8, 637545) Mr. Alibhai Akuji said that, if it was decided to boycott all blacklegs, he would arrange to withdraw the Kanmia employees of Mr. Haloo.
('7', 283, 1, 9, 637682) Mr. M. S. Coovadia said that Mr. Hajee Habib spoke in his letter of some leaders in Johannesburg having secretly got themselves registered.
('7', 283, 1, 10, 637822) Mr. Coovadia was quite sure that this was not true.
('7', 283, 1, 11, 637874) He was in favour of boycotting all blacklegs.
('7', 283, 1, 12, 637920) He said that he had flatly refused to buy flour from Mr. S. Butcher, though he would have gained £50 by doing so, because the latter had conveyed to him that he would supply flour only if Mr. Coovadia got himself registered.
('7', 283, 1, 13, 638145) Mr. Coovadia had thus chosen to suffer a loss.
('7', 283, 1, 14, 638192) Mr. Omarji Sale supported the boycott.
('7', 283, 1, 15, 638231) Mr. Ebrahim Coovadia read out the article and poem on “Permit Piano” that had appeared in Al Islam.
('7', 283, 1, 16, 638331) Speaking again, the Moulvi Saheb proposed that the Hamidia Islamic Society should write to the President of the Indian National Congress about the struggle against the law.
('7', 283, 1, 17, 638504) Something should be done by the community about the refusal of the German Lines to issue first, second and third class tickets for their steamers on the European route.
('7', 283, 1, 18, 638673) Boycott would be a simple remedy.
('7', 283, 1, 19, 638707) Mr. Ebrahim Coovadia supported the Moulvi Saheb’s proposal to write to the Congress.
('7', 283, 1, 20, 638792) The meeting was then addressed by some other gentlemen, after which the President made his concluding remarks and terminated the meeting.
('7', 283, 2, 21, 638930) MEETING OF MADRASIS
('7', 283, 3, 22, 638950) The Madrasis held a meeting in Market Street.
('7', 283, 3, 23, 638996) About a hundred men were present.
('7', 283, 3, 24, 639030) Mr. Gandhi explained the whole position to them.
('7', 283, 3, 25, 639079) They all resolved to oppose the law firmly till the end.

('7', 284, 2, 5, 639799) ESSOP MIA’S LETTER
('7', 284, 3, 6, 639818) In reply to this, Mr. Essop Mia has addressed the following letter 1: Sir, My Association is grateful to you for your temperate leaderette with reference to alleged intimidation by passive resisters.
('7', 284, 3, 7, 640018) The paragraph in your columns is evidently inspired.
('7', 284, 3, 8, 640071) I have no hesitation in denying the existence of a reign of terror, unless the very strong feeling against the Act permeating the whole mass of Indians in the Transvaal acts as a reign of terror among those who want to cut themselves adrift from the community and take out certificates under the Act, not because they like the process, but because they hold their pockets to be superior to their honour.
('7', 284, 3, 9, 640475) I admit the fact that several Asiatics who had left their places of employment with the intention of registering decided not to do so on being accosted by the watchful pickets, who placed before the registrants the true state of the law and disabused their minds of the subtle inducements that had been held out to them.
('7', 284, 3, 10, 640796) The public can have no knowledge of the Herculean efforts being put forth by the Government to induce the community to register.
('7', 284, 3, 11, 640925) The pickets have never used threats, and constant watch is being kept by the responsible members of the community on the doings of the pickets.
('7', 284, 3, 12, 641069) The information about a Mahomedan priest having been assaulted is, unfortunately, true, but he was not assaulted by a number of Indians.
('7', 284, 3, 13, 641206) The facts are these: The priest in question is not an Indian, but a Malay.
('7', 284, 3, 14, 641281) We have in our midst a Dervish, who is a devout follower of the Prophet.
('7', 284, 3, 15, 641354) He passes all his time in a mosque and earns his bread, whenever he thinks it worth while, by accepting the work of
