('7', 285, 0, 1, 641659) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 285, 1, 2, 641701) breaking stones in one of the mines.
('7', 285, 1, 3, 641738) He listens to no one, and is perhaps the most independent spirited man going in South Africa.
('7', 285, 1, 4, 641832) Everyone who has seen him and his simple life respects him.
('7', 285, 1, 5, 641892) When he heard that the Malay priest incited Indians, especially Indian Mahomedans, to violate the sanctity of their solemn oath and to submit to the law, he was enraged.
('7', 285, 1, 6, 642062) He deliberately walked to the Malay Mosque, met the priest, and entered into an argument with him.
('7', 285, 1, 7, 642161) He cited a text from the Koran to convince the priest that he, of all people, should have desisted, especially as he was not an Indian, from interfering with Indian matters and from inducing people to violate the Koranic precepts.
('7', 285, 1, 8, 642392) Hot words followed, and the unfortunate assault was the result.
('7', 285, 1, 9, 642456) To charge Indians with responsibility in the matter would be strictly unfair.
('7', 285, 1, 10, 642534) Many of us have reasoned with the Dervish and have implored him to restrain himself, but he recognizes no intervention between himself and his God.
('7', 285, 1, 11, 642682) To him, needless to say, his home and the gaolyard are one and the same thing, and, when reasoned with, he said he was quite willing to appear before the court and justify his action.
('7', 285, 1, 12, 642866) As to the poisoning of the dog, the charge is wicked.
('7', 285, 1, 13, 642920) I have made very careful inquiry, and I can trace no connection between the poisoning and the registration of the master of the dog.
('7', 285, 1, 14, 643053) It is generally believed that this is done by thieves intending to avoid being detected by the barking of these dogs.
('7', 285, 1, 15, 643171) It will be terrible if every evil occurrence happening to an Indian blackleg were to be debited to Indian passive resisters.
('7', 285, 1, 16, 643296) No, Sir, we have no desire to resort to questionable methods in order to compel obedience to the wish of the majority of Indians on the part of the minority.
('7', 285, 1, 17, 643454) How can we who wish to be free as to our movements and, therefore, refuse to submit to the Asiatic Act put restraint upon others who do not think with us?
('7', 285, 1, 18, 643609) As to the Hindu priest mentioned by your reporter, there was certainly no fracas in Germiston.
('7', 285, 1, 19, 643704) It is perfectly true that the priest has interested himself, like every other Indian priest, whether Hindu or Mahomedan, in the Colony, in a question which affects the welfare of the whole Indian community.
('7', 285, 1, 20, 643911) No Indian prizing his religion can do otherwise.
('7', 285, 1, 21, 643960) Cannot a priest ask his congregation to look up toGod rather than to Mammon in a matter in which there is a choice between God and Mammon?
('7', 285, 2, 22, 644099) COMMENTS ON INCIDENT
('7', 285, 3, 23, 644120) This incident deserves serious reflection.
('7', 285, 3, 24, 644163) There is no doubt that Imam Kamali and Mr. Haloo have made exaggerated and false
('7', 286, 0, 1, 644244) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 287
('7', 286, 1, 2, 644289) statements to the Registration Officers.
('7', 286, 1, 3, 644330) Mr. Essop Mia states that it was not true that he was assaulted by a number of Indians.
('7', 286, 1, 4, 644418) It is obviously unfair to charge the whole Indian community with responsibility for the assault by one Dervish.
('7', 286, 1, 5, 644530) It is quite improbable that an Indian will poison Mr. Haloo’s dog.
('7', 286, 1, 6, 644597) We must realize from this incident that there can be no violence at any stage in our struggle.
('7', 286, 1, 7, 644692) We cannot win by using force.
('7', 286, 1, 8, 644722) Those who fight with trust in God do not need to resort to violence or similar methods.
('7', 286, 1, 9, 644810) I for one will never believe that truth can be defeated.
('7', 286, 1, 10, 644867) The case of Indians is perfectly just, and hence we need not fear the outcome.
('7', 286, 1, 11, 644946) Those who submit to the obnoxious law will find the new permits reacting of their own on the bodies of the Indians like a medically impure compound of mercury; they will then, indeed, soil their hands.
('7', 286, 2, 12, 645148) POLICE COMMISSIONER’S LETTER REGARDING PICKETS
('7', 286, 3, 13, 645195) Readers will recall that a letter was written to the Police Commissioner, saying that the pickets had not used any force.
('7', 286, 3, 14, 645317) The following reply has been received from him: 1
('7', 286, 4, 15, 645367) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, in respect to the pickets placed on the Registration Office, Von Brandis Square, and I am gratified to receive your assurance that no intimidation of intending applicants will be countenanced by your Association, and I trust that your efforts to see that no molestation occurs will be continued.
('7', 286, 4, 16, 645744) This letter makes it clear that there is nothing wrong in posting pickets.
('7', 286, 4, 17, 645819) It is only their using force or offering threats that is wrong.
('7', 286, 5, 18, 645883) NO LICENCES IN JANUARY?
('7', 286, 6, 19, 645907) A notice has been published in the Gazette that no licences will be issued in January to those who might not have taken out the new registers.
('7', 286, 6, 20, 646050) Even then, a notice in writing is being given to individual, leading Indians in every town that if they do not apply for registration before October 31, they will not be able to do so later and no licences will be issued to them in January.
('7', 286, 6, 21, 646291) A written receipt is also obtained when such a notice is served.
('7', 286, 6, 22, 646356) What does this mean?
('7', 286, 6, 23, 646377) It is obvious that the Government is afraid that, if the Indian community does not submit to the law, no action can be taken against it.
('7', 286, 6, 24, 646514) They are, therefore, getting restless now, and they want to get the people to apply for the title deeds of slavery by holding out boththreats and inducements.
('7', 286, 6, 25, 646673) In spite of these visible signs, there are some Indians

('7', 287, 1, 3, 647031) I hope the other Indians will take careful note of these signs and remain firm to the last.
('7', 287, 2, 4, 647123) GERMAN EAST AFRICA LINE 1
('7', 287, 3, 5, 647149) The information which the Moulvi Saheb gave at the Hamidia meeting, that no tickets other than deck tickets are issued to Indians on steamers plying on the European route should not be treated lightly.
('7', 287, 3, 6, 647351) It has been causing much friction for some time.
('7', 287, 3, 7, 647400) As the Moulvi Saheb pointed out, it is chiefly the pilgrims to Mecca who feel the hardship the most.
('7', 287, 3, 8, 647501) The remedy is very straight and simple.
('7', 287, 3, 9, 647541) In the first place, the Line has at different places Indian agents who can make careful arrangements.
('7', 287, 3, 10, 647643) The other remedy is that of a straight boycott.
('7', 287, 3, 11, 647691) The Line has a very large Indian clientele.
('7', 287, 3, 12, 647735) This income can be stopped if the Indian passengers are treated as mere cattle.
('7', 287, 3, 13, 647815) This requires a big effort among Indians.
('7', 287, 3, 14, 647857) It will be possible to make arrangements with the British India Steam Navigation Company and other companies.
('7', 287, 3, 15, 647967) Moreover, the Mogul Line can be got to ply its steamers on this route, as before.
('7', 287, 3, 16, 648049) There are many such remedies.
('7', 287, 4, 17, 648079) LETTER TO “THE STAR”
('7', 287, 5, 18, 648100) The charge against Indian pickets of using threats is obviously false; it is true, however, that at the instance of Government officials, some whites have been harassing Indians and using threats to make them take out the title deed of slavery.
('7', 287, 5, 19, 648345) On this, Mr. Gandhi has written the following letter to The Star: 2
('7', 287, 6, 20, 648413) Sir—Since the totally inoffensive Indian pickets are being charged, without an iota of proof, with intimidation of those who may wish to take out registration certificates, may I draw public attention to the hollowness of the charge, as also to counter intimidation, which is a reality?
('7', 287, 6, 21, 648700) A case happened yesterday in which three Indians from Pietersburg were actually offered escort by the pickets, but it was refused.
('7', 287, 6, 22, 648831) The fact is that an attempt is being made to discredit the pickets by feigning terror, and by asking for police protection.
('7', 287, 6, 23, 648955) If there is any truth in the charge, why has not anyone been prosecuted?
('7', 287, 6, 24, 649028) It must be the easiest thing to prove because intimidation is supposed

('7', 288, 1, 11, 650428) Why should the assistance of European employers be called in to force Indians to take out certificates of slavery?
('7', 288, 1, 12, 650543) That many employers have up to now resisted any such pressure and positively declined to dismiss Indians in their employ, redounds to the credit of both—of the employers because they will not take part in the process of hitting below the belt, of the Indians because they are too valuable and faithful servants to be dismissed.

('7', 289, 1, 2, 652162) Confirming our wire of the 22nd August 1907, offering our sincere sympathy in the trials of our countrymen in the Transvaal and stronglyrecommending them to be firm in pursuing their resistance policy, we beg to impress upon them the entire necessity of sticking to the same to the last.
('7', 289, 2, 3, 652450) Without detailing to you the proceedings of our meeting held on the 21st August, I would briefly inform our friends there that the proceedings were enthusiastic and the meeting was very well attended.
('7', 289, 3, 4, 652651) When the request was made for drawing up a subscription list, everyone without exception paid according to his means, and the list amounted to £33.15.9, which amount, small as it is, we beg to remit you, and to request you to acknowledge same.

('7', 289, 5, 6, 653040) names published in the paper, but in the hope that, by seeing the published list, others may also be induced to come forward with help.
('7', 289, 5, 7, 653176) It is impossible to turn down this request.

('7', 289, 7, 11, 653389) DOG’S COURAGE
('7', 289, 8, 12, 653403) The pickets here have bought a picture by a well known painter.
('7', 289, 8, 13, 653467) It is very striking and is such as will inspire every Indian with courage.
('7', 289, 8, 14, 653542) It shows a dog and two girls.
('7', 289, 8, 15, 653572) The two girls have removed their shoes and one of them is pulling the dog with a string round its neck, and the other is pushing it from behind.
('7', 289, 8, 16, 653717) But the brave animal does not budge an inch from the place.
('7', 289, 8, 17, 653777) That is passive resistance.
('7', 289, 8, 18, 653805) The painter has also named his picture “Passive Resister”.
('7', 289, 8, 19, 653864) The picture shows the dog strong enough to bite the girls, if it wants to.
('7', 289, 8, 20, 653939) Though obstinate, the girls are mere children.
('7', 289, 8, 21, 653986) But the dog merely does not want to move from its place.
('7', 289, 8, 22, 654043) It says, as it were: ‘I shall never be your slave.
('7', 289, 8, 23, 654094) I shall not move just because you pull me with a string or push me from behind.
('7', 289, 8, 24, 654174) If I go with you of my own free will, that will be a different matter.
('7', 289, 8, 25, 654245) But you will not succeed with force.
('7', 289, 8, 26, 654282) Likewise, I too shall not use force against you.’ Such is the nature of the Indian struggle.
('7', 289, 8, 27, 654375) We do not need to use force against anyone.
('7', 289, 8, 28, 654419) But we shall not give up the pledge we have taken.

('7', 291, 2, 6, 657756) VERY IMPORTANT CASE
('7', 291, 3, 7, 657776) I referred earlier to the licence case against Mr. Dulabh Vira at Roodepoort.
('7', 291, 3, 8, 657854) The magistrate showed sympathy for Mr. Dulabh Vira, but gave his judgment against him.
('7', 291, 3, 9, 657941) There were cases against two persons.
('7', 291, 3, 10, 657979) One was against his servant and the other was against himself.
('7', 291, 3, 11, 658042) Mr. Dulabh Vira did not hold a licence.
('7', 291, 3, 12, 658082) The servant was also prosecuted because he had sold the goods.
('7', 291, 3, 13, 658145) The magistrate held that though Mr. Dubabh Vira was entitled to a licence, he had no right to keep the shop running since the Receiver had not issued a licence to him.
('7', 291, 3, 14, 658313) The servant was also held guilty because he had sold the goods and so he was considered to have carried on trade.
('7', 291, 3, 15, 658427) He was not sentenced.
('7', 291, 3, 16, 658449) Mr. Dulabh Vira was fined ls.
('7', 291, 3, 17, 658479) In the appeal to the Supreme Court, the following grounds were advanced: (1) In selling the goods, the employee has committed no offence.
('7', 291, 3, 18, 658617) The employer alone can be found guilty under the law.
('7', 291, 3, 19, 658671) (2) Since it cannot be held to be the fault of Mr. Dulabh Vira that the Receiver had not issued the licence to him, though he had applied for it and was entitled to it, no sentence should have been passed against him.
('7', 291, 3, 20, 658889) In deciding the appeal, the Court held that the law could punish the owner of a shop trading without a licence, but not his employee.
('7', 291, 3, 21, 659023) The employee is therefore free, and nothing can be done to him.
('7', 291, 4, 22, 659087) Mr. Dulabh Vira [according to the Court] had no right to run the shop without a licence.
('7', 291, 4, 23, 659176) He was asked to apply to the Receiver again, and if the Court found that the Receiver was deliberately refusing the licence to him, it would award costs against the Receiver and also damages to the appellant.
('7', 291, 4, 24, 659385) This is a very important judgment.
('7', 291, 4, 25, 659420) It opens up many possibilities.
('7', 291, 4, 26, 659452) It is a judgment which will hearten the people engaged in the Transvaal struggle.
('7', 291, 4, 27, 659534) Many Indians were afraid that, in the absence of licences in January, their shops would have to be closed down.
('7', 291, 4, 28, 659646) But that fear is now dispelled.
('7', 291, 4, 29, 659678) Only the owner of an establishment is liable to be sentenced.
('7', 291, 4, 30, 659740) The law does not provide for forcible closure of a
('7', 292, 0, 1, 659791) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 293
('7', 292, 1, 2, 659836) shop and the servants can continue to work in it.
('7', 292, 1, 3, 659886) There is therefore no question of closing down.
('7', 292, 1, 4, 659934) Only the owner of the store will have to suffer the hardship—according to me, the privilege—of being gaoled.
('7', 292, 1, 5, 660043) I think this is a very valuable judgment.
('7', 292, 1, 6, 660085) It is very encouraging that damages and costs can be awarded against the Receiver.
('7', 292, 1, 7, 660168) If, after this decision, even a single Indian merchant is to yield, it can only be said that we deserve the obnoxious law.
('7', 292, 2, 8, 660291) SHAHJI SAHEB FINED
('7', 292, 3, 9, 660310) Imam Kamali had filed a complaint against Shahji Saheb for assault, which came up for hearing on Wednesday.
('7', 292, 3, 10, 660418) In giving evidence, Imam Kamali stated that he was sorry for having made the affidavit.
('7', 292, 3, 11, 660506) There was a dispute between the two on a religious point in connection with the question of law, during which Shahji Saheb dealt him a blow with a stick.
('7', 292, 3, 12, 660660) The Imam for his part did not now desire any sentence to be passed [on Shahji Saheb].
('7', 292, 3, 13, 660746) In his deposition, Shahji Saheb admitted having dealt a blow, as stated above.
('7', 292, 3, 14, 660825) The court room was packed to capacity.
('7', 292, 3, 15, 660864) The magistrate sentenced Shahji Saheb to a fine of £5 or imprisonment for seven days.
('7', 292, 3, 16, 660950) The latter flatly refused to pay the fine, but, much against his desire, Mr. Gulam Mahomed Kadodia paid the fine on his behalf.
('7', 292, 4, 17, 661078) MEETING OF BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION’S COMMITTEE
('7', 292, 5, 18, 661128) A meeting of the Association and the Anti Indian Law Fund took place at 12 noon on Wednesday.
('7', 292, 5, 19, 661222) Mr. Essop Mia presided.
('7', 292, 5, 20, 661246) Mr. Gandhi said that Mr. Dulabh Vira’s case should now be taken up by the community; that arrangement should be made to maintain the South Africa British Indian Committee; and that, in view of the uncertain situation facing the community, it would be better to vest the moneys of the Anti Indian Law Fund under his (Mr. Gandhi’s) control.
('7', 292, 5, 21, 661585) After Messrs Omarji, Naidoo, Ahmed Moosaji and Fancy had spoken on the subject, it was unanimously resolved that: (1) The South Africa British Indian Committee be maintained for one year, and that Natal be requested to help meet the expenditure for the first six months.
('7', 292, 6, 22, 661856) (2) Mr. Dulabh Vira’s case be taken up by the Association and expenses incurred up to £20.
('7', 292, 7, 23, 661947) (3) The account in the name of the Anti Indian Law Fund be closed, and the Fund be placed under Mr. Gandhi’s control.

('7', 293, 8, 9, 662414) I beg to draw your attention to the crisis that is being approached here in connection with the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 293, 8, 10, 662536) The last day for registration is the 31st instant, after which date, except in special cases, the Government will not entertain applications for registration certificates under the law.
('7', 293, 8, 11, 662722) With the exception of the Memon community, Indians, as a rule, have refrained from going to the Registration Office and, out of 13,000 permit holders, only 250 have applied to come under the law.
('7', 293, 8, 12, 662918) This shows the strength of feeling.
('7', 293, 8, 13, 662954) The mode of seeking redress is for us to suffer all the consequences of a breach of the law.
('7', 293, 8, 14, 663047) Some who are very large merchants are likely to lose everything they possess.
('7', 293, 8, 15, 663125) Many have begun to feel the pinch already, as European wholesale houses have ceased to give credit unless Indian merchants can produce registration certificates.
('7', 293, 8, 16, 663287) Poor Indians have lost their employment, and, yet, there is the same firmness and opposition against the law.
('7', 293, 8, 17, 663397) In the opinion of my Association, the question is of first class Imperial importance and national importance for India.
('7', 293, 8, 18, 663517) My Association, therefore, hopes that the matter will be warmly taken up at the forthcoming Congress, and will also receive that general attention in India which it deserves; and with this end in view, my Association respectfully requests your active sympathy and encouragement.

('7', 294, 8, 8, 664332) SIR, I have the honour to forward, by parcel post, the petition of the British Indians throughout the Transvaal, in connection with the Asiatic Registration Act, and herewith a copy of the instructions 2 issued to the canvassers.
('7', 294, 8, 9, 664562) When the forms were distributed through the Colony, the letter addressed to the Government on behalf of certain Indians asking for a modification of the regulations framed under the Act, was still unanswered and the letter not withdrawn.
('7', 294, 8, 10, 664800) But though since then Messrs Stegmann, Esselen, and Roos’ clients have not received a reply to their satisfaction, and although they have therefore withdrawn the letter, the committee of my Association desires me to forward the petition, as it embodies the sentiments of those who have signed it.
('7', 294, 8, 11, 665097) In the humble opinion of my Association, the petition forms a complete vindication of the attitude adopted by it, and shows that it is representative of the vast majority of Indians in the Colony.
('7', 294, 8, 12, 665294) The petition has been ready for some time, but my Association delayed its presentation, in order to test the action of the community during the period that the Registration Office remained open in Johannesburg.
('7', 294, 8, 13, 665505) There are 4,522 signatories to the petition, and they are drawn from 29 towns, villages, and districts in the Transvaal.
('7', 294, 8, 14, 665626) The following is the analysis according to the centres: Johannesburg, 2,085; Newclare,

('7', 295, 1, 2, 665863) 108; Roodepoort, 136; Krugersdorp, 179; Germiston, 300; Boksburg, 129; Benoni, 91; Modderfontein, 51; Pretoria, 577; Pietersburg and Spelonken, 90; Vereeniging, 73; Heidelberg, 66; Balfour, 14; Stander ton, 123; Volksrust, 36; Wakkerstroom, 12; Piet Retief, 3; Bethal, 18; Middelburg, 29; Belfast, Machadodorp, and Waterval, 21; Barberton, 68; Potchefstroom, 114; Ventersdorp, 12; Klerksdorp, 41; Christiana, 24; Lichtenburg, 7; Zeerust, 59; Rustenburg, 54; Ermilo, 2. There are in the Transvaal Hindus, Mahomedans, Christians, and Parsees from India, and the Mahomedans are divided into three sections, i.e., Surtis, Konkanis, and Memons; the Hindus into Gujarati, Madrassi, and Northerners, commonly called Calcutta people.
('7', 295, 1, 3, 666589) In order to avoid a separate classification for the Sikhs and the Pathans, they have been included among the Northerners, if Hindus, and among the Surtis, if Mahomedans.
('7', 295, 1, 4, 666759) The Christians have not been separately classified as they are nearly all Madrassis, and are not more than 200 in all.
('7', 295, 1, 5, 666878) The following, then, is the religious and provincial classification: Surtis, l,476; Konkanis, 141; Memons, 140; Gujarati Hindus, l,600; Madrassis, 991; Northerners, 157; Parsees, 17. I may mention that, with the exception of the Memons, there are hardly any abstentions, but the task of reaching every Indian in the isolated parts of the Transvaal—as, for instance, farms, etc.—has been beyond my Association during the time that was allotted for the canvassing of signatures.
('7', 295, 1, 6, 667355) Canvassers, who were in all cases responsible and representative men, have reported that a large number of Indians have already left the Transvaal, owing to the struggle that the community is passing through.
('7', 295, 1, 7, 667564) It is common knowledge that nearly 13,000 permits have been issued to British Indians under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and approximately that number of Indians were resident in the Transvaal when unfortunately the struggle commenced in September of last year.
('7', 295, 1, 8, 667831) To day the British Indian population of the Transvaal, according to the information at the disposal of my Association, does not at the outside exceed 8,000, but it is probably nearer 7,000 than 8,000. My Association is aware that, owing to pressure having been exerted by wholesale merchants or other similar causes, a few of the Memons and others, not exceeding 30 signatories, have recanted, and applied for registration under the Act.
('7', 295, 1, 9, 668269) Moreover, according to the information received by my Association, no more than 350 Indians have applied for registration throughout the Transvaal during the period that the registration has been proceeding, namely, July 1 to October 31, and that 95 per cent of these applicants are drawn from the Memon section.
('7', 295, 1, 10, 668582) In conclusion, my Association begs to draw the attention of the Government to the intensity of the feeling of the community
('7', 296, 0, 1, 668706) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 297
('7', 296, 1, 2, 668751) represented by my Association against the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 296, 1, 3, 668820) In taking up the attitude the community has felt called upon to adopt, there has been no intention of defying either the Government or the laws of the country, but a sense of the wrong done to the community by the Act and all it implies has compelled British Indians to prepare for undergoing a course of suffering which passive resistance, as understood by British Indians, involves.

('7', 296, 4, 6, 669307) 231. LETTER TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('7', 296, 5, 7, 669345) [JOHANNESBURG,] November 1, [1907]
('7', 296, 6, 8, 669380) [THE EDITOR THE TRANSVAAL LEADER JOHANNESBURG]
('7', 296, 8, 9, 669427) In your leading article in today’s issue on the Asiatic Registra tion Act, you have imputed to the British Indian Association a state ment to the effect that nearly the whole of the 400 men said to have been registered had no right to be in the Transvaal.
('7', 296, 8, 10, 669683) I am not aware of any such statement having been made by any official of the Associa tion.
('7', 296, 8, 11, 669774) I know that some of our pickets did make some such statement, but that was mere bravado.
('7', 296, 8, 12, 669863) The chief picket, Mr. Naidoo, immediately corrected it, but the correction did not appear in your report.
('7', 296, 8, 13, 669969) The official statement made by the Association is that four men at least, who, according to the interpretation of the law put upon it by the Government, have no right to be in the country, have applied for and probably received registration certificates.
('7', 296, 8, 14, 670224) The Association does not even consider these men to be not entitled to their certificates.
('7', 296, 8, 15, 670315) If the Government keep the office open for receiving applications, I must respectfully decline to consider it as a graceful concession, as it would be, in the opinion of the majority of Indians, a confession of weakness on the part of the Government.
('7', 296, 8, 16, 670566) The British Indian Association, in all humility and in obedience to a higher call, has challenged the Government to do its worst.
('7', 296, 8, 17, 670696) We do not require the
('7', 297, 0, 1, 670718) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 297, 1, 2, 670760) registration pin pricks, and, if the vigilance of the pickets has kept Indians away from what they consider a plague spot, the same vigilance will be exercised in Pretoria also.
('7', 297, 1, 3, 670938) You ask what can be gained by the Indian opposition in the teeth of General Smuts, threat and the refusal of intervention by the Imperial Government.
('7', 297, 1, 4, 671088) So far as I am aware, in the last resort, Indians have not pinned their faith either to intervention from Downing Street or to recognition of the principles of humanity by General Smuts.
('7', 297, 1, 5, 671275) Though the effort now being made by the Indian community is undoubtedly calculated, if successful, to give them a status in the colony, they are fully aware that they may lose their all in the struggle.
('7', 297, 1, 6, 671478) But, if that happens, which I do not believe, they will at least have gained a soul, and put that gain in one scale and all that General Smuts and his Act can give to the Indian community in the other, and I have no hesitation in asking my countrymen to reject at all costs the latter.
('7', 297, 1, 7, 671764) You will then see that, while we take advantage of all that the law may give us, the sanctioning of the Immigration Restriction Bill or any other harsher measure will not turn the community from the straight and narrow path.
('7', 297, 1, 8, 671989) If it does— and I do not say that it will not—then every Indian knows that there is a precipice on either side.

('7', 297, 7, 14, 672328) [SIR,] My Society has been moving very actively in connection with the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 297, 7, 15, 672425) It is hardly necessary for me to state that in South Africa we have no racial differences.
('7', 297, 7, 16, 672516) Hindus, Mahomedans, Parsis, Christians, belonging to the different Provinces, join hands and work for the common good.
('7', 297, 7, 17, 672635) In some respects the Asiatic Registration Act peculiarly affects Indian Mussulmans.
('7', 297, 7, 18, 672719) We have appealed to all parties and all sections, and my Society, therefore, ventures to appeal
('7', 298, 0, 1, 672815) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 299
('7', 298, 1, 2, 672860) to you as the mouthpiece in England of the Indian National Congress, and trusts that the question of the Transvaal Registration Act will be put in the forefront of the subjects to be dealt with by the Congress, as distinguished from the general South African question.
('7', 298, 1, 3, 673129) As you are aware, we are adopting what may, perhaps, be termed heroic measures, in order to meet the special difficulty in the Transvaal.
('7', 298, 1, 4, 673267) The other legislation in South Africa can be lived down and has been, so far, tolerated, but the Transvaal Act is intolerable.
('7', 298, 1, 5, 673394) Under the other South African legislation, Indians have not felt called upon, by way of protest, to lose all rather than submit, but, under the Transvaal Act, that step has been considered and rendered absolutely necessary.
('7', 298, 1, 6, 673618) The other South African legislation deprives us, as a rule, of the avenues to wealth; the Transvaal Registration Act deprives us of our manhood and reduces us to a status almost of slavery.
('7', 298, 1, 7, 673808) And, in so much as this question affects Mahomedans specially, it will, perhaps, be graceful on the part of the National Congress to give the matter of the Transvaal special prominence.

('7', 298, 5, 12, 674292) 233. SMUTS’ BRAVERY(?)
('7', 298, 6, 13, 674315) Many Indians, like women, are unnerved at the thought that General Smuts is a man who will always do what he says he will.
('7', 298, 6, 14, 674438) We stated last week that that gentleman withdrew the Regulations pertaining to the closure of shops no sooner than these were published.
('7', 298, 6, 15, 674575) During the week the Regulations remained gazetted, many white shopkeepers put up a fight against them.
('7', 298, 6, 16, 674678) General Smuts cooled down and withdrew them within ten days of their publication.
('7', 298, 6, 17, 674760) In the same way, that gentleman withdrew the Beer Bill and the Kaffir Law.
('7', 298, 6, 18, 674835) The Shop Regulations were withdrawn for fear of the Transvaal whites, and the other two laws were withdrawn because of the strong opinion against them in England.
('7', 298, 7, 19, 674998) These three instances deserve to be carefully noted by Indian friends.
('7', 298, 7, 20, 675069) They indicate that General Smuts is certainly afraid of brave people; but as some effeminate husbands are brave only in respect of
('7', 299, 0, 1, 675200) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 299, 1, 2, 675242) their wives, so General Smuts shows himself brave in respect of those who panic before him, that is, to those who are like women.
('7', 299, 1, 3, 675372) He has to fear the white businessmen because the power he holds depends on them.
('7', 299, 1, 4, 675453) Why should he fear the Indians?
('7', 299, 1, 5, 675485) Indians change their attitudes ten times a day, like women changing their dress.
('7', 299, 1, 6, 675566) The same Indian may be a picket and yet accept the title deed of slavery; the same Indian may accept a presidentship to oppose the law, and then sign an affidavit and wear the slavish sari; the same Indian taking an oath in the name of God will put down his signature with one pen that he will not submit to the law, and then with a second pen say that he must have slavery.
('7', 299, 1, 7, 675941) Now, say, why should General Smuts be afraid?
('7', 299, 1, 8, 675987) It is still possible under one condition, namely, that those who are yet not involved should continue fighting against General Smuts till the end, even to the point of being ruined.
('7', 299, 1, 9, 676169) Then we shall see if the obnoxious law does not go the way of the Beer Bill!
('7', 299, 1, 10, 676246) Never and nowhere in this world was spectacular success achieved without a struggle.

('7', 300, 1, 2, 677201) 235. “THE FRIEND” OF BLOEMFONTEIN ONCE AGAIN TO SUCCOUR OF TRANSVAAL INDIANS
('7', 300, 2, 3, 677278) “THE LAW IS UNWISE AND UNJUST”
('7', 300, 3, 4, 677309) In The Friend of Bloemfontein of the 24th instant, there is a leader in support of the Transvaal Indians which runs as follows: 1
('7', 300, 4, 5, 677439) From Pretoria comes the report that the resistance of the British Indians to the Registration Act is believed by the authorities to be weakening.
('7', 300, 4, 6, 677585) The grounds for the belief are stated to be that some 48 Indians, a few of them prominent members of their community, have applied to be registered in Pretoria.
('7', 300, 4, 7, 677746) At Johannesburg, however, where the mass of the British Indians resides, there have been only 16 applications, of which but one was made by a local Indian, the others coming from the outside districts.
('7', 300, 4, 8, 677948) To our mind, the above figures are not nearly so significant as the fact, stated further on in the report, that 100 Indians, presumably from the Transvaal, were to embark tomorrow from Durban for India.
('7', 300, 4, 9, 678151) The British Indians in South Africa might be expected like any other community, whether white or coloured, to develop under pressure of persecution their own percentage of cowards.
('7', 300, 4, 10, 678332) What claims our notice is the fact not that two or three scores of them have submitted weakly to a law which they consider degrading and unjust, but that a large number prefer to keep their self respect at the price of leaving the country.
('7', 300, 4, 11, 678572) The action of the Transvaal Government in this matter has been morally wrong and diplomatically foolish.
('7', 300, 4, 12, 678677) Those British Indians who have protested against the Registration Ordinance are British Indians who possess a full and admitted legal right to live in the Transvaal, a right derived from long previous residence.
('7', 300, 4, 13, 678889) The Government has decided, without the slightest justification so far as we can see, to make their further enjoyment of that right conditional on their submission to a law which stigmatises them as serfs or felons.
('7', 300, 4, 14, 679105) It is the simple fact that the finger print method of registration has hitherto been confined in the Transvaal to convicts and indentured Chinamen.
('7', 300, 4, 15, 679253) Some may think that the race inferiority of the British Indians makes it excusable to treat them in this fashion.
('7', 300, 4, 16, 679367) If they were an inferior race, we have no right to mark our superiority by oppressing them, but is it so sure that they are inferior?
('7', 300, 4, 17, 679501) We have Indian regiments which rank in their soldierly qualities with the flower of our army.
('7', 300, 4, 18, 679595) Our universities frequently see
('7', 300, 5, 19, 679627) 1 The translation given here has been collated with the original in English.
('7', 300, 5, 20, 679704) Words underlined in the Gujarati are given in italics.
('7', 301, 0, 1, 679759) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 301, 1, 2, 679801) their best prizes carried off by Indian students.
('7', 301, 1, 3, 679851) In capacity for abstract thought and insight into the mystery of things, the Westerns still sit as children at the feet of the Easterns.
('7', 301, 1, 4, 679988) If capacity for trade and commerce be made the test, it is generally admitted that the average white man has in these no chance against the competition of the average Asiatic.
('7', 301, 1, 5, 680164) In this last fact we have unquestionably the true reason for the way in which the British Indians in the Transvaal are being treated.
('7', 301, 1, 6, 680298) No doubt, we possess as a white race the military advantage over the Asiatics, but one of the anxious questions which agitate the minds of European statesmen is the question how long that advantage is going to last.
('7', 301, 1, 7, 680514) Possibly the Asiatic myriads will within a few years wake from their torpor of centuries and overwhelm the West as they have done more than once before.
('7', 301, 1, 8, 680667) Should they not do so, it will not be because the Transvaal Government is not helping to arouse them.
('7', 301, 1, 9, 680769) Every British Indian sent back to his own country by the injustice of the Transvaal Government will take with him an ineradicable sense of wrong, and it is odds if he becomes an agitator and foments dislike of the white man’s rule.
('7', 301, 1, 10, 681001) We know that the last thing the Transvaal Government wished to do was to add to the anxieties of the Imperial Government.
('7', 301, 1, 11, 681123) Yet the fact is it is getting rid of its own share of the Asiatic problem in a manner which complicates and increases the Imperial Government’s share.
('7', 301, 1, 12, 681274) For this reason we consider the Registration Act unwise as well as unjust.
('7', 301, 1, 13, 681349) We do not suppose that under pressure from India the British Government will bring pressure to bear on the Transvaal Government, demanding the revision of Asiatic legislation in that colony, or, perhaps (as some fear) the opening of our doors to the entrance of British Indians.
('7', 301, 1, 14, 681628) The old country is exceedingly patient of the procedure of her colonies and leaves them to their own way, even when her own interests are hurt thereby, nor does she absolve herself of the liability of defending them with her fleet at her own cost.
('7', 301, 1, 15, 681876) All this the Transvaal Government recognizes.
('7', 301, 1, 16, 681922) General Botha’s Cabinet is personally the friends of the Imperial Government but yet, by means of its Asiatic measure, it is getting their friends into trouble.
('7', 301, 1, 17, 682083) Surely there was a better way?
('7', 301, 2, 18, 682114) Having written thus much, let us suggest the proper alternative.
('7', 301, 2, 19, 682179) This would have been to pass in the first place a law forbidding the future immigration of Asiatics, no matter under what pretexts.
('7', 301, 2, 20, 682311) In the second place, it would have been proper to lay down rules to which all Asiatics in the Colony would have to conform as the condition of their continued residence therein.
('7', 301, 2, 21, 682489) But if there were any Asiatics who preferred to leave rather than submit to these rules, and could prove that they suffered damage by leaving, they should receive liberal compensation.
('7', 301, 2, 22, 682674) Suppose the whole Indian population of the Transvaal
('7', 302, 0, 1, 682727) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 303
('7', 302, 1, 2, 682772) had asked the Government to buy it out, the cost would have been cheap compared to that of an Indian mutiny, and, perhaps the Imperial Government, as interested in a just solution of the difficulty, would have consented to share the cost.
('7', 302, 1, 3, 683011) To some extent the Imperial Government is responsible as having made the case of the Indians in the Transvaal a pretext for the late war.
('7', 302, 1, 4, 683149) Unquestionably, the Asiatic problem is one which a federated South Africa will have to take up as a whole.
('7', 302, 1, 5, 683256) Natal is even more vitally interested than the Transvaal, since she cannot do without Indian labour.
('7', 302, 1, 6, 683357) Her solution of the difficulty may be, as we have several times suggested, to mark off a portion of her territory as an Indian pale, within which all British Asiatics will have equal rights with Europeans, but outside which their presence will not be permitted in South Africa.
('7', 302, 1, 7, 683635) We have the most perfect right to keep our country for ourselves and to decline to be ousted by alien races.
('7', 302, 1, 8, 683744) We have no right to inflict insult or loss on individual members of those races.

('7', 307, 3, 9, 695815) 238. LETTER TO INDIAN NATIONAL CONGRESS
('7', 307, 4, 10, 695855) JOHANNESBURG, November 4, 1907 [SHRI RASH BEHARI GHOSH PRESIDENT ELECT 1
('7', 307, 5, 11, 695928) INDIAN NATIONAL CONGRESS
('7', 307, 6, 12, 695953) SIR,] I beg to draw your attention and that of the Congress to the pre sent critical position of British Indians in the Transvaal in connection with the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 307, 6, 13, 696132) British Indians have been informed that the last day for receiving applications for registration under that obnoxious measure is the 30th instant, whereafter the Government will not entertain applications for registration, except in special cases.
('7', 307, 6, 14, 696380) You will, probably, already have learnt that, with the exception of a very small section of the community, practically the entire Indian population has refused to register under the new law.
('7', 307, 6, 15, 696571) My Association claims that, to date, there have not been more than 350 applications for registration out of a total of 13,000 permit holders.
('7', 307, 6, 16, 696713) From this you will be able to gauge the intensity of the feeling in this matter.
('7', 307, 6, 17, 696794) You will have learnt that our method of endeavouring to redress the wrong that has been done us is that of passive resistance.
('7', 307, 6, 18, 696921) We haveresolved to suffer all the consequences of a breach of the law.
('7', 307, 6, 19, 696992) Many of us have already lost heavily, many more stand to lose everything they possess.
('7', 307, 6, 20, 697079) Several European wholesale houses have even
('7', 307, 7, 21, 697123) 1 Of the 23rd session of the Indian National Congress held at Surat in 1907.
('7', 308, 0, 1, 697200) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 309
('7', 308, 1, 2, 697245) gone so far as to stop credit unless Indian merchants can produce registration certificates issued under the new law.
('7', 308, 1, 3, 697363) Many Indians employed as servants or labourers have accepted dismissal at the hands of their employers rather than register themselves.
('7', 308, 2, 4, 697499) As you will be well aware, the British Indian community in the Transvaal is composed of Mahomedans, Hindus, Christians and Parsis; Madrassis, Gujaratis, Sikhs, Pathans, Hindi men, and men from Calcu tta, all of whom have combined in the great work of resisting an iniq uitous law which threatens to rob every Indian of his material wealth and to destroy that self respect which he has snatched from the ruin with which he has been threatened by previous oppressive legislation.
('7', 308, 2, 5, 697977) My Association approaches the Congress at this moment in the hope that the Transvaal Registration Act will be put in the forefront of the subjects to be dealt with by the Congress and made the main plank of its platform as distinguished from the general South African question.
('7', 308, 2, 6, 698255) Today, there is no other South African question than the awful position of the British Indians in the Transvaal.
('7', 308, 2, 7, 698368) What happens to us today will happen to our brethren everywhere in South Africa tomorrow.
('7', 308, 2, 8, 698458) Nay, we consider that ours is a question of first class importance to the Empire and of national importance to India; for what the South African Colonies succeed in enforcing against us here, other dominions of the Empire will practise against our brethren elsewhere.
('7', 308, 2, 9, 698726) It may be said that we are adopting heroic measures in order to meet a special difficulty in the Transvaal; but we regard ourselves as the representatives, in this country, of our Motherland, and it is impossible for us, as patriotic Indians, to keep silence under an insult that is levied against our race and our national honour.
('7', 308, 2, 10, 699058) No other legislation in South Africa has attacked us so fiercely on these points, but the Transvaal Asiatic Registration Act is intolerable.
('7', 308, 2, 11, 699199) All other South African legislations deprive us, as a rule, of the avenues to wealth.
('7', 308, 2, 12, 699285) The Transvaal Registration Act deprives us of our manhood and reduces us to the status of slavery.
('7', 308, 2, 13, 699384) By the end of December, probably many Indians may have even suffered imprisonment for a principle, whilst the 1st of January will witness a general refusal to issue trade licences to Indians who have refused to register under the new law, so that a very acute stage will have been reached by the time the Congress meets.
('7', 308, 2, 14, 699705) We hold that our movement of passive resistance merits the approval of all religious men, of all true patriots, of all men of commonsense and integrity.
('7', 308, 2, 15, 699858) It is a movement so potent as to com pel the respect of our adversaries by virtue of our very non resistance,
('7', 309, 0, 1, 699968) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 309, 1, 2, 700010) of our willingness to suffer; and we are the more firm in our determi nation to offer this opposition, because we consider that our example, on a small scale in this Colony, whether successful or unsuccessful, may well be adopted by every oppressed people, by every oppressed individual, as being a more reliable and more honourable instrument for securing the redress of wrongs than any which has heretofore been adopted.
('7', 309, 1, 3, 700433) [1 have etc., ESSOP ISMIL MIA CHAIRMAN BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION] Indian Opinion, 9 11 1907
('7', 309, 2, 4, 700526) 239. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('7', 309, 3, 5, 700553) [JOHANNESBURG, November 6, 1907]
('7', 309, 5, 6, 700586) You publish in today’s issue of your paper what purports to be an authorised explanation given to your Pretoria correspondent of the present position of the Government in regard to the administration of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 309, 5, 7, 700820) My Association regrets to find, how ever, that that report is so strangely full of misapprehensions and miss tatements, that a doubt must arise as to whether your representative has not failed to grasp the details of the apologia that has been issued from the Colonial Secretary’s Office.
('7', 309, 5, 8, 701109) With your permission, I will, on behalf of my Association, proceed to examine certain facts alleged therein.
('7', 309, 5, 9, 701218) In the first place, it is stated that representations have been add ressed to the Colonial Secretary on behalf of the Indian community with a view to obtaining certain modifications of the regulations.
('7', 309, 5, 10, 701420) My Association denies the statement absolutely.
('7', 309, 5, 11, 701468) The facts are these: On the 30th August, a petition was addressed by Messrs Stegmann, Esselen & Roos, on behalf of “some leading Indian people of Pretoria, Standerton, Pietersburg, and Middelburg”, to the Honourable the Colonial Secretary to secure some modification of the regulations.
('7', 309, 5, 12, 701755) The intention of Messrs Stegmann, Esselen & Roos, clients was to show that they spoke for quite a number of representative Indians, and immediately these facts became known to my Association, my Association addressed a letter to the Pretoria
('7', 309, 6, 13, 701997) 1 This was addressed to The Transvaal leader and The Star.
('7', 310, 0, 1, 702056) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 311
('7', 310, 1, 2, 702101) solicitors, repudiating the right of these people to speak on behalf of the Indian community and, therefore, of my Association.
('7', 310, 1, 3, 702229) The wording of the letter which I have quoted above suffices to show that the representations made to the Government were made on behalf of certain individuals acting in their private capacity, and most of whom are now registered.
('7', 310, 1, 4, 702460) In reply to these representations, the Honourable the Colonial Secretary informed his petitioners that he was unable to comply with their requests but made some trifling modifications of practically no value.
('7', 310, 1, 5, 702669) The persons on whose behalf the Pretoria solicitors acted were so dissatisfied with this reply, that they returned, through Messrs Stegmann, Esselen & Roos, an answer to the effect that they desired to withdraw their request as set forth in their letter of the 30th August, leaving the Honourable the Colonial Secretary at liberty to withdraw such concessions as he might have been able to make.
('7', 310, 1, 6, 703065) It will thus be seen that the Indian community made no representations to the Honourable the Colonial Secretary in the matter of the regulations, but that whatever representations were made came from certain individuals, who have since withdrawn their request, the letter of withdrawal being dated the 12th ultimo.
('7', 310, 1, 7, 703380) May I be allowed to say here, on behalf of my Association, that it is utterly false to allege that it is only now that the British Indian community has taken up a position which it did not venture to take up during the earlier stages of the agitation?
('7', 310, 1, 8, 703632) The Colonial Secretary’s Department must be singularly ill informed, if it is unaware of the fact that passive resistance to the law has existed since September, 1906. The oath of passive resistance was taken at the Mass Meeting held in Johannesburg in that month, at which the Registrar of Asiatics himself was present.
('7', 310, 1, 9, 703953) My Association has consistently declined to enter at all into the question of regulations framed under the Act.
('7', 310, 1, 10, 704065) Having from the first declined to recognise the validity of the Act itself, it would have been undignified in the extreme had my Association entered into minor details.
('7', 310, 1, 11, 704234) My Association, having ignored the existence of these regulations, cannot by any stretch of imagination be said to have repudiated the modifications alleged to have been made in favour of British Indians by the Honourable the Colonial Secretary at the alleged request of the community.
('7', 310, 1, 12, 704520) It is a mistake altogether to suppose that the passive resistance movement entered into by my Association and by the Indian community commenced in July last when registration was announced.
('7', 310, 1, 13, 704710) The total repeal of the Act has been demanded from the very commencement of the struggle last year.
('7', 310, 1, 14, 704810) A side issue has been raised in connection with the petition recently forwarded by my Association to the Honourable the Colonial Secretary.
('7', 310, 1, 15, 704950) This petition sets forth, amongst other things, that the
('7', 311, 0, 1, 705007) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 311, 1, 2, 705049) signatories thereto dissociate themselves entirely from the letter addressed to the Honourable the Colonial Secretary by Messrs Stegmann, Esselen & Roos on behalf of their clients; and the signatories respectfully submitted that nothing short of a total repeal of the Act could meet the difficult situation that had been created.
('7', 311, 1, 3, 705379) There was nothing new in this.
('7', 311, 1, 4, 705410) The official informant of your correspondent would make it appear that, consequent upon the Honourable the Colonial Secretary’s slight modifications of the regulations which were contained in a letter forwarded about the end of September last, the Indian community took advantage of an alleged act of leniency to circulate the petition in order to take further advantage of what will doubtless have been considered to be an act of grace.
('7', 311, 1, 5, 705848) In point of fact, immediately that it was known to my Association that Messrs Stegmann, Esselen & Roos’ letter of the 30th August had been dispatched to the Colonial Secretary, my Association issued forms of the petition in five different languages and circulated these all over the Colony.
('7', 311, 1, 6, 706139) This was at the beginning of September.
('7', 311, 1, 7, 706179) By the end of September, when the Honourable the Colonial Secretary’s reply was received by the Pretoria solicitors, practically all these forms had been returned to my Association duly completed.
('7', 311, 1, 8, 706376) As, however, Johannesburg was to be the last place where registrations were to be effected and October was to be [the] last month for effecting them, my Association decided to hold over the petition until the end of last month, in order to demonstrate to the Government the solidity of the British Indian community in its opposition to the Asiatic Law Amend ment Act, and this notwithstanding the withdrawal of their letter of Messrs Stegmann, Esselen & Roos’ clients on the 12th ultimo.
('7', 311, 2, 9, 706864) I will now pass briefly to the question of the extension of the period of registration to the end of November.
('7', 311, 2, 10, 706975) My Association asserts emphatically that this decision has taken place at the last moment, and the statements made by no less than three Cabinet Ministers support my Association’s contention.
('7', 311, 2, 11, 707167) If any further confirmation be needed, it will be found in a circular issued to Resident Magistrates throughout the Colony from the Colonial Secretary’s Office on the 16th ultimo and signed by the Registrar of Asiatics, stating that Resident Magistrates should inform Asiatics that “it has been decided that the period for applications for registration, which expires on the 31st instant, cannot be extended”, and that all Asiatics resident in the different districts should be instructed to apply for registration on or before that day at the Old Dutch Church, Von Brandis Square, Johannesburg.
('7', 311, 2, 12, 707763) There is no questioning the definiteness of these instructions, and it is quite obvious that the Hon.
('7', 311, 2, 13, 707865) the Colonial Secretary, finding that the number of applications made at
('7', 312, 0, 1, 707937) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 313
('7', 312, 1, 2, 707982) Johannesburg from the whole [of the] Transvaal did not exceed 25, decided, at the last moment, to extend the time for another month.
('7', 312, 1, 3, 708115) It will thus be seen that Government Notice No.
('7', 312, 1, 4, 708163) 1907 published in the Gazette of the 4th ultimo made no provision whatever for an extension of time during which Asiatics who had not previously registered could make application under the new law.
('7', 312, 1, 5, 708361) One last matter to which my Association desires to draw attention is that, so far from each town having the time marked out for Asiatic residents therein alone to make application, it was advertised that all Asiatics in towns previously visited by the Registration Officers could make application at the town newly advertised, if they had not previously done so, and, whilst Johannesburg was the last place advertised where Asiatics from all over the Transvaal should register and nowhere else, my Association charges the officials of the Registrar’s Office with receiving clandestine applications at Pretoria from a few cowards who furnished affidavits fraudulently and falsely representing that they had been prevented from making application before owing to intimidation on the part of certain unnamed persons.
('7', 312, 1, 6, 709175) My Association desires to make it known once more that, in this struggle, British Indians are fighting with open hands.
('7', 312, 1, 7, 709295) There is no need for them to resort to subterfuge or mendacity.

('7', 312, 1, 9, 709501) It is difficult indeed to characterise the strange distortion of facts contained in your correspondent’s telegram.

('7', 319, 2, 15, 726310) The Asiatic, who formerly never dreamed of going abroad, has started doing so.
('7', 319, 2, 16, 726389) He is thrifty, courteous and economical to a point the European apparently cannot attain to.
('7', 319, 2, 17, 726482) We go into his countries but in dozens for his thousands; and where he can, he stops the dozens.
('7', 319, 2, 18, 726579) Indeed, it is admitted by the Asiatic himself that the Transvaal is not to be called upon to permit an unchecked irruption.
('7', 319, 2, 19, 726703) It is the general profession of our European population that they wish to deal fairly by the Asiatics who are already here.
('7', 319, 2, 20, 726827) All that is at issue is the method.

('7', 319, 2, 22, 726951) Has the Government considered every alternative method?

('7', 320, 2, 7, 728170) WARNING TO BARBERS
('7', 320, 3, 8, 728189) The Johannesburg Municipality has decided to make regulations for barbers; since the regulations are likely to be passed, I summarize them below: l.
('7', 320, 3, 9, 728338) The barber should keep his saloon perfectly clean and arrange for proper ventilation in it.
('7', 320, 3, 10, 728430) 2. The clippers, scissors, razors, combs, brushes, etc., should always be kept clean.
('7', 320, 3, 11, 728516) 3. While shaving or giving a hair cut, the barber should put on a robe reaching up to the neck.
('7', 320, 3, 12, 728612) He should have his hands properly washed.
('7', 320, 3, 13, 728654) 4. In case a barber or any of his assistants suffers from a skin disease or any other contagious disease, he should not shave anyone or give anyone a hair cut.
('7', 320, 3, 14, 728814) 5. After January 1, every barber’s saloon should be registered.
('7', 320, 3, 15, 728878) It will be registered by the Council without any fee.
('7', 320, 3, 16, 728932) 6. A sanitary inspector or physician is entitled to enter any saloon.
('7', 320, 3, 17, 729002) A copy of these regulations should be displayed in every saloon.
('7', 320, 3, 18, 729067) The Council has made the following recommendations: 1. Every shelf or table should be covered with glass, marble slab, slate or tin sheet.
('7', 320, 3, 19, 729206) 2. A fresh towel should be used for every customer and the neck rest should be covered every time with a fresh napkin or piece of paper.
('7', 320, 3, 20, 729343) 3. Two brushes should be kept for use in shaving each one being placed in a disinfectant solution and then taken out for use by turns.
('7', 320, 3, 21, 729478) 4. Soap water, soap powder or a soap stick should be used.
('7', 320, 3, 22, 729537) 5. The razor should be wiped on clean paper.
('7', 320, 3, 23, 729582) After use, the razor and other instruments should be kept in a disinfectant solution for four or five minutes.
('7', 320, 3, 24, 729693) The disinfectant solution should be made by
('7', 321, 0, 1, 729737) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 321, 1, 2, 729779) mixing two teaspoonfuls of Celive 1 or Carol 1 in a quart of water or three teaspoonfuls of Eusoll in an equal quantity of water.
('7', 321, 1, 3, 729909) 6. After shave, instead of an alum stick, a water spray should be used or clean cotton soaked in water.
('7', 321, 1, 4, 730013) 7. A sponge should not be used at all.
('7', 321, 1, 5, 730052) Cotton or some such thing should be used in its place.
('7', 321, 1, 6, 730107) 8. Cotton should be used instead of rags for powdering.
('7', 321, 1, 7, 730163) 9. The hair brush should be white, and it should be washed once every day with water, soap and soda bicarb.
('7', 321, 1, 8, 730271) 10. When giving a close hair cut, the hair dropping on the neck should not be blown off by the mouth, but an air propeller should be used.
('7', 321, 1, 9, 730410) 11. The bits of hair fallen on the ground should be collected into a covered utensil instead of being swept into a corner.
('7', 321, 1, 10, 730533) The regulations and suggestions given above should be noted by every barber.
('7', 321, 1, 11, 730610) It is not merely that anyone ignoring the regulations will be fined; it should be admitted that it is the duty of the barber to observe such cleanliness.
('7', 321, 1, 12, 730764) In India, owing to the carelessness of barbers or their lack of cleanliness, people get infected with eczema, scabies, etc.
('7', 321, 1, 13, 730888) It will be of advantage to the barbers to observe the regulations givenabove they will then be regarded to have received an education that is real and useful.
('7', 321, 1, 14, 731047) All this requires no expenditure, one has only to be keen on it.

('7', 322, 2, 9, 732721) WHITES ARE YIELDING

('7', 322, 3, 11, 732948) This fact should add to the courage of Indians; for, both the Government and the whites are now seriously considering how this knotty question can be resolved, and hence they are trying to understand what we want.

('7', 325, 1, 4, 739435) If the Government keep the Office open for receiving applications, I must respectfully decline to consider it as a graceful concession, as it would be, in the opinion of the majority of Indians, a confession of weakness on the part of the Government.

('7', 326, 2, 6, 742285) 247. LETTER TO GENERAL SMUTS
('7', 326, 3, 7, 742314) The monster petition, along with the forms containing the signatures, has been dispatched to the Colonial Secretary, with a forwarding letter by the Chairman of the British Indian Association, Mr. Essop Mia, a summary of which was reproduced under “Late News” in the last issue.
('7', 326, 3, 8, 742593) We now give the letter in full: 1
('7', 326, 4, 9, 742627) Sir, I have the honour to forward, by parcel post, the petition of the British Indians throughout the Transvaal, in connection with the Asiatic Registration Act, and herewith a copy of the instructions issued to the canvassers.
('7', 326, 4, 10, 742855) When the forms were distributed through the Colony, the letter addressed to the Government on behalf of certain Indians, asking for a modification of the regulations framed under the Act, was still unanswered and the letter not withdrawn.
('7', 326, 4, 11, 743094) But though since then Messrs Stegmann, Esselen and Roos’ clients have not received a reply to their satisfaction, and although they have therefore withdrawn the letter, the committee of my Association desires me to forward the petition, as it embodies the sentiments of those who have signed it.
('7', 326, 4, 12, 743390) In the humble opinion of my Association, the petition forms a complete vindication of the attitude adopted by it, and shows that it is representative of the vast majority of Indians in the Colony.
('7', 326, 4, 13, 743587) The petition has been ready for some time, but my Association delayed its presentation, in order to test the action of the community during the period that the Registration Office remained open in Johannesburg.
('7', 326, 4, 14, 743798) There are 4,522 signatories to the petition, and they are drawn from 29 towns, villages and districts in the Transvaal.
('7', 326, 4, 15, 743918) The following is the analysis according to the centres: Johannesburg, 2,085; Newclare,

('7', 327, 1, 2, 744241) 108; Roodepoort, 136; Krugersdorp, 179; Germiston, 300; Boksburg, 129; Benoni, 91; Modderfontein, 51; Pretoria, 577; Pietersburg and Spelonken, 90; Vereeniging, 73; Heidelberg, 66; Balfour, 14; Standerton 123; Volksrust, 36; Wakkerstroom, 12; Piet Retief, 3; Bethal, 18; Middelburg, 29; Belfast, Machadodorp, and Waterval, 21; Barberton, 68; Potchefstroom, 114; Ventersdorp, 12; Klerksdorp, 4l; Christiana, 24; Lichtenburg, 7; Zeerust, 59; Rustenburg, 54; Ermilo, 2. In order to avoid a separate classification for the Sikhs and the Pathans, they have been included among the Gujaratis, if Hindus, and among the Surtis, if Mahomedans.
('7', 327, 1, 3, 745059) The Christians have not been separately classified as they are nearly all Madrassis, and are not more than 200 in all.
('7', 327, 1, 4, 745178) With the exception of the Memons, there are hardly any abstentions, but the task of reaching every Indian in the isolated parts of the Transvaal—as, for instance, farms, etc.—has been beyond my Association during the time that was allotted for the canvassing of signatures.
('7', 327, 1, 5, 745452) Canvassers, who were in all cases responsible and representative men, have reported that a large number of Indians have already left the Transvaal.
('7', 327, 1, 6, 745600) It is common knowledge that nearly 13,000 permits had been issued to British Indians before the struggle commenced in September, 1906. Today the British Indian population of the Transvaal, according to the information at the disposal of my Association, does not at the outside exceed 8,000, but it is probably nearer 7,000 than 8,000, the rest having preferred to leave the country rather than be reduced to slavery.
('7', 327, 1, 7, 746017) My Association is aware thatpressure was brought to bear by white employers on most of those who have registered, excepting a few Memons.
('7', 327, 1, 8, 746155) Moreover, according to the information received by my Association, no more than 350 Indians have applied for registration throughout the Transvaal during the period from July l to October 3l, and that 95 per cent of these applicants are drawn from the Memon section.
('7', 327, 1, 9, 746422) In conclusion, my Association begs to draw the attention of the Government to the intensity of the feeling of the community represented by my Association against the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 327, 1, 10, 746615) In taking up the attitude the community has felt called upon to adopt, there has been no intention of defying the Government; rather, it is a proof of the community’s intense sense of the wrong done to it.
('7', 327, 1, 11, 746821) This sense of injury is so deep that the community has felt compelled to prepare for undergoing a course of suffering which passive resistance, as understood by British Indians, involves.

('7', 328, 1, 2, 747096) 248. TRIAL OF RAM SUNDAR PUNDIT 1
('7', 328, 2, 3, 747130) [GERMISTON,
('7', 328, 3, 4, 747142) November 11, 1907]
('7', 328, 4, 5, 747161) Mr. Gandhi said that, whilst he did not wish to oppose the application for a remand, he informed the Court that, so far as Mr. Pundit was concerned, there was no defence to be offered, but that facts in justification only were to be brought to the notice of the Court.
('7', 328, 4, 6, 747430) The Pundit would admit that he was in the Colony without a permit.
('7', 328, 4, 7, 747497) His client was most anxious that the case should be finished without delay.
('7', 328, 4, 8, 747573) In any case, he had already been in custody for four days and, although scores of Indians had offered to bail him out, the Pundit refused to be bailed out.
('7', 328, 4, 9, 747729) If, therefore, the case was remanded, Mr. Gandhi suggested that the Pundit should be released on his own recognisance.
('7', 328, 4, 10, 747848) To this the Court agreed.
('7', 328, 5, 11, 747874) Indian Opinion, 16 11 1907
('7', 328, 6, 12, 747901) 1 Ram Sundar Pundit was the first Indian to be prosecuted under the Asiatic Act.
('7', 328, 6, 13, 747982) He was arrested on November 8 for “unlawfully entering and remaining in the Transvaal”, after the expiry of his temporary permit.
('7', 328, 6, 14, 748112) It was suggested to the Asiatic Department that his arrest would produce a salutary effect on Indians.
('7', 328, 6, 15, 748215) This was the first case to be instituted under the Asiatic Law Amendment Act and was brought before the Assistant Resident Magistrate.
('7', 328, 6, 16, 748350) The Public Prosecutor having asked for “a remand” to enable him to summon the Registrar of Asiatics, Gandhiji put in this plea.
('7', 328, 6, 17, 748478) Vide also Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XVIII.
('7', 328, 6, 18, 748527) The Transvaal Ieader, 12 11 1907, reported Gandhiji as having said that Ram Sundar Pundit “considered himself innocent of any offence and was prepared to fight the case and therefore would duly appear when called upon to do so”.
('7', 329, 0, 1, 748756) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 329, 1, 2, 748798) 249. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER” 1
('7', 329, 2, 3, 748841) [GERMISTON, November 11, 1907]
('7', 329, 3, 4, 748872) Mr. Gandhi informed me that it 2 was against the religion of Indians— Mohamedans especially—because it took away the personal liberty of every Asiatic coming within the meaning of the Act, the result being that, instead of his being the creature of God only, he became the creature of any official appointed under the Act, and a man believing in God would never even dream of submitting to an Act which really enslaved him.
('7', 329, 3, 5, 749296) Now, religion comes more into play because all Indians are bound by a solemn oath not to accept the Registration Act, as it is opposed to their religion, and every Indian, therefore, would be doing violence to his conscience if he now, for any material advantage he might gain, were to accept the Act.
('7', 329, 3, 6, 749598) Consequently, the priest has actively interested himself in seeing that the people do not register, and that rather than look to the things on earth, they look to those from above.
('7', 329, 3, 7, 749779) This accounts for his (Ram Sundar Pundit) having acted as chief picket when the Asiatic Registration Office was [kept] open in Germiston, picketing having been a purely persuasive act.
('7', 329, 3, 8, 749964) The Transvaal Leader, 12 11 1907
('7', 329, 4, 9, 749997) 250. TRIAL OF RAM SUNDAR PUNDIT 3
('7', 329, 5, 10, 750031) [GERMISTON, November 14, 1907]

('7', 332, 9, 15, 755231) THE DEFENCE
('7', 332, 10, 16, 755243) .PUBLIC PROSECUTOR: The accused had not had anything to do with the pickets?
('7', 332, 10, 17, 755320) MR. GANDHI: I admit he was the chief picket....
('7', 332, 11, 18, 755368) Mr. Gandhi then addressed the Court.
('7', 332, 11, 19, 755405) He admitted that a conviction, as the law stood, was bound to follow, but he urged that this was one of the cases in which an expression from the Bench was necessary.
('7', 332, 11, 20, 755572) He cited the case of Rex vs.
('7', 332, 11, 21, 755601) Bhabha, in which the Supreme Court had expressed strong opinion against the manner of administering the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 332, 11, 22, 755735) His client was not prosecuted because he did not hold a permit, but, as was quite evident, because he had dared to hold strong views about the Asiatic Act and had not hesitated to place them before his countrymen.
('7', 332, 11, 23, 755949) If that was a crime, then the majority of Indians were guilty equally with the accused.
('7', 332, 11, 24, 756037) Ram Sunder Pundit, rightly or wrongly, believed that it was a part of his duty as a preacher to place the real facts about the Act before his countrymen.
('7', 332, 11, 25, 756191) The religious objection went far beyond finger prints and giving the wife’s name.
('7', 332, 11, 26, 756273) The Pundit had preached, because, in his opinion, as in the opinion of every self respecting Indian, the Act took away all manliness from Indians if they submitted to it.
('7', 332, 11, 27, 756444) He considered that, in view of what the priest had done, instead of deserving censure, he was entitled to praise.
('7', 332, 11, 28, 756558) He asked the Court to believe the accused when he said that there was no truth in the complaints which had never seen the light of day, and of the nature of which, even to the day of trial, the accused knew nothing.
('7', 332, 11, 29, 756774) The accused knew the consequences of disobedience to the Registrar’s order, but, in his own words, he had a call of higher duty in obedience to which he was before the Court to suffer imprisonment or worse.

('7', 334, 1, 2, 758645) 253. TRIAL OF PICKETS
('7', 334, 2, 3, 758667) [PRETORIA, November 15, 1907]
('7', 334, 3, 4, 758697) Gavarishanker Vyas, Sharfoodeen, Govind Prag and Frank Lutchman were charged on the 15th instant with the crime of assault, or inciting to the commission of an offence in that upon (or about) the 13th day of November 1907, and at (or near) Pretoria in the said District, the accused did each and all or one or other of them wrongfully and unlawfully assault one Lutchman, an Indian there residing and did then and there gather round him and arrest his progress, thereby preventing him from proceeding to the Indian Registration Office as desired by him (or alternately).
('7', 334, 3, 5, 759268) At the same time and place, the said accused did each and all or one or other of them wrongfully and unlawfully incite the said Lutchman to refrain from applying for registration as required by Sections 1, 2 and 8 of Act 2/1907 1, by threatening the said Lutchman that if he did register, he would be assaulted and have his face blackened.
('7', 334, 3, 6, 759608) The accused pleaded not guilty, and were defended by Mr. Gandhi.
('7', 334, 3, 7, 759673) Mr. Graham conducted the prosecution.
('7', 334, 3, 8, 759711) The Court was crowded with Indians and many could not gain admission.
('7', 334, 4, 9, 759781) The complainant said that the accused spoke to him outside the Registration Office, and said that their people were not taking out permits and advising him to consult those who were wiser than himself.
('7', 334, 4, 10, 759983) The accused had never assaulted him.
('7', 334, 5, 11, 760020) Mr. Graham asked that the witness I [Lutchman] be treated as a hostile witness, but Mr. Gandhi objected.
('7', 334, 5, 12, 760125) The objection was noted, and the witness said that he was taken to the Charge Office and there he was asked by Mr. Cody if the accused had assaulted him, and he said, “No”.
('7', 334, 5, 13, 760298) Mr. Cody said that he had arrested the accused, and when the witness asked, “Why?” he was told that it had been his (witness’) wish.
('7', 334, 5, 14, 760431) Witness said that was not so.
('7', 334, 5, 15, 760461) He said “They are of my nationality and ought not to be arrested.
('7', 334, 5, 16, 760527) I came for a pass, and when I get it I shall go.
('7', 334, 5, 17, 760576) They did not assault me.”
('7', 334, 6, 18, 760602) BY MR. GANDHI: He came to Pretoria to get a pass because he had been told by a white man that he would be sent away if he did not.
('7', 334, 6, 19, 760733) The white man had taken his documents and sent them to Mr. Cody.
('7', 334, 6, 20, 760798) He was a washerman at Witbank.
('7', 334, 6, 21, 760829) He was afraid of the Government in his heart, and that was why he came here.
('7', 334, 6, 22, 760906) He was taken to the Registration Office by two white men who met him at the station...
