('7', 335, 7, 13, 762082) 254. LETTER TO “INDIAN OPINION” 3
('7', 335, 8, 14, 762116) JOHENNESBURG, November 15, 1907
('7', 335, 9, 15, 762148) TO THE EDITOR INDIAN OPINION
('7', 335, 10, 16, 762177) SIR, May I be allowed to bring to the notice of the public some very painful facts which came to light during the course of Ram Sundar Pundit’s trial 4 on Thursday?
('7', 335, 10, 17, 762342) The Registrar of Asiatics admitted that it was a rule of his Office to issue temporary permits to priests, the tacit understanding being that, so long as they only restricted themselves to the priestly vocation, the permits should be extended, in the Registrar’s words, “to the end of time”.
('7', 335, 10, 18, 762634) He then stated that the Hindu priest had added something to the priestly vocation, which in the Registrar’s estimation, disqualified him for the right to extension.
('7', 335, 10, 19, 762799) It was with difficulty that I was able to ascertain that that “some thing” included the priest’s preaching against the Asiatic Act.
('7', 335, 10, 20, 762931) His other misdemeanour was darkly hinted at, but the Registrar point blank refused to disclose the nature of the complaints or the names of the complainants.
('7', 335, 10, 21, 763089) He admitted that the
('7', 335, 11, 22, 763110) 1 Assistant Resident Magistrate 2 Later the pickets were garlanded and taken in a procession to Vyas’s house where A. M. Cachalia, M. L. Desai, chief picket, Gandhiji and others spoke in praise of the brave stand taken by the pickets.
('7', 335, 11, 23, 763345) 3 A Gujarati translation of this appeared in Indian Opinion, 23 11 1907.
('7', 335, 12, 24, 763418) 4 Vide “Trial of Ram Sundar Pundit”, 14 11 1907
('7', 336, 0, 1, 763466) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 337
('7', 336, 1, 2, 763511) priest was never given the opportunity of facing his unknown traducers or answering the complaints; in other words, he was condemned unheard.
('7', 336, 1, 3, 763653) I am not aware of any precedent, except during war time, of any such high handed, unjust and tyrannical action.
('7', 336, 1, 4, 763765) One man, who, as he admitted in the witness box, has not the slightest knowledge of law, is utterly incapable of weighing evidence, and who can scarcely distinguish between sedition and respectful and manly opposition to a particular law touching personal liberty, possesses under the Act extreme powers over the persons of free and inoffensive British subjects.
('7', 336, 1, 5, 764128) He can dictate terms on which he would allow religious preachers to remain in the country, and, if he is displeased with them, he has the power almost summarily to close temples and deprive communities of religious consolation.
('7', 336, 1, 6, 764356) And yet, Asiatics are often asked why they should object to a very simple law, whose only purpose is to identify those that are in the Colony !
('7', 336, 1, 7, 764500) Mr. Leung Quinn has brought to the public notice one tragedy.
('7', 336, 1, 8, 764562) The other that was enacted at Germiston on Thursday was great enoughfor the Magistrate to remark that he could not withhold sympathy from the accused, but the court was helpless, and an innocent man had to be sacrificed on the altar of prejudice, ignorance, incompetence; and insolence of office—attributes un British enough, surely!
('7', 336, 2, 9, 764896) I am, etc.,
('7', 336, 3, 10, 764908) M. K. GANDHI
('7', 336, 4, 11, 764921) Indian Opinion, 23 11 1907
('7', 336, 5, 12, 764948) 255. THE CAXT0N HALL MEETING
('7', 336, 6, 13, 764977) Mr. Ameer Ali and the Moslem residents of the United Kingdom deserve the gratitude of the Indian community in the Transvaal for their having championed their cause.
('7', 336, 6, 14, 765142) It was a happy thought on the part of the Hamidia Islamic Society to send out a general letter 1 to the Indian Mussulmans.
('7', 336, 6, 15, 765265) The cablegrams show that the proceedings were enthusiastic, and that the meeting was attended by many prominent Europeans.
('7', 336, 6, 16, 765388) It is a curious coincidence that the meeting should have taken place on the 9th of November, the birthday of the King Emperor.
('7', 336, 6, 17, 765515) What would have been the feeling of Mr. Ameer Ali and his audience, had they known that, whilst they were pleading for justice and humanity on behalf of the
('7', 336, 7, 18, 765672) 1 Vide “Appeal to Indian Muslims”, 19 8 1907.
('7', 337, 0, 1, 765718) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 337, 1, 2, 765760) down trodden Indians in the Transvaal, that Government had already laid violent hands on an Indian priest?
('7', 337, 1, 3, 765867) We are informed by Reuter that the speeches in denunciation of the Asiatic Act were punctuated by cries of “shame” and “disgraceful”.
('7', 337, 1, 4, 766001) One way of dismissing this important meeting from consideration is to vote it down as the opinion of ignorant people knowing nothing of the local situation.
('7', 337, 1, 5, 766158) Another way is to accept this opinion as being typical of the great dissatisfaction that permeates thousands upon thousands of Indians.
('7', 337, 1, 6, 766294) Interpreted in the latter sense, the resolution passed by the meeting should command the earnest and sympathetic attention of the Transvaal Government.
('7', 337, 1, 7, 766446) And, yet, we feel that, unless the Imperial Government makes effective representations, the authorities in the Transvaal will turn a deaf ear to anything that may be said by Indians, no matter how influential and well informed they may be.
('7', 337, 1, 8, 766686) Be that, however, as it may, one thing the meeting has undoubtedly done, namely, that the Mussulmans from all parts of the world feel that they should not sympathise and work only for their co religionists, but that they should also extend the scope of their activity to the Hindus.
('7', 337, 1, 9, 766969) This is a good sign and it shows that we are fast approaching a time when men will work for men, irrespective of nationality or religion.
('7', 337, 1, 10, 767107) Indian Opinion, 16 11 1907
('7', 337, 2, 11, 767134) 256. LAJPAT RAI’S RELEASE
('7', 337, 3, 12, 767160) LESSON FOR TRANSVAAL INDIANS
('7', 337, 4, 13, 767189) Lala Lajpat Rai and his lieutenant Ajit Singh have been released.
('7', 337, 4, 14, 767255) It is true that they had to suffer banishment, but they also succeeded in getting the [Punjab Lands] Act repealed.
('7', 337, 4, 15, 767370) This success is a strong proof of the effectiveness of passive resistance.
('7', 337, 4, 16, 767445) Does any Indian in the Transvaal have now reason for hesitation in the face of this recent example?
('7', 337, 4, 17, 767545) We hope not.
('7', 337, 4, 18, 767558) On the contrary, even those who have applied, if they can grasp the significance of Lajpat Rai’s success, will take the step, in case they have still the opportunity, of withdrawing their applications, i.e., of not going to receive the register.
('7', 337, 4, 19, 767804) For, everyone admits that the Asiatic Act is bad.
('7', 337, 4, 20, 767854) Those who have registered themselves have been trapped into slavery merely out of blind self interest and fear of imprisonment.
('7', 337, 4, 21, 767982) Lajpat’s success proves that those who entertain any fears are cowardly and as good as defeated; and that those who fight are heroes and as good as victorious.
('7', 337, 4, 22, 768142) The signs that we see these days also point to the same conclusion, namely, that those who are fighting have as good as won.
('7', 337, 4, 23, 768267) There is only one condition, that the fight should be continued to the last, even at the
('7', 338, 0, 1, 768356) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 339
('7', 338, 1, 2, 768401) cost of imprisonment or deportation, which is also what Lajpat’s example points to.
('7', 338, 1, 3, 768485) Therefore, we have not the slightest hesitation in saying that, if the Transvaal Indians draw the lesson which ought to be drawn from the banishment of India’s Lala and prepare themselves boldly to act accordingly, they are bound to win.
('7', 338, 1, 4, 768723) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 16 11 1907
('7', 338, 2, 5, 768766) 257. KING EMPEROR’S BIRTHDAY
('7', 338, 3, 6, 768795) We think it was proper that telegrams of birthday greetings were sent to His Majesty King Edward.
('7', 338, 3, 7, 768893) We are an ancient people.
('7', 338, 3, 8, 768919) Courtesy runs in our blood.
('7', 338, 3, 9, 768947) If the telegrams had not been sent, we would have been found wanting in courtesy.
('7', 338, 3, 10, 769029) We have not sent the greetings specially by way of flattery, or in the hope of gaining anything in connection with the question of the [new] law.

('7', 345, 1, 2, 783635) 264. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 345, 2, 3, 783660) BRAVE TAILORS AND WHITE MERCHANT
('7', 345, 3, 4, 783693) Some of the facts of the hardships of tailors here have already been published in this paper.
('7', 345, 3, 5, 783787) But the case is so important that I give a more detailed account.
('7', 345, 3, 6, 783853) Mr. T. Allbret had addressed the following letter to tailors: It appears from the latest speech of the Colonial Secretary that those Indians who do not conform to the provisions of the new law of the Transvaal Government in respect of Indians will not be given licences and will be arrested and imprisoned, as provided for in the law.
('7', 345, 3, 7, 784188) We should like, with your assistance, to avoid getting involved in any complications, and we very much regret to have to request you therefore to arrange for cash payment in respect of future transactions between us, and to settle the outstanding bills before December.
('7', 345, 3, 8, 784458) It is hoped that no ulterior motive will be attributed to us.
('7', 345, 3, 9, 784520) God willing, if your present uncertain condition is brought to a successful end, we shall be quite happy to have the normal business between us resumed.
('7', 345, 3, 10, 784673) We tender our thanks to you for the satisfaction you have given us in your business dealings and financial transactions with us.
('7', 345, 4, 11, 784802) This is a very polite letter.
('7', 345, 4, 12, 784832) Though it is not rude, it only means that those who do not get themselves registered will get no credit.
('7', 345, 4, 13, 784937) Hence, the tailors were annoyed.
('7', 345, 4, 14, 784970) Had they been cowards, they would have been impelled by fear to get themselves registered.
('7', 345, 4, 15, 785061) Being brave, they flung back to him all his samples and wrote the following letter with 21 signatures: We are in receipt of your notice in Gujarati.
('7', 345, 4, 16, 785210) We are very sorry to inform you that with effect from today, i.e., November 7, 1907, we do not wish to maintain any account with you.
('7', 345, 4, 17, 785344) Moreover, we shall not buy goods worth even a single penny from you, for we have taken an oath not to get ourselves registered.
('7', 345, 4, 18, 785472) We do notwish to violate it in any circumstances, whatever the cost.
('7', 345, 4, 19, 785541) We shall pay off your outstanding credits to us at our earliest convenience.
('7', 345, 4, 20, 785618) Mr. Allbret got into a fright at this.
('7', 345, 4, 21, 785657) The boycott was complete.
('7', 345, 4, 22, 785683) A picket was posted at his shop to watch if anyone bought cloth from there, for, the tailors would refuse an order for stitching if such cloth
('7', 346, 0, 1, 785826) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 347
('7', 346, 1, 2, 785871) was brought to them.
('7', 346, 1, 3, 785892) Thereupon, Mr. Allbret pleaded with the people and offered the following apology: The notice that we issued in English and Gujarati to our clients has been interpreted to mean that we want them to register, and that we would withhold credit in case they failed to do so.
('7', 346, 1, 4, 786163) They have accordingly felt offended, and have called for our boycott.
('7', 346, 1, 5, 786233) We need hardly say that nothing could have been further from our intention than to offend the sentiments of our customers, and we can naturally understand resentment at any pressure being put upon anyone with reference to compliance or non compliance with the laws of the Colony.
('7', 346, 1, 6, 786513) Under our Constitution, we have always believed that everyone is entitled to his own opinion.
('7', 346, 1, 7, 786607) We, therefore, unreservedly withdraw the letter in question and we can only reiterate our hope that Indians will come out of their terrible struggle successfully and that they will be treated by the Government of the Colony with fairness and justice; and, as an earnest of our good faith and as a token of the good relations that have hitherto subsisted between them and ourselves, we hereby send you a cheque for £25 to help the Indian cause.
('7', 346, 1, 8, 787051) With reference to the boycott, we can only trust that it will be removed, but it depends entirely upon our customers whether to deal with us or not.
('7', 346, 1, 9, 787200) If they do, we shall be glad to do our best for them and to sell on the usual terms, but we state that our letter has absolutely nothing to do with the boycott.
('7', 346, 1, 10, 787361) We simply wish to place ourselves right in the matter, and to show that in writing the letter we did not intend to offend anybody.
('7', 346, 1, 11, 787492) We have never heard of such a letter of apology having been written by a white.
('7', 346, 1, 12, 787572) I think it is a sufficiently polite letter.
('7', 346, 1, 13, 787616) This incident should raise the prestige of the tailors, and others ought to take a lesson from it.
('7', 346, 1, 14, 787715) If we are not afraid of the whites, they are not likely to stop credit to us.
('7', 346, 1, 15, 787793) How can they do so?
('7', 346, 1, 16, 787813) Do they not want to earn [money]?
('7', 346, 1, 17, 787847) I have also heard that this firm has had a business of £60,000 with Indians during the last five years, in the course of which it has lost so far only £23. If Indians are honest, they will get credit without asking for it.
('7', 346, 2, 18, 788070) MOOSA ISMAIL MIA Mr. Moosa Ismail Mia has gone on pilgrimage to Mecca.
('7', 346, 2, 19, 788141) I offer him greetings.

('7', 347, 5, 13, 789195) I give below a translation of the letter: 1
('7', 347, 6, 14, 789239) From Chow Kwai to the Chairman, the Chinese Association, November 10, 1907: I am going to leave the world, but I must give a public explanation why I intend to commit suicide.
('7', 347, 6, 15, 789415) Since I came to South Africa I have only been in domestic service.
('7', 347, 6, 16, 789482) My dialect is quite different from that of the rest of my countrymen, with whom I have very seldom associated.
('7', 347, 6, 17, 789593) My employer advised me to re register.
('7', 347, 6, 18, 789632) At first, I refused to do so, but I was informed that I would be dismissed from my employment.
('7', 347, 6, 19, 789727) I thought that I should have to lose my situation.
('7', 347, 6, 20, 789778) Therefore, I was obliged to re register, but I did not know the degradation that would follow until my friend talked to me about the registration matter and showed me the translation of the law.
('7', 347, 6, 21, 789973) I found that I would be treated as a slave, which would be a disgrace to myself and my nation.
('7', 347, 6, 22, 790068) I was not aware of all this before.
('7', 347, 6, 23, 790104) Now it is too late for me to repent.
('7', 347, 6, 24, 790141) I cannot look my countrymen in the face.
('7', 347, 6, 25, 790182) I hope all my countrymen will take warning from my error.

('7', 354, 1, 2, 802780) 271. LETTER TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('7', 354, 2, 3, 802818) [JOHANNESBURG, Before November 23, 1907] [THE EDITOR THE TRANSVAAL LEADER JOHANNESBURG
('7', 354, 3, 4, 802905) SIR,] I had the privilege of being present at the trial of my co priest Ram Sundar Pundit.
('7', 354, 3, 5, 802996) A thought struck me most forcibly, that there must be something radically wrong in the laws of the Transvaal.
('7', 354, 3, 6, 803106) As everyone now knows, I struck Imam Kamali in the heat of the moment for what I considered was a breach of the Koranic injunctions.
('7', 354, 3, 7, 803239) I was fined £5 for it, with the option of imprisonment.
('7', 354, 3, 8, 803295) An unkind friend, who is good enough to describe himself as my disciple, paid the fine, and I escaped gaol.
('7', 354, 3, 9, 803403) I struck again Mahomed Shahboodeen, who, in his evidence, admitted he had broken his oath on the Koran, and said my striking him was as from father to son.
('7', 354, 3, 10, 803559) An indulgent court, therefore, let me off with the warning that I may at any time be required to come up for sentence.
('7', 354, 4, 11, 803678) Ram Sundar Pundit, who has, so far as I am aware, and I know something of him, never hurt anybody, was sentenced to be imprisoned for one month, because he did not hold a piece of paper authorising him, a British subject, to cater for the religious wants of his fellow countrymen in a British Colony.
('7', 354, 5, 12, 803979) According to what I have always understood, if any man deserved gaol, it was I, and yet it was possible for somebody to buy what he thought would be freedom for me; whereas Ram Sundar Pundit must be shut out for one month practically from all intercourse with those whom he has been in the habit of meeting every day, and cut off from his religious work.
('7', 354, 5, 13, 804334) The thought shakes me to the marrow.
('7', 354, 5, 14, 804371) I feel that I am in gaol and Ram Sundar Pundit is free.
('7', 354, 5, 15, 804427) May God give him peace and courage.
('7', 354, 6, 16, 804463) [I am, etc.,
('7', 354, 7, 17, 804476) MAHOMED SHAH] Indian Opinion, 23 11 1907
('7', 355, 0, 1, 804517) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 355, 1, 2, 804559) 272. PUNDITJI’S PATRIOTIC SERVICE
('7', 355, 2, 3, 804593) The service that Ram Sundar Pundit has rendered by going to gaol is such that no service by any other Indian remaining outside can equal it, however great that Indian may be.
('7', 355, 2, 4, 804768) Punditji has opened the gates of our freedom.
('7', 355, 2, 5, 804814) All of us can enter by that gate.
('7', 355, 2, 6, 804848) The Congress President is right in saying that by going to gaol, Punditji has sanctified it.
('7', 355, 2, 7, 804941) All innocent people who go to gaol make it holy.
('7', 355, 2, 8, 804990) We think Punditji and his family are fortunate.
('7', 355, 2, 9, 805038) His fame has spread throughout South Africa.
('7', 355, 2, 10, 805083) It will spread in India too.
('7', 355, 2, 11, 805112) This is the result of real service.
('7', 355, 2, 12, 805148) It is a real service, we think, that Punditji has rendered by unhesitatingly offering himself as sacrifice for the sake of the country.
('7', 355, 2, 13, 805284) What will the community do now?
('7', 355, 2, 14, 805316) This question can have only one answer.
('7', 355, 2, 15, 805356) If, after sending Punditji to gaol, any Indian submits to the obnoxious law, we do not think he deserves the name of man.
('7', 355, 2, 16, 805478) The fight that we have taken up is not a children’s game.
('7', 355, 2, 17, 805536) There can be no immediate fruits of success to enjoy.
('7', 355, 2, 18, 805590) What we wish to achieve is no ordinary thing.
('7', 355, 2, 19, 805636) We shall have to undergo sacrifices worthy of it.
('7', 355, 2, 20, 805686) We shall have to go to gaol in such numbers and till such time as may be necessary to convince the Government that we are in earnest and not merely making an outward show.
('7', 355, 2, 21, 805858) This case has proved that the Government’s talk of being able to deport [people] was baseless.
('7', 355, 2, 22, 805953) Weak kneed Indians need particularly to bear this fact in mind.
('7', 355, 2, 23, 806017) The biggest gain that we see from Punditji’s case is that Hindus and Muslims have become completely united.
('7', 355, 2, 24, 806125) Both have realized that this work concerns all Indians.
('7', 355, 2, 25, 806181) We shall be content if it is said that this has been the only gain of this struggle and of this case.
('7', 355, 3, 26, 806283) [From Gujarati]
('7', 355, 4, 27, 806299) Indian Opinion, 23 11 1907
('7', 355, 5, 28, 806326) 273. TRIAL OF PICKETS
('7', 355, 6, 29, 806348) In the case of the pickets arrested in Pretoria, we have won an unexpected success.
('7', 355, 6, 30, 806432) No one had expected that they would not even be examined.

('7', 356, 1, 6, 806856) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 23 11 1907
('7', 356, 2, 7, 806899) 274. DELEGATES TO CONGRESS
('7', 356, 3, 8, 806926) The resolution passed by the Transvaal British Indian Association to send delegates to the [Indian National] Congress deserves to be welcomed.
('7', 356, 3, 9, 807069) The strong appeal that will be made at the Congress by the five prominent businessmen from here attending it cannot but have some good effect.
('7', 356, 3, 10, 807212) That appeal will have been made at the right time, that is, when many Indians in the Transvaal will be enjoying the luxury of gaol.
('7', 356, 3, 11, 807344) There is a heavy responsibility on the delegates.
('7', 356, 3, 12, 807394) They should carry on a vigorous campaign throughout India.
('7', 356, 3, 13, 807453) Mr. Ameeroodeen, who goes after having seen things for himself here, has the heaviest responsibility.
('7', 356, 3, 14, 807555) Even after the Congress is over, they will have much work to do.
('7', 356, 3, 15, 807620) We intend to publish a photograph of Mr. Ameeroodeen in the next issue.
('7', 356, 3, 16, 807692) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 23 11 1907
('7', 356, 4, 17, 807735) 275. WHEN WILL CAPE INDIANS WAKE UP?
('7', 356, 5, 18, 807772) We have repeatedly said that there is an urgent need for Indians in the Cape to wake up.
('7', 356, 5, 19, 807861) We gave an account in the last issue of the efforts being made there to prevent licences being issued to Indians.
('7', 356, 5, 20, 807975) In view of this, we ask the Cape Indians once again how long they will remain asleep.
('7', 356, 5, 21, 808061) Only a little while ago, we were obliged to point out that the Indians must thank their own indifference for the tyranny of the Cape Immigration Act.
('7', 356, 5, 22, 808211) After that, there were some signs of awakening but it seems the awakening has again subsided.
('7', 356, 5, 23, 808305) In the result, while the hardships of immigration yet remain to be overcome, they find the problem of licences staring them in the face.
('7', 356, 5, 24, 808442) We must say that, even for the loss of the right of appeal to the Supreme Court, Indians themselves are for the most part responsible.
('7', 356, 5, 25, 808577) On that question it was necessary for the people in the Cape to take a lesson from the
('7', 357, 0, 1, 808664) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 357, 1, 2, 808706) conditions in Natal and put up a strong fight.
('7', 357, 1, 3, 808753) But it is to be regretted that this was not done.
('7', 357, 1, 4, 808803) They remained altogether indifferent while the Bill was before the Parliament.
('7', 357, 1, 5, 808882) It needs to be dinned into the minds of Indians in South Africa that, having come to this country, they cannot afford to be asleep all the time.
('7', 357, 1, 6, 809027) We are living here surrounded by an armed camp.
('7', 357, 1, 7, 809075) All people are against us.
('7', 357, 1, 8, 809102) If we remain idle and do not look after the interests of our community, we and our descendants will very likely be reduced to a miserable plight in future.
('7', 357, 1, 9, 809258) Hence, we again ask our brethren in the Cape to be alert on this question from today, lest the enemies who have been giving them pin pricks every now and then and are determined to uproot them altogether reduce them to the condition now prevailing in the Transvaal.
('7', 357, 1, 10, 809524) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 23 11 1907
('7', 357, 2, 11, 809567) 276. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 357, 3, 12, 809592) RAM SUNDAR PUNDIT’S CASE
('7', 357, 4, 13, 809617) A question has been raised whether this case was tried under the new law or the old one, but it is quite easy to decide this.
('7', 357, 4, 14, 809743) The summons issued to him itself quoted Section 17 of the new law, and if that Section were not applicable, Punditji could have been defended along another line.
('7', 357, 4, 15, 809905) Moreover, the readers of this paper know that, even in the letter which Punditji wrote, he had stated that he was also unable to take out a temporary permit under the new law.
('7', 357, 4, 16, 810081) Hence, in my judgment, this case falls under the new law.
('7', 357, 4, 17, 810139) Not only that, it is a case which very much strengthens our hands.
('7', 357, 4, 18, 810206) For, it has covered many legal points.
('7', 357, 4, 19, 810245) There was an attack on religion!
('7', 357, 4, 20, 810278) Moreover, it has been shown how absurd was the reason for not extending the permit.
('7', 357, 4, 21, 810362) And, in any case, Punditji is considered to be one of the leaders which means that they have laid hands on a leader.
('7', 357, 4, 22, 810479) Besides, he is a priest and, therefore, not likely to have interfered with anyone.
('7', 357, 4, 23, 810562) In view of all these facts, the case can obviously be regarded as a very strong one.
('7', 357, 4, 24, 810647) That is the impression made on the minds of the whites, too.
('7', 357, 5, 25, 810708) COMMENT IN “PRETORIA NEWS”
('7', 357, 6, 26, 810735) Commenting on this, Pretoria News says: 1
('7', 357, 7, 27, 810777) There seems to be no very good reason for suddenly declining to permit the Hindus the ministrations and consolations of their religion.
('7', 357, 8, 28, 810913) 1 The text given here is from the original English as reproduced in Indian Opinion, 23 11 1907.
('7', 358, 0, 1, 811009) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 359
('7', 358, 1, 2, 811054) accounts, if Mr. Smuts carries out his threat to enforce the law, they will need these consolations to fortify them in the difficult time through which they will have to pass.
('7', 358, 1, 3, 811230) It seems to us that the Government has blundered.
('7', 358, 1, 4, 811280) It is a mistake to make martyrs, especially religious martyrs, and Mr. Pundit today is a religious martyr upheld by a conscientious belief that he is doing right, and supported by theapplause and admiration of his countrymen and co religionists.
('7', 358, 1, 5, 811526) Quite what the Government has gained is difficult to see.
('7', 358, 1, 6, 811584) We see now that as a result of the case against the Pundit, the sympathies of the whites, too, have been drawn towards Indians.
('7', 358, 1, 7, 811712) The case is considered so important that the local newspapers have devoted much space to it.
('7', 358, 2, 8, 811805) MORE SYMPATHY
('7', 358, 3, 9, 811819) There is a letter in the newspapers by Mr. Phillips, who is a prominent personality in Johannesburg, is himself a priest and President of the Association of Clergymen; the letter is worthy of note.
('7', 358, 3, 10, 812017) He welcomes the offer of voluntary registration by Indians and recommends its acceptance by the Government.
('7', 358, 3, 11, 812125) We reproduce the letter 1 elsewhere.
('7', 358, 3, 12, 812162) Further, Mr. MacIntyre writes in the Leader that here only criminals are required to give ten finger prints, and that if the Government were to abandon the idea of ten finger prints, there would be an annual gain to it of £500. Thus, we are receiving support from all sides.
('7', 358, 3, 13, 812437) If voluntary registration is accepted and the taking of ten finger prints is dropped, we get all that we ask for.
('7', 358, 4, 14, 812551) CASE AGAINST PRETORIA PICKETS
('7', 358, 5, 15, 812581) Commenting on this case, Pretoria News writes as under: The Government scored nothing over the case of Ram Sundar Pundit, and it scored less over the arrest of certain pickets in Pretoria on Thursday.
('7', 358, 5, 16, 812782) This case has proved beyond any doubt that it is not the pickets who use threats; rather, it is the Government that uses intimidation to get people to register.
('7', 358, 5, 17, 812943) If, in spite of these signs, there is any Indian who blackens his face, he will definitely not deserve the name of Indian.
('7', 358, 7, 18, 813066) When Punditji was sentenced to gaol, shops everywhere in the Transvaal remained closed.
('7', 358, 7, 19, 813154) The hawkers stopped going on their rounds.
('7', 358, 7, 20, 813197) Newspaper boys stopped selling newspapers, unmindful of loss.
('7', 358, 7, 21, 813259) The news agency refused to give them copies the next day.
('7', 358, 8, 22, 813317) 1 Not reproduced here
('7', 359, 0, 1, 813339) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 359, 1, 2, 813381) made the subscribers angry.
('7', 359, 1, 3, 813409) The news paper boys had to write letters of apology to their patrons, and even now their difficulties have not come to an end.
('7', 359, 1, 4, 813536) While, on the one hand, the whole body of people was prepared to suffer loss, on the other hand, there was a businessman in Offerton, Mr. Kamalkhan by name; who kept his shop open.
('7', 359, 1, 5, 813717) Likewise in Heidelberg, Messrs Khota, Abou Mian Camroodeen and Adam Mamuji kept their shops open.
('7', 359, 1, 6, 813815) This has caused resentment in the whole of the Indian community.
('7', 359, 2, 7, 813880) CONGRATULATIONS TO BLACKLEGS
('7', 359, 3, 8, 813909) I have had to write bitter things about Mr. Khamisa and his friends.
('7', 359, 3, 9, 813978) I am glad that I have now got an opportunity to give them compliments.
('7', 359, 3, 10, 814049) Mr. Khamisa and all others who had their hands and faces blackened kept their shops closed for the sake of the community.
('7', 359, 3, 11, 814171) Everyone did the same in Pietersburg.
('7', 359, 3, 12, 814209) This fact proves that a mass of water cannot be divided into two by striking at it with a stick.
('7', 359, 3, 13, 814306) It can never happen that the people of the same country will be altogether divided against one another.
('7', 359, 3, 14, 814410) When the poison of self interest disappears, the bond of sympathy for the community cannot but assert itself.
('7', 359, 4, 15, 814520) CHAMNEY’S PRANKS
('7', 359, 5, 16, 814537) There are people who cannot do anything good.
('7', 359, 5, 17, 814583) At present, Mr. Chamney is in such a state of mind.
('7', 359, 5, 18, 814635) By harassing us under some pretext or other, that gentleman wants to make us take out registers.
('7', 359, 5, 19, 814732) His latest performance is that he has made arrangements with the blind Portuguese Government to have those who do not take out permits subjected to harassment.
('7', 359, 5, 20, 814892) A notice is displayed in the office of the Portuguese Consul to the effect that an Indian wishing to go to India via Delagoa Bay will be given a permit to enter Delagoa Bay only if he produces the new register and, in case he does not do so, only if he declares in writing that he does not intend returning to the Transvaal.
('7', 359, 5, 21, 815217) This is mere harassment.
('7', 359, 5, 22, 815242) It shows that they want to make Indians take out the new registers by holding out all kinds of inducements.
('7', 359, 5, 23, 815350) There is nothing else, by way of compulsion, that is likely to succeed.
('7', 359, 5, 24, 815422) The Indian community will not get frightened if permits for Delagoa Bay are not issued.
('7', 359, 5, 25, 815510) Those who wish to go to India by some other route will be able to do so.
('7', 359, 5, 26, 815583) Even then, efforts are being made for this.
('7', 359, 6, 27, 815627) SUGGESTION BY “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”

('7', 359, 7, 29, 815838) The Government will regret it later if it does not arrive at such a compromise.
('7', 360, 0, 1, 815918) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 361
('7', 360, 1, 2, 815963) SHAHJI SAHEB’S BRAVERY
('7', 360, 2, 3, 815986) Shahji Saheb has felt much concerned at Punditji’s imprison ment and he has therefore written the following letter 1 to the newspa pers:
('7', 360, 4, 4, 816123) I was present at the trial of my co priest Ram Sundar Pundit.
('7', 360, 4, 5, 816185) A thought struck me most forcibly, that there must be something radically wrong in thelaws of the Transvaal.
('7', 360, 4, 6, 816294) As everyone now knows, I struck Imam Kamali in the heat of the moment for what I considered was a breach of the Koranic injunctions.
('7', 360, 4, 7, 816427) I was fined £5 for it, with the option of imprisonment.
('7', 360, 4, 8, 816483) An unkind friend, who is good enough to describe himself as my disciple, paid the fine, and I escaped gaol.
('7', 360, 4, 9, 816591) I struck again Mahomed Shahboodeen, who, in his evidence, admitted he had broken his oath on the Koran, and said my
('7', 360, 5, 10, 816707) striking him was as from father to son.
('7', 360, 5, 11, 816747) An indulgent court, therefore, let me off with the warning that I may at any time be required to come up for sentence.
('7', 360, 6, 12, 816866) Ram Sundar Pundit, who has, so far as I am aware, and I know something of him, never hurt anybody, was sentenced to be imprisoned for one month, because he did not hold a piece of paper authorising him, a British subject, to cater for the religious wants of his fellow countrymen in a British Colony.
('7', 360, 7, 13, 817167) According to what I have always understood, if any man deserved gaol, it was I, and yet it was possible for somebody to buy what he thought would be freedom for me; whereas Ram Sundar Pundit must be shut out for one month practically from all intercourse with those whom he has been in the habit of meeting every day, and cut off from his religious work.
('7', 360, 7, 14, 817522) The thought shakes me to the marrow.
('7', 360, 7, 15, 817559) I feel that I am in gaol and Ram Sundar Pundit is free.
('7', 360, 7, 16, 817615) May God give him peace and courage.
('7', 360, 8, 17, 817651) SYMPATHY FROM CAPE TOWN
('7', 360, 9, 18, 817675) The African Indian Association at Cape Town has sent a telegram to the [British Indian] Association expressing its concern and sympathy, and has also sent a telegram to the High Commissioner saying that he should intervene, that the grievances of Indians should be redressed and that Ram Sundar Pundit should be released.
('7', 360, 9, 19, 817997) Such telegrams have been received from many places and I intend to give the names of the places and the contents of the telegrams next week.

('7', 362, 1, 2, 820437) 278. PETITION TO GAEKWAR 1
('7', 362, 2, 3, 820464) [JOHANNESBURG,] November 25, 1907
('7', 362, 4, 4, 820498) HIS HIGHNESS THE GAEKWAR [OF BARODA] 1. Your Petitioners are Your Highness’ subjects, and have migrated to the Transvaal for earning an honest livelihood.
('7', 362, 4, 5, 820653) 2. Your Petitioners have most of them a large stake in the Transvaal.
('7', 362, 4, 6, 820723) 3. Your Petitioners venture respectfully to draw Your Highness’ attention to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act passed by the Transvaal Parliament.
('7', 362, 4, 7, 820866) 4. As protected British subjects and in common with other British Indians in the Transvaal, your Petitioners have, as perhaps Your Highness may be aware, already approached the Imperial Government.
('7', 362, 4, 8, 821064) 5. Your Petitioners attach hereto copy of the submission made to the Right Hon’ble the Secretary of State for the Colonies in connection with the Act, wherein are set forth all the objections.
('7', 362, 4, 9, 821257) 6. As Imperial intervention has been directly refused and as the law in question is considered exceptionally humiliating and insulting and as your Petitioners are bound by a solemn oath not to submit to the Act, they have entered upon what has been termed a passive resistance crusade and have risked the loss of all their belongings.
('7', 362, 4, 10, 821592) The Local Government have threatened imprisonment, deportation and other penalties, all [of] which your Petitioners consider are bearable and worth suffering in preference to bearing the yoke imposed by the Act above mentioned.
('7', 362, 4, 11, 821820) 7. In the humble opinion of your Petitioners, it will strengthen the hands of the Imperial Government as also the Indian Government and it will encourage your Petitioners very greatly to receive Your Highness’ sympathy and active intervention.
('7', 362, 4, 12, 822064) 8. Your Petitioners, therefore, respectfully trust that Your Highness will extend to them your protection in any manner that may be considered desirable, and for this act of justice and mercy your Petitioners shall, as in duty bound, for ever pray, etc.

('7', 363, 1, 2, 822660) 279. PETITION TO HIGH COMMISSIONER 1
('7', 363, 2, 3, 822697) [JOHANNESBURG, Before November 26, 1907]
('7', 363, 4, 4, 822738) HIS EXCELLENCY THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR SOUTH AFRICA
('7', 363, 5, 5, 822792) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT: 1. Your Petitioners are old Indian soldiers, and represent 43 Panjabi Mahomedans, 13 Sikhs, and 54 Pathans.
('7', 363, 5, 6, 822953) 2. Your Petitioners are all British subjects, and were most of them brought to the Colony in connection with the Transport Corps raised at the time of the late war.
('7', 363, 5, 7, 823118) When your Petitioners came to South Africa, they were told by their officers that it would be possible for them, at the end of the war, to settle in any part of South Africa and to receive honourable employment.
('7', 363, 5, 8, 823330) 3. Some of your Petitioners have fought under the British flag during the Chitral Expedition 2, the Tirah Campaign 3, and other expeditions.
('7', 363, 5, 9, 823471) 4. Your Petitioners are mostly holders of permits and registration certificates issued to them under the Peace Preservation Ordinance and Law 3 of 1885. Your Petitioners are not pre war residents of the Transvaal, but were granted permits in exchange for discharge certificates issued by their respective officers.
('7', 363, 5, 10, 823786) 5. With the exception of a few, all are at present without employment, largely because of the struggle against the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 363, 5, 11, 823927) In some cases, their employers have dismissed them for non registration, and, in other cases, on application for employment, your Petitioners have been told that they could get it, if they allowed themselves to be registered under the new Act.
('7', 363, 5, 12, 824171) 6. In the humble opinion of your Petitioners, it is not possible for them to submit to the Asiatic Act, inasmuch as it subjects them to humiliation never experienced by them in India, and reduces them to a state which is incompatible with their self respect and dignity as soldiers.

('7', 364, 1, 4, 825011) 9. Your Petitioners now venture respectfully to claim Your Excellency’s protection in your capacity as High Commissioner and trustee of Imperial interests in South Africa.

('7', 365, 6, 8, 826923) ACCOUNTS OF ASSOCIATION
('7', 365, 7, 9, 826947) These accounts 1 are published along with the advertisements, and I bring them to the notice of every Indian in the Transvaal.
('7', 365, 7, 10, 827074) It can be seen from them that the Association is now left with a sum of £140.18.1 only.
('7', 365, 7, 11, 827162) Moreover, £95 out of this was given by Mr. Allbret.
('7', 365, 7, 12, 827214) The Association has undertaken a Hereulean task.
('7', 365, 7, 13, 827263) Compared to that task, the money is very little.
('7', 365, 7, 14, 827312) We do not know of any other body working economically as this Association.
('7', 365, 7, 15, 827387) Its recurring expenditure is under £10. But now there will be increased expenditure on account of telegrams, etc.
('7', 365, 7, 16, 827501) There is no expenditure on account of rent.
('7', 365, 7, 17, 827545) Mostly, the burden of expenditure is being borne by Johannesburg.
('7', 365, 7, 18, 827611) If the example of Rustenburg is followed by other places, even that will bring a little relief to the Association.
('7', 365, 7, 19, 827726) Only recently, a sum of £15 was received from Rustenburg.
('7', 365, 7, 20, 827784) Its example deserves to be emulated by other towns.
('7', 365, 8, 21, 827836) HOW THEY BESIEGE US
('7', 365, 9, 22, 827856) I have already pointed out how Mr. Chamney has seen to it that we find it difficult to go to Delagoa Bay.
('7', 365, 9, 23, 827962) It appears that now there is a threat at Volksrust.
('7', 365, 9, 24, 828014) We hear it suggested that the Indian who wants to pass through Natal should have his permit examined at Volksrust or Charlestown.
('7', 365, 9, 25, 828144) His thumb impression should be taken before he is allowed to proceed.
('7', 365, 9, 26, 828214) The object behind this is that a record can be
('7', 365, 10, 27, 828261) 1 Vide “British Indian Association, Johannesburg”, 26 10 1907.

('7', 366, 1, 2, 828369) is not to be given.
('7', 366, 1, 3, 828389) Neither of these things is objectionable in itself.
('7', 366, 1, 4, 828441) But if the Government wants to harass us, it should not be allowed to do so.
('7', 366, 1, 5, 828518) All these annoyances are incidental to a struggle.

('7', 366, 1, 7, 828596) The question as to what will happen now ought not to occur to us at all.

('7', 366, 6, 17, 829485) REGULATIONS CONCERNING CABS

('7', 366, 7, 21, 829768) This means that a black barrister in rags or one who is drunk can ride in a first class cab, but a wealthy and well dressed, Indian merchant cannot!
('7', 366, 7, 22, 829917) Moreover, a barrister may ride in it, but not his wife and children.
('7', 366, 7, 23, 829986) There is no limit to the stupidity of the people who make such laws.

('7', 368, 4, 13, 833759) PETITION TO GAEKWAR
('7', 368, 5, 14, 833779) The subjects of His Highness the Gaekwar have submitted the following petition to him in connection with the new law, signed by nearly 150 persons.
('7', 368, 6, 15, 833927) WHAT SHOULD BE DONE IN DECEMBER?
('7', 368, 7, 16, 833960) Many of our readers will be eager to read the answer to this question.
('7', 368, 7, 17, 834031) I have reserved the question for the last place in my letter, but it would have deserved the first.
('7', 368, 8, 18, 834131) WHAT CAN BE DONE
('7', 368, 9, 19, 834148) Before deciding what should be done, let us consider what can be done.
('7', 368, 9, 20, 834219) We have seen that the Government has no authority to expelus with physical force.
('7', 368, 9, 21, 834301) The only thing that remains is putting us into gaol.
('7', 368, 9, 22, 834354) Under Section 8 of the Act, the police can demand the new register from every Indian.
('7', 368, 9, 23, 834440) If he does not have it, he can be produced before a magistrate.
('7', 368, 9, 24, 834504) There he will get a notice to leave the country within a specified period.
('7', 368, 9, 25, 834579) When the order is disregarded, the person will be arrested again, and can be sentenced to imprisonment for up to six months.
('7', 368, 9, 26, 834704) When a person is tried under this Section, the magistrate has no power to impose a fine.
('7', 368, 9, 27, 834793) If we read the Act, we shall find that the court can order anyone to apply for the register.
('7', 368, 9, 28, 834886) Instead of trying a person in this manner, the Government can also prosecute him for

('7', 369, 0, 1, 835012) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 369, 1, 2, 835054) not making such application.
('7', 369, 1, 3, 835083) The penalty for the offence of not making an application is a fine of £100 or imprisonment.
('7', 369, 1, 4, 835175) The Government can deal with every Indian in this manner, which means that every Indian can be put into gaol.

('7', 369, 6, 17, 836118) NO APPLICATION FOR BAIL
('7', 369, 7, 18, 836142) The arrested person must not offer bail.
('7', 369, 7, 19, 836183) A lawyer is also not to be engaged.
('7', 369, 7, 20, 836219) When he attends the court on the day of hearing, he should state:
('7', 369, 8, 21, 836285) I oppose the law.
('7', 369, 8, 22, 836303) I am a bona fide resident of the Transvaal.
('7', 369, 8, 23, 836347) I hold a genuine permit.
('7', 369, 8, 24, 836372) Under this law we cease to be human beings.
('7', 369, 8, 25, 836416) We also lose our religion.
('7', 369, 8, 26, 836443) I will not therefore submit to it.
('7', 369, 8, 27, 836478) Our whole community is against it.
('7', 369, 8, 28, 836513) If the Government serves me with a notice to leave, that also will not be complied with.
('7', 369, 8, 29, 836602) Hence, whatever penalty is to be inflicted on me may be inflicted just now.
('7', 369, 8, 30, 836678) If a notice has to be given, it may please be as short as possible.
('7', 369, 8, 31, 836746) This should be said by the person himself through an interpreter.
('7', 369, 9, 32, 836812) NOTICE WILL BE SERVED
('7', 369, 10, 33, 836834) Thereupon, the chances are that a notice will be served.
('7', 369, 10, 34, 836891) Even after the expiry of the period of notice, no lawyer will be needed.
('7', 369, 10, 35, 836964) The person concerned will remain free till the notice period expires.
('7', 369, 10, 36, 837034) During that time, he may make whatever arrangements he thinks
('7', 370, 0, 1, 837096) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 371
('7', 370, 1, 2, 837141) necessary concerning his personal affairs.
('7', 370, 2, 3, 837184) AFTER EXPIRY OF NOTICE PERIOD
('7', 370, 3, 4, 837214) After the expiry of the notice period, he will be arrested again.
('7', 370, 3, 5, 837280) No further statement is to be made on this occasion.

('7', 370, 3, 7, 837401) He should then go through whatever sentence is inflicted.

('7', 370, 3, 9, 837546) The telegram should contain particulars of whether the person has a family, where it lives, whether he has left it to the community to provide for its maintenance or whether he has resources of his own, etc.
('7', 370, 4, 10, 837754) It should be remembered that, wherever necessary, the dependants [of the arrested person] will be maintained by the community till the day of his release from gaol.
('7', 370, 4, 11, 837919) The best thing will be for every place to assume responsibility for its own people, just as the responsibility for the family of Ram Sundar Pundit was assumed by the Indians of Germiston.
('7', 370, 4, 12, 838107) But if this is not possible the Association will certainly make some arrangements, If they do not strike at Johannesburg and, consequently, Mr. Gandhi is not occupied there, he will run up to any place where Indians (bona fide residents) may have been arrested and he will not charge fees [for their defence].

('7', 370, 4, 14, 838492) Even if this is not done, the Association will pay them and Mr. Gandhi will make himself available at that place.
('7', 370, 5, 15, 838606) There is no need to say anything about the business of a person sent to gaol.

('7', 370, 5, 17, 838734) The Government will not be able to force anyone to close down his shop.

('7', 370, 5, 20, 838953) Even while in gaol, one can look after one’s business: one may write letters or send messages.

('7', 370, 7, 23, 839185) That is the best way.

('7', 371, 6, 13, 840181) HALOO’ S TURN ABOUT

('7', 371, 9, 15, 840337) I beg respectfully to return herewith the registration certificate granted to me on the 12th day of October, 1907. In doing so, I am quite aware that it is not possible for me to cast off the yoke of the Act I have undertaken to bear; but that is, under the circumstances in which I am placed, the least I can do.
('7', 371, 9, 16, 840651) Indeed, when I went to your temporary office in Von Brandis Square, Johannesburg, I had conflicting emotions—on the one hand was my creditor pressing me to submit to the Act or threatening to sell me out, on the other was the shame I would have to incur by reason of my submission.
('7', 371, 9, 17, 840933) But I did not then realize the magnitude of the shame; I yielded to the threat.
('7', 371, 10, 18, 841013) I now see that my existence has become intolerable.
('7', 371, 10, 19, 841065) I am shunned by my countrymen and my co religionists.
('7', 371, 10, 20, 841119) My sister and my other relations write to me disowning me entirely and telling me that, in breaking my oath that I had solemnly taken, I have become an unfit member of my family.
('7', 371, 10, 21, 841298) Even if I should retain my possessions, I see that they would be more a burden to me than anything else, with all those who have associated with me and with whom I had the privilege of associating putting me outside their pale.

('7', 373, 2, 9, 844848) PETITION BY PUNJABIS The Punjabis have addressed a petition to Lord Selborne which we translate below: 1
('7', 373, 3, 10, 844953) Your Petitioners are old Indian soldiers, and represent 43 Punjabi Mahomedans, 13 Sikhs, and 54 Pathans.
('7', 373, 3, 11, 845058) Your Petitioners are all British subjects, and were most of them brought to the Colony in connection with the Transport Corps raised at the time of the late war.
('7', 373, 3, 12, 845220) When your Petitioners came to South Africa, they were told by their officers that it would be possible for them, at the end of the war, to settle in any part of South Africa.
('7', 373, 4, 13, 845395) Some of your Petitioners have fought under the British flag during the Chitral Expedition, the Tirah Campaign, and other expeditions.
('7', 373, 4, 14, 845529) With the exception of a few, all are at present without employment, largely because of the struggle against the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 373, 4, 15, 845667) In some cases, their employers have dismissed them for non registration, and, in other cases, your Petitioners have been told that they could get employment if they allowed themselves to be registered under the new Act.
('7', 373, 5, 16, 845887) In the humble opinion of your Petitioners, it is not possible for them to submit to the Asiatic Act, inasmuch as it subjects them to humiliation never experienced by them in India.
('7', 373, 5, 17, 846068) How could they sacrifice their self respect and dignity as soldiers?
('7', 373, 5, 18, 846137) Your Petitioners cannot return to India and find the wherewithal to support themselves.
('7', 373, 5, 19, 846225) Your Petitioners now venture respectfully to claim Your Excellency’s protection in your capacity as High Commissioner and trustee of Imperial interests in South Africa.
('7', 373, 5, 20, 846394) Your Petitioners, therefore, respectfully pray that Your Excellency will be pleased to secure them such relief as may be possible under the circumstances.

('7', 374, 1, 2, 846773) MEMORIAL MEETING OF CHINESE [Wednesday]
('7', 374, 2, 3, 846813) The Chinese Association held a memorial meeting today (Wednesday) to commemorate the Chinaman who had committed suicide.
('7', 374, 2, 4, 846934) No one present at the meeting could help feeling admiration for the Chinese.
('7', 374, 2, 5, 847011) Their beautiful hall was adorned with black cloth.
('7', 374, 2, 6, 847062) On one side in the hall there was a photograph of the Chinaman who had died.
('7', 374, 2, 7, 847139) In the centre were standing all those who had served as pickets.
('7', 374, 2, 8, 847204) Surrounding them on all sides were chairs which were occupied by invitees.
('7', 374, 2, 9, 847279) About a thousand Chinese, with flowers in their hands, gently passed by the photograph, praying for the soul of the departed one, and went out through the door opposite.
('7', 374, 2, 10, 847449) All these men were neatly dressed.
('7', 374, 2, 11, 847484) Then they sang dirges in Chinese, after which there was a meeting in another hall.
('7', 374, 2, 12, 847567) The hall was packed to capacity and the chairman, Mr. Quinn, made a speech in Chineseand English.
('7', 374, 2, 13, 847665) He was followed by Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Polak who commented upon the law.
('7', 374, 2, 14, 847737) The meeting was then dissolved.
('7', 374, 2, 15, 847769) Their unity, neatness and courage—all these three things deserve to be emulated by us.
('7', 374, 3, 16, 847856) ASSAULT IN PRETORIA
('7', 374, 4, 17, 847876) A case is going on against a Pathan, named Banutkhan, for having assaulted Mr. Hajee Ebrahim, who is a blackleg Full reports about it have not yet arrived.
('7', 374, 4, 18, 848032) But it appears that Banutkhan dealt a blow with a stick to Mr. Ebrahim for having taken out a register and broken the oath.
('7', 374, 4, 19, 848156) Hajee Ebrahim tossed him to the ground and pressed him down.
('7', 374, 4, 20, 848217) To get free from his clutches, Banutkhan bit Ebrahim on the cheek.
('7', 374, 4, 21, 848284) At first the amount of bail for Banutkhan was fixed at £100, for Mr. Chamney had reported that Banutkhan had threatened him too.
('7', 374, 4, 22, 848413) Half way through the proceedings, the amount of bail was reduced to £50. The magistrate fined Banutkhan £20 and he has paid the amount.
('7', 374, 5, 23, 848549) LETTER FROM MANILAL DESAI

('7', 375, 1, 2, 848949) 282. SPEECH AT CHINESE ASSOCIATION 1
('7', 375, 2, 3, 848986) [JOHANNESBURG, November 27, 1907]
('7', 375, 3, 4, 849020) He said that it seemed like profanity to discuss the Act on such an occasion; yet, as the Chairman had set the example, 2 he could not but follow it, especially as the ceremony at which they had so recently assisted was so intimately connected with the Act.
('7', 375, 3, 5, 849278) He had often heard it remarked that the Chinese people did not value human life as other people did, but if he at any time had any illusions on that point, they were set at rest after what he had seen that afternoon.
('7', 375, 3, 6, 849495) He wished General Smuts could have attended the gathering to witness the great ceremonial through which they had passed.
('7', 375, 3, 7, 849616) He thought, in that case, that General Smuts would have thought twice before saying he had put his foot down and was going to keep it there.
('7', 375, 3, 8, 849757) He (Mr. Gandhi) had taken upon himself the responsibilityof advising the fighting of the Asiatic Act, and he still felt he was doing what was right, proper and just.
('7', 375, 3, 9, 849923) He gave that advice to his countrymen and he had no hesitation in giving the same advice to them as fellow Asiatics.
('7', 375, 3, 10, 850040) He tried hard, and for a long time, to draw a line between British subjects and non British subjects.
('7', 375, 3, 11, 850142) He pleaded hard with the Government here and with the Imperial Government that at least there should be a discrimination between British subjects and other Asiatics.
('7', 375, 3, 12, 850308) “No,” was the emphatic answer both from the Imperial Government and the local Government, and although he claimed for his countrymen and himself all the rights that should properly belong to British subjects, that claim was summarily rejected and British Indians and other Asiatics were classed alike.
('7', 375, 4, 13, 850610) Adversity had made them strange bed fellows in this struggle.
('7', 375, 4, 14, 850672) It was perfectly true that in spite of the position, British Indians still, somehow or other, clung to the British subject idea, and they felt that some day or other, they would be able to make good the plea.
('7', 375, 4, 15, 850881) So far as that was concerned, the Chinese fight was different to the British Indian fight, but so far as the incidence of this wretched legislation was concerned, the Chinese fight was identical with that of the British Indians, and it was because the law pressed equally heavily on both that both were fighting it.
('7', 375, 4, 16, 851197) If any justification were to be sought for repealing the Asiatic Act, he thought there were two instances.
('7', 375, 4, 17, 851304) The first in importance was undoubtedly the death of a countryman of his Chinese audience.
('7', 375, 4, 18, 851395) Their countryman had sacrificed himself for what he thought
('7', 375, 5, 19, 851455) 1 A memorial service was held for Chow Kwai, a Chinese who, feeling the degradation of having submitted to registration, had committed suicide.
('7', 375, 5, 20, 851599) Gandhiji was invited by Mr. Quinn, Chairman of the Chinese Association, to address the gathering.
('7', 375, 5, 21, 851697) 2 He had exhorted the audience to resist imposition of the Asiatic Law Amendment Act.
('7', 376, 0, 1, 851783) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 377
('7', 376, 1, 2, 851828) was a mistake.
('7', 376, 1, 3, 851843) A miserable attempt had been made to show that the man had given his life for other reasons, but the fact stood out prominently that the man had given his life for the sake of this wretched, miserable Asiatic Act.
('7', 376, 1, 4, 852057) The other instance he referred to was among his (the speaker’s) own countrymen.
('7', 376, 1, 5, 852137) A man perfectly guiltless and striving to live his life as he best knew how, serving the spiritual needs of his countrymen, had been sent to jail, and was today in default in Johannesburg simply because of this Asiatic Act.
('7', 376, 1, 6, 852361) 1 All sorts of charges had been made against him, and there was not an iota of proof of the seditious charges.
('7', 376, 1, 7, 852472) He (Mr. Gandhi) could only say that an Act which had exacted already this heavy price could never be submitted to, either by [the] Chinese or by British Indians, if they were true to themselves, if they were true to their countrymen, and if they valued their honour above anything else.
('7', 376, 1, 8, 852759) The struggle was a moral and religious one.
('7', 376, 1, 9, 852803) He reminded them that virtue was its own reward, and said if this was a question of conflicting rights between Europeans and Asiatics, he could understand the position taken up by the Government.
('7', 376, 1, 10, 852999) But he felt convinced that this was not a struggle between Europeans and Asiatics.
('7', 376, 1, 11, 853082) General Smuts was reputed to be very strong, and so he was; but so far as the Asiatics were concerned, that strength remained to be proved.
('7', 376, 1, 12, 853222) He submitted that they were violating the consciences of thirteen thousand British Indians and thirteen hundred Chinese, and that they had chosen the rottenest way of doing a thing which could have been done in a better way long enough ago.
('7', 376, 1, 13, 853463) After the 2nd December, their freedom was not their own, but, whether arrested or not, they would keep before their minds the spirit of the dead man and remember in this struggle that virtue was its own reward.
('7', 376, 2, 14, 853674) Indian Opinion, 7 12 1907
('7', 376, 3, 15, 853700) 1 The reference is to Ram Sundar Pundit; vide " Trial of Ram Sundar Pundit”, 11 11 1907; 14 11 1907
('7', 377, 0, 1, 853800) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 377, 1, 2, 853842) 283. WHY WE OPPOSE
('7', 377, 2, 3, 853861) During the past fifteen months, hardly a week has passed but these pages have contained some statement against the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, and yet there is no denying the fact that the majority of Europeans and even many Indians will not be able to say why there should be such bitter and sustained opposition to a mere registration law.
('7', 377, 2, 4, 854202) Some say that the Act is objectionable because it requires Asiatics and their children over eight years to give digit impressions; others, again, because this law gives unlimited power to harass Asiatics.
('7', 377, 2, 5, 854407) Whilst we do not minimise the importance of these objections, we do not hesitate to admit that, by themselves, they would be trivial, at any rate, certainly not worth the sacrifice that British Indians have pledged themselves to make.
('7', 377, 2, 6, 854642) Why, then, this strenuous struggle?
('7', 377, 2, 7, 854678) The answer is because the Act, read in conjunction with the events that preceded it and produced it, is one that takes away the very manhood from British Indians, who claim to be just as civilised as the law givers themselves, in all the essentials of life.
('7', 377, 2, 8, 854936) The Act constitutes, on the one hand, an assertion of a right on the part of the Government of the Transvaal to treat British Indians as they please, and without reference to the latter’s opinion or feelings.
('7', 377, 2, 9, 855145) On the other, there is a denial of any such inherent right in the Government, especially when their act involves a curtailment of or an attack on personal liberty.
('7', 377, 2, 10, 855309) If we were asked to point out in which Section of the Act is to be seen any such intention or assertion on the part of the Government, it would, perhaps, be difficult to lay our finger on any particular Section without exposing ourselves to the charge of sentimentality.
('7', 377, 2, 11, 855580) Just as it is not possible to say in what particular grain of opium lies the poison, so, perhaps, is it not possible to point to the venom in the Act.
('7', 377, 2, 12, 855731) But the whole of it is, undoubtedly, rank poison to a self respecting Asiatic, and the trivialities mentioned above are, taken together, sure indications of the fact.
('7', 377, 2, 13, 855898) The general effect of the Act can only be felt but cannot be expressed; hence it is that the people at large have used symbols to represent the deadly spirit they have always sensed sub consciously yet not the less really.
('7', 377, 2, 14, 856121) What has happened during the attempted administration of the Act—the futile prosecution of Carim Jamal, the secret examination of applicants, the startling revelations at the trial of the Indian priest 1—furnishes a terrible confirmation and a
('7', 377, 3, 15, 856365) 1 Vide “Johannesburgg Letter”, 29 7 1907, ; 5 8 1907 and “Trial of Ram Sundar Pundit”, 14 11 1907
('7', 378, 0, 1, 856463) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 379
('7', 378, 1, 2, 856508) complete justification of the view held by the Indian community.
('7', 378, 1, 3, 856573) After what we have stated above, it is, perhaps, hardly necessary to show wherein lies the religious objection, but a little closer examination is possibly necessary, as even well meaning friends have asked the question.
('7', 378, 1, 4, 856794) Judging from the highest standpoint, we will not use the very effective argument drawn from the wantonly invidious distinction made between Turkish Mahomedans and other Turkish subjects, but for men of religion we would venture to put our argument in the form of a simple question: If it be a fact that Indians conscientiously consider that the Act unmans them, degrades them, practically enslaves them, can those who are less than men ever worship God; can men who, well knowing the injurious consequences of a particular measure, accept it from base, because purely selfish and worldly, motives ever serve God?
('7', 378, 1, 5, 857407) Viewed in this light, it is clear that the struggle is of paramount importance.
('7', 378, 1, 6, 857487) A handful of men, usually accounted as not particularly brave, are crossing swords with a comparatively mighty Government with unrestricted power.
('7', 378, 1, 7, 857634) Can they succeed?
('7', 378, 1, 8, 857652) We say, emphatically, “Yes” —provided that they are, as they have hitherto shown themselves to be, willing and ready to sacrifice commensurately with the result to be obtained.
('7', 378, 2, 9, 857829) Indian Opinion, 30 11 1907
('7', 378, 3, 10, 857856) 284. WHY DO WE OPPOSE LAW?
('7', 378, 4, 11, 857883) For the past twelve months, we have been writing something or other in this journal in reply to this question.
('7', 378, 4, 12, 857994) In spite of that, the cause behind the struggle, we are afraid, has remained obscure to most Indians.
('7', 378, 4, 13, 858096) We can hope that the game will start in right earnest now.
('7', 378, 4, 14, 858155) We expect that, though the Government is afraid, it will surely lay hands on about a hundred Indians at least.
('7', 378, 4, 15, 858266) If it does not, we shall be really sorry.
('7', 378, 4, 16, 858308) Superficially, it may not appear proper to talk in this strain; yet, we think that what we have said is right.
('7', 378, 4, 17, 858419) For, the time for our test has arrived.
('7', 378, 4, 18, 858459) The people are in high spirits.
('7', 378, 4, 19, 858491) If the Government denies us the opportunity of being tested, it will not come again.
('7', 378, 4, 20, 858576) As warriors on the battle field feel sorely disappointed when they return without fighting, so is the condition of the Transvaal Indians just now.
('7', 378, 4, 21, 858723) Only if a hundred Indians, at least, went to gaol, could it be said that a fight was given.
('7', 378, 4, 22, 858815) This journal will be in the hands of the Transvaal readers just on the 1st or 2nd of December.
('7', 378, 4, 23, 858910) At that time, the brave will be eagerly waiting to be the first on the battle field, that is, to be arrested without having committed any crime.
('7', 378, 4, 24, 859055) The cowards, frightened to
('7', 379, 0, 1, 859082) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 379, 1, 2, 859124) death, will be hiding in their houses, terrified at the thought of being arrested.
('7', 379, 1, 3, 859207) And as for those who have blackened their faces, how can they have the good fortune of such an occasion of patriotic service?
('7', 379, 1, 4, 859333) Whether cowards or heroes, for both we consider December 2 to be a grand occasion.
('7', 379, 1, 5, 859416) We congratulate even the cowards because, though panicky, for the sake of the country they have not submitted to registration.
('7', 379, 1, 6, 859543) Why do we write thus?
('7', 379, 1, 7, 859565) What heavy task is the Indian community facing?
('7', 379, 1, 8, 859613) Why are we opposing the law?
('7', 379, 1, 9, 859642) Let us now consider the answer.
('7', 379, 1, 10, 859674) To many it appears that there is a fight because of the objection to giving ten finger prints , to some, the only objectionable thing is submitting the names of mother and wife ; while others say that it is painful to think of the police making a house to house search.
('7', 379, 1, 11, 859944) It is true that all these things are rather humiliating.
('7', 379, 1, 12, 860001) Only thieves submit ten fingerprints; reference to the sacred name of the mother, by way of insult, has called forth daggers from waist bands; when the police have asked for passes from people, presuming them to be suspects, they have had from the persons, enraged by the insult, a blow with the fist which sent them staggering to the ground.
('7', 379, 1, 13, 860344) In spite of this, if someone asks for finger prints courteously, and without compulsion, and we comply, no serious resentment is felt.
('7', 379, 1, 14, 860479) It is with great joy that we take the name of the mother in the same manner as we utter the name of Ishwar or Khuda while saying prayers with the rosary.
('7', 379, 1, 15, 860633) That is to say, the things referred to above are objectionable because they have been introduced with a view to insulting us.
('7', 379, 1, 16, 860759) Not all yellow people suffer from jaundice.
('7', 379, 1, 17, 860803) But, generally speaking, if we see an emaciated body which is yellow, we shall take it for granted that the person has got that disease.
('7', 379, 1, 18, 860940) A physician will not treat the person for being yellow.
('7', 379, 1, 19, 860996) He will treat him for jaundice.
('7', 379, 1, 20, 861028) We have to spot out, then, the jaundice in the law.
('7', 379, 1, 21, 861080) It is this: that the white people, by introducing this law, wish to show that the Asiatics are not men but beasts; not free men, but slaves; not their equals, but their inferiors; that they are born to endure whatever is inflicted on them, that they have no right to protest; that they are not men, but cowards.
('7', 379, 1, 22, 861392) [Taking of] finger prints, etc., is only a symptom of this condition, this jaundice.
('7', 379, 1, 23, 861477) Whatever the law wants us to do, it wants us to do under compulsion.
('7', 379, 1, 24, 861546) The Indian, who is a man of credit, is assumed to be a thief.
('7', 379, 1, 25, 861608) Assuming that we are thieves, they also consider our children to be thieves, and strike fear in them by unworthy attacks on them.
('7', 379, 1, 26, 861738) In our country the words, “A European is coming”, arouse terror in children from infancy.
('7', 379, 1, 27, 861828) So here also this law is intended to terrorize them.
('7', 379, 1, 28, 861881) If we were asked to point out in which section of the law all this occurs, it would be difficult to reply.
('7', 379, 1, 29, 861988) No one can point to
('7', 380, 0, 1, 862008) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 381
('7', 380, 1, 2, 862052) the flower of Deadly Nightshade and say which part of it contains the poison.
('7', 380, 1, 3, 862130) The proof of the poison is in eating [its berries]; and the same is true of this law.
('7', 380, 1, 4, 862216) If this law is read and fully understood by a proud and self respecting man, it cannot but send a shudder through his body.
('7', 380, 1, 5, 862340) It deprives the Indian of the very spirit of manliness in him.
('7', 380, 1, 6, 862403) And just as a blunted sword becomes useless, so the Indian who submits to this law ceases to be a human being.
('7', 380, 1, 7, 862514) After this, who will ask where the objection from the point of view of religion lies.
('7', 380, 1, 8, 862600) Leaving aside the fact that in Turkey, it applies to the Muslims but that the Christians and the Jews are excluded, if this law exists to insult us and to treat us like animals, we want to know whether animals know God or understand religion.
('7', 380, 1, 9, 862843) In fact, this law amounts to a war between the Asiatics and the white people.
('7', 380, 1, 10, 862921) The latter declare: ‘We shall keep the Asiatics merely as machines to slave for us.’ The Indians opposing the law in the Transvaal say: ‘If we stay, we shall stay as free men and as equals in everyday affairs.’ That is the true significance of the law.
('7', 380, 1, 11, 863174) To challenge a strong enemy to a struggle like this and to win is difficult as well as easy.
('7', 380, 1, 12, 863267) It is difficult because we have to invite trouble; easy in the sense that the man feels happy in suffering loss while serving the community with a view to securing the welfare of the country.
('7', 380, 1, 13, 863459) A match for the mighty in every respect, in wealth, physical strength and such are the white people; then, how will a handful of Indians prevail against them?
('7', 380, 1, 14, 863618) To the man who asks such a question, we shall not hesitate to reply that he has little faith in God.
('7', 380, 1, 15, 863719) How can we forget: He who is born must die; Yield not to despair; The Almighty is with you, The merciful God.
('7', 380, 1, 16, 863829) Moreover, we are told what happens when a person, though strong, takes to oppression: “I am myself God,” so declared Mansur to the entire world.
('7', 380, 1, 17, 863974) [But] he mounted the gallows—so full of difficulties is this life.
('7', 380, 1, 18, 864041) In this struggle, only one condition is required for our success, and that is that our courage must be real.
('7', 380, 1, 19, 864150) Our sword, in the form of our capacity to suffer, must be made not of wood, but of tempered steel.

('7', 381, 2, 4, 864494) He has from the first shown unflinching opposition to the law.
('7', 381, 2, 5, 864557) Therefore, when he was to go to India, several of his friends asked him whether he would like to go as a delegate.
('7', 381, 2, 6, 864672) Mr. Ameero odeen instantly took up the challenge.
('7', 381, 2, 7, 864722) That would be the first thing he would attend to in India; that was the assurance he gave before leaving.
('7', 381, 2, 8, 864828) We publish that gentleman’s photograph in this issue.
('7', 381, 2, 9, 864882) Mr. Ameeroodeen is 36 years old.
('7', 381, 2, 10, 864915) His parents belonged to a family of Zamindars, which is the reason why his surname is Fajandar.
('7', 381, 2, 11, 865011) He belongs to the famous Zatam family.
('7', 381, 2, 12, 865050) When he first came to the Transvaal in the year 1888, he joined the well known firm of Sheth Mahomed Cassim Camroodeen as a clerk.
('7', 381, 2, 13, 865181) He served there till 1893, when he started his own business.
('7', 381, 2, 14, 865242) The name of his firm is Messrs Mahomed Hussain & Co.
('7', 381, 2, 15, 865295) Many whites tried to get him to apply for registration by threatening to withhold credit, but he stuck to his resolution.

('7', 381, 3, 17, 865460) 286. OBNOXIOUS LAW AND REGULATIONS MADE UNDER IT
('7', 381, 4, 18, 865509) We give in this issue the English text of the new law and the regulations made under it, and a Gujarati translation of the same.
('7', 381, 4, 19, 865638) We also gave a Gujarati translation earlier.
('7', 381, 4, 20, 865683) 1 There are some changes in the translation that is being given herewith.
('7', 381, 4, 21, 865757) We also give the relevant sections of the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 381, 4, 22, 865829) Apart from this, there are also other important items in this issue.
('7', 381, 4, 23, 865898) We therefore advise every Indian to read this issue carefully and then preserve it.
('7', 381, 4, 24, 865982) Since we know that the new law and the regulations made under it provide the most effective arguments against themselves, we intend to publish the law and the regulations in the form of a booklet, both in English and Gujarati.
('7', 381, 4, 25, 866209) It will be priced at 6d.
('7', 381, 4, 26, 866234) We are convinced that this issue.
('7', 381, 4, 27, 866268) and the booklet on the law deserve to find a place in every home in India.

('7', 381, 4, 29, 866351) 3 of 1885 will remain in force with the modifications that follow.

('7', 382, 1, 2, 866529) 2. The term “Asiatics” will mean Indians, coolies and Muslim subjects of Turkey.
('7', 382, 1, 3, 866610) It will not include Malays and the Chinese who had come in as indentured labourers.
('7', 382, 1, 4, 866694) (There are other definitions of Registrar, etc., which are not given here.) 3. Every Asiatic lawfully residing in the Transvaal must register himself.
('7', 382, 1, 5, 866845) There will be no fee for such registration.
('7', 382, 1, 6, 866889) Asiatics of the following description will be deemed lawful residents of the Transvaal: (a) Any Asiatic who holds a permit under the Permit Act, unless such permit was fraudulently obtained.
('7', 382, 1, 7, 867080) (Temporary permits are not covered by this).

Every Asiatic resident in the Transvaal at the date of the taking effect of this Act shall apply for registration to such officer, at such place and before such date as may be prescribed by the Colonial Secretary.
('7', 382, 1, 9, 867472) Every Asiatic who enters the Transvaal after the date of the taking effect of this Act and who has not previously been registered thereunder shall apply for registration within eight days of his entry.
('7', 382, 1, 10, 867674) (a) It is not necessary to make an application under this clause for a child under the age of eight years.
('7', 382, 1, 11, 867781) (b) For the registration of a child above eight years and under sixteen years, the application shall be made by his guardian and if not so made shall be made by such child within one month after attaining the age of 16 years.
('7', 382, 1, 12, 868007) 5. The Registrar shall consider the applications of Asiatics who are lawful residents, and register every such applicant whose application may be approved by him.
('7', 382, 1, 13, 868170) If the Registrar rejects the application of any Asiatic, he will give to the person concerned at least 14 days’ notice to appear before a magistrate.
('7', 382, 1, 14, 868320) If he fails to appear at the time specified or, having appeared, fails to satisfy the magistrate as to his right to remain in the Transvaal, the magistrate shall order such Asiatic to leave the Transvaal if he is above 16 years of age, and sections 6, 7 and 8 of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, 1903 shall apply to such order.
('7', 382, 1, 15, 868649) 6. Any Asiatic who is the guardian of a child under eight shall upon making application for registration on his own behalf supply to the Registrar such particulars and furnish such means

('7', 383, 1, 2, 868878) of identification in respect of the child as may be prescribed by regulation.
('7', 383, 1, 3, 868956) If the applicant is himself registered, such particulars shall be noted on the register.
('7', 383, 1, 4, 869045) Within one year of the child attaining the age of eight, the guardian concerned shall make application for registration on behalf of the child at the office of the Resident Magistrate of the district in which he resides.
('7', 383, 1, 5, 869266) An Asiatic who is the guardian of a child born in the Transvaal shall apply for registration on behalf of the child within one year of the child reaching the age of eight.
('7', 383, 1, 6, 869438) (a) If the guardian does not apply as required above, he shall if required by the Registrar or the Resident Magistrate make such application at any later date.
('7', 383, 1, 7, 869598) (b) If the guardian does not apply, or if the application made by the guardian is rejected, the application for registration shall be made by the child within one month after reaching the age of sixteen.
('7', 383, 1, 8, 869802) The Resident Magistrate at whose office such application is made shall cause the application along with the relevant documents to be forwarded to the Registrar who shall if satisfied that the same is in order issue a certificate of registration.

('7', 383, 2, 10, 870443) 8. Any person who shall fail to make application for registration as required by this Act shall be liable to a fine not exceeding £100 and in default of payment to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding three months.
('7', 383, 2, 11, 870689) Any person who brings into the Transvaal an Asiatic under the age of sixteen years not lawfully resident in the Transvaal, and any person who shall employ such child, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to penalties mentioned above and to cancellation of the certificate of registration, in addition to which he will be ordered to leave the Transvaal.
('7', 383, 2, 12, 871055) If he does not leave the Transvaal, he will be liable to a fine or to imprisonment as provided for in the law, sections 6, 7 and 3 of the Peace Preservation Ordinance being applicable to such order.

('7', 384, 1, 4, 871808) If the person fails to obtain registration within the appointed time, he shall again be ordered to leave the Transvaal, and if he fails to do so, he shall be liable to the usual penalties.
('7', 384, 1, 5, 871997) 9. ('7', 384, 1, 6, 872297) With regard to an Asiatic under the age of 16 years, the guardian of such child shall produce the certificate of registration and supply the particulars and furnish the means of identification required by this Act.
