('7', 384, 1, 9, 872956) If he fails to do so, he will be liable to a fine not exceeding £50 or to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a period not exceeding one month.
('7', 384, 1, 10, 873109) 12. Any person who loses his certificate of registration shall apply to the Registrar to have it renewed.
('7', 384, 1, 11, 873215) The application shall contain such particulars as may be required under the rules, and it must have a stamp of 5s affixed to it.
('7', 384, 1, 12, 873344) 13. After a date to be notified in the Gazette, no Asiatic shall obtain a trading licence under the Revenue Licences Ordinance or under any bye law in force in a municipality unless he shall produce his certificate of registration and supply such particulars and furnish such means of identification as may be prescribed by Regulation.

('7', 385, 1, 3, 873948) 15. Any affidavit that may have to be made under this Act shall be exempt from stamp duty.
('7', 385, 1, 4, 874039) 16. Any person, who commits any fraudulent act in connection with an application for registration or for the purpose of obtaining a certificate of registration or makes a false statement, or incites or aids any person in such act or statement, or forges any certificate of registration, or uses as his certificate any certificate of registration of which he is not the lawful holder or any forged certificate, or causes such certificate to be used by others, shall be liable to a fine not exceeding £500 or to imprisonment with or without hard labour for a term not exceeding two years.
('7', 385, 1, 5, 874626) 17. The Colonial Secretary may in his absolute discretion issue to any Asiatic a permit for a limited period only and after the expiry of such period such person shall be deemed to be a person not duly authorized to be in this Colony and if found may be arrested without warrant and the provisions of sections 7, 8 and 9 of the Peace Preservation Ordinance shall apply to such person who shall be liable to the penalties provided therein as if he were a person who had been ordered to leave the Colony under the said Ordinance.
('7', 385, 1, 6, 875154) Temporary permits issued before the date of the taking effect of this Act shall also be governed by this Act.
('7', 385, 1, 7, 875264) Any person who holds a temporary permit may be exempted from the restrictions on the use of liquor.
('7', 385, 1, 8, 875364) The Colonial Secretary may also grant such exemption to an Asiatic who is not subject to the provisions of this Act.
('7', 385, 1, 9, 875481) 18. ('7', 386, 1, 4, 876658) 20. The Labour Importation Ordinance relating to the Chinese shall not apply to Asiatics.

('7', 388, 3, 7, 880860) 287. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIGH COMMISSIONER
('7', 388, 4, 8, 880914) 21 24 COURT CHAMBERS, CORNER RISSIK & ANDERSON STREETS, P. O. BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, December 3, 1907 THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE HIGH COMMISSIONER JOHANNESBURG
('7', 388, 5, 9, 881092) SIR, Mr. David Pollock has just brought me a message from Mr. Hosken suggesting to me that I should approach His Excellency priv ately in connection with the serious situation that has arisen regarding the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, and to place before His Excellency what I consider would be acceptable to the Asiatic communities and would, at the same time, meet the main object of the Government.
('7', 388, 5, 10, 881492) I need hardly preface what I am about to say with the statement that, in the position I have felt called upon to take up in this matter, my desire has been to serve the Government equally with my countrymen.
('7', 388, 5, 11, 881700) It is because I consider myself to be a lover of the Empire for what I have learned to be its beauties that, seeing, rightly or wrongly, in the Asiatic Law Amendment Act seeds of danger to it, I have advised my countrymen at all costs to resist the Act in the most peaceful and, shall I add, Christian manner.
('7', 388, 5, 12, 882010) The object of the Government being to identify every Indian entitled to remain in and enter the Colony, in my humble opinion, it can be met by amending the Immigration Restriction Act, which still awaits the Royal sanction, and which, I trust, will not receive the Royal sanction in its present form.
('7', 388, 5, 13, 882311) In my humble opinion, the offer for voluntary registration will not, in view of the prospective repeal of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, be of much use, because any
('7', 388, 6, 14, 882479) 1 Here followed in the original the Regulations framed under the Act, vide “Obnoxious Law”, 6 7 1907 and Appendix IV.
('7', 389, 0, 1, 882597) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 389, 1, 2, 882639) registration certificates that might be taken out would be of no avail without the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 389, 1, 3, 882752) I, therefore, venture to suggest as follows: (a) to withdraw the notices in the Government Gazette regarding registration under the Act; (b) to amend the Immigration Restriction Act at the next session of Parliament so as to provide for the issue of certificates of domicile to those Indians who may be entitled to remain in orenter the Colony the Peace by Preservation Ordinance, and those who may hold £3 registration certificates under Law 3 of 1885, who can establish their claim to the certificates.
('7', 389, 1, 4, 883257) Certificates of domicile will take the place of registration certificates, and will contain full identification particulars.
('7', 389, 1, 5, 883382) This does not contemplate certificates for the minor children of domiciled Asiatics, but, in order to prevent any fraud, children, with their names and ages, will be described in certificates of domicile; so that, at the utmost, what may happen can never be an unlawful increase in the number of Asiatic children in the Colony, but, possibly, in the rarest cases, personation, which can be dealt with stringently under the Immigration Restriction Act.
('7', 389, 1, 6, 883834) The amendment does also not contemplate certificates of domicile for Asiatics who will be able to pass the education test, which, under the clause as it at present stands, is sufficiently heavy and, therefore, provides complete identification by itself.
('7', 389, 1, 7, 884088) The amendment will also repeal the Asiatic Act.
('7', 389, 1, 8, 884136) Seeing that fifteen months have passed by without any registration, perhaps three or four more would not matter; but, if the Government think otherwise, it is respectfully submitted that they may, after the withdrawal of the notices, issue registration certificates in place of the existing documents, if only in order to test the bona fides of the community.
('7', 389, 1, 9, 884496) These may, at the time of amending the Immigration Act, be recognised as certificates of domicile.
('7', 389, 2, 10, 884595) In my opinion, the chief reason for passing the Asiatic Act was the charge of surreptitious entry on a wholesale basis 1. I have always felt most strongly about it, as I have always known intimately the working of the Asiatic Department under successive officers.
('7', 389, 2, 11, 884859) The evidence that led Captain Hamilton Fowle to suppose that there was little surreptitious entry was the evidence that was used by Mr. Chamney to report unfavourably.
('7', 389, 2, 12, 885027) I still believe that Mr. Chamney is entirely incompetent for the office he holds, in having no legal ability
('7', 389, 3, 13, 885136) 1 These words are underlined in the original.
('7', 390, 0, 1, 885182) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 391
('7', 390, 1, 2, 885226) to sift evidence.
('7', 390, 1, 3, 885244) I have nothing against him personally.
('7', 390, 1, 4, 885283) He is affable and above suspicion, but these two qualities do not make up for the want of a further qualification which is indispensable to an office such as he holds.
('7', 390, 1, 5, 885451) I, therefore, as an alternative to the exchange of existing certificates, venture to suggest the appointment of a judge of the Supreme Court, the Chief Magistrate for the Witwatersrand District, or some such high official with legal knowledge to investigate the charge of surreptitious entry.
('7', 390, 1, 6, 885744) He will be able to report upon anything that the Asiatic Officers may have to place before him; and, if the inquiry made is open to the public, and witnesses are publicly examined, it will allay the anxiety of the people of the Transvaal, and any report that might be made could not bequestioned by any people and would, perhaps, pave the way for the amendment suggested in this letter.
('7', 390, 2, 7, 886131) I purposely refrain from examining the methods of identification and considering the question of finger prints, which is only a secondary matter.
('7', 390, 2, 8, 886277) If the idea of repealing the Asiatic Act and seeking the co operation of the Indian community be entertained, other difficulties can, I have no doubt, be overcome.
('7', 390, 3, 9, 886441) If required, I shall be prepared to submit in legal phraseology amendments to the Immigration Restriction Act that would, in my humble opinion, completely fulfil the object of the Asiatic Act so far as identification is concerned, without in any way wounding the susceptibilities of British Indians.
('7', 390, 4, 10, 886741) I have the honour to be,
('7', 390, 6, 11, 886766) Your obedient servant,
('7', 390, 7, 12, 886789) M. K. GANDHI

('7', 393, 4, 7, 891671) 291. RITCH’S SERVICES
('7', 393, 5, 8, 891693) Not all Indians, perhaps, have a full idea of the tireless pains taken by Mr. Ritch in England for their benefit.
('7', 393, 5, 9, 891807) Recently, he has placed the Indians under a further obligation by publishing a brief pamphlet 1 which gives a vivid account of the hardships of Indians in the Transvaal.
('7', 393, 5, 10, 891977) Every Indian knows that Mr. Ritch’s services are invaluable.
('7', 393, 5, 11, 892038) He has compressed the whole account into a pamphlet of twenty three pages(octavo size); it is a succinct statement, covering the whole ground and giving the history as from 1885. It is not only through the efforts of Mr. Ritch that we stand to gain; his position also counts.
('7', 393, 5, 12, 892314) That is to say, a veteran white colonist of eighteen years standing like Mr. Ritch taking up the struggle on behalf of the rights of Indians can have a more powerful effect on the white people.
('7', 393, 5, 13, 892508) It is for this reason that he has referred to this fact in the preface to his pamphlet.
('7', 393, 5, 14, 892596) The vast amount of information which he has compressed into such a small pamphlet shows the anxious labour bestowed on his work by Mr. Ritch.
('7', 393, 5, 15, 892738) Mr. Ritch has done the right thing in recalling the promises given to the Indian community by Lord Milner in the year 1903. Lord Milner had said then:
('7', 393, 6, 16, 892889) Once on the register, their position is established and no further registration is necessary, nor is a fresh permit required.
('7', 393, 6, 17, 893015) That registration gives you a right to be here, and a right to come and go.
('7', 393, 7, 18, 893091) Mr. Ritch has compared compulsory and voluntary registration in order to point out the difference between the two.
('7', 393, 7, 19, 893206) Voluntary regist 
('7', 393, 8, 20, 893224) 1 Vide “British Indians and the Transvall”, 7 11 1907. 2 Vide “The British Indian Association and Lord Milner”, 11 6 1903.
('7', 394, 0, 1, 893347) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 395
('7', 394, 1, 2, 893391) ration would be devoid of the sting of compulsion, and would consti tute an act of grace performed by the Asiatic community in deference to white sentiment.
('7', 394, 1, 3, 893548) If registration is made compulsory, there will be no difference between Indians and Kaffirs, and the neighbouring Colony will be tempted to adopt it as a precedent.
('7', 394, 1, 4, 893713) It may also turn out to be a prelude to compulsory segregation in Coloured Locations.
('7', 394, 1, 5, 893799) Mr. Ritch has not endeavoured to argue the question, but has relied upon facts, which he has marshalled so as to lead the reader to the irresistible conclusion that the Indian case is just.
('7', 394, 1, 6, 893989) As has been pointed out by Mr. Ritch at the end of the pamphlet, the inconsistency between prewar promises and post war performance exposes the Government’s perfidy.
('7', 394, 1, 7, 894155) In Mr. Ritch’s own words: 1
('7', 394, 2, 8, 894183) Apart from the duty, of the Transvaal Government to protect the interests of a wholly unrepresented minority, there is the obligation of the Transvaal to subordinate merely local interests to the welfare of the Empire at large.
('7', 394, 2, 9, 894411) Let the whites only consider to what extent the authority and prestige of the Imperial Government have been endangered by their heaping of indignity upon indignity upon representatives of the three hundred millions of Indians for the sake of a quarter of a million whites.
('7', 394, 2, 10, 894684) Mr. Ritch’s pamphlet will enable the whites in England and else where to consider the Indian point of view on the Transvaal question.
('7', 394, 2, 11, 894818) That will be a very important gain for the Indian community.
('7', 394, 2, 12, 894879) We are thus putting up a strong fight, and it seems that even negotiations for a compromise have started; in view of this, it should hardly be necessary for us to add that we expect every Indian to remain firm and, guarding himself against any trap that the Govern ment may lay, boldly to hold himself ready for imprisonment.
('7', 394, 2, 13, 895205) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 7 12 1907

('7', 395, 3, 7, 896257) 293. RAM SUNDAR PUNDIT
('7', 395, 4, 8, 896280) We have received letters asking some questions about Punditji.
('7', 395, 4, 9, 896343) We do not intend to publish them, for the people who wrote them have been altogether misinformed.
('7', 395, 4, 10, 896441) One of the questions raised in the letters will be answered here.
('7', 395, 4, 11, 896507) Someone wants to know how the community can gain anything by Punditji’s staying on here after the expiry of his temporary permit and being imprisoned for that.
('7', 395, 4, 12, 896667) It is quite wrong to raise such a doubt.
('7', 395, 4, 13, 896708) All persons holding temporary permits are not in a position to fight as Punditji did.
('7', 395, 4, 14, 896794) Such persons are bound to leave the Transvaal on the expiry of the period but those working as priests are in a position to stay on even if an extension is not granted to them.
('7', 395, 4, 15, 896971) That is the reason why he stayed on, as desired by the community.
('7', 395, 4, 16, 897037) The [Indian] residents of Germiston had written [to the authorities] on this subject.
('7', 395, 4, 17, 897123) And in the trial which took place, he was charged under section 17 of the new Act.
('7', 395, 4, 18, 897206) We are convinced that the case against him has done much good to the community.
('7', 395, 4, 19, 897286) Everyone feels bolder as a result of Punditji’s going to gaol.
('7', 395, 4, 20, 897349) At a time like this, nothing but good can be done by any Indian going to gaol in the course of the struggle against the law.
('7', 395, 4, 21, 897474) For, this is our first experience.
('7', 395, 4, 22, 897509) The imprisonment of a man like Punditji is bound to have a very powerful effect; in fact, there has been such an effect.
('7', 395, 4, 23, 897630) It is because of that effect that Shahji Saheb and others did their utmost to follow him to gaol, and that a meeting was held in Germiston attended by hundreds of Indians, where Punditji was complimented on his courage.
('7', 395, 4, 24, 897850) Everyone can talk, but, so far, only Punditji has shown himself capable of action.
('7', 395, 4, 25, 897933) It is enough for us that he has sacrificed himself for the benefit of the community, and is prepared to make still further sacrifices after coming out of gaol.

('7', 396, 1, 2, 898179) 294. VOLUNTEERS FOR NATAL
('7', 396, 2, 3, 898205) There is again a rebellion of Kaffirs in Zululand.
('7', 396, 2, 4, 898256) In view of this, hundreds of white troops have been dispatched.
('7', 396, 2, 5, 898320) The Indian commu nity must come forward at such a time without, however, thinking of securing any rights thereby.
('7', 396, 2, 6, 898434) They must consider only the duty of the community.
('7', 396, 2, 7, 898485) It is a common observation that when we attend to our duty, rights follow as a matter of course.
('7', 396, 2, 8, 898582) It will be only proper for the Indian community to make the offer that was made last year.
('7', 396, 2, 9, 898673) 1 There is a move at present to levy a tax on those who do not enlist.
('7', 396, 2, 10, 898744) The burden of this levy will fall on Indians alone; even though paying the tax, they will get no credit.
('7', 396, 2, 11, 898849) We are, therefore, convinced in our minds that the Indian community should repeat its offer.
('7', 396, 2, 12, 898942) We assume that there are many Indians now who will welcome such work enthusiastically.
('7', 396, 2, 13, 899029) Those who went to the front last year can do so again.
('7', 396, 2, 14, 899084) Most of them are seasoned people and familiar with the nature of the work.
('7', 396, 2, 15, 899159) We very much hope that this work will be taken in hand without any delay.

('7', 396, 3, 17, 899275) 295. JOHANNESBURG LETTER
('7', 396, 4, 18, 899300) HUGE MASS MEETING
('7', 396, 5, 19, 899318) There is no end to mass meetings of Indians.
('7', 396, 5, 20, 899363) And each such meeting is better than the preceding one.
('7', 396, 5, 21, 899419) The last meeting held in Pretoria was much larger than the one held earlier.
('7', 396, 5, 22, 899496) The meeting held on Sunday last at Johannesburg 2 surpassed even the one at Pretoria, so impressive were the spirit of the people and the size of the crowd.
('7', 396, 5, 23, 899653) Nowadays people attend the meetings on their own and everyone is filled with enthusiasm.
('7', 396, 5, 24, 899742) Everywhere there is evidence of a burning desire for patriotic service at any cost.
('7', 396, 6, 25, 899826) MORE THAN TWO THOUSAND
('7', 396, 7, 26, 899849) This meeting was attended by more than 2,000 people.
('7', 396, 7, 27, 899902) There were delegates from many places.
('7', 396, 7, 28, 899941) There were nearly 40 from Pretoria, 16 from Potchefstroom, and so on from every place.
('7', 396, 8, 29, 900028) 1 Vide “Speech at Congress Meeting”, 24 4 1906,to “Interview to The Natal Mercury”, 26 4 1906. 2 The meeting was held in Fordsburg, a suburb of Johannesburg.

('7', 397, 1, 2, 900228) MEETING IN SURATI MOSQUE
('7', 397, 2, 3, 900253) The meeting was held in the compound of the Surati mosque.
('7', 397, 2, 4, 900312) There were men sitting everywhere, on the verandah of the mosque, its terrace and roof.
('7', 397, 2, 5, 900400) Originally, it was intended to hold the meeting in Mr. Essop Mia’s new house.
('7', 397, 2, 6, 900478) But quite a large number of men had collected there even before the meeting commenced, and since it was impossible to accommodate all of them in that building, it was decided on the spot to hold the meeting in the open.
('7', 397, 3, 7, 900698) ESSOP MIA Mr. Essop Mia took the chair, though, in view of the situation obtaining then, he and most others from Johannesburg kept standing all the time.
('7', 397, 3, 8, 900852) He welcomed the delegates who had assembled, and thanked the pickets for their work.
('7', 397, 4, 9, 900937) SUBSTANCE OF OTHER SPEECHES Mr. Gandhi explained what was likely to happen in December, and referred to the growing feeling of sympathy on the part of the whites.
('7', 397, 4, 10, 901100) This was the time for Indians to win their freedom and they were not, therefore, to keep on looking to the leaders all the time.
('7', 397, 4, 11, 901229) Everyone was to look upon himself as a leader and boldly face imprisonment or any other hardship that might be inflicted on him.
('7', 397, 4, 12, 901358) Our petition no longer lay with an earthly ruler; it was to be addressed to the Creator.
('7', 397, 4, 13, 901447) Mr. Emam Abdool Cadir showed that those who had faith in God had no cause for fear.
('7', 397, 4, 14, 901531) He was a picket, and he would be glad if the Government laid hands on him first.
('7', 397, 4, 15, 901612) Mr. Manibhai Desai (from Pretoria) said that if the Government came down on the pickets first, he would be very happy to bear the brunt of the attack.
('7', 397, 4, 16, 901763) One Kanmia picket, whose name I do not know, said that he would not be in the least afraid.
('7', 397, 4, 17, 901855) Mr. Abdool Gani said that in this struggle God was on their side, since their cause was just.
('7', 397, 4, 18, 901949) They were not in the least afraid of going to gaol.
('7', 397, 4, 19, 902001) Mr. Naidoo spoke in Tamil and explained the position.
('7', 397, 4, 20, 902055) Mr. Shahji Saheb, after referring to what Hazrat Imam Hussein had suffered, said that what had happened to Ram Sundar Pundit might also happen to a Muslim priest.
('7', 397, 4, 21, 902218) Unable to bear this thought, he had forced himself to be prepared to follow the Pundit to gaol.
('7', 397, 4, 22, 902314) Mr. Omarji Sale said that he would have no fear of gaol.
('7', 397, 4, 23, 902371) Mr. Coovadia said that it would not matter if the Government

('7', 398, 1, 2, 902476) attacked businessmen and forced them to close down the shops.
('7', 398, 1, 3, 902538) That would bring our freedom very near.
('7', 398, 1, 4, 902578) Mr. Khurshedji Desai (from Krugersdorp) described the difficulties of the Kaffirs in obtaining the passes which they were required to carry.
('7', 398, 1, 5, 902719) Mr. Abdul Rahman (from Potchefstroom) said that Potchefstroom was quite strong and that all people there were prepared to go to gaol.
('7', 398, 1, 6, 902853) Mr. Osman Latief (from Potchefstroom) said that he was prepared to go to gaol, leaving his wife and children behind.
('7', 398, 1, 7, 902970) Mr. Quinn (President of the Chinese Association) spoke in English and said that this was a struggle to secure the freedom of Asiatics.
('7', 398, 1, 8, 903105) All the Chinese were ready to fight unto death.
('7', 398, 1, 9, 903153) Mr. Ebrahim Aswat said that if the Indian community yielded now and took out registers through fear, it would be called to account before God by the Chinaman who had committed suicide, for it was the Indians who had exhorted the Chinese to fight.
('7', 398, 1, 10, 903400) Mr. Nawab Khan said that it was the duty of every Indian to fight to the last for the benefit of the community and for the sake of religion.

('7', 398, 1, 12, 903660) Mr. Polak said that it was only now that the time of real test had drawn near.

('7', 398, 1, 14, 903841) In reply to some questions, Mr. Gandhi said that if, after being arrested, anyone was required in gaol to give digit impressions, he should give them.
('7', 398, 1, 15, 903992) This was a struggle for freedom from slavery, not against digit impressions.

('7', 398, 1, 18, 904162) If, however, anyone asked them in gaol to get themselves registered, that must not be done.

('7', 399, 2, 7, 905193) MESSAGE FROM RAM SUNDAR PUNDIT On Monday, Mr. Gandhi had an interview with Ram Sundar Pundit, having obtained special permission for it.
('7', 399, 2, 8, 905330) Since the Governor had ordered that they should talk in English, the whole interview took place in English in the presence of the Chief Warder.
('7', 399, 2, 9, 905474) Punditji spoke of many things, of which I reproduce here only the essential part: Please tell everyone that I am happy here.
('7', 399, 2, 10, 905599) It would have been better if the Government had awarded me hard labour.
('7', 399, 2, 11, 905671) After my release, I shall be prepared to go to gaol again for the sake of the community.
('7', 399, 2, 12, 905760) While here, I have read all the poems on gaol going.
('7', 399, 2, 13, 905813) I have been deeply moved by them, especially by the poems of Mr. Mehtab.
('7', 399, 2, 14, 905886) When I come out, I hope to see a copy of these poems in the hands of every Indian in Germiston.
('7', 399, 2, 15, 905982) How is it that other Indians have not been arrested, though it is already December?
('7', 399, 2, 16, 906066) We shall gain freedom only when that happens.
('7', 399, 2, 17, 906112) Please tell everyone that there is no hardship in gaol.
('7', 399, 2, 18, 906168) I see even women here.
('7', 399, 2, 19, 906191) No one should feel anxious on my account.
('7', 399, 2, 20, 906233) I feel as if I am in a palace.
('7', 399, 2, 21, 906264) I only wish that no Indian submits to the law.
('7', 399, 2, 22, 906311) The Governor and the Chief Warder look after me very well.
('7', 399, 2, 23, 906370) I have felt much hesitation in reproducing what Punditji said about the poems on gaol going.
('7', 399, 2, 24, 906463) But I have given the message as a matter of duty because he was very particular about it.
('7', 399, 2, 25, 906553) No one, however, should imagine that any monetary interest of those working with Indian Opinion is involved in this.
('7', 399, 2, 26, 906670) The paper is brought out with great difficulty, and even now those who are working on it do not make any profit worth the name.

('7', 400, 0, 1, 907121) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 401
('7', 400, 1, 2, 907165) BLACKLEGS IN NOVEMBER Daring the month of November, pickets worked at Pretoria as well as they had done at Johannesburg.
('7', 400, 1, 3, 907286) Thanks to their alertness, very few Indians got themselves registered, and not a single one, it can be claimed, from Pretoria itself.
('7', 400, 1, 4, 907420) But there were a few here and there in the Colony.
('7', 400, 1, 5, 907471) Heidelberg gave the lead.
('7', 400, 1, 6, 907497) Mr. Ratilal, who is counted among the educated people, was the first.
('7', 400, 1, 7, 907567) He was followed by some of Mr. Abu Mian Camroodeen’s men, and last came Mr. Khota’s men.
('7', 400, 1, 8, 907656) Everyone felt sorry that Mr. Khota’s men had applied.
('7', 400, 1, 9, 907710) The Surati community feels humiliated by the action of these men.
('7', 400, 1, 10, 907776) The Gujarati Hindus are very much upset on account of Mr. Ratilal’s application.
('7', 400, 1, 11, 907857) It was observed that the Gujarati Hindus had so far remained clean.
('7', 400, 1, 12, 907925) Mr. Ratilal has disproved the general belief that, apart from Mr. Lakshmi Chand, no one else would apply.
('7', 400, 1, 13, 908031) As regards the servants of Mr. Khota, he writes to say that it was not their fault.
('7', 400, 1, 14, 908115) It was because of his pressure on them that they went.
('7', 400, 1, 15, 908170) They were quite disinclined to go, but went because of his pressure.
('7', 400, 1, 16, 908239) Mr. Khota is now sorry and feels ashamed.
('7', 400, 1, 17, 908281) He adds that he was very much afraid, for he owned four shops.
('7', 400, 1, 18, 908344) As for himself, he would not now apply under any circumstances, but would rather go to gaol.
('7', 400, 1, 19, 908437) Since Mr. Khota does not defend his conduct, there is no more comment to be made.
('7', 400, 1, 20, 908519) But it should be a matter of regret to everyone that he was overcome by fear.
('7', 400, 1, 21, 908597) It would have been a fine thing if he had not faltered.
('7', 400, 1, 22, 908653) I very much hope that no one will follow Mr. Khota’s example.
('7', 400, 1, 23, 908715) Other blacklegs include some poor men from Madras and Calcutta.
('7', 400, 1, 24, 908779) No weight is to be attached to them because they are quite unknown here and have been living almost as slaves.
('7', 400, 1, 25, 908890) The argument that some leaders wanted registration to continue in November is thus proved to be baseless.
('7', 400, 2, 26, 908996) “THE SUNDAY TIMES”
('7', 400, 3, 27, 909015) The Sunday Times has remarked that, if the former permit officers had not proved corrupt, there could have been no need for the new law.
('7', 400, 3, 28, 909152) It is thus proved that the Government is punishing the Indian community for the fault of its own officers.
('7', 400, 4, 29, 909259) OTHER NEWSPAPERS

('7', 400, 5, 31, 909332) No ne of them considers it likely that the Government could send anybo dy to gaol.
('7', 400, 5, 32, 909415) The Star even goes to the extent of saying that there sho uld be no need to send anyone to gaol.

('7', 401, 1, 2, 909721) produced before a magistrate, the latter, instead of sending the Indian to gaol, should merely give him further time to apply for a register.
('7', 401, 2, 3, 909863) BE ON GUARD The statement in The Star appears to be inspired by the Government and hence every Indian should be on his guard.
('7', 401, 2, 4, 909989) If any Indian produced before a magistrate proves to be a coward, the result will be anything but good.
('7', 401, 2, 5, 910093) The magistrate, instead of giving notice to such an Indian to leave the country, will only advise him to apply for a register.
('7', 401, 2, 6, 910220) If the Government thus wants to lay a trap, it is necessary for the Indians to be watchful.
('7', 401, 2, 7, 910312) A plain refusal will solve all difficulties.
('7', 401, 2, 8, 910357) Everyone should utter only an emphatic ‘no’ in reply.
('7', 401, 2, 9, 910411) There is no limit now to the weakness of the Government.

('7', 401, 2, 12, 910565) What has happened to his talk of deportation?
('7', 401, 2, 13, 910611) Though the Government is betraying so much weakness, there are Indians who continue to harbour fear in their hearts.

('7', 402, 2, 9, 912535) KONKANI PASSIVE RESISTER A Konkani named Mahomed Essak holds an old register and permit.

('7', 404, 0, 1, 916191) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 405
('7', 404, 1, 2, 916235) 296. TRIAL OF INDIANS 1
('7', 404, 2, 3, 916259) [VOLKSRUST, December 9, 1907]
('7', 404, 3, 4, 916289) In cross examination, the witness admitted that the permits produced by the men had hitherto been accepted under instructions as sufficient authority for Asiatics to enter or re enter.
('7', 404, 3, 5, 916474) The witness did not know whether re entry was in accordance withthe permits or the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 404, 3, 6, 916587) He allowed Asiatics to re enter, such being his instructions.
('7', 404, 3, 7, 916649) [GANDHIJI:] What are your instructions now?
('7', 404, 3, 8, 916693) [WITNESS:] My instructions are to detain and arrest all male Asiatics above 16 years who could not produce registration certificates under the Asiatic Act, or who did not produce temporary authorisation allowing them to re enter the Colony.
('7', 404, 3, 9, 916934) Do these instructions apply even to Asiatics whom you may know to be old residents, who may have produced permits, and who may have only recently left the Colony?
('7', 404, 3, 10, 917097) Yes, because such is my duty under the instructions.
('7', 404, 3, 11, 917150) I am to detain all Asiatics without distinction, if they cannot produce authority under the new Act.
('7', 404, 3, 12, 917251) In answer to farther questions, Sergeant Mansfield produced the permits and registration certificates and said that they were taken out under Law 3 of 1885. This closed the case for the Crown.
('7', 404, 3, 13, 917444) Mr. Gandhi urged that Crown witness had proved his clients’ case.
('7', 404, 3, 14, 917510) The question before the Court was purely one as to whether his clients possessed permits issued under the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 404, 3, 15, 917646) These permits were produced by Sergeant Mansfield who admitted that they were in order.
('7', 404, 4, 16, 917734) MR. DE VILLIERS: Then you argue that the matter is purely one of argument of law?
('7', 404, 5, 17, 917816) MR. GANDHI: Precisely, Your Worship.
('7', 404, 5, 18, 917853) Mr. Mentz then argued that the permits held by the men were authority only to enter and reside in the Colony, but not to leave it and re enter.
('7', 404, 5, 19, 917997) It was contended that once the men left the Colony, the permits stood cancelled.
('7', 404, 5, 20, 918078) Mr. Gandhi, in reply, said that the question was not even that of re entry.
('7', 404, 5, 21, 918154) The Court had to keep within the four corners of the indictment, which charged his clients
('7', 404, 6, 22, 918245) 1 On December 6, twenty Indians and, during the next two days, another 17 Indians were arrested on arrival at Volksrust.
('7', 404, 6, 23, 918366) They were tried in the court of the Assistant Resident Magistrate, Mr. De Villiers.
('7', 404, 6, 24, 918450) The case of the 20 Indians was taken up first.
('7', 404, 6, 25, 918497) Examined by the Public Prosecutor, Mr. Mentz, Sergeant Mansfield deposed that all the accused held permits and registration certificates under the Peace Preservation Ordinance, their thumb impressions were in order and their permits authorized them to enter, but not to re enter, the Colony.
('7', 404, 6, 26, 918789) The accused had told him that they did not wish to submit to the Asiatic Act.
('7', 404, 6, 27, 918867) Gandhiji cross examined him.
('7', 405, 0, 1, 918896) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 405, 1, 2, 918938) with having entered the Colony without permits under Section 5 of the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 405, 1, 3, 919038) The evidence before the Court conclusively proved that his clients were actually in possession of their permits on entering.
('7', 405, 1, 4, 919163) They had all, moreover, paid £3 under Law 3 of 1885. Nor could the Public Prosecutor’s contention be justified.
('7', 405, 1, 5, 919275) The Supreme Court had decided in the case of Bhabha vs.
('7', 405, 1, 6, 919331) Rex that a permit to enter the Colony included permission to leave it and to re enter.
('7', 405, 1, 7, 919418) These were almost the exact words used by Justice Bristowe in that case.
('7', 405, 1, 8, 919491) Whichever way, therefore, the case was looked at, his clients were entitled to a discharge.
('7', 405, 1, 9, 919583) The Court had nothing to do with instructions from the Law Department or the construction that it might have placed upon Section 5 of the Peace Preservation Ordinance.
('7', 405, 1, 10, 919751) The proper course would certainly, in his opinion, have been for the Asiatic Office, if his clients had committed a breach of the new Act, to have charged them under it.
('7', 405, 2, 11, 919921) Indian Opinion, 14 12 1907
('7', 405, 3, 12, 919948) 297. LETTER TO “INDIAN OPINION”
('7', 405, 4, 13, 919980) JOHANNESBURG, December 12, 1907
('7', 405, 6, 14, 920012) THE EDITOR INDIAN OPINION
('7', 405, 7, 15, 920038) SIR, Perhaps you will allow me the hospitality of your columns to draw the attention of the public to the lesson of the thirty eight prosecutions 2 of British Indians, seemingly under the Peace Preservation Ordinance but really under the Asiatic Registration Act.
('7', 405, 7, 16, 920302) The lesson is that the proceedings of the Asiatic Office are all secret.
('7', 405, 7, 17, 920375) It required the arrest of Punia to learn that illegal instructions were given to arrest Indian women though they may be wives accompanying their husbands duly authorised to enter the Colony, unless the women themselves held permits.
('7', 405, 7, 18, 920608) It required the prosecution of a lad of twelve to learn that secret and illegal instructions were issued that innocent children should hold separate permits.
('7', 405, 7, 19, 920766) It required the incarceration of Ram Sundar Pundit 3 to learn that
('7', 405, 8, 20, 920833) 1 The Court upheld Gandhiji’s contention and discharged the accused.
('7', 405, 8, 21, 920902) The other 17 men were then brought before the Court, but the charge against them was withdrawn.
('7', 405, 8, 22, 920998) 2 Vide “Trial of Mahomed Essak”, 6 12 1907 and the preceding item.
('7', 405, 8, 23, 921065) 3 Vide “Letter to Indian Opinion”, 15 11 1907.
('7', 406, 0, 1, 921112) VOL. 7: 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 407
('7', 406, 1, 2, 921156) the Asiatic Office was not governed by ordinary and known rules for investigation into charges against Asiatics.
('7', 406, 1, 3, 921269) Lastly, it required the arrest of thirty eight Indians and their detention from two to four days to learn that the Asiatic Office had suddenly, after five years’ practice to the contrary, discovered that permits issued under the Peace Preservation Ordinance did not cover temporary withdrawal from and return to the Colony.
('7', 406, 1, 4, 921593) Instructions as to the new reading of the law were given secretly and without the Indians having been previously informed.
('7', 406, 1, 5, 921716) The public do not know that these self same men were actually examined by the Transvaal Asiatic Officer posted at Durban and passed by him.
('7', 406, 1, 6, 921856) Thirty six of these men were return passengers by the Sultan.
('7', 406, 1, 7, 921918) The Asiatic Office took, I am told, three days to examine these men.
('7', 406, 2, 8, 921987) And yet Mr. Lindsay, who as a lawyer ought to know better, glibly talks of surreptitious entry without, I dare say, having taken the trouble of ever even thinking that there might possibly be an Indian side to the story.
('7', 406, 2, 9, 922208) Passive resisters depend upon creating public opinion, though they are not turned from their conscientious purpose if they cannot create it in their favour.
('7', 406, 2, 10, 922365) It will not be denied that their suffering has at last made some public men in this Colony think.
('7', 406, 2, 11, 922463) May I ask them and others who still continue to disregard the Indian standpoint whether it is not the sacred duty of Indians to refuse to submit to an Act which concentrates arbitrary powers in the hands of a single man who carries on inquiries in secrecy, issues instructions under secrecy, and condemns men without hearing them?
('7', 406, 2, 12, 922794) Even Dinuzulu 1, who is suspected of rebellious designs, is not condemned on suspicion and without getting a hearing, although Colonel McKenzie 2 has received absolute powers under the proclamation of Martial Law in Zululand.
('7', 406, 2, 13, 923020) Why should Indians be expected to labour uncomplainingly under the foul charge of organised fraudulent entry and to submit to non jud icial investigation under the Asiatic Act of their title to remain in the country?
('7', 406, 2, 14, 923237) If their repudiation of the charge were hollow, would they not rather that the whole matter were hushed up than that, as they have repeatedly asked, it should be inquired into openly and judiciously?
('7', 406, 2, 15, 923437) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI
('7', 406, 3, 16, 923462) Indian Opinion, 21 12 1907
('7', 406, 4, 17, 923489) 1 Zulu Chief, who was tried for alleged complicity in the poll tax rebellion 2 A missionary, who was appointed Commissioner of Bechuanaland in 1884
('7', 407, 0, 1, 923637) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 407, 1, 2, 923679) APPENDICES
('7', 407, 2, 3, 923690) APPENDIX I
('7', 407, 3, 4, 923701) PETITION TO CHINESE AMBASSADOR
('7', 407, 4, 5, 923732) JOHANNESBURG, October 14, 1907
('7', 407, 6, 6, 923763) HIS EXCELLENCY THE ENVOY EXTRAORDINARY
('7', 407, 7, 7, 923802) AND MINISTER PLENIPOTENTIARY OF
('7', 407, 8, 8, 923834) HIS IMPERIAL MAJESTY THE EMPEROR OF CHINA
('7', 407, 10, 9, 923876) THE PETITION OF LEUNG QUINN IN HIS CAPACITY AS CHAIRMAN OF THE CHINESE ASSOCIATION OF THEIR TRANSVAAL
('7', 407, 11, 10, 923978) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT:
('7', 407, 12, 11, 923999) 1. Your Petitioner is the Chairman of the Chinese Association established in Johannesburg four years ago to represent the free Chinese population of the Transvaal.
('7', 407, 12, 12, 924163) 2. The free Chinese population is at present estimated at over 1,100, the majority of whom are settled in Johannesburg.
('7', 407, 12, 13, 924283) 3. The majority of the Chinese in the Transvaal are storekeepers of good standing and are all old residents of the Colony.
('7', 407, 12, 14, 924406) 4. Your Petitioner invites Your Excellency's attention to the Asiatic Law Amendment Act passed by the Transvaal Legislature, copy whereof is hereto attached.
('7', 407, 13, 15, 924564) 5. The said measure was first passed during the latter part of last year, and it was so deeply resented by the Chinese community of the Transvaal that it was considered advisable to send a special representative to London to plead the cause of the Chinese before Your Excellency's predecessor, so that proper representations might be made to the British Government, and your Petitioner is glad to be able to say that, as a result of the efforts made by Your Excellency's predecessor, the measure was suspended by His Majesty's Government.
('7', 407, 14, 16, 925103) 6. It was then re passed unanimously with very great haste by the newly elected Transvaal Parliament.
('7', 407, 14, 17, 925205) 7. In the humble opinion of the Chinese Association, the measure fails totally to recognise our ancient civilisation and the fact of our being an independent sovereign nation.
('7', 407, 14, 18, 925381) 8. It places Chinese subjects on the same level as British subjects coming from India.
('7', 407, 14, 19, 925468) While it may be proper for the British Government to treat its Indian
('7', 408, 0, 1, 925538) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 409
('7', 408, 1, 2, 925583) subjects as it pleases, your Petitioner respectfully submits that subjects of the Chinese Empire should not be treated in a manner derogatory to the dignity of the Empire to which Your Excellency's Petitioner has the honour to belong, especially in view of the fact that China is a State in alliance with Great Britain and that the subjects of Great Britain receive the most favoured nation treatment in China.
('7', 408, 2, 3, 925994) 9. The Asiatic Act requires, under insulting and heavy penalties, every Chinaman, among others, resident in the Transvaal to take out a new registration certificate in place of the documents already held by him.
('7', 408, 2, 4, 926206) It subjects [the] Chinese to a system of inspection which is utterly degrading.
('7', 408, 2, 5, 926286) It requires even children under 16 to be registered by their parents in a most humiliating manner.
('7', 408, 2, 6, 926385) It requires adult male Chinese and their children to give 18 finger prints, a requirement which is insisted upon only in connection with habitual criminals.
('7', 408, 2, 7, 926542) The legislation proceeds upon the assumption, totally denied by the Chinese Association, that many of the Chinese are capable of fraudulent representations.
('7', 408, 2, 8, 926699) It reduces [the] Chinese to a level lower than that of the natives of South Africa and other coloured people.
('7', 408, 2, 9, 926809) In short, it is such legislation as can be accepted only by slaves, not free men.
('7', 408, 2, 10, 926891) 10. The feeling of the Chinese community being as above described, it has decided not to submit to the Act and to suffer any consequences that may follow such breach of the law.
('7', 408, 2, 11, 927069) The community understands that total material ruin may follow passive resistance to the law and that every Chinaman may even be deported.
('7', 408, 2, 12, 927207) Over 900 members of the community have signed a solemn declaration not to accept the degrading Act.
('7', 408, 2, 13, 927307) 11. The Chinese Association recognises that immigration into the Transvaal should be regulated and that an effective check should be placed upon illicit entry into the Transvaal Colony and, in order to assist the Local Government in so doing, the Chinese Association has offered to submit to voluntary re registration as a test merely of the bona fides of the Chinese community, and not by way of admission that any such re registration is necessary.
('7', 408, 2, 14, 927758) It is the compulsion in a matter of this kind which your Petitioner’s Association resents.
('7', 408, 2, 15, 927849) 12. If the voluntary offer cannot be accepted and substantial relief cannot be granted, in the opinion of the Chinese Association, strong representations should be made to the British Government that every Chinaman should be sent back to China, subject to full compensation being paid to him for deprivation of vested rights as to trade, residence, etc.
('7', 408, 2, 16, 928203) 13. In conclusion, your Petitioner respectfully trusts that the rights of the Chinese subjects resident in the Transvaal will be fully protected by Your Excellency; and for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioner shall, as in duty bound, for ever pray, etc.
('7', 408, 2, 17, 928468) [I have, etc.,]
('7', 408, 3, 18, 928484) LEUNG QUINN CHAIRMAN, TRANSVAAL CHINESE ASSOCIATION
('7', 408, 4, 19, 928536) Indian Opinion, 26 10 1907
('7', 409, 0, 1, 928563) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 409, 1, 2, 928605) APPENDIX II
('7', 409, 2, 3, 928617) TRANSVAAL IMMIGRATION RESTRICTION BILL
('7', 409, 3, 4, 928656) The following is the text of a Bill, published in the.
('7', 409, 3, 5, 928711) Transvaal Government Gazette, “to place restrictions on immigration into this Colony, to provide for the removal therefrom of prohibited immigrants and other persons and to establish and maintain an Immigration Department”: Be it enacted by the King’s Most Excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Council and the Legislative Assembly of the Transvaal as follows: 1. The Peace Preservation Ordinance 1903 shall be and is hereby repealed; provided that no such repeal shall affect or abridge any powers or jurisdiction by the Asiatic Law Amendment Act 1907 conferred for the purpose of carrying out such Act.
('7', 409, 3, 6, 929350) 2. In this Act and in any regulation made thereunder unless inconsistent with the context: “department” shall mean the Immigration Department established and maintained under the provisions of this Act;
('7', 409, 4, 7, 929553) “Governor” shall mean the officer for the time being administering the government of this Colony acting by and with the advice of the Executive Council; “imprisonment” shall mean imprisonment with or without hard labour, as the court sentencing an offender to imprisonment may direct; “magistrate” shall include a resident magistrate and an assistant resident magistrate of any district of the Colony;
('7', 409, 5, 8, 929955) “Minister” shall mean the Colonial Secretary or such other Minister to whom the Governor may from time to time assign the carrying out of this Act; “minor” shall mean any person under the age of sixteen years; “police officer” shall mean any member of a police force lawfully established in this Colony;
('7', 409, 6, 9, 930259) “prohibited immigrant” shall mean and include any of the following classes of persons desiring to enter or entering this Colony after the date of the taking effect of this Act:
('7', 409, 7, 10, 930436) (1) any person who when asked whether within or outside this Colony by a duly authorized officer shall be unable through deficient education to write out and sign in the characters of an European language an application for permission to enter this Colony or such other documents as such officer may require; provided that for the purposes of this sub section, Yiddish shall be accepted as an European language; provided further that
('7', 409, 8, 11, 930870) (a) if the Minister publish a notice in the Gazette that arrangements have been made with the government of any country for regulating the admission to this Colony of the subjects or citizens of such
('7', 410, 0, 1, 931070) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 411
('7', 410, 1, 2, 931115) country, such subjects or citizens shall not while such notice is in force be required to comply with the provisions of this sub section; (b)the Minister shall not issue any such notice unless such arrangements have been sanctioned by resolution of both Houses of Parliament; (c) any such notice shall cease to have effect as it is cancelled by further notice of the Minister in the Gazette; (2) any person who has not in his possession or at his disposal means to support himself for a reasonable time within this Colony or who is likely to become a public charge if he were allowed to enter therein; (3) any prostitute or person living on the earnings of prostitution or procuring women for immoral purposes; (4) any person who under any law in force at the date of his entering or attempting to enter this Colony would be liable if found therein to be removed from or to be ordered to leave the Colony whether on conviction of an offence against such law or for failure to comply with its provisions or otherwise; provided that such conviction be not the result of the commission by such person elsewhere than in this Colony of an offence for which he has received a free pardon; (5) any person who is a lunatic within the meaning of the Lunacy proclamation 1902 or any amendment thereof; (6) any person who is a leper or is suffering from such infectious or contagious disease of a loathsome or dangerous character as may from time to time be prescribed by regulation; (7) any person who, owing to information officially received by the Minister from any Secretary of State or from a member of any colonial government (whether British or foreign) or through diplomatic channels from an officer of any foreign state, is deemed by the Minister to be an undesirable; (8) any person who the Minister has reasonable grounds for believing would be dangerous to the peace, order and good government of this Colony if he entered therein; but shall not include (a) members of His Majesty’s regular forces; (b) the officers and crew of any public ship of a foreign state; (c) any person who is duly accredited to this Colony by or under the authority of His Majesty or of the government of a foreign state together with his wife, family and servants; (d) any person who has served in any of His majesty’s volunteer forces in South Africa and has received a good discharge and who does not come within the scope of sub section (3), (4), (5), (6), (7) or (8) of the definition of prohibited immigrant; (e) the wife or minor child of any person who is not a prohibited immigrant;
('7', 411, 0, 1, 933686) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 411, 1, 2, 933728) (f) descendants of the aboriginal races of Africa south of the Equator who do not come within the scope of sub section (3), (4), (6), (7) or (8) of the definition of prohibited immigrant; (g) European persons who are agricultural or domestic servants, skilled artisans, mechanics, workmen or miners who are able to produce acertificate signed by the Agent General of this Colony in England or by an officer in England or elsewhere appointed for the purpose by the Governor to the effect that the person named therein has been engaged to serve immediately on arrival in this Colony an employer therein of repute at an adequate remuneration and for a reasonable period of time; “regulation” shall mean any regulation made under section fifteen of this Act.
('7', 411, 2, 3, 934483) 3. (1) The Governor may establish and maintain out of moneys voted by Parliament for the purpose a department to be known as the “Immigration Department”, which shall be under the control of the Minister and in charge of such officer as he may from time to time appoint.
('7', 411, 2, 4, 934754) (2) The function of the department shall be the performance of all work whether within or outside this Colony necessary for or incidental to the prevention of the entrance into the Colony of prohibited immigrants or their removal therefrom and the carrying out of any powers or duties that may be specially conferred or imposed on it by this Act or by regulation.
('7', 411, 2, 5, 935118) (3) The Governor may from time to time appoint and remove such officers as he may think necessary or expedient to assist in the administration of the department who shall have such powers and perform such duties within or outside this Colony as may be conferred upon them by this Act or by regulation.
('7', 411, 2, 6, 935420) 4. The Governor may from time to time enter into agreement with the government of any colony or territory in South Africa for the doing of such acts or things as are necessary or expedient for the carrying out of the objects and purposes of this Act.
('7', 411, 2, 7, 935671) 5. Every prohibited immigrant entering into or found within this Colony shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction
('7', 411, 3, 8, 935807) (1) to a fine not exceeding one hundred pounds or in default of payment to imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months or to both such fine and such imprisonment; and (2) to be removed at any time from the Colony by warrant under the hand of the Minister and pending such removal to be detained in such custody as may by regulation be prescribed; provided that (a) such prohibited immigrant may be discharged from such detention if he find two approved sureties in this Colony (each in the sum of
('7', 412, 0, 1, 936311) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 413
('7', 412, 1, 2, 936356) one hundred pounds) for his leaving the Colony within one month;
('7', 412, 2, 3, 936421) (b) if such prohibited immigrant be sentenced to imprisonment, such imprisonment shall terminate as soon as he is removed from the Colony.
('7', 412, 3, 4, 936560) (6) Any person convicted after the date of the taking effect of this Act of a contravention of section three, thirteen or twenty one of the Immorality Ordinance 1903 or any amendment of such sections and any person who may be deemed by the Minister on reasonable grounds to be dangerous to the peace, order and good government of this Colony if he remain therein may be arrested and removed from the Colony bywarrant under the hand of the Minister and pending removal may be detained in such custody as may be prescribed by regulation.
('7', 412, 3, 5, 937096) 7. Any person who (1) wilfully aids or abets a prohibited immigrant in entering or remaining in this Colony; or (2) wilfully aids or abets a person ordered to be removed under section six in remaining in this Colony; or (3) enters into or purports to enter into a contract as employer with any person outside this Colony with intent that the provisions of this Act be evaded or at the time of entering into or purporting to enter into such contract shall be unable to fulfil his part thereof or has no reasonable expectation of being so able shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding one hundred pounds or in default of payment to imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months or to both such fine and such imprisonment.
('7', 412, 3, 6, 937868) 8. No prohibited immigrant shall be entitled to obtain a licence to carry on in this Colony any trade or calling or to acquire therein any interest in land whether leasehold, freehold or other interest; and any such licence (if obtained) or any contract deed or other document by which such interest is acquired in contravention of this section shall on conviction of such immigrant under section five of this Act be null and void.
('7', 412, 3, 7, 938300) 9. Every person found in this Colony who is reasonably suspected of being a prohibited immigrant may be arrested without warrant by any magistrate, justice of the peace, police officer or officer of the department and shall as soon as possible be brought before a court of resident magistrate to be dealt with according to law.
('7', 412, 3, 8, 938628) 10. No prohibited immigrant shall be exempt from the provisions of this Act or allowed to remain in this Colony by reason only that he had not been informed that he could not enter the Colony or that he may have been allowed to enter through oversight or owing to the fact being undiscovered that he was a prohibited immigrant.
('7', 412, 3, 9, 938956) 11. Any person ordered to be removed from this Colony under this Act and any other person who shall have been convicted under section seven of aiding or abetting him in entering or remaining in the Colony in contravention of this Act shall be liable to pay all expenditure incurred by the Government in carrying out such
('7', 413, 0, 1, 939277) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 413, 1, 2, 939319) removal whether from the Colony or South Africa or in the detention within the Colony or elsewhere of any person pending his removal; and the amount of such expenditure on production to the Sheriff of the certificate of an officer of the department stating the items and total amount of such expenditure shall be recovered by execution levied on the property within the Colony of the person so liable in manner provided for execution levied under a judgment of the Supreme Court; and the proceeds of such execution shall be paid by the Sheriff to the Colonial Treasurer who after deduction of the amount of expenditure aforesaid and the costs of execution shall remit the balance to the person so liable or to any person appointed by him to receive the same.
('7', 413, 1, 3, 940078) 12. (1) It shall be the duty of every keeper or person having the management of a place used as an hotel, boarding house, lodging house or otherplace wherein persons receive sleeping accommodation for money or valuable consideration to cause to be kept a book in which every person immediately he first receives such accommodation shall enter his name, permanent residence, place of birth and place from which he last came.
('7', 413, 1, 4, 940502) (2) Every such book shall be open to the inspection of any police officer or officer of the department at all reasonable times.
('7', 413, 2, 5, 940630) (3) Any person failing to comply with the requirements of this section or obstructing or preventing any such officer in carrying out his powers thereunder or making any false entry in such book shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding twenty pounds or in default of payment to imprisonment not exceeding one month or to both such fine and such imprisonment.
('7', 413, 3, 6, 941035) 13. The burden of proving that a person has not entered or remained in this Colony in contravention of this Act or any regulation shall in any prosecution for such contravention lie upon the accused person.
('7', 413, 4, 7, 941242) 14. Every court of resident magistrate shall have jurisdiction to impose the maximum penalties for all contraventions of this Act or of any regulation.
('7', 413, 4, 8, 941394) 15. The Governor may from time to time make, alter or rescind regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act for all or any of the following purposes: (a) Prescribing the powers and duties of officers of the department, (b) For preventing the entrance of prohibited immigrants into this Colony, (c) For the removal from this Colony of persons ordered under this Act to be removed therefrom, (d) For the detention pending removal of persons ordered under this Act to be removed from the Colony, (e) Prescribing the diseases which are infectious or contagious diseases for the purposes of sub section (6) of the definition of prohibited
('7', 414, 0, 1, 942043) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 415
('7', 414, 1, 2, 942088) immigrant, (f) Prescribing the forms of (i) the certificate mentioned in sub section (g) of the classes of persons excluded from the definition of prohibited immigrant; (ii) the warrants to be issued by the Minister under sections five and Six; (iii) the book to be kept under section twelve, (g) Prescribing the conditions under which prohibited immigrants may be allowed to pass through this Colony while journeying to a place outside the same, (h) Generally for the better carrying out of the objects and purposes of this Act, and may by any such regulations prescribe penalties for contraventions thereof not exceeding a fine of one hundred pounds or in default of payment imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months or both such fine and such imprisonment.
('7', 414, 1, 3, 942857) 16. This Act may be cited for all purposes as the Immigrants Restriction Act 1907 and shall take effect on such date as may be declared by proclamation of the Governor in the Gazette.

('7', 414, 3, 5, 943067) APPENDIX III
('7', 414, 4, 6, 943080) REGULATIONS
('7', 414, 5, 7, 943092) MADE UNDER SECTION 18 OF THE ASIATIC LAW AMENDMENT ACT OF 1907
('7', 414, 6, 8, 943155) I. In these Regulations, unless inconsistent with the context
('7', 414, 7, 9, 943217) “Act” shall mean the Asiatic Law Amendment Act, 1907;
('7', 414, 8, 10, 943271) “Adult,’ shall mean a male Asiatic of the age of sixteen years or over; “applicant” shall mean any person who makes application for registration on his own behalf or any person on whose behalf application for registration is made by his guardian; “application for registration” shall mean an application to be placed on the register of Asiatics, made in such manner and form and accompanied by the supplying of such particulars and the furnishing of such means of identification as are required by Regulation No.
('7', 414, 8, 11, 943784) 3; “area” shall mean a magisterial district or such portion thereof as the Colonial Secretary may appoint by notice in the Gazette, under sub section (1) of section four of the Act; “Asiatic” shall mean any such male person as is described in Article one of Law No.
('7', 414, 8, 12, 944050) 3 of 1885, not being a Malay born and resident in any British Colony or possession in South Africa, not a person introduced into the Colony under the Labour Importation Ordinance, 1904, and not being an officer in the Chinese Consular Service; “certificate of registration” shall mean a certificate of registration issued under
('7', 415, 0, 1, 944378) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('7', 415, 1, 2, 944420) sub section (I) of section three of the Act; “guardian” shall mean the parent of an Asiatic under the age of sixteen or any other person under whose care or control such Asiatic is Living for the time being or failing any such person the employer of such Asiatic; “lawful holder” as used in relation to any certificate of registration shall mean the person whose registration is thereby certified; “minor” hall mean a male Asiatic over the age of eight and under the age of sixteen years; “police force” shall mean a police force lawfully established in this Colony; “police officer” shall mean any member of a police force; “Registrar” shall mean the officer appointed by the Governor to keep the register of Asiatics and any person lawfully acting in such capacity; “Resident Magistrate” shall include an assistant resident magistrate.
('7', 415, 1, 3, 945258) 2. The form of the register of Asiatics shall be that set forth in Schedule “A” hereto.
('7', 415, 2, 4, 945346) 3. The form of application for registration hall be:
('7', 415, 3, 5, 945399) (1) for an adult applicant the form set forth in Schedule “B” hereto;
('7', 415, 4, 6, 945469) (2) for minor applicant the form set forth in Schedule “C” hereto.
('7', 415, 5, 7, 945536) 4. (a) Every adult making application for registration on his own behalf shall appear before such person as the Colonial Secretary may by notice in the Gazette appoint for the area in which such applicant is resident and shall furnish such person with the particulars required by the form of application set forth in Schedule “B” hereto, and shall produce and surrender to such person:
('7', 415, 6, 8, 945922) (1) any permit to enter and reside in the Transvaal issued to him under the provisions of the Indemnity and Peace Preservation Ordinance of 1902, or any amendment thereof; (2) any certificate of registration or receipts for payment of the fee prescribed for registration under the provisions of Law No.
('7', 415, 6, 9, 946225) 3 of 1885 as subsequently amended;
('7', 415, 7, 10, 946260) (3) any other documents in his possession which he may desire to produce in support of his application for registration.
('7', 415, 8, 11, 946381) (b)Every guardian making application for registration on behalf of a minor shall appear before such person as aforesaid with such minor, and shall furnish such person with the particulars regarding himself and such minor as are required by the form set forth in Schedule “C” hereto, and shall produce and surrender to such person such documents relating to such minor as are in the preceding sub section described.
('7', 415, 9, 12, 946796) (c) Every application for registration shall be made at such place and before such date as the Colonial Secretary may for any area prescribe by notice in the Gazette.
('7', 416, 0, 1, 946963) VOL. 7 : 15 JUNE, 1907 12 DECEMBER, 1907 417
('7', 416, 1, 2, 947008) (d) Every person appointed to receive application for registration as aforesaid shall, immediately the form of application in respect of any applicant is completed, issue to the applicant or guardian a written acknowledgement under his hand of the receipt of the application for registration and of the documents produced and surrendered in support of such application.
('7', 416, 1, 3, 947378) Such acknowledgement shall be in duplicate in the form set forth in Schedule “D” hereto, and the duplicate copy thereof shall forthwith be transmitted by such person to the Registrar with the form of application and any documents produced in support thereof.
('7', 416, 1, 4, 947637) 5. ('7', 416, 1, 5, 948022) 6. The certificate of registration shall be in the form set forth in Schedule “F” hereto.
('7', 416, 1, 6, 948112) 7. Every adult required by a police officer or by any person duly authorised thereto by the Colonial Secretary to produce the certificate of registration of which he is the lawful holder shall, in addition to producing such certificate, supply on the demand of such police officer or other person aforesaid the following particulars: (1) his name in full; (2) his present residence; (3) his residence at the date he made application for registration; (4) his age; and shall furnish to and in the presence of such police officer or other person aforesaid: (1) a specimen of his signature, if he is able to write; (2) impressions of his thumbs or of his thumbs and his fingers.

('7', 417, 8, 9, 951569) (3) the present residence of such Asiatic;
('7', 417, 9, 10, 951612) (4) the power of attorney or other authority under which he is authorised to apply for such licence or to carry on the trade of the absentee, and such power or other authority shall bear a clear impression of the right thumb of such absentee and shall furnish to and in the presence of such person, if so required, the impression of his own right thumb.
